headline: ALBERTA ENERGY BIDS CASH AND STOCK FOR AMBER ENERGY
abstract: Alberta Energy Co offers to buy struggling rival, Amber Energy Inc, for about $750 million (Canadian) in cash, stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: One Patch of Russia's Economic Crazy Quilt
abstract: Financial crisis has stirred many of Russia's far-flung regions to set own economic course and price controls; Russia is fast becoming crazy quilt of zones with strict controls, territories with milder curbs and regions with no controls; populist decrees bring some comfort to consumers, but threaten stores and factories and cause shortages in regions with tight controls; Siberian Gov Aleksandr Lebed discusses his strict price controls, holding they have played their role and will be quickly abolished, interview; map; photos (M)

headline: Apartheid Assassin Confesses Killings in Other Lands
abstract: Johan Coetzee, former senior official of South Africa's police and one of apartheid era's worst assassins, begins confessing to Truth and Reconciliation Commission about murders and bombings he and seven other colleagues committed outside South Africa; although confessions will result in amnesty against prosecution in South Africa, all eight face extradition requests from countries where crimes were committed, notably, England, Angola and Mozambique; Coetzee photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tracking the Rich Deals of TCI's Chairman Is No Easy Job
abstract: Market Place column examines how John C Malone struck savvy deal for himself in selling his Tele-Communications Inc to AT&T, and reaped extraordinary benefits for part of TCI empire he will still control, Liberty Media Corp; Liberty will get tax loss of roughly $1.8 billion that can be used to offset future tax bills, and will get right to borrow billions without seeking permission from AT&T; Liberty is not an operating company, but a portfolio of investments in companies run by other people; it usually puts one of its own executives on boards of companies it invests in; photo; chart (M)

headline: Argentina Seeks $8 Billion In Emergency Loan Reserves
abstract: Argentina, in attempt to ease any future economic tremors from neighboring Brazil, is negotiating loan packages totaling more than $8 billion with various international lenders to insure Government financing in case of severe economic slowdown next year; publicly, Government officials are still painting rosy picture of economy, making every effort to differentiate Argentina from other emerging market countries (M)

headline: Russia Reaches Pact For Billions in Loans
abstract: The Russian Government said it had reached agreement with the International Monetary Fund on $11 billion in new loans to help stabilize its financial markets.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Agency.com acquires Primary Group; terms undisclosed; Edelman Public Relations Worldwide acquires GTT Communications; terms undisclosed; Altus Group forms hospitality marketing division to service clients, including Omni Hotels and ITT Sheraton (S)

headline: British Telecom to Acquire MCI's Stake in Joint Venture
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC announces agreement to acquire MCI Communications Corp's 24.9 percent stake in companies' international joint venture for $1 billion in cash; with British Telecom's agreement to buy stake in Concert, as venture is known, the British communications giant will be free to move forward with plans to form $10 billion joint venture with MCI's rival, the AT&T Corp (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income   June  Construction Spending   June

headline: The Business of Child Care
abstract: Craig J Cantoni letter disputes June 21 article by Rosemary Jordano and Marie Oates on paying child care workers higher wages (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices fall 7.5 percent after Hurricane Earl veers away from rigs off Texas and Louisiana, easing supply worries; graphs (S)

headline: TYSON FOODS TO TAKE $200 MILLION CHARGE TO CUT COSTS
abstract: Tyson Foods Inc will take pretax charge of about $200 million in its fiscal fourth quarter to cover expense of cost-cutting plan that could include plant closings, laying off workers or selling businesses; Tyson says third-quarter earnings beat analysts' forecasts, rising 3.1 percent, to $46.6 million, from $45.2 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 23 percent, to $1.95 billion from $1.59 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japanese Economy Continues to Shrink  In the starkest sign so far of the depth of Japan's recession, the Government said that the economy contracted in the April-to-June quarter by an annual rate of 3.3 percent, nearly twice as steep a fall as most economists had expected. It was the first time that Japan's economy had contracted for three consecutive quarters.    The data suggest that the core of the economy slid even more rapidly than it did earlier in the year, and there are fears that the recession could worsen. The figures were released after the close of a volatile session in Japanese stocks. The Nikkei index plunged 749.05 points, or 5.11 percent. [Page C2.]

headline: Advanswers Renames New York Office
abstract: Advanswers in St Louis, media services company owned by Omnicom Group, renames its New York office, formerly known as Paul Schulman Co, as Schulman/Advanswers NY; Tom DeCabia, senior vice president for network television and account supervisor at Schulman, is promoted to new position of executive vice president and general manager at Schulman/Advanswers (S)

headline: As Stocks Teeter, a Safe Harbor May Be Found in Corporate Bonds
abstract: Article on rising value of mutual funds that invest in corporate bonds (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Marketing Chief of G.M. Gives Gloomy Assessment  The strike this summer at two General Motors parts factories will continue to hurt the auto maker's sales until October, and some customers have been permanently lost, G.M.'s top marketing executive said.

headline: How the U.N. Voted
abstract: General Assembly roll-call on resolution giving Palestinians larger role in United Nations

headline: Fight, Survive And Conquer: The Shortcuts
abstract: Michel Marriott reviews Prima's Official Strategy Guide: Unreal, by Joe Grant Bell; photo (M)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.54   5.34        3-month T-bills   4.85   4.87   5.14        6-month T-bills   4.94   4.97   5.22        10-yr. headline: From the Drudge Report To the Drudge Retort
abstract: Two opportunistic satirists, Rogers Cadenhead and Jonathan Bourne, register Internet site that parodies Matt Drudge's Drudge Report, seeking to mock Drudge's style of journalism; Drudge is an Internet gossip columnist (S)

headline: Mexico's Rookie Deputies Hope for Better Season
abstract: Lower house of Mexico's Congress records major accomplishments in the year since it came under opposition control; formerly discredited body is now set on a new democratic path, one in which presidential initiatives are no longer blindly passed, where debate is vigorous and where the art of compromise is being refined; transformation is not complete, and governing party is still in control of Senate; photos (M)

headline: Patent Weaknesses
abstract: Putnam Hayes & Bartlett senior adviser Cecil D Quillen Jr letter responds to June 7 article by Jeffrey D Tekanic and Richard C Hsu on cost of patent litigation (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Russian Instability Sends Stock Prices Even Lower  Stock prices fell sharply for the second straight day as continued fears about instability in Russia and economic weakness closer to home led the stock market to its worst week in nine years.

headline: The Small Investor: Still Holding On, On a Bumpy Road
abstract: Stock market analysts find that, amid gloom over falling prices, small investors are showing signs of hanging on (M)

headline: A Drug Maker Reports Profit Gain of 46%
abstract: Warner-Lambert Co reports 46 percent gain in second-quarter earnings; says earnings rose to $338 million from $231 million a year earlier; sales rose 30 percent, to $2.56 billion from $1.97 billion (S)

headline: Irene Kraus, 74, Nun Who Led Big Nonprofit Hospital Chain
abstract: Sister Irene Kraus, onetime schoolteacher who later served as founding chief executive of $3 billion Daughters of Charity National Health System, dies at age of 74; photo (M)

headline: CROWN BOOKS TO CLOSE 79 STORES AND LAY OFF 1,250
abstract: Crown Books Corp to close 79 of its 174 stores as soon as possible and lay off 1,250 workers as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection and return to profitability (S)

headline: Apple TV Spot Wins Emmy Award
abstract: Commercial for Apple Computer Inc wins Emmy Award for outstanding television commercials; spot was created by TBWA Chiat/Day to introduce Apple's 'Think different' campaign (S)

headline: C. R. Youngdahl, 82; Led Securities Firm
abstract: C Richard Youngdahl, former chairman and chief executive of Aubrey G Lanston & Company, firm dealing in government securities, died August 6 at age 82 (S)

headline: OIL RICH, OIL POOR: A special report.; High Claims in Spill Betray Depth of Nigerian Poverty
abstract: Special report on Mobil oil spill off Nigerian coast in January, which has become subject of vehement dispute and catalyst for pent-up claims fed by poverty and state neglect; as Nigeria approaches delicate transition from military rule to democracy, delta region's long-festering problems pose threat of widespread violence; sabotage against pipelines is becoming routine, and poverty-stricken villagers are making huge financial demands on Mobil; since oil was discovered in delta region 42 years ago, enormous wealth has been taken by Western companies and by country's military rulers; now Mobil is facing billions of dollars in claims from population that feels it has been long ignored and Government of Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar is making conciliatory gestures but initiating little real reform; maps; photos (M)

headline: True Grit in the Gritty Inner City; Some Dreams Come True, but Company Fights for Life
abstract: Industrial jobs have steadily been migrating out of urban areas into suburban and rural industrial parks, contributing to deterioration of inner-city neighborhoods and making it more difficult for minority residents to move up economic ladder; goal of returning skilled, industrial jobs to blighted inner cities remains daunting one, even when economy is booming and many companies are scavenging for skilled--or simply trainable-- labor; financial problems of Milwaukee-based Steeltech Manufacturing Inc, which is in one of city's poorest, toughest neighborhoods, discussed; chief executive Charles Wallace comments; graph; photo (M)

headline: Continental Airlines' Earnings Jumped 27% in Second Quarter
abstract: Continental Airlines' second-quarter profit jumped 27 percent; profit rose to $163 million from $128 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 14 percent, to $2.04 billion from $1.79 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: METRO GLOBAL MEDIA INC., Cranston, R.I., an adult entertainment company, will buy Fanzine International Inc., a New Jersey magazine publisher, for about $7.8 million in cash and stock.    PFIZER INC., New York, said its Irish unit was planning a $280 million extension to its plant in Ringaskiddy, County Cork.

headline: Kosovo Albanians Fear for Lost Kin
abstract: Many ethnic Albanians who have returned to Kosovo after fleeing Government forces are finding that family members and friends are missing; although many of those considered missing may still be hiding in mountains, refugees who have returned say they fear that others have been arrested or killed; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Analysts Ponder Banks' Woes, but Investors Jump Ship
abstract: How the mighty have fallen.    Bank stocks, among the sizzlers in the stock market's bull run of the last few years, have been battered in recent weeks.

headline: Stake in Sotheby's Sold by Bass Group
abstract: Bass family investment group sells entire stake in Sotheby's Holdings Inc's Class A shares to another group led by money manager Ronald S Baron for about $110 million (S)

headline: Renault Profit Tripled In Its First Half
abstract: Renault SA says its first-half profit almost tripled; company earned 4.44 billion French francs ($780 million), up from 1.67 billion francs a year earlier (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Murdoch's BSkyB May Bid For British Soccer Team  B Sky B, Rupert Murdoch's British satellite broadcasting unit, confirmed that it was in discussions to acquire the Manchester United soccer team for a reported $950 million. The move comes after Mr. Murdoch's United States holdings have acquired stakes in American sports franchises. [Page C4.]    Russian Bank Chairman Resigns  The chairman of Russia's central bank, Sergei Dubinin, resigned amid mounting financial chaos in that country. He criticized Parliament's failure to act more quickly to help resuscitate the economy. Trading in the ruble was halted on the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange barely an hour after opening because no traders were willing to sell their dollars. [A12.]

headline: Editor of The New Yorker Leaving for New Venture
abstract: Tina Brown, who reshaped The New Yorker with photographs and late-century topicality, announces that she will resign as editor to start company affiliated with Miramax Films that would publish new monthly magazine, publish books and produce films and television programming; announcement comes after months of rumors of growing tension between Brown and Conde Nast Publications, which owns The New Yorker, over company's attempts to make magazine less unprofitable; during Brown's six-year tenure, The New Yorker won nearly two dozen major awards and newstand sales rose 145 percent, but it lost $11 million last year; Conde Nast spokeswoman says successor to Brown would be named shortly; Brown will be joined in new Miramax venture by Ronald A Galotti, who is resigning as publisher of Vogue magazine; photos; chart (M)

headline: REWARD IS OFFERED AND CLUES STUDIED IN AFRICAN BLASTS
abstract: US offers $2 million reward for information about US embassy bombings in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania; eyewitnesses say they saw truck that may have carried bomb that wrecked embassy in Nairobi; CIA and FBI officials are evaluating other leads in attacks; leads include terrorist manifesto delivered in Cairo that praises Osama Bin Laden, Saudi financier whom US officials have identified as possible suspect, and vague warnings picked up by foreign intelligence agency that Islamic terrorist group might have been planning attack in Kenya; bombings killed over 200 people and wounded nearly 5,000 others; photos (M)

headline: On-Line Petition Solicits Outrage at Congress
abstract: Berkeley Systems posts petition on Web inviting fellow citizens to express collective disgust at Washington's protracted preoccupation with Pres Clinton's relationship with Monica Lewinsky and to urge Congress to censure Clinton and then turn its attention to more important matters (S)

headline: Panel Suggests Bank Changes For Canada
abstract: Task Force on the Future of the Canadian Financial Services Sector endorses mergers of large Canadian banks and recommends easing rules for foreign banks to operate in Canada as long as public interest is protected; report comes amid debate over two recently announced mega-mergers--the Royal Bank of Canada and Bank of Montreal and Toronto Dominion Bank and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (S)

headline: Decoding Jackpot Is $5 Million, But You'd Better Get Started
abstract: Jaws Technology, computer encryption company, offers $5 million dollars to anyone who can decode two documents encrypted with new 4,096-bit key, and tell company how they did it (S)

headline: BELL MICROPRODUCTS IS ADDING ALMO DIVISION
abstract: Bell Microproducts Inc to acquire Almo Corp's computer-products division for cash and warrant (S)

headline: U.S. to Investigate Electricity Price Run-Up
abstract: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission will investigate huge run-up in price for electricity on wholesale market in which some Midwest utilities had to buy large amounts of power to get through heat wave and disruptions caused by storms; agency is responding to request by five utilities that bought power on June 25 and June 26, when prices surged to more than 100 times normal levels (S)

headline: Unisys Reports Big Rise in Net Income
abstract: Unisys Corp says net income more than doubled in second quarter; net income rose to $90.1 million from $41.9 million a year earlier; sales rose 9 percent, to $1.73 billion from $1.59 billion (S)

headline: DDB Needham Is Best of Ace Show
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide takes Best of Show Award at annual Ace Awards for business-to-business communications, sponsored by Business Marketing Association; other winners noted (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS: JAMES E. GOODWIN of UAL; Taking Over And Already In the Know
abstract: Brief interview with James Goodwin, new president and chief operating officer of UAL Corp; Goodwin succeeded John A Edwardson, who resigned after United's two biggest unions made it clear they would block his becoming chief executive when Gerald Greenwald retires next year; photo (M)/

headline: Scientists Debate China's Law on Sterilizing the Carriers of Genetic Defects
abstract: Many of 2,000 scientists who attended International Congress of Genetics in Beijing debated controversial Chinese law, one that many experts believe permits doctors to require that people with serious genetic conditions be sterilized; law has so offended some scientists that national genetics societies from England, Holland and Argentina boycotted their profession's most prestigious general meeting, held once every five years (M)

headline: CLINTON OPTIMISTIC ON CHINA'S FUTURE AS HE HEADS HOME
abstract: Pres Clinton, in news conference that closes his nine-day trip to China, calls Pres Jiang Zemin a visionary leader who could be the figure who leads China to democracy; Clinton also praises Premier Zhu Rongji, architect of China's current economic policies; says that profound differences still remain between China and US on questions of individual liberty, but defends his engagement with Chinese leadership as the course most likely to yield progress; photo (M)

headline: Lowe & Partners/SMS Appoints Key Executive
abstract: Lowe & Partners/SMS names William Sawyer managing director of its San Francisco office (S)9

headline: Ulster Parade Talks Planned
abstract: Protestant and Roman Catholic officials in Northern Ireland agree to proposal by British Prime Min Tony Blair to open talks on ending rising Protestant violence over ban on disputed Protestant parade through Catholic neighborhood, Belfast; will be in separate rooms, with 'facilitators' shuttling back and forth; photo (S)

headline: Three Agencies Report Acquisitions
abstract: Draft Worldwide ad agency acquires KBA Marketing; Ziccardi & Partners acquires Internet Group, which has been renamed Z.Interactive; Jonathan Bednarsh will head Z.Interactive as interactive services director; Seth Hyman, president of Internet Group, is leaving; Healthworld Corp ad agency acquires 80 percent of Torrent SA for $2.56 million (S)

headline: International Briefs; Nestle Sales Rose 12.4% In Second Quarter
abstract: Nestle SA says second-quarter sales rose 12.4 percent, to 18.1 billion francs ($12 billion) from 16.1 billion in year-earlier period (S)

headline: The Travel Channel and Conde Nast Traveler are teaming up for a variety of cross-ventures.
abstract: Advertising column describes partnership being formed between Conde Nast Traveler, monthly travel magazine published by Conde Nast Publications, and Travel Channel, travel and tourism TV network, for cross-media and cross-marketing ventures that will include prime-time travelogue series called Conde Nast Traveler Presents Amazing Destinations; marketers will be encouraged to advertise on series as well as in Conde Nast Traveler (M)

headline: A Chaperone for Sea Turtles' Turkish Summer Nights
abstract: Turkish environmental activist June Haimoff leads successful campaign to preserve breeding grounds for giant loggerhead turtles on beach of Mediterranean coastal town of Dalyan; she blocked efforts of Turkish-German consortium to build hotel on beach; photo (M)

headline: Nasdaq Sets a Record on Gains From Technology Issues
abstract: Nasdaq composite index rises 22.49 points, to record 1,965.53; Dow Jones industrial average falls 9.53 points, to 9,096.21; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inches up 0.86 points, to 1.165.19; graph; chart (M)

headline: MCI Reported To Be Near Full Internet Sale
abstract: MCI Communications Corp is close to agreement to sell its entire Internet business to Cable and Wireless PLC for $1.5 billion to $2 billion in cash; deal would clear the way for Justice Department to approve $37 billion acquisition of MCI by Worldcom Inc (M)

headline: Television, Past and Future
abstract: Letter from Melvin Rosenberg comments on Aug 20 article on high-definition television (S)

headline: IMPERIAL CREDIT REJECTS A RIVAL'S BID
abstract: Imperial Credit Commercial Mortgage Investment Corp rejects unsolicited bid from rival mortgage real estate investment trust, Wilshire Real Estate Investment Trust Inc (S)

headline: N2O: At Its Best at High Volume in the Dark
abstract: Sony Playstation's new computer game, N2O, described and assessed; photos (M)

headline: Nigeria Ruler Acts to Scrap Political Setup Of Dictator
abstract: Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar, Nigeria's military ruler, moves to dismantle elaborate political apparatus put in place by late predecessor, Gen Sani Abacha; dissolves committees set up by Abacha to create veneer of democracy while insuring that he became sole candidate of all five parties in election that was scheduled for August 1; is expected to lay out plans for return to genuine multiparty democracy (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises against dollar after Japanese officials warn that they will intervene in foreign markets to support yen; dollar trades at 144.97 yen, down from 145.60 yen on Aug 3 in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: INTERVENTION THREATS HELP YEN.  The yen rose for the fourth time in five days after Japanese Finance Ministry officials said they might sell dollars to support the currency. In New York, the dollar fell to 145 yen from 145.96.

headline: Cruelty of Giant Wave: 'Most of the Children Are Dead'
abstract: Relief workers continue counting dead on Papua New Guinea as fears rise that giant tidal wave that obliterated several fishing villages on July 17 swept away far more children than adults; say 70 percent of survivors have been adults; current death toll put at 1,200, with 6,000 unaccounted for; maps; photo (M)

headline: Washington Stands By, Keeping Its Head Down
abstract: R W Apple Jr analysis of Clinton Adm's low-key reaction to turmoil in Russia; photo of Muscovites lining up at automated teller machine in GUM department store (M)

headline: Publicis Says Profit Rose 72% in Half
abstract: Publicis SA says first-half profit rose 72 percent; company earned 160 million francs ($28 million), up from 93 million francs in first six months of 1997; sales rose 41 percent, to 17.41 billion francs ($2.9 billion) (S)

headline: Iraqi Official Criticizes U.N. Chief Over Role in Arms Inspection
abstract: Hamed Youssef Hummadi, adviser to Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein, levels unusual direct attack on United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan, apparently trying to draw him into growing confrontation over arms inspections; holds Annan pledged in Feb to end embargo on Iraq and has failed to honor pledge; remarks reflect annoyance with Annan's stand that Iraq must reverse decision to stop on-site inspections (M)

headline: Swing Vote in East Worries Germans
abstract: Former East German Communists could win enough votes in German national elections to play important swing role and have good chance of becoming minority partner in governing coalition in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania; could make it hard for Gerhard Schroder to form majority governing coalition by stealing votes from his left-of-center Social Democrats; Schroder has ruled out coalition with ex-Communists, move that would be political suicide in western Germany; map (M)

headline: Merrill Lynch Net Rose 13% in 2d Quarter
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co says net income for second quarter rose 13 percent; gain, to $545 million from $481 million, was cut by some $75 million because of costs from operating retail brokerage operation in Japan; investment banking revenue rose 39 percent, while commissions from customers' trades rose 29 percent; profit at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette rose 42 percent, to $142.3 million from $100.2 million; net revenue increased 45 percent, to $1.2 billion (S)

headline: Airport Group Acquisition
abstract: Airport Group International buys USAirports' cargo division (S)

headline: Web Shopping? Not for the Picky
abstract: Article on advantages and disadvantages of grocery shopping on World Wide Web; drawing (M)

headline: Dow Edges Higher as Curtain Drops on a Troubled Week
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 4.38 points, to 8,937.36; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 1.05, to 1140.80; Nasdaq composite index falls 4.23, to 1,930.99; graphs of Dow Jones average; tables (M)

headline: Wendy's Says No to Pepsi, Yes to Coca-Cola
abstract: Wendy's International Inc renews its soft-drink contract with Coca-Cola Co for 10 years; says it will force franchisees that serve Pepsico Inc's drinks to switch to Coke once their agreements end; Coca-Cola, which already serves 4,400 of Wendy's 5,207 restaurants, will provide $100 million to Wendy's national advertising drive over decade (M)

headline: No Slacking About Saving
abstract: Louis Harris & Associates survey of 1,000 adults for Alliance Capital Management finds that people between ages of 18 and 39 started saving for retirement at 25, earlier than older groups (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen snaps three-day slide against US dollar, reflecting concern that Latin American economic weakness could hurt US; dollar falls to 132.18 yen from 134.90 in New York trading (S)

headline: Despite A-Test, U.S. Won't Bar Pakistan Bailout
abstract: Clinton Administration, less than two months after declaring that Pakistan would suffer harsh economic sanctions for its nuclear test, says that it will not oppose efforts by International Monetary Fund to head off country's economic collapse (M)

headline: Hilton Says Its Earnings Will Fall Short
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp says third-quarter earnings will fall short of analysts' expectations and figures a year earlier (S)

headline: Fuddruckers Hamburger Chain Being Sold
abstract: Unique Casual Restaurants Inc to sell its Fuddruckers chain of 204 hamburger restaurants to King Cannon Inc for $43 million in cash to raise capital for its other restaurant business (S)

headline: Indonesia Cuts Timor Force But Islanders Are Skeptical
abstract: Indonesia begins withdrawing 1,000 combat troops from East Timor, but critics and residents remain skeptical about the more than 11,000 troops and police officers who will continue to patrol territory; photo; map (M)

headline: ROYAL AHOLD SAYS IT HAS FOUND BUYERS FOR 10 U.S. STORES
abstract: Royal Ahold NV, largest food retailer in Netherlands, says it has found buyers for 10 stores in US, meeting Federal Trade Commission demand and bringing it one step closer to planned $2.7 billion acquisition of Giant Food Inc (S)

headline: Burnett and MacManus Continue Talks
abstract: Leo Burnett Co and MacManus Group continue talks on possibly broadening media alliance; say companies will remain independent (S)

headline: PAPER COMPANY BUYING 45% OF PACKAGING PLANT IN CHINA
abstract: Westvaco Corp to acquire 45 percent stake in packaging plant in Guangzhou, China, for about $25 million from Shorewood Packaging Corp; Shorewood, will own remaining 55 percent of plant (S)

headline: Where Sites Go to Die
abstract: Q. What happens to abandoned Web sites? Do they stay on the Web?    A. Orphaned sites are a sad thing, indeed. Ignored by its creator for whatever reason, a stranded page will just sit there until someone (or some program) deletes it from the host Web server.

headline: Hitachi to Reduce Number of Directors
abstract: Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest electronics maker, said yesterday that it planned to reduce the number of its board members by June 1999 to streamline management as part of wider efforts to return the company to profitability. Hitachi will trim the board as it reorganizes itself by the middle of next year into financially independent divisions, arranged according to product category.

headline: Taiwan Airline Expects Record Loss for Year
abstract: China Airlines, Taiwan's largest airline, says it will post record loss this year after one of its Airbus jets crashed in February (S)

headline: OLSTEN TO BUY BACK 4 MILLION SHARES AND CUT DIVIDEND
abstract: Olsten Corp will buy back as many as 4 million, or about 5 percent, of its common shares outstanding and plans to cut its quarterly dividend payment by 43 percent (S)

headline: For Banks, A Big Nudge To Do More
abstract: Community groups, residents and politicians express hope that banks, as result of current mega-merger boom, will keep promises of multimillion dollar investments in low-income communities nationwide; photos; chart; graphs (L)

headline: Moscow Mood: What if They Ascended a Summit and No One Cared
abstract: Pres Clinton's upcoming summit with Pres Boris Yeltsin in Moscow is being treated with indifference among Russians, many of whom regard it as trivial by comparison with pressing economic problems; photo (M)

headline: A Familiar Terror Clothed in New Software
abstract: New computer game called Sentinel Returns appraised; it is from Psygnosis; photo (M)

headline: Changes at the Top For Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi PLC announces series of top-level executive changes; Kevin J Roberts, chief executive at Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide, is promoted to chief executive of agency, succeeding Robert Seelert, who is promoted to succeed Charlie Scott as chairman; Scott will relinquish his position on Jan 1, and continue his role as chairman of Cordiant Communications Group PLC; Steve Chin, European planning director, is promoted to new position of planning director for international business development (S)

headline: Safety Data From F.D.A.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration maintains Web site with data on drugs' safety records and Government reprimand letters about advertising campaigns; site throws spotlight on drug industry's latest sinners; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Ex-Investment Banker Charged
abstract: Michael Lissack, former Smith Barney Investment banker, is charged with using Internet to harass executives at firm (S)

headline: Terrorism Doubted in Crash, With 229 Aboard, Off Nova Scotia : No Hope of Swissair Jet Survivors
abstract: WASHINGTON  Canadian search and rescue teams found part of a Swiss airliner's fuselage in deep waters off a Nova Scotia fishing town on Thursday but held no hope that any of the 229 passengers and crew members aboard survived a desperate attempt to land at sea after smoke filled the cockpit.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Wheat futures surge as expectations grow that Pakistan, Jordan and other countries will buy American wheat this week; wheat for December delivery rises 4.75 cents, to $2.7075 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Most Consuming More, and the Rich Much More
abstract: United Nations reports that consumption of goods and services was rising phenomenally in industrial and many developing nations before the world slipped into a global financial crisis in 1997 and that it is still rising despite economic setbacks; predicts that cost of public and private consumption will top $24 trillion this year, twice the 1975 level and six times that of 1950; warns, however, that gaps between the world's richest and poorest people have been steadily rising, an indication that even if economies right themselves, there will be a huge backlog of unmet demands and needs, the kind that fuel popular unrest in an age of mass media; notes, for example, that annual bill for cosmetics in US and ice cream in Europe could provide basic education or water and sanitation to the more than 2 billion people worldwide who go without schools and toilets (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises against US dollar after Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan hints at lower US interest rates; in New York, dollar settles at 1.6783 marks, down from 1.6824; graph; chart (S)

headline: New German Leader to Seek Coalition With the Greens
abstract: Germany's Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroeder will seek to form coalition Government with environmentalist Green Party, opening way for first 'Red-Green' Government in 49-year history of postwar republic; final election results show Schroeder's Social Democrats and Greens sweeping to comfortable 21-seat majority in 656-member Parliament as weariness with Helmut Kohl's 16-year rule and anger over high unemployment prompted decisive vore for change; photo (M)

headline: For $5, a Family Video Store Will Cut 2 'Titanic' Scenes
abstract: Sunrise Family Video store, American Fork, Utah, is winning business by cutting two steamy scenes from home video copies of film Titanic for $5 fee; ignores complaints from Paramount Pictures; photo (S)

headline: HDTV: High Definition, High in Price
abstract: Most of world's consumer-electronics manufacturers will have new high-definition television sets ready for sale in September; least expensive one will cost $8,000; price is twice as high as manufacturers had estimated when they lobbied Federal Communications Commission to pass digital-television rules; manufacturers say some components cost more than they anticipated; retail price of HDTV set is also driven by fact that manufacturers do not expect to make or sell large numbers of such expensive sets; retailers say they expect to sell as many as industry makes, but industry is not expected to make that many; research shows that consumer electronics products reach true mass acceptance only after price falls below $500; manufacturers cannot even guess how long before industry is able to sell HDTV's at that price; photos; charts; drawings (M)

headline: Offering Old-Fashioned Values For Teen-Agers Using the Web
abstract: New web site offered by Legacy International, nonprofit organization that develops leadership skills among promising teenagers, promotes old-fashioned values and helps teen-agers develop a sense of community with global chat room and program that helps visitors volunteer in their local community (www.legacyintl.org); soon to be offered is life-simulation game (www.global rewards.org/ggame/index.html) designed to show youths how their lives might turn out, based on choices they make (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark gains on improved outlook for Russian accord with International Monetary Fund; graphs; table (S)

headline: Patents; A technique to solve a broad array of computing problems with manipulation of DNA molecules.
abstract: Dr Warren Smith and Dr Allan Schweitzer receive what appears to be first patent covering DNA computing process that at least theoretically can solve broad array of problems, just as conventional desktop computer might; William M Miller receives patent for 'lawn renovating tool' that he says can be used to mulch, de-thatch, seed, fertilize and even aerate lawns; Joe Gasperino receives patent for special holder for doorstops that delivery drivers can fit onto hand truck; Thomas William George Dean and Kenneth Leslie Hawes receive patent for alarm system that sounds when roulette players try to put down late bets (M)

headline: Livent Says Suit by Drabinsky Adds to Woes of Shareholders
abstract: Livent Inc, Broadway theater producer, is arguing in Canadian court that lawsuit filed by its founder, Garth H Drabinsky, threatens to prolong pain of company's shareholders who have been unable to trade their shares since early August because of accounting investigation; Livent's executive vice president Robert B Webster says if Drabinsky succeeds in stopping investigation, by KPMG Canada, it may be many weeks before company can provide more information on extent of its accounting problems; US and Canadian stock exchange officials suspended trading of Livent shares on Aug 10 (M)

headline: Cool to U.S., Caribbean Hails Castro All the More Warmly
abstract: Pres Fidel Castro of Cuba makes triumphant tour of English-speaking Caribbean, where Cuba is once again actively seeking to foster trade and political ties with countries that regard US as uninterested in their development and rigid in its policy toward Cuba; photo; map (M)

headline: Hexcel to Buy Assets of Fiberglass Maker
abstract: Hexcel Corp, synthetic-materials maker, will buy most of assets of Clark-Schwebel Inc for $435 million in cash, adding fiberglass operations in United States, Japan and Germany; as precursor to deal, Clark-Schwebel, producer of fiverglass fabrics, has been acquired by Stamford C-S Aquisitions Corp for $488 million in cash from Vestar Capital Partners; Stamford C-S will keep $60 million of Clark-Schwebel property, plants and equipment and lease it to Hexcel (M)

headline: Calling on Technology to Build a Better Handcuff
abstract: Touchstone Research Laboratory is using device programmed by National Institute of Standards and Technology engineer Jim Worthey to find weakest parts of various handcuffs and recommend improvements in national standards; need for improvements in current models appers to be great, especially for police officers transporting prisoners; photo (M)

headline: James Carter, 99, an International Banker
abstract: James Prescott Carter, international banker and economic consultant, died on Aug 10 at age 99 (S)

headline: U.S. Manufacturer Slowly Changes Course: Will Its A3XX Permit Airbus to Break Boeing's Hold on Jumbo Jet Market?
abstract: WASHINGTON  If you think of the mammoth Boeing Co. of Seattle not, say, as one big shiny 747 jumbo jet but as a fully loaded milelong oil tanker trying to shift course and outmaneuver a frigate in rough seas, you get a picture of the challenge facing the world's largest aircraft maker.

headline: ALBERTA ENERGY BIDS CASH AND STOCK FOR AMBER ENERGY
abstract: Alberta Energy Co offers to buy struggling rival, Amber Energy Inc, for about $750 million (Canadian) in cash, stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: One Patch of Russia's Economic Crazy Quilt
abstract: Financial crisis has stirred many of Russia's far-flung regions to set own economic course and price controls; Russia is fast becoming crazy quilt of zones with strict controls, territories with milder curbs and regions with no controls; populist decrees bring some comfort to consumers, but threaten stores and factories and cause shortages in regions with tight controls; Siberian Gov Aleksandr Lebed discusses his strict price controls, holding they have played their role and will be quickly abolished, interview; map; photos (M)

headline: Apartheid Assassin Confesses Killings in Other Lands
abstract: Johan Coetzee, former senior official of South Africa's police and one of apartheid era's worst assassins, begins confessing to Truth and Reconciliation Commission about murders and bombings he and seven other colleagues committed outside South Africa; although confessions will result in amnesty against prosecution in South Africa, all eight face extradition requests from countries where crimes were committed, notably, England, Angola and Mozambique; Coetzee photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tracking the Rich Deals of TCI's Chairman Is No Easy Job
abstract: Market Place column examines how John C Malone struck savvy deal for himself in selling his Tele-Communications Inc to AT&T, and reaped extraordinary benefits for part of TCI empire he will still control, Liberty Media Corp; Liberty will get tax loss of roughly $1.8 billion that can be used to offset future tax bills, and will get right to borrow billions without seeking permission from AT&T; Liberty is not an operating company, but a portfolio of investments in companies run by other people; it usually puts one of its own executives on boards of companies it invests in; photo; chart (M)

headline: Argentina Seeks $8 Billion In Emergency Loan Reserves
abstract: Argentina, in attempt to ease any future economic tremors from neighboring Brazil, is negotiating loan packages totaling more than $8 billion with various international lenders to insure Government financing in case of severe economic slowdown next year; publicly, Government officials are still painting rosy picture of economy, making every effort to differentiate Argentina from other emerging market countries (M)

headline: Russia Reaches Pact For Billions in Loans
abstract: The Russian Government said it had reached agreement with the International Monetary Fund on $11 billion in new loans to help stabilize its financial markets.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Agency.com acquires Primary Group; terms undisclosed; Edelman Public Relations Worldwide acquires GTT Communications; terms undisclosed; Altus Group forms hospitality marketing division to service clients, including Omni Hotels and ITT Sheraton (S)

headline: British Telecom to Acquire MCI's Stake in Joint Venture
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC announces agreement to acquire MCI Communications Corp's 24.9 percent stake in companies' international joint venture for $1 billion in cash; with British Telecom's agreement to buy stake in Concert, as venture is known, the British communications giant will be free to move forward with plans to form $10 billion joint venture with MCI's rival, the AT&T Corp (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income   June  Construction Spending   June

headline: The Business of Child Care
abstract: Craig J Cantoni letter disputes June 21 article by Rosemary Jordano and Marie Oates on paying child care workers higher wages (S)

headline: North Korean Missile Is Fired Across Japan
abstract: North Korea fired a ballistic missile over Japan, which called the firing ''extremely dangerous.''     The action suggests that North Korea has greatly increased the range of its missiles. Before, its missiles could reach only part of Japan, but the new missile appeared to be a medium-range ballistic missile that may be able to reach all of Japan.

headline: Goldman Plan To Sell Stock Is Canceled
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co's top partners announce that firm will withdraw its registration to go public; Goldman's surge of quarterly profit gains has reversed since its announcement in June that it would go public, sky-high stock prices of its leading rivals have tumbled, and stock and bond markets have tanked; co-chairmen and chief executives Henry M Paulson Jr and Jon S Corzine say decision does not mean that Goldman will abandon plans to issue shares; they stress offering is unlikely to be revived immediately given market's current turmoil (M)

headline: Israeli Exchange Hopes Domestic Companies Keep One Foot at Home
abstract: Tel Aviv Stock Exchange officials, worried about flight of prominent high-tech stocks to US's Nasdaq, are trying to lure them back; photo; chart (M)

headline: New Java Venture By Sun and I.B.M.
abstract: IBM and Sun Microsystems Inc plan to begin shipping latest version of their jointly developed Java operating system for networked computers (S)

headline: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Speech
abstract: Excerpts from speech by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman

headline: 3 Pros Are Grabbing the Bear by the Horns
abstract: Money managers Ronald Baron, of Baron Asset fund, Christian A Felipe of MFS Massachusetts Investors Growth fund and Jeff Tyler of American Century Income and Growth fund comment on their buying activities as stock market plunges; photos; graphs (L)

headline: LG&E DISCONTINUES ITS BUSINESS IN TRADING OF ELECTRICITY
abstract: LG&E Energy Corp, Kentucky's largest electric utility, discontinues trading electricity, citing recent volatility in power market and its current portfolio of energy-marketing contracts; will record after-tax loss of $225 million in second quarter on disposition of operations (S)

headline: UNITED WATER AND SUEZ LYONNAISE WIN ATLANTA CONTRACT
abstract: Joint venture of United Water Resources Inc and Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux wins 20-year contract to privatize Atlanta's drinking water system (S)

headline: Large Companies Fall Out of Favor in Volatile Stock Markets : Bargain-Hunters Think Small
abstract: NEW YORK  Small is beautiful, at least as far as stocks are concerned.

headline: LIBRARY/PERSONAL-FINANCE SITES; The Street: For Investors With Passion
abstract: The Street, subscriber service on Internet, was started in 1996 by James J Cramer and Martin Peretz, who saw need for intense focus in investment news (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of July 19 article on relationship between company's environmental policies and stock performance which misspelled Salomon Smith Barney asset manager Lisa Leff's name (S)

headline: Lazard to Pay $9 Million in Yield-Burning Suit
abstract: Lazard Freres & Co agrees to pay $9 million to settle civil lawsuit brought by Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Agency accusing Lazard of grossly overcharging agency in 1993 bond transaction; deal marks first time major Wall Street firm has agreed to settle civil suit related to bond-sales practice that in 1990's came to be known as 'yield burning,' or profiting heavily by vastly inflating prices of government securities (M)

headline: Study the Trees Closely, But Just Skim the Forest
abstract: Interview with Peter Lynch, legendary stock picker, who stresses investing based on fact rather than feeling in advertising drive with entertainer Lily Tomlin for Fidelity Investments; he holds individuals should focus on researching their investments, not trying to gauge overall direction of economy; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of headline on Sept 20 Private Sector page about executive compensation plan at Computer Associates; headline referred incorrectly to grant received by Charles B Wang, chief executive, and two aides; they were given shares of company, not options

headline: LIBRARY/ASTRONOMY SOFTWARE; With a Desktop Computer's Aid, Your Own Planetarium
abstract: Article by astronomy Prof Marshall L McCall on astronomy computer programs and desktop planetariums; reviews Astronomy Village (NASA Central Operation of Resources for Educators), Real Sky CD (Astonomical Society of the Pacific), Redshift 3 (Piranha Interactive Publishing), Starry Night Deluxe (Sienna Software), The Sky: Level IV (Software Bisque), Voyager II (Carina Software), Dance of the Planets (ARC Science Simulations); photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Daniel Morel is named to new position of chief executive for marketing services network of Euro RSCG Worldwide; Eugene J Grossman is named to newly created position of executive vice president at Siegel & Gale; Aaron Sugarman, vice president and creative director of Agency.com, is promoted to new position of president; Amy Jones, associated media director at Freedman, Gibson & White, is promoted to media director, succeeding Larry Chiricosta, who continues as vice president for operations; Ron Kovas is named chief operating officer at I-Traffic Inc, succeeding Ed Dintrone, who is named chief team officer (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Interest Rates Slide As Stock Prices Tumble  The prices of Treasury securities jumped, sending the yields on 10-year notes and 30-year bonds down to levels not seen since 1967. The yield of the 30-year bond dropped to 5.19 percent, from 5.26 percent on Wednesday. The decline shows that investors are betting that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates, a move that could help stabilize stock markets here and abroad.

headline: Prudential Complex Sale
abstract: Avalon Bay Communities Inc has bought apartment property portion of Boston's Prudential Center from Prudential Insurance Co of America for $130 million (S)

headline: Business Travel; United Air Offers Joint Plane and Train Ticket
abstract: United Airlines is offering tickets that combine air travel between Chicago, San Francisco and Washington, DC, gateways and Paris with fast train service between Paris and Lyons, France; carrier is timing its flights to connect with SNCF-French Rail's high-speed TGV train service from Charles De Gaulle Airport to Lyons; Corporate VAT Management, computer software company, introduces new version of its software that helps businesses reclaim value-added tax from 15 European countries and Canada; Marriott International is putting self-service business centers, jointly operated by Mail Boxes Etc and USA Technologies, into 13 of its US hotels (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Japan Considers Nationalizing Some Banks
abstract: Japan considers trial step toward nationalizing troubled big banks; idea would be odd and embarrassing step for Government to adopt; yet taking over one or more giant banks could avoid risk of large-scale bankruptcy that would rattle nation's financial system; test is likely to be played out with Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, which has been teetering as political parties squabble over how to save it (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar climbs against Japanese yen on disappointment over economic plans outlined by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan; in New York trading, dollar rises to 146.13 yen from 144.32 yen on Sept 17; graph; chart (S)

headline: Rising Phone Sales Lift Nokia Earnings
abstract: Finnish company Nokia reports second-quarter profits rose to 2.17 billion markkaa ($401 million), from 1.33 billion markkaa in 1997 period (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VAIL RESORTS INC., Avon, Colo., a ski resort operator, agreed to buy two real estate packages at the Village at Breckenridge in Colorado from TBA Entertainment Corp., Hickory Ridge, Tenn., for $34 million in cash.    BOHLER UDDEHOLM A.G., Vienna, a maker of high-grade steel products, said it had bought a unit of Allegheny Teledyne Inc., Pittsburgh, for $30 million.    VISIO CORP., Seattle, a supplier of business diagramming software, bought the privately held Kaspia Systems Inc., Beaverton, Ore., for Visio stock valued around $23.3 million.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 5 chart in special Mutual Funds Report (Money & Business Part 2) listing best-performing diversified stock funds which misstated return and ranking of United Income fund, class A (S)

headline: Cows Cloned In First Case Like Dolly's, Japanese Say
abstract: Japanese scientists report creating two calves that were clones of adult cows; used much same method as Dr Ian Wilmut of Roslin Institute in Scotland in cloning of sheep named Dolly (M)

headline: Hoechst and Mobil Call Off Joint Venture
abstract: Hoechst AG and Mobil Corporation abandon plans to form joint venture to make plastic film after failing to agree on terms (S)

headline: After Dispute In Pakistan, Leader Leaves For U.S. Visit
abstract: Pakistani Prime Min Nawaz Sharif leaves for visit to United States after facing Parliamentary opposition to his proposal to make Islamic justice supreme law of the land (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ING GROUP, Amsterdam, a financial-services company, said it had an agreement to buy Clarion Partners L.L.C., New York, becoming the world's third-largest real estate asset manager.    P-COM INC., Campbell, Calif., a maker of network-access systems for wireless communications, said it would cut about 120 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and reduce pay for senior managers by 10 percent to get its costs down as sales in Asia slide.

headline: Levi Sells 25 Outlets
abstract: Designs Inc., the operator of 121 retail clothing stores, will buy 25 outlet stores from Levi's Only Stores Inc., a unit of Levi Strauss & Company, for about $12 million as Designs moves to eliminate its Boston Traders brand and concentrate on name brands. The purchase consists of 16 Dockers outlet stores and 9 Levi's outlet stores in the Eastern United States.

headline: Confidence Index Hovers Near Record
abstract: Conference Board says consumer confidence in US economy stuck close to 30-year high in July; reports index fell to 135.4 from revised 138.2 in June (S)

headline: The Chairman Of Cendant Steps Down
abstract: Cendant Corp chairman, Walter A Forbes, resigns after weeks of intensifying pressure from accounting scandal; board immediately elects Henry R Silverman, company's chief executive, to additional post of chairman; company was formed in December from merger of HFS Inc, led by Silverman, and CUC International Inc, led by Forbes; Forbes will get severance package worth more than $35 million; E Kirk Shelton, former president of CUC and seven other former CUC directors on Cendant board also resign; Frederick D Green, another former CUC director and current audit committee chairman, says he will leave board by end of year (M)

headline: U.N. Says Iraq Will Have More to Spend on Food and Medicine
abstract: As President Saddam Hussein of Iraq continues to defy arms inspectors and to demand an end to the eight-year trade embargo against his nation, the United Nations said today that Iraq would have more money to spend on imported food, medicine and related supplies this year than at any time since sanctions began in 1990.    Mr. Hussein's recent conduct makes it unlikely that the Security Council will want to lift that embargo anytime soon, and the money will be less than he had sought. But United Nations members also recognize that public support for continued sanctions would rapidly evaporate unless their harshest effects on ordinary Iraqis are mitigated by allowing Iraq to sell some of its oil for food and other necessities.

headline: E-Mail Flaws Make Usually Confident Users Feel Uneasy
abstract: Recent news that simply opening an e-mail message could destroy data on hard drive has created new concern about personal software security among e-mail users; chart describes flaws in and scheduled fixes for Netscape, Microsoft and Qualcomm e-mail programs (M)

headline: Hershel L. Herzog, 74, Executive And Pharmaceutical Researcher
abstract: Hershel L Herzog, pharmaceutical executive instrumental in developing several popular antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Now It's Grapevines Climbing the Rockies; Small Wineries Gaining Footholds In Many Unlikely U.S. Locales
abstract: Small wineries are gaining footholds in many states without long wine-making traditions, including Colorado; number of American wineries doubled, 1980-95, with more than half of new wineries outside California; most states now have at least one winery, but many operate on fine line between hobby and small business; table of top wine-producing states; photos (M)

headline: Paying Attention
abstract: Carleton H Freedman letter on his irritation at talking on the telephone with someone who is simultaneously eating, working a computer, watching television or multitasking in some other way (July 23 article)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization           July 17   July 10   July 18       1998   1998   1997       Gasoline production, daily   8.5   8.4   8.0       Distillate production, daily   3.6   3.6   3.4       Gasoline stocks   220.2   221.4   197.8       Distillate stocks   139.7   135.3   120.1       Crude imports, daily   8.8   9.3   8.1       Product imports, daily   1.9   1.8   2.3       Crude stocks   341.5   334.7   318.6       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.3       Refinery utilization (%)   100.3   100.2   96.2          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: COURT APPROVES MARVEL REORGANIZATION PLAN
abstract: Delaware bankruptcy court approves Marvel Entertainment Group's reorganization; investor Carl C Icahn agrees to amended plan calling for Marvel to be merged into Toy Biz Inc (S)

headline: Executive Exiting Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Mary Doan resigns as worldwide director for client service applications at Saatchi & Saatchi (S)

headline: Dear Mr. President: What to Do in Moscow
abstract: Pres Clinton is offered all kinds of advice on what to do about summit meeting in Moscow from Henry A Kissinger, Brent Scowcroft, Zbigniew Brzezinski, Colin Powell and Lawrence S Eagleburger (M)

headline: Putting the 'M' Back in MTV
abstract: MTV president, Judy McGrath, and executive vice president, Brian Graden, comment on success of network's re-emphasis on music programming; photos (M)

headline: Korea Bid Expected To Go to Rothschild
abstract: Creditors of South Korea's insolvent Halla Group seem likely to accept Rothschild Inc's $1.8 billion bid for four of group's companies (S)

headline: New Threats Reported as Rapes in Indonesia Are Investigated
abstract: Human rights workers investigating scores of organized gang rapes during three days of rioting in Jakarta, Indonesia, in May say they and victims have been receiving threats from unidentified men; say they have confirmed rapes of 168 women during riots, 20 of whom died during or after assaults (M)

headline: A New Generation of Deal Makers
abstract: Profile of Goldman Sachs investment banker Gene T Sykes; brief biographical sketch; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Water Truck Discounted As Carrier Of Explosive
abstract: Two American security officials say embassy-owned water truck is now being discounted as carrier of bomb that exploded outside American Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and are shifting their attention to other possibilities; say they have no explanation of how bomb arrived at entrance gate (M)

headline: Executive Fallout From a Merger Accord
abstract: MCI Communications Corp chief executive Gerald H Taylor resigns following company's acquisition by Worldcom Inc; Taylor says he first considered leaving MCI after company agreed to be acquired by British Telecommnications in 1996; photo (M)

headline: When Fashion Jumps Into Sports Arena
abstract: PARIS  Fashion and sport may just be a match made in heaven. Ticket scams and hooligans aside, 80,000 spectators and an estimated 1.7 billion television fans will watch the World Cup soccer championship on July 12 and the warm-up act will be Yves Saint Laurent's 300 models gliding through the Stade de France, a symbol of what Pierre Berge describes as "the mysterious wedding of beauty and sport."

headline: U.S. Cancels Plans For Raid on Bosnia To Capture 2 Serbs
abstract: Clinton Administration officials drop secret plans for commando missions in Bosnia to seize Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, wartime political and military leaders of Bosnian Serbs, on war crimes charges; spent two years and tens of millions of dollars preparing missions; cite concerns about bloodbath, French reluctance to act and growing sense that mission could rekindle Serbian aggression (M)

headline: Drop in AT&T Stock Price Raises Concern on TCI Deal
abstract: Sharp drop in AT&T Corp stock price spurs speculation that AT&T's deal to acquire Tele-Communications Inc for $31.8 billion in stock may have to be renegotiated in light of poor shareholder reaction; stock has fallen 16 percent since deal was announced; Tele-Communications president Leo J Hindery Jr reportedly admits renegotiation may be needed; another person involved in talks says new talks are not planned (M)

headline: U.S. Expected to Seek Scottish Trial in Hague for Pan Am Suspects
abstract: Clinton Administration reportedly will announce proposal to create Scottish court in Netherlands to try two Libyans accused of blowing up Pan American jetliner over Lockerbie in 1988, killing all 259 aboard and 11 on ground (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ruble Throws Another Scare Into Markets
abstract: Market Place: Growing possibility of devaluation of Russian ruble throws scare into world's markets; although Russians insist there will not be devaluation, threat has already led to major selloff in emerging markets and proved drag on Wall Street and other major stock markets; Russia's crisis could be sign of broadening malaise that would stunt strong economy in US; Russian stock market plunges and is closed temporarily as sellers swamp buyers; yields on short-term Russian bonds jump to nearly 200 percent; main stock market index falls 6.5 percent for day, resulting in loss of almost 50 percent in just last four weeks; George Soros, well-known financier and big investor in Eastern Europe, calls for major financial reforms and 15 to 25 percent devaluation of ruble; graph (M)

headline: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Russians Hope Economy Has Reached Turning Point
abstract: Prime Min Sergei Kiriyenko and other top Russian leaders express hope that their floundering economy is finally turning corner toward solvency; analysts say Government gained few months to put its fiscal house in order when it secured $4.8 billion loan from International Monetary Fund and international investors bought up $4.4 billion in long-term bonds to refinance exorbitant short-term loans that are coming due (M)

headline: ALBERTSON'S GAINS F.T.C. APPROVAL TO BUY BUTTREY FOOD
abstract: Albertson's Inc wins Federal Trade Commission approval to complete its $169 million purchase of Buttrey Food & Drug Stores Co after it agrees to sell 15 supermarkets in Montana and Wyoming; Smith's Food & Drug Centers Inc agrees to buy 13 of stores and Supervalu Inc (S)

headline: Mandela Words a Poignant Farewell
abstract: Excerpt from remarks made at opening session of UN General Assembly by Pres Nelson Mandela of South Africa, who called it valedictory address before world body; photo (M)

headline: Hadera Journal; Jewish Family Heirloom: 15 Square Miles of Death
abstract: Zypora Frank, 62-year-old Israeli teacher, finds out that her family owned part of land on which Auschwitz death camp stood, where most of her mother's family perished; discovery of deed to land ends her quest to learn exactly what the properties were that her parents told her about 10 years ago; Frank has only vague childhood memories of fleeing her homeland and taking tortuous route that ended in Israel; photo (M)

headline: Rolls-Royce Reports A Flat First Half
abstract: Rolls-Royce PLC reports it had no growth in first half of year in its core business as competition squeezed margins on engines; company's net income rose 11.5 percent, to $175 million, as result of lower research and development spending; graph (S)

headline: Conagra Expands Links to Grey
abstract: Conagra Inc expands its relationship with Grey Advertising by naming agency to handle advertising for its Healthy Choice line of food products; billings estimated at $40 million; account has been handled by Campbell Mithun Esty (S)

headline: When Lending Money Just Isn't Enough; Critics Seek a New Role for the I.M.F. As Recent Bailout Programs Fall Short
abstract: Critics are seeking new role for International Monetary Fund as recent bailout programs fall short; IMF's reserves are shrinking, largely because the fund has had to bail out Russia and countries hardest hit by Asian crisis; George Soros, chairman of Soros Fund Management, Stanley Fischer, first deputy managing director of IMF, and Jeffrey Sachs, director of Harvard Institute for International Development, suggest ways IMF should change; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Even as Latin Markets Plunge, Drastic Remedies Are Avoided
abstract: Latin American governments have let interest rates rise, spent billions of dollars to support their currencies and tinkered with other lmited responses to recent panic in world markets that has weakened their currencies and drastically reduced wealth of many corporations; hope to avoid shift to more Draconian monetary policies; Latin markets get breather as stock prices rise, even as gloom deepens among investors and business executives; photo (M)9

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.38   5.57        3-month T-bills   4.55   4.67   4.77        6-month T-bills   4.51   4.67   4.93        10-yr. T-infl.   3.62   3.65   3.56        10-yr. T-note   4.66   4.71   6.03        30-yr. T-bond   5.16   5.15   6.31        Telephone bd.   7.01   7.05   7.40        Municipal bds.   5.09   5.09   5.45          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: PURCHASE PLANS AND TOP APPOINTMENTS ARE ANNOUNCED
abstract: Bank of New York Co's BNY Capital Markets Inc unit to buy Patricof & Co Capital Corp, which will be integrated into BNY Capital; terms undisclosed; Thomas J Perna, Bruce W Van Saun and Joseph M Velli are named to new positions of senior executive vice president and Thomas P Gibbons to executive vice president at Bank of New York; Robert J Mueller will head new asset based lending sector; Leslie V Godridge is named head of corporate banking, and Harold F Dietz will be chief credit policy officer and head of credit policy sector (S)

headline: Net Income at Deutsche Telekom Rises 19% as Rivals Cut Growth
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG says net income rose 19 percent in second quarter; income increased to 950 million marks, or $560.3 million, from 800 million marks in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 3 percent, to 17.1 billion marks, or $9.6 billion, from 16.6 billion marks (S)

headline: Media Talk; Two More Television Stations Drop Howard Stern's Show
abstract: KTVK-TV, Phoenix, and KUSI-TV, San Diego, drop Howard Stern's late-night show, The Howard Stern Radio Show, from their schedules; official for KTVK comments on decision (S)

headline: Comcast Speeds Up Jones Intercable Bid
abstract: Comcast Corp, fourth-largest US cable-TV company, says it will accelerate its purchase of 2.9 million control shares of Jones Intercable Inc for $200 million in cash, giving it control of cable-television company (S)

headline: True North's new unit aims to reach ethnic households, which have money to spend.
abstract: True North Communications is stepping up its efforts in multicultural marketing, forming unit, New America Strategies Group, devoted to encouraging advertisers to keep pace with changing face of consumers by increasing sales pitches aimed at ethnic groups (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stock Prices Are Mixed, Capping Loss-Ridden Week  Stocks seesawed yesterday to finish mixed, closing out the worst week for the market since January on investor concern that corporate profit growth is faltering. Gateway led a decline in computer stocks after reporting unexpectedly weak earnings, while Pepsico gained after saying it might spin off some bottling operations.

headline: APACHE IS PLANNING ADDITIONAL ACQUISITIONS
abstract: President Steven Farris says Apache Corp wants to buy another oil and natural-gas exploration company or another company's fields within next year, interview (S)/

headline: TBWA Chiat/Day Wins Top Obie Award
abstract: TBWA Chiat/Day takes top honors, winning Best of Show at annual Obie Awards for creative excellence sponsored by Outdoor Advertising Association of America; other winners noted (S)

headline: Russian Legislators Reject Prime Minister Candidate
abstract: Russia's Parliament emphatically rejects Pres Boris Yeltsin's nomination of Viktor S Chernomyrdin for Prime Minister, leaving nation virtually rudderless in midst of deepening economic crisis; Chernomyrdin implores lawmakers to approve his appointment, warning that Russia is on verge of economic and political breakdown; appeal draws jeers from Communist-led opposition, which controls lower house of Parliament; their strategy seems aimed at discrediting or toppling Yeltsin Government or forcing Yeltsin to agree to more generous power-sharing arrangement; rejection also seems aimed at torpedoing Chernomyrdin's claim that only he can unify splintered nation and serve as Yeltsin's heir; Yeltsin immediately renominates Chernomyrdin; aides warn that Parliament will be dissolved if it refuses to yield, raising worrisome prospect for many deputies who have grown comfortable with many perquisites of office and who might fear national election; photos (M)

headline: A Conglese Joining Up To New Life, Or Death
abstract: Kinshasa is filled these days with young men who have volunteered to join the Congolese Government's notoriously unprofessional, untrained and disorganized army, compelled by vague notions of duty and unshakable belief that the Congo has been attacked by the hated Tutsi and their Rwandan backers; Tonton Miaka, one such volunteer, and several family members comment; photo (M)

headline: Sprint Is Laying Out Details Of Plan to Revamp Network
abstract: Sprint Corp is laying out details of ambitious program to revamp its communications network to provide integrated data and video information at high speeds; chairman William T Esrey comments (M)

headline: FINGERHUT IN $120 MILLION DEAL FOR ARIZONA MAIL ORDER
abstract: Fingerhut Companies acquires Arizona Mail Order for $120 million (S)

headline: PULTE EXPANDS SOUTHEAST OPERATIONS BY BUYING DIVOSTA
abstract: Pulte Corporation, nation's biggest home builder, acquires closely held Florida builder DiVosta & Company; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Bitter Festival Chief Says It's Definite: Shanghai Opera Won't Appear
abstract: Lincoln Center Festival dir Nigel Redden announces in Shanghai that his struggle with local culture authorities over how to produce The Peony Pavilion has ended in failure; says it is impossible to perform classic Chinese opera in New York on July 7 because officials will not permit members of Shanghai Kunju Opera Co to depart; photo (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correcton of July 19 Viewpoint article about ways in which privatizing Social Security system could affect stock market, wirter Herbert Barchoff was special adviser to President's Council of Economic Advisers in Truman administration (S)

headline: IRAQIS BREAK OFF ALL COOPERATION WITH INSPECTORS
abstract: Iraq says it is ending all cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors and demands dismissal of chief inspector Richard Butler through restructuring of his disarmament commission; action breaks agreement made in Feb with Sec Gen Kofi Annan, which averted US and British military action against Iraq; independent international technical evaluation in July, one of number demanded by Iraq, concluded that Baghdad had not met commission's requirements on accounting for biological arms; Iraq also urges that disarmament panel be moved to Geneva or Vienna from New York to free itself of US influence (M)

headline: Patience Pays Off as Pair Join Rush to Consolidate
abstract: Article on Bell Atlantic Corp's acquisition of GTE Corp focuses on GTE chief executive Charles R Lee, who will become chairman and co-chief executive of merged company, and Ivan G Seidenberg, Bell Atlantic's chief executive, who will become president and co-chief executive; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. signals concern as stock prices of Internet companies ascend toward atmospheric heights.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is voicing subtle warnings about unusually high prices of Internet industry stocks by trying to block acquiring companies from writing off most of price of acquisitions up front, as one-time hit investors tend to dismiss; SEC is insisting that costs be deducted over many quarters, weight on profit investors are more likely to heed; at issue is bid by technology firms to write off as immediate expense purchase of continuing research of acquired company (M)

headline: Elder Statesman in Nigeria Laments a Tattered Nation
abstract: Gen Olusegun Obasanjo, former President of Nigeria, laments country's decline into madness; Obasanjo, who was released from prison on June 16 after serving three years for alleged complicity in plot to overthrow Government of late dictator, Gen Sani Abacha, says Abacha ruined nation's oil industry for personal gain, closing refineries so that he could profit on imports of refined fuel and leaving one of the world's greatest oil producers unable to meet its own gasoline needs; says he believes Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar is committed to returning armed forces to their barracks and reinstituting democracy; says demands by some opposition groups for a return to civilian rule by Oct 1 may be overhasty; photo (M)

headline: Equities and Convertible Debt Set To Be Offered This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Amtran Inc., Indianapolis, 3.7 million shares. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co.    C. D. Smith Healthcare Inc., St. Joseph, Mo., an initial public offering of 4.8 million shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

headline: Media Talk; Miami Herald to End Its International Edition
abstract: Miami Herald plans to stop publishing international edition it has sold throughout Latin America and Caribbean for 52 years and instead replace it with portion of Miami edition; newspaper cites financial reasons and push to include more news about Miami for foreign readers (S)

headline: CARGILL TO BUY PLANTATION FOODS, A TURKEY PROCESSOR
abstract: Cargill Inc to acquire Plantation Foods Inc; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Appeals Court Panel Upholds Prudential Insurance Settlement
abstract: Federal appeals court panel in Philadelphia upholds huge class-action settlement between Prudential Insurance Co of America and millions of its customers who had been sold unnecessary life insurance by Prudential agents over 13-year period ending in 1995; settlement had been approved in March 1997; court affirms basic terms of settlement, which calls for Prudential to repay estimated $2 billion to customers through direct refunds and enhancements to existing policies; court does not approve lower court's award of about $90 million in legal fees (M)

headline: International Briefs; Projections Show Profit Falling 36% for Adidas
abstract: Adidas-Salomon AG says first-half profit rose 3 percent; figure suggests second-quarter net income fell 36 percent, to 44 million marks ($24.65 million) (S)

headline: UAL President, Pressured by Unions, Quits
abstract: John A Edwardson resigns as UAL Corp president and chief operating officer under pressure from employee-owned company's unions, which oppose his promotion next year to chief executive (S)

headline: Gloom in German East May End Kohl's Streak
abstract: Helmut Kohl is fighting uphill battle for fifth term as German Chancellor; stubbornly high unemployment in former East Germany and nationwide malaise confront Kohl and Christian Democrats with cruel irony that German unification, the biggest single triumph of his 16 years in office, could could deprive his coalition of majority in Parliament; economic tribulations in eastern Germany are of particular significance since politically volatile region has swing voters who can make or break narrow margins of success; election on September 27 could fundamentally redraw Germany's political landscape and determine future of Europe, just as continent confronts upheavals of globalization and its own striving for economic unity; map; charts; photos (M)

headline: Home Web Sites Thrust Students Into Censorship Disputes
abstract: Legal experts say school censorship of student Web sites outside schools is on the rise, and courts have made no definitive rulings; case of Sean O'Brien, who won lawsuit against Westlake High School in Ohio for suspending him over insults he posted about a teacher on his home site, discussed; photo (M)

headline: Caldor Given Extra Time
abstract: US bankruptcy court has given Caldor Corp extra six months to reorganize its finances; Caldor filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of US Bankruptcy Code in 1995 (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- Scrambling for Lifeboat Seats; Indonesia's Troubles Swamp Even the Well-Run Banks
abstract: Financial problems at Indonesia's Bank Bali, country's fourth-largest bank, illustrates just how thoroughly Asian economic disaster has wrecked Indonesia's banking system; vast majority of country's 240 banks are insolvent--relics waiting to be taken over by state or simply shut down; even few well-run banks, like Bali, have been impacted by suffocating debts, collapsed currency and social unrest that has led to panicky bank runs; Bank Bali's president Rudy Ramli comments; experts say Pres B J Habibie must take sweeping measures to clean up entire sector, including closing numerous banks, forcing many others to merge and holding bank managers accountable for what turned out to be reckless lending; chart; graph; photo (M)

headline: Mortgage Rate Hits a Low
abstract: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp says average rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 6.64 percent in week ending Sept 18, from previous week's 6.66 percent (S)

headline: There were no summer doldrums for the agencies and start-ups involved in deals late last week.
abstract: Advertising column notes recent acquisitions and start-ups in advertising field in recent weeks (M)

headline: In Kosovo Death Chronicles, Serb Tactic Revealed
abstract: Human rights officials chronicle what they say is arbitrary arrests and torture of ethnic Albanian civilians by Serb authorities seeking to discourage popular support of a separatist guerrilla force fighting for independence in Kosovo province; say extrajudicial methods used by officials under control of Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, run parallel to military intimidation by special police force and Yugoslav Army; photos; map (M)

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; Yes, France Is a Friend Of the Euro
abstract: Article by Martin Hufner, Bayerische Vereinsbank of Munich chief economist, on misreading of France's support of European common currency; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Pressing Kabul to Oust Saudi Linked To Bombings
abstract: The United States is urging the Taliban militia in Afghanistan to expel a Saudi-born multimillionaire from the country in hopes that he can be captured as a suspect in the bombing of American embassies in East Africa, senior Clinton Administration officials said today.     Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright came close to making the request public when she described the views of the man, Osama bin Laden, as ''inimical to those of the civilized world'' and called on Afghanistan to ''stop harboring those considered terrorists.''

headline: Air France-American Express Card Plans
