abstract: Air France and American Express Co plan to offer co-branded charge card aimed at strengthening customer loyalty at airline and allowing American Express to expand its network in world's biggest tourist destination; Air France says card, which will go on sale next month, will cost $104 (US) a year and allow holders to withdraw as much as 6,000 francs in cash a week; Air France and American Express also introduce corporate charge card, in partnership with Accor SA and Credit Lyonnais SA (S)

headline: Mindspring to Buy Sprynet
abstract: Mindspring Enterprises Inc will buy Sprynet, Internet service provider, from America Online Inc for about $35 milion to $45 million in cash (S)

headline: Pepsico Studies Possible Conversion of Bottling Operations
abstract: Pepsico says it is studying possible conversion of some bottling operations into separate publicly traded company, a move that would make it fiercer competitor to Coca-Cola Co; announcement by Pepsico's chairman and chief executive Roger A Enrico is seen by analysts as confirmation that Pepsico plans to create major national bottler similar to Coca-Cola Enterprises (M)

headline: SUNBEAM GRANTED MORE TIME ON LOANS BY LENDERS
abstract: Sunbeam Corp reaches accord with lenders to avert default on $1.7 billion in loans until at least end of year (S)

headline: Japan Bank Bailout Fails to Go Forward
abstract: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party fails to win support from major opposition parties for proposal to bail out troubled financial concerns (S)

headline: Jiang: Reformer, or the Last of the Apparatchiks?
abstract: News analysis of Pres Clinton's encounters with Pres Jiang Zemin during state visit to China; even though Clinton seemed to think he had found China's Gorbachev, Jiang is more likely to be China's Brezhnev--one of last leaders of old Communist regime, who is far more interested in shoring up party's monopoly over political power than in dismantling it (M)

headline: U.S. Experts Arrive to Study Clues in Blast That Killed 9
abstract: Team of United States antiterrorism experts arrives in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, to start sifting through rubble from badly damaged American Embassy for clues as to who bombed building (S)

headline: Union Pacific to Limit Traffic on Its Tracks
abstract: Union Pacific Corp, which is still recovering from some of worst congestion in industry's history, announces plan to improve and, in some cases, ration its service; executives acknowledge that company will not be able to reliably, or profitably, accommodate all that want to use its tracks; Richard K Davidson, chairman, says primary goal is to recover 10 percent of railroad's traffic lost in last year (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Early signs are that Wall St. may now see E.D.S. as more than the company Ross Perot founded.
abstract: Market Place column on Electronic Data Systems' latest effort to define itself as something other than company that Ross Perot founded; board plans to hire new chairman and chief executive from outside, having announced retirement of Lester M Alberthal Jr; Alberthal expanded company, especially abroad, but he was reluctant pitchman; investors, disappointed by EDS, have drawn confidence from leadership of James A Baker 3d, chairman of board's governance committee; graph (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Existing Home Sales -- June    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence -- July    WEDNESDAY  Durable Goods OrdersJune    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims  New Home Sales -- June    FRIDAY  G.D.P. -- 2d Qtr.

headline: Media Talk; Scholar Puts His Opinion Of Clinton Aide on the Record
abstract: Michael Ledeen, resident scholar at American Enterprise Institute, says he 'hates' Sidney Blumenthal, White House aide, but denies every suggesting to anyone that Blumenthal abused his wife; Ledeen's deposition is given in Blumenthal's civil lawsuit accusing Internet gossip columnist Matt Drudge of defamation; photo (S)

headline: Dollar Rises Against Yen, Masking Recent Weakness
abstract: US dollar gains almost 4 percent against Japanese yen after Japan's central bank announces surprise cut in important interest rate; sudden surge hides real surprise about dollar's recent performance against both yen and German mark: dollar has weakened against these two leading currencies despite economic turmoil and political uncertainty that has roiled financial markets last two months; analysts argue decline is disturbing because it is another indication of how global economic crisis is having intensifying effect on US; analysts say drop in dollar's value, especially against the mark, reflects belief that global crisis will spread to Latin America, weakening those economies; in turn, that weakness will restrain large markets for American exports, helping to slow growth in US and further undercut corporate earnings and stock market; in the end, economic slowdown and stock market declines will force Federal Reserve to cut interest rates; graph (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS IS ADDING BUSINESSES
abstract: International Home Foods reports it is paying $126 million in cash for Nestle SA's Libby's canned meat business and paid $39 million for Puritan products business of Unilever Canada's Lipton unit (S)

headline: Top Officers Shifted At 3 Agencies
abstract: Three advertising agencies make changes in top executives; Peter Krivkovich, president and chief operating officer at Cramer-Krasselt in Milwaukee, will succeed retiring chairman and chief executive Paul Counsell; Stephen Badenhop, executive vice president and managing director at Jordan McGrath, is named president, succeeding Pat McGrath, who continues as chief executive and assumes added new post of chairman; M&C Saatchi names Robert Fletcher executive chairman and managing partner of New York office, succeeding Bill Muirhead, who will return to London office (S)

headline: ITT PLANS $1.1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK AFTER SALE OF UNITS
abstract: ITT Industries plans to buy back $1.1 billion of its stock as first step toward spending expected proceeds from sale of auto-parts units Continental AG and Valeo SA (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NORRELL CORP., Atlanta, a temporary personnel and outsourcing company, acquired FSS International Ltd., a London-based recruitment company, for an undisclosed sum.    ADVANCED ENERGY INDUSTRIES, Fort Collins, Colo., a maker of power systems for semiconductor-equipment manufacturers, laid off 14 percent of its work force and will take a $1.8 million third-quarter charge because of a significant downturn in the semiconductor business.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Legal-Fee Firecracker in the Cendant Case
abstract: New York class-action lawyer Howard Sirota files motion, US District Court in Newark, arguing that three pension funds that invested in Cendant Corp should not be allowed to run case against Cendant because they cannot assure lowest possible legal fees and may be influenced by campaign contributions that have been made by one of law firms representing them; Judge William H Walls is scheduled to hear arguments on motion on Aug 4; Sirota wants Wall to award 'lead plaintiff' status to plaintiff whose lawyers will work for smallest percentage of ultimate recovery; Sirota notes that law firm Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossmann contributed more than $40,000 to election campaign of New York State Comptroller H Carl McCall, who is sole trustee of New York State pension fund involved in case; Cendant lost unprecedented $14 billion in market value on April 16 after company reported accounting irregularities (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Tbilisi Journal; A Historic Trove of Houses, in Need of Handymen
abstract: Much of Tbilisi, Georgia's old town was declared historic district in 1975, but although that decree has preserved much of its character, little has been done to restore crumbling facades and interiors; architectural historians are mapping area house by house, and hope to attract international help for large-scale preservation program; map; photo (M)

headline: CENTURA BANKS IN $23 MILLION DEAL FOR SCOTLAND SAVINGS
abstract: Centura Banks Inc says it agreed to acquire Scotland Savings Bank Inc for about $23 million in cash (S)

headline: Madras Journal; Political Melodrama: Don't Cry for Her, Tamil Nadu
abstract: Among great melodramas about politically powerful women -- the Evitas and Imeldas, the risen and fallen, the adored and despised -- India these days offers Jayalalitha Jayaram, a former movie star whose fickle control over a 27-vote bloc in Parliament threatens to topple the five-month-old Hindu nationalist Government.    Notoriously imperious, clad in ornate capes, Jayalalitha, as she is known, was the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu, a state in south India, from 1991 to 1996, when she was voted out of office in disgrace.

headline: Lockerbie Suspects May Be Tried at World Court
abstract: US and Britain may allow trial in Hague, under Scottish law, for two Libyans accused of blowing up Pan American World Airways jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988; had previously insisted that suspects, Abdul Basset al-Megrahi and Lamin Khalifah Fhimah, be tried in US or Scotland (S)

headline: METRIS TO BUY $1 BILLION IN CREDIT CARD LOANS FROM PNC
abstract: Metris Companies, credit card concern, agrees to buy $1 billion of credit card loans from PNC Bank Corp; Metris is buying 518,000 accounts from customers who do not bank with PNC and do not hold affinity cards from any of PNC's credit card partners (S)

headline: Mexicans' Radical New Politics: Top Party May Adopt Primaries
abstract: Government corruption and economic crisis have fueled surging opposition in Mexico; Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), which monopolized Mexican politics for six decades after its founding, has lost so many recent elections that opposition governors and mayors now run much of country; scores of leaders have deserted party, and many Mexicans wonder if it can survive in competitive atmosphere; Pres Ernesto Zedillo has vowed that unlike previous PRI presidents he will not anoint his successor, decision that has forced party to start looking for new way to nominate its candidate for presidential voting in 2000; PRI has begun testing primaries as way of nominating some gubernatorial candidates, and in Chihuahua state, experiment attracted thousands of new voters and appears to have been factor in PRI's victory in July 5 general elections (M)

headline: Internet Sites for Children Raise Concerns on Privacy
abstract: Kathryn C Montgomery, president of Center for Media Education, voices concern over ability of commercial Internet Web sites to gather detailed information from children without their parents' knowledge; says that even if sites are not now exploiting information they request, they might in future; much concern stems from recent Federal Trade Commission study that found that almost half of all Web sites aimed at children have made little effort to explain their practices to their young visitors and that most fail to notify parents when children are asked to give out personal information; Elizabeth L Lascoutx, director of Children's Advertising Review unit of Council of Better Business Bureaus, estimates there are thousands of such commercial sites (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PROTECTIVE LIFE CORP., Birmingham, Ala., a provider of insurance and investment services, agreed to acquire 260,000 individual life insurance policies from Lincoln National Corp.    P. H. GLATFELTER CO.,  Spring Grove, Pa., a maker of paper used for writing, tea bags and cigarettes, plans to cut about 125 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, at one of its North Carolina factories amid unfavorable market conditions for its tobacco-related paper.

headline: Car Thefts Lead Israel To Wall Off West Bank
abstract: A record number of car thefts has persuaded Israel's right-wing government to abandon its longtime opposition to  erecting any new barriers between Israel and the West Bank.    Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Government had resisted the idea fiercely out of concern that such a line could be interpreted as a demarcation of Israel's future border. But it has shifted course in the face of public outcry over the disappearing cars, some 46,000 of which were stolen in Israel last year.

headline: Inspector Says He May Test Iraqi Resolve On Arms Sites
abstract: Interview with Richard Butler, chief UN arms inspector for Iraq, who warns he may soon test Baghdad's resolve to block further weapons inspections by sending team to examine new site (M)

headline: Canada Tries to Bar Pro-Nazi View on Internet
abstract: Canadian Government moves to shut down Internet site run by Ingrid Rimland that promotes words and ideas of Ernst Zundel, a Toronto resident who is one of world's most insistent Holocaust deniers and distributors of anti-Semitic literature; contends that although Rimland operates the site out of her home in California, Zundel controls its content; says its aim is to subject Zundel, not the Internet, to Canadian law (M)

headline: Missile Test by North Korea: Dark Omen for Washington
abstract: Clinton Administration and arms control experts say North Korea's test of medium-range missile able to reach targets in Japan represents technological breakthrough that has raised new fears of spread of ballistic missiles; with North's record of selling missiles and related technology to Iran, Pakistan and Syria, concern is that more advanced, longer-range missiles are now within reach of less developed countries (M)

headline: DECISION TO STRIKE FACTORY IN SUDAN BASED ON SURMISE INFERRED FROM EVIDENCE
abstract: Article reconstructs how US chose targets for August 20 strikes against Saudi exile, Osama bin Laden, in Afghanistan and Sudan following terrorist bombing of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania; reconstructs how 'small group' and President picked bombing targets, and how act of war was approved on basis of shards of evidence gleaned from telephone intercepts, spies and scientific analysis (L)

headline: Mahbub ul Haq, 64, Analyst And Critic of Global Poverty
abstract: Mahbub ul Haq, former Finance Minister of Pakistan and an early proponent of economic liberalization who in later years argued that poor countries failed to prosper because they neglected the basic development of their people, dies at 64; photo (M)

headline: Spice World, Land of Missed Opportunities
abstract: J C Herz reviews Spice World, new interactive game from Sony, which allows users to make their own music videos starring Spice Girls; photo (M)

headline: Patents; An inventor says a bracelet with a computer chip embedded in it could help cut crime rates.
abstract: Stephen Heiser patents tracking technology that uses computer chip embedded in bracelet to enable authorities to constantly monitor location of paroled felon; radio signals relayed every 30 seconds to central computer would identify parole violations and presence of felons at crime scenes; Dr Patricia Bowling patents contact lens that focuses and intensifies light on remaining retinal rod and cone cells of people suffering from retinal diseases to improve their vision; 125th anniversary of writer Mark Twain patenting self-pasting scrapbook recalled (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DCI TELECOMMUNICATION INC.,  Stratford, Conn., a long-distance service and prepaid phone-card provider, agreed to buy the closely held Locus Corp., Fort Lee, N.J., a provider of intergrated telecommunication services, for $25 million in cash and stock.

headline: SPENDING IT / EARNING IT: VICARIOUS CONSUMPTION; Stables Fit for a King: Splendor in the Bluegrass
abstract: Article on thoroughbred horse industry in Kentucky's Blue Grass country, which is in midst of comeback after bottoming out in 1980s; describes luxurious stables where horses are shown to their best advantage to prospective buyers and breeders; photos (M)

headline: Opium Surge Threatens U.N. Aid to Afghans, Official Warns
abstract: Top United Nations official, Pino Arlacchi, warns that an anti-narcotics program begun in Afghanistan late last year is in danger of being dismantled, citing reports that opium poppy production may be increasing in areas under control of Islamic Taliban movement; Arlacchi,exec dir of UN Drug Control Program, also says that he is hearing for first time of opening of refineries to produce morphine, if not heroin, near heart of Taliban's religious center of Kandahar; both increased production and refining of opium would violate accord under which United Nations would provide development aid in return for gradual reduction in poppy production; Noorullah Zadran, Taliban's representative-designate to United Nations, asserts that Taliban strongly opposes narcotics but that drug-control program had demanded too much of Taliban too soon; map (M)

headline: Flaws in U.S. Account Raise Questions on Strike in Sudan
abstract: Some key statements initially made by Clinton Administration officials to justify attack on what was called a secret chemical weapons plant in the Sudan prove to be inaccurate, misleading or open to question; descriptions of plant as a highly secretive, tightly secured military-industrial site, statement that plant produced no commercial products, and assertion that exiled Saudi millionaire Osama bin Laden directly financed the plant do not appear to be factual; inconsistencies and aura of secrecy have given Sudanese Government chance to challenge the attack and call for international inquiry; photo (M)

headline: A Number of Banks Report Strong Profits in 2d Quarter
abstract: BankAmerica Corp and several other large banks meet or beat second-quarter earnings expectations; earnings at BankAmerica rose 11.4 percent, and Fleet Financial Group Inc says net income increased 13 percent; BankAmerica says net income was $890 million; Fleet says net income rose to $393 million from $347 million; US Bancorp says net income rose 5.5 percent, to $320.6 million; Wachovia Corp says operating earnings rose 17 percent; net income rose 6.7 percent, to $209.9 million from $196.8 million; Republic New York Corp says second-quarter earnings rose 7.5 percent; net income rose to $118.8 million from $110.5 million; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Troubled Health Plan's Stock Price Ills
abstract: Market Place column on continued decline in price of stock of Oxford Health Plans; says Oxford's shares, which traded above $20 earlier this year, closed on July 30 at $8.4325, after touching new low of $7.375 during previous day's trading; graph (M)

headline: Ammirati Executive Announces Departure
abstract: Duncan Pollack, a longtime top executive at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, said yesterday that he had resigned.    ''It's been a great 13-year run at A.P.L., but the time has come for a new challenge,'' Mr. Pollack, 54, said, adding that he was ''investigating a number of opportunities'' and would announce his plans in the near future.

headline: THE MARKETS: Shocks and Aftershocks; The Bear Is Rampant in the Markets for Riskier Bonds
abstract: Prices of bonds have barely budged; August, one of most brutal months on record in almost every bond market around the world, has been followed by a September in which most of these securities have mustered only merest gains; investors in wide variety of bonds, from convertibles to mortgage-backed securities, have found themselves trapped in game of economic dominoes gone awry; bond market action in August is painful lesson in how topping of one market can, in turn, hurt even the most seeingly unrelated market worlds away; charts and graphs on performances of various bonds (M)

headline: Honors
abstract: Chicago Association of Direct Marketing elects Ron Jacobs president, succeeding Sheldon M Soble, who remains on executive board; Women Executives in Public Relations names Dorothy Crenshaw president; she succeeds Valerie Di Maria (S)

headline: Their Quiet Lives, Rendered Stark and Bold by the Manner of Their Deaths
abstract: Profile of Prabhi Kavaler, US foreign service officer who died in bombing of US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya (S)

headline: DONALDSON, LUFKIN FUND TO PAY $23 A SHARE FOR DECRANE
abstract: Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Inc's DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II fund agrees to acquire DeCrane Aircraft Holdings Inc, maker of avionics components, for $23 a share, a total of $172.5 million (S)

headline: U.S. Strategy: Keep the Pressure on Iraq
abstract: United States vows to 'keep the pressue on' to persuade Iraq to end its defiance of United Nations arms inspectors (S)

headline: Palestinians Carry Out First Executions
abstract: Palestinian firing squad carries out first executions under Palestinian self-rule, executing two brothers convicted of killing two brothers from another family who were popular leaders in Fatah Movement of Yasir Arafat; the accused were members of security organization who apparently used official weapons in shootings; their action roused storm of protest throughout Gaza Strip among Palestinians fed up with members of security forces who strut around firing weapons into air and using them to threaten civilians (M)

headline: France Selects Buyer For State-Owned Insurer
abstract: French Government will sell its 87.1 percent stake in insurer Groupe des Assurances Nationales to Groupama Assurances for $2.8 billion, making Groupama fourth-largest insurer in France (S)

headline: Fallon Names Office President
abstract: Fallon McElligott names Alison Burns president of New York office (S)

headline: American Inspector on Iraq Quits, Accusing U.N. and U.S. of Cave-In
abstract: William S Ritter Jr, longest-serving US weapons inspector in Iraq, resigns, charging that Sec Gen Kofi Annan, Security Council and Clinton Administration have stymied inspectors on 'doorstep' of uncovering Iraq's hidden weapons programs; says in his resignation letter that failure to push aggressively ahead with inspections is 'surrender to Iraqi leadership' that makes 'farce' of commission's efforts to prove that Iraq is concealing chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs; asserts that between Nov 1997 and Aug 1998, Administration made at least seven efforts to delay or stop investigation or block line of inquiry; makes his resignation letter public in effort to force US and United Nations to return to tougher stance; Ritter photo (M)

headline: Italian Media Tycoon Convicted Again on Corruption Charges
abstract: Silvio Berlusconi, flamboyant media tycoon and former Prime Minister of Italy, is convicted by Milan jury of making illegal political donations; he gets prison of two years and four months and $5.6-million fine; head of center-right opposition leader already stands convicted of bribing tax inspectors and accounting fraud, but he is in no immediate danger of actually going to jail because of parliamentary immunity; Berlusconi instead is turning legal woes into charge of persecution by left-leaning prosecutors (S)

headline: Mountbatten Bomber Is Freed, Outraging Many in Britain
abstract: Thomas McMahon, former Irish Republican Army member who was convicted of preparing and planting the bomb that killed Lord Mountbatten and others in 1979, becomes one of the first prisoners to be released as part of peace agreement, outraging many in Great Britain; Mountbatten photo (M)

headline: W. Frederick Laird, Gas Company Executive, 79
abstract: W Frederick Laird, former chairman and chief executive officer of Columbia Gas System, dies at age 79 (S)

headline: Company Has a Problem With Net's John Doe(s)
abstract: Itex Corp, which brokers and records barter exchanges, files suit to bar individuals known only by their on-line handles from posting defamatory statements against firm on Yahoo message boards; Yahoo says it is not responsible for messages and has no way of knowing who posted them; suit spurs further derogatory postings; drawing (S)

headline: The Post-Lewinsky Winner Is the Web
abstract: Emergence of Internet as key medium for breaking news discussed in light of release via World Wide Web of Kenneth W Starr's report and Pres Clinton's videotaped grand jury testimony; release created hefty new audience in workplace; tools proliferating on Net allowed users to select parts of tapes to view; photos (M)

headline: Roiled Market Takes a Breath As Dow Slips
abstract: Stock prices are broadly mixed in comparatively sluggish trading after two days of frenzied selloff and partial recovery; Dow Jones industrial average is up more than 100 points, but is down 45.06 points at close, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,782.37; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dips 3.79 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 990.47; Nasdaq composite index rises 17.76 points, or 1.13 percent, to 1,592.85; trading volume is relatively light, with just more than 896 million shares changing hands; photo; graphs (M)

headline: America Online Grows Despite Increasing Fees
abstract: America Online says operating earnings totaled $57.3 milion for quarter ended June 30, tenfold increase over same period a year earlier; company says it cannot publish its net earnings pending agreement with Securities and Exchange Commission over several special charges; chairman Steve Case says that whatever SEC decides, company will meet its earnings forecasts for coming year; revenues increased by 67 percent, to $792 million (M)

headline: Samsung May Withdraw From Auction for Kia
abstract: Samsung Group says it might withdraw from auction of Kia Motors Corp and Asia Motors Co if buyer must assume their $10 billion in debt (S)

headline: Brazil Phone Stock Dives, A Proxy for Latin Markets
abstract: Three weeks ago, Brazil celebrated Latin America's largest privatization, selling its stake in the giant phone company Telebras for almost $19 billion, roughly 70 percent above the asking price.    Optimism over Brazil's long-term economic prospects remains high. But Telebras, along with numerous other equities from here to Buenos Aires, has taken a stomach-churning dive in value since the auctioneer's gavel came down on July 30. Its American depository receipts closed today at $95, down from $124.625 when international phone companies seized the chance to buy stakes in the Brazilian communications market.

headline: BB&T AGREES TO $554 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR MAINSTREET
abstract: BB&T Corp says it will acquire Mainstreet Financial Corp in stock transaction valued at $554.3 million (S)

headline: Medicare Panacea Turns Patient; H.M.O's Now Must Treat Their Own Ills
abstract: Many of nation's health maintenance organizations, after aggressively recruiting elderly and disabled into their Medicare plans, are heavily retreating; United Healthcare Corp, once darling of Wall Street, recently took $900 million charge against earnings, in part to scale back its Medicare operations in 35 counties; in last year, Aetna, Pacificare Health Systems, Oxford Health Plans, Foundation Health Systems, Kaiser Permanente and Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations have canceled Medicare plans in parts of 13 states; virtually no Medicare HMO's are available in Utah or in rural Ohio; despite HMO financial problems in Medicare market, Congress is now pushing for even more people to enroll in plans; financial setbacks for some HMO's have raised serious questions as to whether they can prosper covering Medicare patients; charts; photo of Eugene and Yuriko DeLorenzo, who have had their Medicare coverage canceled (M)

headline: Quark Quits Its Quest for Adobe Systems
abstract: Quark Inc drops its bid to acquire rival Adobe Systems Inc; Quark, which never stated price or how it intended to finance its unsolicited offer, says Adobe spurned its advances and that it does not want to pursue hostile deal (M)

headline: Treasury Schedules Auctions for Bills and Note
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a two-year note to be auctioned on Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.93 percent, and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.02 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.47 percent.

headline: Morgan Stanley In China Deal
abstract: China Three Gorges Project Development Corp, company in charge of world's biggest dam project, hires Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co to draft preliminary documents for sale of shares on New York and Hong Kong stock exchanges (S)

headline: An Eerie Echo
abstract: Similar quotes by Pres Clinton and John D Rockefeller on topic of 'legally accurate' testimony; Clinton's statement was made about his relationship with Monica Lewinsky when he was deposed in Paula Jones sexual harassment suit in January; Rockefeller quote referred to testimony in 1888 before New York State Senate committee; when committee's counsel mistakenly referred to price-fixing and kickback scheme as Southern Improvement Co instead of South Improvement Co; Rockefeller was able to deny taking part in it without committing perjury (S)

headline: Chernomyrdin Rallies Forces for Another Try at Confirmation
abstract: Acting Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin of Russia rallies new forces to try to stop Communist-led lower house of Parliament from rejecting his nomination for second time; Pres Boris N Yeltsin proposes to reopen talks on sharing power with lower house as constitutional confrontation intensifies and economy threatens to follow currency into free fall; if Chernomyrdin is rejected again, Yeltsin faces politically agonizing choice: resubmitting Chernomyrdin's nomination and then having to disband lower house and call for new parliamentary elections if it is rejected third time, or dropping Chernomyrdin and putting forward compromise candidate; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Sends Dual Message To China in Interview on TV
abstract: Pres Clinton gives television interview in Shanghai in which he says that he will continue to speak out for democracy and individual liberty, but that United States does not seek to dictate path of China's development; lauds China's current course of economic liberalization and greater personal freedom as 'morally right'; subtly signals to Chinese leader that US will not try to impose its will on China, while signaling to ordinary Chinese and US critics of his China policy that he will continue to press for more personal freedom and more open political system; meets with young entrepreneurs and visits private housing development; map; photo (M)

headline: The Fellow Travelers
abstract: Russia Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin, in his drive to consolidate his power, embarks on first attempt since fall of Soviet Union to negotiate sharing of power between remains of Communist Party and tycoons who rose from ashes of socialism; sends signals that he wants to form coalition govt that embraces tycoons and Communists alike; photo (News Analysis) (M)

headline: Shell Projects in Malaysia
abstract: Royal/Dutch Shell Group says two Malaysian units will invest 12 billion ringgit ($2.8 billion) in oilfield and exploration projects over next five years in Sarawak and Sabah (S)

headline: Associates First Capital to Buy Textron Unit for $3.9 Billion
abstract: Associates First Capital Corp, finance company spun off from Ford Motor Co, agrees to buy Avco Financial Services for $3.9 billion in cash; Associates First is buying Avco from Textron Inc (S)

headline: HARRAH'S TO ACQUIRE RIO SUITE HOTEL IN LAS VEGAS
abstract: Harrah's Entertainment Inc will acquire Rio Hotel and Casino Inc to entice customers from its other US casinos to vacation at Rio's sole property, upscale Rio Suite Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev; deal is valued at $518 million; Harrah's will assume about $370 million of Rio debt (S)

headline: The Shrinking Oligarchs Of Russia
abstract: Empires of some of Russia's top business leaders, known as the oligarchs, are facing collapse, along with Russia's brand of capitalism; oligarchs like Vladimir Potanin, chief executive of Interros Group, are credited with helping put Russian economy on its knees; Potanin's career epitomizes an era in which hopes of Western investors and Governments came to repose in handful of power brokers; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Raw sugar futures fall 3 percent on concerns about drop in demand and large crops; Oct raw sugar falls 0.26 cent, to 7.93 cents a pound; graphs; table (S)

headline: Who Said Computers Have to Be Square?
abstract: Apple's new iMac model combines computer and monitor into one unit housed in rounded, see-through, aqua-and-white plastic case; company hopes bold design combined with speed will woo customers away from Windows-based systems; chart compares iMac with IBM Aptive; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Tim Spengler, deputy director for national television at Western International Media, is promoted to senior vice president and general manager, succeeding Bill Croasdale, who is named to new position of office of the president (S)

headline: Rekindling Love's Fire Along the Last Frontier
abstract: Legal dispute blocks publication of Alaska Men, magazine that profiles, for fee, some of state's many eligible bachelors; Internet version is allowing founder Susie Carter to resume matchmaking; photos (M)

headline: Top Iraqis Affirm Threat to End Arms Checks
abstract: Iraq's ruling council endorses threat to end all cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors if Security Council does not restore regular reviews of its sanctions against Iraq (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: AMP Buying Shares to Stop Takeover by Allied Signal  AMP announced a plan to buy back as much as 30 million shares of stock for $55 each. The action met with mixed reviews from analysts, and shares of AMP fell $2.1875, to $37.    The buyback is intended to counter a hostiletakeover bid of $9.7 billion, or $44.50 a share, from Allied Signal. By offering some stockholders a higher price for their shares, AMP, the maker of electrical connectors, is seeking to appease investors and gain some time to illustrate that its management can improve profitability and increase its stock price. [Page C4.]

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Pivotal Departure of a Value Investor
abstract: Michael F Price resigns as chief executive of Franklin Templeton Group; Robert L Friedman is named chief investment officer, and Peter Langerman, currently chief operating officer, will take over as chief executive; Friedman says first order of business will be to address causes of recent underperformance; photo (Market Place) (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp, West Greenwich, RI, pays $27.8 million for 80 percent stake in Europrint Holdings Ltd, British provider of games that media use for promotion (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.56   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.94   4.95   4.96        6-month T-bills   5.02   5.04   5.07        10-yr. T-infl.   3.75   3.75   3.68        10-yr. T-note   5.42   5.41   6.24        30-yr. T-bond   5.62   5.60   6.56        Telephone bd.   7.08   7.06   7.63        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.21   5.56          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: LIBRARY/PERSONAL-FINANCE SITES; Mixing Analysis With Fun
abstract: Description of Invest-o-rama, Web site that features hard information rather than in-depth analysis (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Stage a Rally As Investors Seek Safe Havens
abstract: US Treasury prices rally; 30-year bond rises 22/32, to 104 29/32; yield drops to 5.18 percent, from 5.22 percent on Sept 16; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Libyans Are Pressed Over Pan Am Trial
abstract: Prominent international allies pressed Libya to accept an offer to allow two Libyans to go on trial in the Netherlands for the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.65   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.92   4.95   5.07        6-month T-bills   5.03   5.04   5.13        10-yr. T-infl.   3.76   3.77   3.68        10-yr. T-note   5.43   5.46   6.12        30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.71   6.41        Telephone bd.   7.10   7.16   7.49        Municipal bds.   5.25   5.26   5.46          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Donaldson Buys Big Stake
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc is expected to purchase majority stake in PM Realty Group (S)

headline: Kosovo Separatist Chief Picks Delegation Without Rebels
abstract: Ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova names team to negotiate peace with the Serbs that does not include representatives of all ethnic Albanian political forces; this is setback for Western governments hoping to end war through negotiations because team lacks any representatives of the rebel army fighting Serbia's rule of Kosovo, meaning its authority to reach agreements binding on the rebels is doubtful; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: POLAROID CORP.,  Cambridge, Mass., the instant photography company, agreed to buy NBS Imaging Systems Inc., Fort Wayne, Ind., for $12.9 million, expanding its digital identification operations.

headline: Japanese Senior Managers Are Lagging in Internet Access
abstract: Andersen Consulting's recent study on Internet usage found only 71 percent of Japanese executives have access to Internet, lowest level among senior management in nine of world's leading economies; 99 percent of American executives have Internet access, leading field (S)

headline: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA STOCK UP 14% ON NEWS OF TCI ORDER
abstract: Scientific-Atlanta Inc says Tele-Communications Inc has ordered 'substantial quantities' of advanced digital-cable control boxes, with deliveries to begin later this year; terms of contract undisclosed (S)

headline: New Low for High-End Hi-Fi
abstract: Market for high-end audio equipment lags far behind the growth of personal wealth in recent years; total sales for high-end part of audio market are estimated at less than $500 million, compared with total home electronics market of $75.1 billion; high-end audio sales rose in 1997, but some companies had declines; demographic and economic factors are holding down growth, and technological trends threaten industry's relevance; photos (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/  If the Internet is transforming the retail business, investors should begin looking for the next Amazon.com. By Sana Siwolop.    INVESTING IT /Page 6/  Starting with a quantitative screen, C. Beth Kotner's research has Putnam Investors outperforming the market. By William R. Long.

headline: At Schwab, a Big Web Shift
abstract: Charles Schwab & Co, traditional discount stock broker, reports that 52 percent of its customer trading volume is now done online (M)

headline: New President of Colombia Meets Guerrilla Leaders
abstract: Pres-elect Andres Pastrana of Colombia meets with top leaders of country's largest guerrilla force in unannounced session; comes away pledging to remove security forces from five municipalities and start peace talks with rebel leaders within 90 days of taking office; his top campaign promise was pledge to negotiate end to nearly four decades of political violence in Colombia; photo (M)

headline: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO ADD MEDICAL PRODUCTS MAKER
abstract: Tyco International Ltd agrees to buy Graphic Controls Corp, maker of disposable medical and surgical products, from investment group Bessemer Holdings LP for $460 million in cash (S)

headline: Technology Start-Ups Suffer Market Jitters
abstract: Technology start-up firms are feeling the impact of the erratic stock market; while there is still a good deal of money poised to be invested in promising start-up companies, less certain is how many two- and three-year-old companies will be able to sell stock with the market as skittish as it is; venture capital firm, Flatiron Partners, New York, says it has stopped making investments and has encouraged the companies it owns to raise cash as a cushion in case of a downturn; other funds say they are investing but more cautiously; Nasdaq market has declined 22 percent from its high on July 20, but is still essentially flat for the year (M)

headline: TRACKING BAGHDAD'S ARSENAL: INSIDE THE ARSENAL: A special report.; Defector Describes Iraq's Atom Bomb Push
abstract: Khidhir Abdul Abas Hamza, Iraqi scientist who defected in 1994, describes inner workings of Iraq's 27-year effort to build nuclear bomb, interviews; says Iraq could quickly resume program if United Nations cut back on inspections and lifted economic sanctions; says his colleagues were lavishly rewarded for successes and tortured by secret police for failures; says Pres Saddam Hussein personally directs program, abetted in past by host of Western companies; says Iraq was within months of making bomb when Persian Gulf War disrupted program in 1991; map; photo of Iraqi nuclear reactor complex destroyed by Israel in 1981 (M)

headline: Ulster Assembly Starts, With Debates on Flags and Languages
abstract: New Northern Ireland Assembly holds first working session; Protestant and Catholic members discuss some cultural and political issues that have divided province for centuries, instead of dealing with how to enact the provisions of the peace settlement reached in spring 1999 (M)

headline: Death Benefits, Now for The Living
abstract: Article on growing number of financial companies and insurers that are buying back values of life insurance policies while insured is alive and healthy; says one company, Viaticus Inc, unit of CNA Financial Corp, expects to buy up to $300 million of policies this year, up from $75 million last year; holds Viaticare Financial Services expects to buy $100 million in policies, up from $18 million last year; some insurers welcome new approach while others question whether it will cost life insurance industry in long term; photos (L)

headline: Treasury Issues Scheduled for Pricing This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned Tuesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.88 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 4.91 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill is at 4.95 percent.

headline: Consulting By Auditors Stirs Concern
abstract: Federal securities regulators are concerned that accounting industry's lucrative expansion into computer consulting may create conflicts with accountants' role of being watchdogs for investors; consultants from Big Five accounting firms are installing complex software packages at hundreds of companies; Federal regulations prohibit close ties between accountants and companies they audit because auditors are expected to give unbiased opinion on accuracy of companies' financial statements; sudden consulting boom has made accounting firms more involved in day-to-day operations of some of their audit clients; Ernst & Young affiliate audited books of Baan Co even as Ernst & Young consultants installed software that Baan produces; Price Waterhouse Coopers audits books of J D Edwards & Co even as its consulting side searches for potential recruits skilled in working with Edwards software; chart (M)

headline: Boeing in Deal With Union On the 737
abstract: Boeing Co and its biggest union, International Association of Machinists, announce agreement that paves the way for Boeing to produce model-737 commercial jets at former McDonnell Douglas complex in Long Beach, Calif; but while deal is designed to ally union fears of job losses, Boeing also says that it plans to cut even more employees than it had indicated last month; Boeing agrees that assembly of most of jets will remain outside Seattle and that major parts, such as fuselage and wings, will continue to be produced at their current locations; company also pledges that it will not lay off any union workers as a result of move (M)

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF; Forget Football. Who's No. 1 Among Business Schools?
abstract: Article by Texas University student Daniel J Crean on importance of university's being listed in Business Week's annual ranking of graduate business programs (M)

headline: Flaw in Word 98 Can Spread Your Personal Information
abstract: Microsoft Word 98 for Macintosh reportedly contains flaw that can make personal information accessible to others by transferring data from user's hard drive or RAM and embedding it in Word documents; photo (S)

headline: The Sky Is Becoming the Only Limit for Credit Card Users
abstract: Article on current practice of banks and other credit-card issuers to raise credit limits far faster than consumers borrow despite record number of delinquencies and bad debts; graph (M)

headline: What's Going to Happen To Russian Nest Eggs?
abstract: Today's de facto devaluation of the ruble and rescheduling of government debt is supposed to spare the Russian Government financial ruin. Then there is Valeriya Yan, who is not being let off so easily.    Two years ago, Ms. Yan set a goal: to raise $24,000 so she and her husband could buy a two-room apartment for themselves and their 10-year-old son, away from the tiny one they share with two parents. She gave up teaching for a mindless but more lucrative job routing calls for a paging service for $300 a month.

headline: Months of Water Rationing Leave a Lot of Throats Parched : Kuala Lumpur's Taps Tapped Out
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR  T. Shanmuganathan does not remember the last time he had two consecutive days of running water.

headline: Texans Call Terror Suspect Apolitical
abstract: People in Arlington, Tex, who knew Wadih el Hage describe him as even-tempered, devout and utterly apolitical; el Hage is first US citizen to be charged with being part of Osama bin Laden's terrorist organization (M)

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; Let Oil Companies Talk to Iran
abstract: Viewpoint article by foreign policy analyst Joe Barnes and energy analyst Amy Myers Jaffe on possibility that move by US and Iran toward normalizing relations may be thwarted by longstanding distrust; holds focus should be on investments in Iran's oil and natural gas sectors (M)

headline: Worldwide Rebound Seen in Chip Sales
abstract: Dataquest research unit of Gartner Group says worldwide sales of computer chips are expected to rise 12 percent in 1999, rebounding from decline of 6 percent this year; adds total revenue from computer chips is expected to increase to $155 billion in 1999 (S)

headline: MERRILL LYNCH SELLS HSBC 4% OF BEZEQ FOR $102.5 MILLION
abstract: HSBC Investment Bank, arm of HSBC Holdings PLC of London, acquires 4.15 percent of Bezeq Ltd, Israel's state-run telephone company, for $102.5 million from Merrill Lynch & Co; HSBC also sells Cable and Wireless PLC the right to buy stake at $3.30 a share from Aug 20, 1999; Cable and Wireless owns 12.75 percent in company; Merrill, which will cut its stake in Bezeq to 2.27 percent, bought 12.4 percent of Bezeq from Israeli Government for $250 million a year ago (S)

headline: DuPont May Be Seeking Sale of Conoco
abstract: DuPont Co, which in May announced plans to sell the public 20 percent of its Conoco Inc oil subsidiary, may now be looking to sell all of Conoco; Elf Aquitaine is reportedly ready to offer to buy Conoco for $24 billion; speculation is that middle-size oil companies are merging to hold down costs in era of cheap oil and compete with biggest of oil giants; Conoco has developed large tracts of oil in North Sea, Indonesia and off West Coast of Africa; Elf also has fields in North Sea which, if combined with Conoco's, could potentially allow for lower-cost operations there (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Lockheed Calls Off Merger With Northrop Grumman  Faced with continued resistance from the Government, Lockheed Martin has abandoned its planned $8.3 billion acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation.    The decision followed months of negotiations between the companies and the Government to avoid a court fight. The deal's breakup signals the end of a wave of consolidation that swept through the military industry after the cold war ended. [Page A1.]

headline: Consumer Spending Declines For First Time in Two Years
abstract: Commerce Department reports consumer spending fell 0.2 percent, July, first drop in over two years; reports incomes rose 0.5 percent; University of Michigan reports its consumer sentiment index fell to 104.4 in Aug, from 105.5 in July (S)9

headline: WINBOND ELECTRIC TO BUY REST OF INFORMATION STORAGE
abstract: Winbond Electronics Corp of Taiwan to acquire stake in Information Storage Devices Inc it does not already own for $63.8 million (S)

headline: I.B.M. Uses Existing Hardware To Sharpen Flat-Panel Image
abstract: International Business Machines Corp will announce its much-sought-after breakthrough in computer monitor technology, a flat-panel screen that produces four times resolution of typical desktop monitors yet is driven by off-the-shelf hardware and software components; quad-resolution display screen produces images as discernible as those printed on paper; in some cases it is clearer; analyst says big question now is when, at what price and in which market this new technology would be introduced (M)

headline: Saudi Prince Insists an Attack That Killed 19 Americans Is Still Being Investigated
abstract: Saudi Prince Abdul Aziz bin Fahd insists probe of 1996 terrorist bombing that killed 19 American airmen in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, continues, news conference, Washington, after meeting with Pres Clinton; says Saudi officials cooperate with American counterparts; contradicts stand of American officials, who say probe broke down because of disputes with Saudis (M)

headline: Clinton's Sojourn in China, Viewed From the Cookout
abstract: Most people in Springfield, Ill, are pleased with Pres Clinton's visit to China; believe China is too big a force to ignore, given growing importance of global economy; some people accuse Clinton of giving a poor defense of rights of political dissenters and using trip to distract from embarrassing reports spilling out of investigations in Washington; photos (M)

headline: Web Offers Wide Menu For Sports
abstract: Fans of the biggest American sports have certainly benefited from explosion of information provided by the World Wide Web, but it has probably made the greatest difference to enthusiasts of lesser-known sports that receive limited or no regular media coverage; several Web sites noted (M)

headline: A Half-Million Pictures to Beautify Your Words
abstract: Bill Gates's privately held company, Corbis Corp, which has amassed rights to 23 million images and photographs, forms partnership with Compaq's Alta Vista search service, allowing users to browse or search through more than 500,000 images from collection to create and send E-mail postcards; photo (S)

headline: PUBLIC STORAGE INC. BUYS STAKE IN STORAGE TRUST REALTY
abstract: Public Storage Inc purchases 5.9 percent stake in Storage Trust Realty and offers to acquire company's remaining outstanding shares for $25 each (S)

headline: Moscow Plan: Spend Now, Save Later
abstract: Russia's acting Prime Minister, Viktor S Chernomyrdin, outlines for upper house of Parliament a two-stage plan for rescuing the nation's economy; first part calls for printing money so that Government can pay workers back wages and prop up ailing bank; ruble would be allowed to float, and only later would iron discipline be imposed on it by rigidly linking it to gold and hard-currency reserves; analysts agree that plan might secure approval of Chernomyrdin's nomination by lower house of Parliament and defuse strikes and mass demonstrations planned by Communists, but they say it would also speed Russia's roaring inflation and further depress its collapsing currency before corrective action is finally taken (M)

headline: Vodafone Group To Buy Phone Network
abstract: Vodafone Group PLC, Britain's No 1 cellular telephone company, agrees to buy New Zealand mobile phone network owned by BellSouth New Zealand Wireless Holdings Inc and ST Telecommunications for $369 million (US); merger will give Vodafone more than 120,000 customers in New Zealand (S)

headline: A Compass for Those Choppy Seas
abstract: Advice on steps households should consider in face of highly unsettled stock market; stock investment strategies and alternatives to stocks discussed; drawings; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Corning Reaches Deal To Settle Implant Battle  Dow Corning and lawyers for women claiming injury from silicone breast implants have agreed to a $3.2 billion settlement to the nearly 10-year-long battle.    The agreement would allow women seeking damages from the implants to receive money as early as next year and enable Dow Corning, a joint venture between the Dow Chemical and Corning, to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. [Page A1.]

headline: Japanese Stocks Are Sharply Lower
abstract: Japan's benchmark Nikkei stock index plunges 405.99 points, or 2.73 percent, in early trading on Aug 27, after markets drop across Europe and United States; on Aug 26, average dropped 206.90, or 1.37 percent; in Hong Kong, Hang Seng index is up 3.43 points, less than one-tenth percent, in first half-hour of trading (S)

headline: Bills and Notes Being Offered By Treasury
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5 percent and the rate for the six-month bill was 5.02 percent.

headline: Bank Reform, Not Bankruptcy, Is the Big Talk in Tokyo
abstract: Financial markets virtually ignore financial fallout of Japan's largest postwar bankruptcy, rallying instead on progress in bank-reform plan viewed as important step toward overcoming severe recession; although ripple effects of Japan Leasing Corp's bankruptcy could cause string of financial collapses among dominant Liberal Democratic Party's basic supporters, some analysts see silver lining; they say Japan Leasing's downfall appears to reflect new willingness by Liberal Democrats to let big, politically important business fail if they are insolvent, rather than bail them out (M)

headline: Microsoft Co-Founder to Sell More Shares
abstract: Microsoft Corp co-founder Paul G Allen files to sell 700,000 common shares for expected $73.3 million (S)

headline: Court Bars Bells From Offering Long Distance
abstract: Federal appeals court, 2-1, reverses Judge Joe Kendall's ruling and upholds law requiring local Bell phone companies to convince Federal regulators that they have opened their local networks to competition before they are allowed in long-distance market; ruling is victory for big long-distance carriers; comes in suit by SBC Communications, Bell Atlantic Corp and U S West Inc (M)

headline: Chrysler Tells About Plans With Daimler
abstract: Chrysler Corp president Thomas T Stallkamp says company plans to begin building Mercedes sport utility vehicles at Austrian factory, and may buy type of side air bag from Mercedes; Stallkamp says combined company, Daimler-Chrysler AG, will have ordinary shares that will be traded in New York, Germany and elsewhere with equal ease (S)

headline: Todi Journal; For a Happy Few, the Hamptons With Castles
abstract: Medieval city of Todi, Italy, is summer home to growing numbers of wealthy Americans who are lovingly restoring 14th-century fortresses, abbeys and farmhouses, and adding luxury bathrooms, swimming pools and tennis courts; longtime expatriates, old guard who got to Todi first, are unhappy about influx of new and flashier guard that threatens to follow; stringent new zoning law makes it impossible to build new houses or to renovate in anything but time-honored Umbrian style; but old-timers worry that new generation of jet-setters will bring 'Hamptons' style to Todi, complete with catered lunches, cocktail parties and charity balls; photos; map (M)

headline: Patch of Desert Is Key to Mideast Talks' Next Step
abstract: Article on arid parcel of land in Judean Desert, so-called nature reserve that is home to bedouin nomads, that is focus of renewed efforts by US and others to revive long-stalled peace process; parcel, southeast of Hebron, is latest three percent of West Bank that Israelis have been loath to surrender and Palestinians hesitant to accept; map; photo (M)

headline: RJR Nabisco Reports Big 2d-Quarter Loss
abstract: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp reports $130 million second-quarter loss compared with earnings of $243 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue was $4.292 billion, compared with $4.286 billion; chart (M)

headline: Taiwan Chief Sees Separate Identity
abstract: Taiwan Pres Lee Teng-hui, resisting pressure to forge closer ties with mainland China, says he is seeking to break out of isolation imposed by Beijing; ridicules Beijing's concept of 'one China,' and says Taiwan's destiny must be determined only by people of Taiwan; rejects suggestions that he work out deal with China over Taiwan's future; Lee photo (M)

headline: Thompson New York was looking for a savior, and Bob Jeffrey intends to succeed at the job.
abstract: Bob Jeffrey, who became president of J Walter Thompson USA ad agency in March, comments on how he plans to wipe away tarnish put on agency's reputation by almost two years of turnover in accounts, shortfalls in several high-profile reviews and turmoil in top executive ranks (M)

headline: U.S. Halts Business At Embassy In Albania
abstract: State Department shuts down routine operations at American Embassy, Tirana, Albania, citing threats from Islamic extremists; warns Americans not to travel to Albania; Clinton Administration officials question whether bombings of embassies in Kenya and Tanzania were response to arrest and deportation to Egypt of three Muslim fundamentalists by Albania; Albanian move spurred threat by Islamic Jihad against American targets abroad; Albanian reportedly plans to deport fourth Egyptian Muslim militant; authorities evacuate American Embassy, Bern, Switzerland, in response to phone threats (S)

headline: Media; An author questions the existence of Deep Throat, Watergate's man in the shadows.
abstract: David Obst, former literary agent for Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, writes in book, Too Good to Be Forgotten, that man known as Deep Throat, singular figure in American culture credited with being source of explosive articles written by Woodward and Bernstein as they unraveled Nixon Administration's abuses of power, was a composite, a plot device to fit narrative needs of the book and film, All the President's Men; photo (M)

headline: Brazil's Leader Calls for Reforms, Heartening Investors
abstract: Brazilian Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso, responding to international investor concerns about growing deficits, vows reforms if re-elected; banks on big lead in polls in apparently bracing voters for difficult measures ahead; pledges talks with International Monetary Fund and other international lenders; photo (M)

headline: Treasury to Retire $45 Billion of Debt Through September
abstract: US Treasury announces it will retire $45 billion in debt through September--first time it has been able to do that in third quarter since 1973; Treasury prices rise; price of 30-year bond rises 25/32, to 106 22/32; yield falls to 5.65 percent, from 5.71 percent on July 31; graph on 3-month Treasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn drops on speculation that ideal weather in coming days will help Midwest farmers reap bumper crop; September contract falls 3.5 cents, to $2.2975 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Soros's Quantum Fund Losses in Russia Put at $2 Billion
abstract: Russia's financial crisis is beginning to draw disclosures from some big international investors, such as George Soros's Quantum Fund, that they have suffered large losses from investments in that country; Stanley Druckenmiller, manager of Quantum Fund, says Soros's group of funds, operated by Soros Fund Management, lost $2 billion in Russian markets during last year, with greatest losses coming in equities; word of Soros's fund losses comes less than two weeks after Times of London published his letter expressing concern about Russian economy and financial markets; spokesman for Soros Fund, says even with losses Quantum Fund's $10.6 billion in assets were up 19.13 percent for year; Soros photo (M)

headline: In a battle over the prices of commercials during N.F.L. games, the sponsors played defense well.
abstract: Television networks scale back to estimated 8 to 10 percent the advertising rate increases for National Football League games in face of stiff resistance from advertisers to rises of 25 to 30 percent; most feverish opposition to higher rates came from Detroit auto makers; photo (M)

headline: Chicago Board Seeks To Add Contracts
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade plans to offer on-line futures contracts for every commodity traded by new Board of Trade of New York (S)

headline: WASSALL TOPS COOPER INDUSTRIES' OFFER FOR TLG
abstract: Wassall PLC offers 351 million pounds ($582 million) to buy TLG PLC, exceeding earlier bid of 321 million pounds from Cooper Industries; Wassall is asking TLG to withdraw its recommendation that shareholders accept Cooper offer (S)

headline: Congo Rebels Cut Power and Water Again
abstract: Rebels again cut electricity and water to this capital of five million people today, heightening fears about an imminent attack. As the threat intensified, support for President Laurent Kabila apparently grew.     Hours after the blackout began, the Government acknowledged its loss of control over the huge Inga hydroelectric dam. On Friday, Government ministers privately reported that the dam had fallen.

headline: VLASIC FOODS SAYS IT WILL SELL TWO BUSINESSES IN EUROPE
abstract: Vlasic Foods International says it will sell its Kattus gourmet foods distribution business in Germany and its frozen baked goods plant in Britain and concentrate on its Vlasic and Swanson brands; company says it is negotiating with several parties to sell Kattus; will also sell its plant in Peterlee, Eng, to Hibernia Foods for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Rape Cases Shake Up The Army In Canada
abstract: Many Canadians are upset over reports of sexual assaults at gunpoint and widespread acceptance of crude behavior toward women in military; although many soldiers say reports about rape in military are unfair and inaccurate, others say they are not surprised that such abuses may have occurred because of officers' pervasive indifference to such concerns (M)

headline: JAPANESE PREMIER RESIGNS AS VOTERS REBUKE HIS PARTY
abstract: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto resigns after voters rebuke Japan's governing party in parliamentary elections; several senior officials in Liberal Democratic Party are jockeying to succeed Hashimoto, and decision is expected soon, to reassure unsettled financial markets throughout Asia; transition is sure to create new uncertainties about Japan's political and economic course; since July 12 elections were for upper house of Parliament, not more important lower house, they did not directly affect Hashimoto's post as Prime Minister or his party's lock on power; Hashimoto billed vote as referendum on his leadership, and party won only 44 of 126 seats up for election; photos (M)

headline: Rumors and Contradictions Fuel Russia Market Crisis
abstract: During financial crisis, average Russian is stumbling from rumor to rumor in forest of official statements made and then withdrawn by Government; photo (M)

headline: Top Managers Are Out At Chinese Broker
abstract: Zhang Guoqing, chairman of China-based J&A Securities, and Yang Jun, president, relinquish control of brokerage firm and are being questioned by central Government authorities over their personal financial dealings (S)

headline: MARKET WATCH
abstract: Article on $3.5 billion bailout of Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund by consortium of large banks and brokerage firms; says many Wall Streeters are amazed that so speculative a firm would be saved from demise of its making (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures rise sharply on speculation that Saudi Arabia and Venezuela may move to bolster prices by proposing further cuts in output; crude oil for September delivery rises 50 cents, to $13.21 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Three Strategies, One Outcome: A Spring That Came Up Roses
abstract: Mutual fund managers Michael B Orkin, Tracy P Stouffer and Scott W Schoelzel describe winning strategies in spring 1998 quarter; photos (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (L)

headline: Tatham Loses In Tobacco Shuffle
abstract: Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp unit of BAT Industries PLC says it will consolidate and realign its American ad agency roster effective Jan 1, eliminating one of longtime shops, Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago (S)

headline: Another Woe As Ciena Loses AT&T Business
abstract: AT&T's decision not to buy Ciena Corp's technology for expanding capacity of fiber optic networks causes Ciena stock to plunge and forces delay of vote on Ciena's merger with Tellabs Inc (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Different Focus, Different Profit Figures
abstract: Investors are focused on corporate earnings as stock market struggles to get back on its feet, buoyed by reports that profits among biggest companies are still rising, albeit slowly; gauge of corporate profits produced by Government paints darker picture; as measured in National Income and Product Accounts, corporate earnings declined in fourth quarter of 1998; next week, when Commerce Department releases that report for second quarter, analysts expect decline in corporate earnings for third consecutive month; there have been six declines of at least three consecutive quarters since 1960; and five of those times, Dow Jones industrial average fell at least 15 percent from its peak ahead of that profit decline in those five stock spills, average Dow drop was 23.4 percent; average earnings decline of three quarters or more was 11.3 percent; graph (M)

headline: Partners & Shevack Get Spiegel Account
abstract: Spiegel Inc names Partners & Shevack in New York to handle advertising for its Spiegel Catalog account, with combined billings estimated at $13 million (S)

headline: Iran Issues Warning To Afghan Leaders
abstract: Iran said it would hold the militant Taliban movement that controls most of neighboring Afghanistan responsible for the deaths of nine Iranian diplomats whose bodies were recovered there yesterday.

headline: Treasury Yields Plummet on Expectations of Rate Cut by Fed
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rise, sending yields on 10-year notes and 30-year bonds down to levels not seen since 1967; price of 30-year bond jumps 1 1/32, to 104 21/32, while yield drops to 5.19 percent, from 5.26 percent on Sept 9; yield on 10-year note falls to 4.77 percent; graph on yield on 10-year note; chart on US key interest rates (S)

headline: DELTA DROPS PLANS TO LINK FLIGHTS WITH UNITED
abstract: Delta Air Lines drops plans for code-sharing with United Airlines after failing to reach agreement with pilots; decision comes two weeks after board refused to grant voting rights to member representing pilots' union; union said it would not support plan without same voting rights that United's pilots enjoy on their company's board (S)

headline: Second Time Around, and Around; Remanufacturing Is Gaining Ground in Corporate America
abstract: Remanufacturing--method of re-using old parts in new machines--is gaining ground in corporate America; companies of all types and technologies are looking to remanufacturing as premier way to hold costs down and keep products out of landfills; many companies are beginning to design products with eventual remanufacturing in mind; Federal Trade Commission, Environmental Protection Agency, and Congress have recently embraced remanufacturing, with money, technological support and new rules; numerous universities are studying it and teaching it; development of remanufactured components for copiers at Xerox Corp plant in Webster, NY, detailed; chart; photo (M)

headline: Japan Brokerage Firms Have Sluggish Quarter
abstract: Nomura Securities reports profit of 14.79 billion yen ($105 million) for quarter ended June 30, down 57.7 percent from year earlier; Daiwa Securities had profit of 2.40 billion yen ($17 million) in period, down 84.3 percent from profit of 15.32 billion yen a year earlier; Nikko Securities reports loss of 7.39 billion yen ($52.5 million) compared with loss of 1.93 billion yen in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Media Talk; From Mostly Wrong To Just About Right
abstract: New polls taken by Media Studies Center and Pew Research Center for People and Press show public has become less critical of news media coverage of Pres Clinton's relationship with Monica S Lewinsky since Clinton admitted sexual affair; graphs (S)

headline: United Nations Journal; Rome, My Dear Watson, Was Not Built in a Day
abstract: Mystery of what happened to $339,000 that United Nations received with Nobel Peace Prize in 1988 is cleared up when it turns out that it was bureaucratic indecisiveness about what to do with money that accounted for its apparent absence; Nobel Peace Prize check will be spent on a memorial at United Nations headquarters in New York commemorating fallen peacekeepers, as well as any peacekeepers who may die in years ahead; United Nations will issue Dag Hammarskjold Medals to relatives of all slain peacekeepers, paid for out of its own budget; photo (M)

headline: In Russia Reformer's Fall, Wealthy Insider Triumphs
abstract: Sudden demise of Prime Min Sergei Kiriyenko's four-month-old Government came partly from Russia's deepening financial crisis and Pres Boris N Yeltsin's penchant for sacrificing loyal subordinates; it also is demonstration of power of Boris Berezovsky and other tycoons, who exploited crisis and Yeltsin's weakened position to install more pliant Government; Berezovsky and his allies are playing role of go-between in formation of that Government, helping Acting Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin negotiate with Communists who dominate lower house of Parliament; photos (M)

headline: New Company For Productions
abstract: Several commercial producers and directors are joining forces at new production company in Los Angeles, the Farm Studios; Scott Gardenhour will be president and chief executive; Jeff Gorman, Gary Johns and Ramaa Mosley have signed with company (S)

headline: E.D.S. Posts 25% Gain but Issues Warning
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp says second-quarter profit rose 25 percent; reports profit before charges of $239.7 million compared with $192.4 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 14 percent, to $4.19 billion from $3.69 billion; figures for first six months noted (S)

headline: Betty Harragan, 77, Advocate Of Women's Workplace Rights
abstract: Betty Lehan Harragan, writer, consultant and advocate for women's equality in workplace, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: Phone Deal in Afghanistan Catches Many by Surprise
abstract: Telephone Systems International of Parsippany, NJ, signs $240 million contract to build cellular telephone system for the Taliban, the Islamic fundamentalists who control most of Afghanistan and who Clinton Administration says are harboring Osama bin Laden, suspected mastermind of embassy bombings in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, last month; telephone system will be built using equipment from Motorola, AT&T, Nokia and Ericsson, says Gary Breshinsky, who identifies himself as one of three owners of company; second owner is Ehsan Bayat, Afghani who lives in Queens, NY; there are no Federal restrictions on American companies doing business with Taliban (M)

headline: WASHINGTON HOMES TO BUY SOME REGENCY HOMES ASSETS
abstract: Washington Homes Inc agrees to pay $25.5 million for certain assets of Regency Homes Inc, regional home builder that filed for bankruptcy (S)

headline: 'Smart' Guns Can Check Identities Before Firing
abstract: Researchers are developing 'smart' guns that can only be fired by authorized users; advocates see smart guns as promising way to disable firearms taken from police officers or firearms stored in homes; critics warn they could create misleading sense of safety (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee futures drop 4.4 percent amid fears that Brazil will devalue its currency, prompting wave of selling; in New York, coffee for December delivery falls 4.85 cents, to $1.0415 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Between Consenting Co-Workers
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin column discusses ethics of consensual workplace romances; holds company's concern should be about impact of behavior on company and other employees; notes most companies, worried about sexual harassment charges, see issue as liability management problem; drawing (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/  A small drug company in a low-risk niche must race the calendar to remake itself as a full-fledged drug maker. By Anne Tergesen.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSTRIES, -- Honolulu, a utility company, said its HEI Power Corp., had paid $100 million for a 60 percent interest in a 206-megawatt coal-fired power plant under construction in China.    TELESPECTRUM WORLDWIDE INC., -- King of Prussia, Pa., which provides telemarketing services, agreed to acquire CRW Financial Inc., its largest shareholder, in a stock swap valued at $23 million.

headline: Goldman Keeps It Private Even in Going Public
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co, in prospectus for its public stock offering, reveals few details about its operations, planning to disclose data at last legal moment; filing says little about how firm's expected net worth of $28 billion will be divided and is vague about uses for new capital; opens window on firm's profit-making machinery, disclosing it is worldwide leader among investment banks in underwriting initial public offerings and advising companies on mergers; puts firm's compound annual growth rate in last 15 years at 15 percent; graphs (M)

headline: Argentine Chief Drops Bid for Third Term
abstract: Argentine Pres Carlos Saul Menem, facing virtual rebellion within his party, announces that he is ending his bid for unprecedented third term; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; What's in a Web Name? Sometimes, Mistaken Identity
abstract: Jeff Woods, owner of Internet service provider to Raleigh and Durham, NC, has discovered that using an address, or domain name, that people associate with well-known company may not be worth free publicly that comes with mistaken identity; he owns delta.com, a domain name he chose in 1993 for his company Deltacomm Internet Services; nearly everyone who comes to his Web site (www.delta.com) is really looking for site of Delta Air Lines; Woods has tried to sell address to Delta Air Lines; but airlinee, which does business on the Web as www.delta-air.com, has repeatedly rejected his asking price as too high (S)

headline: Air France Reports Loss From Pilot Strike in June
abstract: The strike by airline pilots at Air France in June, just as World Cup competition was starting in France, cost the struggling airline one billion francs ($165.9 million) in lost profit, a spokeswoman for the company said yesterday. She said the strike also cost the airline 1.6 billion francs in lost revenue. ''It will be very difficult to recoup these losses,'' she added. She declined to say whether the airline would have a profit for the first half or the full fiscal year.

headline: Hong Kong Talk Radio Host Is Slashed by Attackers
abstract: Albert Cheng, Hong Kong's most famous talk-radio host, is attacked by two unidentified knife-wielding men and seriously slashed, requiring six hours of surgery; he will survive, but in city where talk radio has become vital form of public expression, brutal assault on Cheng has left people reeling; listeners fear he may no longer be able to wield his sharp tongue; photo (M)

headline: John J. Ryan, 86, Investment Banker
abstract: John J Ryan, former investment banker and founder of John J Ryan & Co, died June 23 at age 86 (S)

headline: Bosnia Massacre Mars Do-Right Self-Image the Dutch Hold Dear
abstract: Dutch public is stricken with shame at new disclosures on performance of Dutch peacekeepers in Eastern Bosnian town of Srebrenica in July 1995, when 7,000 Bosnian Muslim men were massacred by Serb; most disturbing report is that while Dutch peacekeepers were under Serb attack, one Dutch unit fled its post in a light tank and plowed through a cluster of armed Muslims who were trying to block their flight, running over and crushing an unknown number of people (M)

headline: Burmese Opposition Issues Risky Challenge to the Junta
abstract: Small group of Burmese opposition politicians say they will act as country's legitimate parliament, and declare null and void all of ruling junta's laws and proclamations; risky challenge to military comes from ten politicians, led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, whose party won 1990 elections for parliament that was never allowed to take office; Government does not respond immediately, but tone of recent statements has grown more threatening, describing pro-democracy figures as traitors and terrorists (S)

headline: NETWORK ASSOCIATES IN CASH DEAL FOR SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: Network Associates will buy Cybermedia Inc for $130.2 million in cash (S)

headline: Call Letter Lore
abstract: History of call letters used by radio and television broadcasters reviewed; broadcasters use call letters as easy way to carve out station's identity; drawing (M)

headline: A.D.S.L. Lines of BellSouth To Start Including Mac Users
abstract: BellSouth, which launched its ADSL high-speed Internet connection in the Windows market, is now targeting Mac users as well (S)

headline: BRANDYWINE TO BUY AXINN PROPERTIES FOR $103.5 MILLION
abstract: Brandywine Realty Trust to acquire Donald E Axinn Companies for $103.5 million (S)

headline: SEAGATE TO TAKE A CHARGE AFTER CO-FOUNDER RESIGNS
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc says co-founder Alan F Shugart has resigned from its board in separation agreement that will result in charge of $8 million to $10 million this quarter (S)

headline: How to Get the Most From Computers in the Classroom
