abstract: Growing numbers of teachers are attending summer workshops to learn ways to introduce technology into their classrooms; American schools have been on 20-year spending spree on educational technology, with computers pouring into classrooms, but most of nation's education schools use traditional training courses and treat technology as frill; this means both new and experienced teachers need help with learning theories geared to computer use in classroom; summer computer workshops tend to appeal to teachers who get bored by routine and seek ways to excite their students and keep themselves from getting burned out; photo (M)

headline: Congo's War Turns to Brutal Killings on City's Streets
abstract: Congo Govt tightens security in Kinshasa, even as fighting just outside capital diminishes; evidence emerges that civilians and soldiers had brutally killed several suspected rebel infiltrators; photos of soldiers executing suspected rebel (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, said it would increase quarterly dividends 8 percent and announced a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid after the cash dividend.    KEY TRONIC CORP., Spokane, Wash., a maker of computer keyboards, advanced input products and engineered devices, will lay off 200 people and shift the assembly of products to Mexico.

headline: Hedge Fund Bailout Rattles Investors and Markets
abstract: 3.5 billion rescue of Long-Term Capital Management LP, big, risky investment fund verging on collapse, unnerves markets around the world, and raises clamor for Govt investigation and creates fear that other enormous hidden losses might become evident in weeks and months ahead; rather than contain problem and bring stability to Wall Street, cash infusion by consortium of banks and brokerage firms to salvage fund only seems to rattle investors; banks begin to tighten lending requirements to other investment funds, raising fears of credit shortage (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deutsche Bank Is Shopping For Acquisition or Alliance  Deutsche Bank, reeling from the recent defection of several top investment bankers to Credit Suisse First Boston, is looking to buy an American investment firm or to establish a significant alliance with one.    The chairman of Germany's biggest bank said he did not yet have a specific target. Industry executives have mentioned J. P. Morgan, Paine Webber and Hambrecht & Quist as possible partners. [Page D2.]

headline: Moscow Journal; For the Rolling Stones' Fans, Satisfaction at Last
abstract: 50,000 fans jam Luzhniki stadium in Moscow to see Rolling Stones in their first concert in Russia; rock music was banned in Russia under Communists; Mick Jagger photo (M)

headline: 3 Options for Russia: Populist Path Seems Most Likely but Dangerous
abstract: Prominent Western economists are considering three possible courses of action for Russia: take populist path of tightening direct control over economy, strike deal with International Monetary Fund or, most radically, link nation's finances to strong foreign currency like dollar; graph; photos (M)

headline: LASALLE PARTNERS TO BUY BUSINESSES FROM LEND LEASE
abstract: LaSalle Partners Inc agrees to acquire real estate management-services unit and United States retail-property management business of Lend Lease Corp of Australia for $180 million, plus additional payments of up to $77.5 million (S)

headline: Software Operation Is Sold
abstract: Astea International, a maker of customer-management software, agreed today to sell its Bendata Inc. help-desk software unit to Ixchange Technology Holdings Ltd. of South Africa for more than $43 million in cash and assumed debt. Astea, based in Horsham, Pa. said it would use proceeds from the sale to expand its sales and marketing force and project-management service. Bendata is based in Colorado Springs.

headline: Some Soothing Words For Computer-Phobic
abstract: Dr Barbara Probert and Dr Edward Delgado-Romero of University of Florida offer simple steps for people overwhelmed by anxiety when faced with computer keyboard (S)

headline: Defying Warnings, Serbs Press Attacks on Kosovo Albanians
abstract: Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, scoffing at warnings that West might use force to end fighting in Kosovo, presses ahead with tank and artillery offensive; chases some 10,000 ethnic Albanian civilians into hills and sets fire to many of their homes; new refugees spend night in cold and damp with no shelter and little food; map; photo (M)

headline: Philippine Airlines Ends Operations
abstract: Last-ditch attempt to save Asia's oldest airline fails after management and unions of Philippine Airlines are unable to reach agreement on rescue plan for ailing carrier; company says it will file for liquidation soon (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: British Petroleum to Buy Amoco in $48.2 Billion Deal  British Petroleum announced that it would acquire Amoco, the big oil company, for $48.2 billion in stock. The deal is the largest oil industry merger ever, as well as the largest foreign takeover of an American company.    If approved by regulators and shareholders of both companies, BP Amoco, as the company is to be known, will be the world's third-largest multinational oil company in terms of net income after Exxon and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies. [Page A1.]

headline: Staff Writer Named Editor At New Yorker
abstract: David Remnick, Pulitzer Prize-winning author who has spent last six years writing for The New Yorker, is named fifth editor of magazine; he replaces Tina Brown, who resigned; photo (M)

headline: Alcatel Considers Plan To Buy Back Shares
abstract: Alcatel SA weighs significant share buyback in wake of sharp stock price drop spurred by warning that it will not meet earnings forecasts (S)

headline: For 2 Teen-Age Sisters, Final Trip to Kenya Village
abstract: Gloria and Caroline Mutuiri, teen-age sisters who died in US Embassy bombing in Nairobi, Kenya, are buried in Kathera cemetery; map; photo (M)

headline: Possible Benign Use Is Seen for Chemical At Factory in Sudan
abstract: Organization for Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, international agency overseeing treaty that bars chemical weapons, says chemical that US cited to justify its missile attacks on Sudanese factory can be used for commercial products; US has insisted that chemical found outside plant could only mean that plant was intended to make nerve agent VX; treaty group concedes that it is not aware of any commercial product on market that contains chemical, known as Empta; defense and intelligence officials say they still believe there is no other explanation for presence of Empta in soil sample secretly collected outside factory several months ago; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls for first time in four days after central bank says recent efforts to revive growth will have little effect; dollar rises to 140.40 yen from 138.88 in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: Operating Profit Rises For Cadbury Schweppes
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes PLC says pretax profit from continuing operations rose 7.6 percent in first half of 1998; profit rose to 254 million pounds, or $417 million, in six months ended June 20, from 236 million pounds in year-earlier period; graph (S)

headline: Bayer Profit Fell 14% in Second Quarter
abstract: Bayer AG says second-quarter profits fell unexpected 13.9 percent; net income fell to 870 million marks ($486 million) from 1.01 billion a year earlier; sales fell 1 percent, to 14.05 billion marks (S)

headline: Are Britain's Covert Operatives Messing Up? Don't Even Ask
abstract: British Government obtains injunction barring newspapers and television news programs from publishing embarrassing allegations about inner workings of nation's security services that were made by disgruntled former agent, David Shayler; he is being held in Paris prison, while he fights Britain's efforts to extradite him (M)

headline: Ulster Buries Bomb Victims, Fearful for Peace Accord
abstract: Funerals are held in Omagh, Northern Ireland, for 16 victims of Aug 15 car bomb; mourners heap scorn on Republican die-hards responsible for violence; revulsion is only increased by news that splinter group, Real IRA, has suddenly called cease-fire after earlier admitting responsibility for blast; some funerals are attended by Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein leader, and David Trimble, Protestant Unionist leader; photo (M)

headline: I.M.F. Lets Its Rule on Full Repayment Slip
abstract: International Monetary Fund, pummeled by Asia and now Russia, is gradually softening its policies, becoming more tolerant of arrangements it would have rejected year ago and even allowing some Asian debtors not to repay all they owe to foreign banks; Russia is pushing this process a step further with its announcement that $40 billion in debt, scheduled for repayment over 18 months, will be 'stretched out' and paid over three to five years; probable devaluations of ruble over so long a period raises odds that foreign lenders, which include Chase Manhattan and Bank of America, will not be fully repaid in dollars (M)

headline: Media Talk; An HBO Advertisement Makes the Front Page
abstract: New York Post runs advertisement for The Rat Pack, HBO movie, on front pages of some 3,000 specially printed editions sent to New York tastemakers; says papers were not distributed to public or sold at newsstands; photo (S)

headline: As Ruble Withers, Russians Survive on Barter
abstract: Russian companies, which have developed special brand of cashless capitalism, are counting more than ever on barter to survive in face of tumbling ruble; barter, ridiculed by Western economists, reflects gritty termination to get by without bank credits and investment capital; increasingly involves schemes in which goods are shipped across nation in complex swaps that can involve dozen or more companies; map; diagram; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.54   5.46        3-month T-bills   4.95   4.96   4.96        6-month T-bills   5.04   5.01   5.07        10-yr. T-infl.   3.75   3.76   3.69        10-yr. T-note   5.41   5.38   6.29        30-yr. T-bond   5.60   5.57   6.58        Telephone bd.   7.06   7.03   7.65        Municipal bds.   5.21   5.21   5.57          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge   Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: LAIDLAW IS PLANNING TO DISMISS 700 EMPLOYEES
abstract: Laidlaw Inc to dismiss 700 employees of its American Medical Response Inc unit, about 3 percent of staff, by end of Aug to cut costs (S)

headline: Computing an Options Grant
abstract: Lisa Sanders, a Computer Associates shareholder, is suing to force its top executives, Charles B Wang, Sanjay Kumar and Russell M Artzt, to return 9.5 million of 20.25 million company shares they got in May; says stock option plan approved in 1995 had no provision to adjust for stock splits (S)

headline: NOVACARE CONSIDERS SPINNING OFF AT LEAST ONE BUSINESS
abstract: Novacare Inc hires Salomon Smith Barney and Wasserstein Perella & Co to look at spinning off one or more of its businesses (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DUNDEE REALTY CORP.,  Toronto, plans to sell all of its residential revenue properties and all of its commercial revenue properties in the United States and to close its property office in Dallas by the end of next month.

headline: Start-Ups Are Catching Fire in Poland
abstract: Jane Perlez reports on explosion of start-up companies in Poland following collapse of Communism; Poland may well go down as mecca for small business at end of 20th century; official statistics show that about two million small businesses have been registered in last eight years, by far the largest number for any nation that was once behind Iron Curtain; they range from laundromats to retail stores, from car-part manufacturers to language schools, from headhunters to public relations firms; photo (M) (Special section on entrepreneurship) (M)

headline: Most Borrowers in U.S. Can Expect to Benefit
abstract: Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rates for first time since January 1996 should translate into lower borrowing rates on many consumers loans and keep mortgage rates for home purchases and refinancings below 7 percent at least through end of the year (M)

headline: The Neighborhood Business; Geocities' Cyberworld is Vibrant, but Can It Make Money?
abstract: Geocities is service that gives people free space to publish their own pages on World Wide Web; service is attracting impressive and growing number of members and visitors, yet as it moves toward public stock offering, it is struggling to formulate credible image as viable business; as of June, more than two million members created personal Web sites consisting of more than 15 million pages about nearly every imaginable topic; but advertisers are wary of placing their product next to chat that is likely as not to turn sexual, and investment bankers promoting initial public offering hope investors will not be discouraged by financial statements; giving megaphone to millions of people involves risks and David Bohnett, founder of Geocities, says playing censor in chief for two million people weighs heavily on him; photo; charts (M)

headline: Appalachian Trail Sites Offer Virtual Walks on Wild Side
abstract: World Wide Web sites cater to Appalachian Trail hikers, both day hikers and 'through hikers' attempting to walk entire 2,160 miles; some 17,000 visitors checked into site charting progress of through hiker Brian Vaughan, whose mother, Valerie McKay, maintained site; photo (M)

headline: Health Care Deal Under Inquiry
abstract: United Healthcare Corp says Federal antitrust enforcers are seeking information about company's proposed $6.23 billion acquisition of Humana Inc, deal that would create one of largest US managed health care companies; Justice Department has 20 days to determine whether to seek to block or approve transaction or seek divestitures (S)

headline: A Subdued Anniversary at a Place Dedicated to Diana
abstract: Britons have shed some of saintly adulation of Diana, Princess of Wales, in the year since her death; prepartions for anniversary have been muted, reflecting what some newspapers call 'Diana fatigue,' even as they, like most television stations, fill columns and air time with memorials to her; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Raids Provoke Fury in Muslim World
abstract: In mosques, on street corners and from some govt ministries, many Muslims voice fury over American missile strikes in Afghanistan and Sudan and predict that assault would beget more violence (M)

headline: INTRAWEST ACQUIRES SANDESTIN RESORTS FOR $130 MILLION
abstract: Intrawest Corp purchases Sandestin Resorts hotel and conference site in Florida for about $130 million from Sime Darby of Malaysia (S)

headline: Big Award Set for Ex-Stratton Investor
abstract: Former brokers at Stratton Oakmont Inc. were ordered today to pay an Indiana retiree $13.1 million, including $10.5 million in punitive damages, in the largest investor arbitration award ever.    The National Association of Securities Dealers' arbitration panel found that Daniel Porush, the former chief executive of the penny-stock firm, now defunct, and three brokers were liable for fraud, theft and unauthorized trades.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline falls 2.6 percent to 4 1/2-year low after release of weekly industry report that shows slowing demand and rising refinery output; August contract falls 1.11 cents a gallon, to 41.11 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: 7 to Settle Charges in Insider Trading Case
abstract: Dr Alejandro C Zaffaroni, founder of Affymax NV, and six of his friends and family members agree to pay $1.85 million to settle charges they traded company shares based on inside knowledge that Glaxo PLC was negotiating to buy Affymax; Securities and Exchange Commission says seven people made illegal profits from Affymax securities they bought shortly before Glaxo announced its $485 million tender offer for Affymax in January 1995; Glaxo, now known as Glaxo Wellcome PLC, completed its acquisition of Affymax in March 1995 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen ends little changed on concerns about Japan's steps on economy; graphs; table (S)

headline: Earnings at Airtouch More Than Double
abstract: Airtouch Communications says net income in second quarter was $147 million, up from pro-forma profit of $71 million a year earlier; revenue increased to $1.35 billion from $901 million (S)

headline: Island Nation Loses a Bridge As Philippine Airlines Fails
abstract: Demise of Philippine Airlines in short run could raise acute transportation problems for 76 million people of island nation who relied on airline to hop from island to island; in long run, Governemnt officials and airline analysts say collapse will be remembered more as blow to national pride--and to prestige of Pres Joseph Estrada, for whom labor dispute was major test of leadership; photo (M)

headline: Serbian Troops Step Up Terror in Kosovo
abstract: Serbian policemen backed by Yugoslav Army soldiers are stepping up their terror against ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo, driving tens of thousands of them from their homes and shelling, looting and burning their villages; relief agencies estimate that up to 200,000 civilians have fled their homes since Government began military offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels on July 19; map; photo (M)

headline: EMI Shares Drop 15% On Weak Profit Outlook
abstract: EMI Group PLC's shares fall 15 percent to their lowest level in six years after company warns that problems in its major markets will push first-half operating profit down about 20 percent; graph (S)

headline: GIANT INDUSTRIES CANCELS APRIL AGREEMENT TO BUY HOLLY
abstract: Holly Corp says Giant Industries canceled its agreement to acquire Holly for $168 million because of antitrust concerns from Federal Trade Commission (S)

headline: U.N. Council Renews Sanctions After Iraq Expresses Defiance
abstract: UN Security Council votes unanimously to renew economic sanctions against Iraq for refusal to obey resolution requiring full access for arms inspectors; move follows Iraq's rejection of plea by Richard Butler, chief arms inspector, to resume cooperation; US Amb Bill Richardson warns sanctions may never be lifted (S)

headline: With Misgivings, Austria Guides Europe to East
abstract: VIENNA  For Austria, enlarging the European Union to the east  the task for which it assumed oversight when it took over the EU presidency this week  is no abstraction.

headline: Chase and Citicorp Lead Strong Earnings at Banks
abstract: Chase Manhattan and Citicorp report surprisingly high second-quarter earnings; Banc One Corp and Wells Fargo & Co also beat Wall Street analysts' estimates; Chase says earnings rose 15.7 percent; earnings rose to $1.07 billion from $925 million in year-earlier quarter; noninterest revenue increased 27 percent, to $2.73 billion, as investment banking revenue rose to $438 million; Citicorp says earnings rose 7.1 percent, to $1.10 billion from $1.02 billion a year earlier; noninterest revenue increased 31 percent, to $3.21 billion; other revenue increased 67 percent, to $791 million; Banc One says earnings rose to $614.6 million from $377.5 million; net income was $487 million; net interest income fell 1.7 percent, to $1.4 billion; Wells Fargo & Co says earnings rose 48 percent; earnings were $337 million, up from $228 million a year earlier; chart (M)

headline: By Appealing to Rebels, U.N. Chief Makes Peace With Mexico
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan defuses diplomatic crisis with Mexican Govt during visit to Mexico City by calling on Zapatista rebels to return to negotiating table to resolve smoldering conflict in state of Chiapas; repeatedly praises Pres Ernesto Zedillo's strategy in four-year-old face-off between Govt and ragtag guerrilla army with broad base of support in Indian villages (M)

headline: Cisco Systems Plans National TV Campaign
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc will introduce its first national television advertising campaign, created by Goldberg Moser O'Neill (S)

headline: AMP Steps Up Efforts to Fend Off Allied Signal Takeover
abstract: AMP Inc, fighting hostile takeover bid of $44.50 a share from Allied Signal Inc, anounces plan to buy back as many as 30 million shares of its common stock for $55 a shareholders; AMP's counteroffer is intended to thwart Allied Signal's $9.7 billion offfer for entire company (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Volatile Trading With Less Intervention
abstract: Market Place column on whether there will be intervention if another selloff in stocks occurs on Aug 5; says trading will not be halted, as it was last Oct 27, and financial exchanges will do little to intervene in trading of shares unless selling reaches epic proportions for single session, meaning drop of 10 percent or more in Dow Jones industrial average; chart lists biggest drops in Dow since Oct 1987 (M)

headline: A new Leo Burnett acquisition will bestow on the agency company that T-word cachet.
abstract: Leo Burnett Co will join rival ad agencies in rapidly growing field of business-to-business technology marketing by acquiring TFA Communications LLC (M)

headline: Russia to Pump Huge Ruble Reserve Into Banks
abstract: Russia's central bank, seeking to restart stalled financial activity, will let insolvent banks use about $1.65 billion in ruble reserves; is gambling that errant banks will use reserves to settle delinquent bills, not buy dollars, move that would further drive down value of ruble; plans to print more rubles to replenish reserve; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Muted Pressure on Iraq
abstract: The United States urged United Nations arms inspectors to avoid a confrontation with Iraq this month, officials say. Page A5.

headline: Site-Seeing: Medical Information; Sorting Health Facts From Fiction on Line
abstract: Among the more trustworthy sources of health information on World Wide Web are sites maintained by Federal Department of Health and Human Services and medical journals; Dr Tom Ferguson, who publishes a newsletter about on-line health information, says real value of Internet is not generic information found on most sites but the support groups, chat rooms, news groups and mailing lists (M)

headline: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; A Well-Paced Music Tutorial
abstract: Matt Resnicoff assesses computer guitar course from G-Vox Interactive Music; photo (M)

headline: Suspect in Embassy Blasts Being Taken to Kenya
abstract: Law enforcement officials say that US investigators in Pakistan are preparing to fly to Kenya with man whom they identify as suspect in embassy bombings in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania; say investigators were sent to Pakistan to question several people who had been arrested there in connection with bombings; people under arrest are suspected of being associated with Osama bin Laden, Saudi-born businessman who has vowed to wage holy war against US (M)

headline: G.E. Introduces Faster Medical Scanner
abstract: General Electric Co introduces medical scanner that it says captures images of inner workings of patient's body in seconds, not minutes; GE expects to sell about 400 of new CT (for computerized tomography) scanners a year, at $1.25 million each (S)

headline: Father of Nairobi Bomb Victim Says Clinton Kept His Promise
abstract: Kenneth Hobson Sr, resident of Lamar, Mo, whose son, Army Sgt Kenneth R Hobson Jr, died in terrorist bombing of US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, says Pres Clinton fulfilled promise to victims' families with retaliatory missile strikes against suspected terrorist sites in Afghanistan and Sudan (M)

headline: Soccer Fans Find New Ways To Root for Faraway Favorites
abstract: Internet offers soccer fans growing access to news of teams they root for, no matter where in the world; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Won't Cower From Terrorism, Clinton Vows
abstract: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton on Monday mourned the victims of the bombings in Africa, vowed to "do whatever we can to bring the murderers to justice" and said the United States would "not be deterred by the threat of other action."

headline: Union Pacific Track-Sharing Order Is Lifted
abstract: Surface Transportation Board finds that rail congestion in Houston area has eased, and will not extend emergency orer to Union Pacific to share track in Texas with Texas Mexican Railway and Burlington Northern Santa Fe; order was issued last October in response to huge rail traffic jams, caused mostly by Union Pacific's difficulties in absorbing Southern Pacific after takeover; chairman Richard K Davidson comments (S)

headline: American Express Earnings Help Push Dow Past 9,000
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 90.88 points, to close at 9,028.24; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 6.47 points, to 1,147.27; Nasdaq composite index gains 2.27 points, to 1,933.26; graph; charts (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY    None    TUESDAY    Consumer Borrowing   July

headline: GUIDANT AGREES TO ACQUIRE INCONTROL FOR $135 MILLION
abstract: Guidant Corp to acquire Incontrol Inc for $135 million (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Gracious Concession On Internet 'Spam'
abstract: Hormel Foods Corp, whose brand name for luncheon meat, Spam, was turned into derisive label for unwanted junk E-mail, has stopped being defensive about Spam's pejorative use and decided to have fun with its brand name; its Spam Web site sells line of Spam-logo clothing and offers Spam history that starts with product's debut in 1937; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Evan Sirof was named to head a new public relations division at Marcomm Group Inc., Great Neck, N.Y., as public relations director. He had been marketing communications manager at Scitex Digital Video, Redwood City, Calif.

headline: With Favorable Loans, a Generation Rediscovers Second Homes
abstract: Growing number of American families, with more disposable income and decrease in mortgage rates, are buying vacation homes; photo; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Cummins Says Its Profit Was Flat for Quarter
abstract: Cummins Engine Co's second-quarter earnings are unchanged at $53 million; sales rise 17 percent, to $1.64 billion (S)

headline: BANKERS TRUST AGREES TO SELL INSURANCE BUSINESS
abstract: Bankers Trust Corp will sell its insurance-products business to RR Holding Co, unit of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co (S)

headline: New Jersey Bank Acquired
abstract: Commerce Bancorp Inc acquires Community First Banking Co of New Jersey for about $60 million (S)

headline: MEDPARTNERS EXPLORING THE POSSIBLE SALE OF UNIT
abstract: Medpartners Inc hires investment bank Bowles Hollowell Conner & Co to assist in exploring possible sale of its Government Services unit (S)

headline: STOCK OF HARVEY ENTERTAINMENT RISES AS IT WEIGHS SALE
abstract: Stock of merchandising and film concern Harvey Entertainment Co jumps 24 percent after company says it has hired financial adviser to explore ways to raise cash or increase revenues (S)

headline: New Peace Diplomacy Gets Mostly Shrugs in Israel
abstract: There are neither cheers nor boos in Israel following Pres Clinton's intervention in stalemated peace talks--indication that few believe there has been diplomatic breakthrough worth celebrating or condemning; many Israelis debate Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's intentions and political repercussions for him if peace agreement is reached during next round of three-way talks (M)

headline: Stock Buyback for Payless
abstract: Payless Shoesource Inc will buy back up to $150 million of its stock (S)

headline: Good Sound, Cheap
abstract: Douglas Milburn letter suggests patching computer into stereo system to feed computer sound through those speakers (July 30 article)

headline: Their Quiet Lives, Rendered Stark and Bold by the Manner of Their Deaths
abstract: Profile of Mary Louise Martin, one of 12 Americans to die in bombing of US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOOL AGREES TO ADD POLYHEDRON HOLDINGS
abstract: The American Tool Companies of Hoffman Estates, Ill., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Polyhedron Holdings P.L.C., a British machine tool maker, for $:33 million ($53.2 million) in cash. American Tool, which is closely held and 44.9 percent owned by the Newell Company, said it would pay Polyhedron 88 pence a share. The acquisition, recommended by the Polyhedron board, gives American Tool a presence in Britain, which it sees as one of its most important markets, and expands Polyhedron's business in the United States. Polyhedron's shares rose 19 pence, or 29 percent, to 85 pence.

headline: South Korea's President to Free Even the Unrepentant Political Prisoners
abstract: Pres Kim Dae Jung orders release of a large number of South Korea's political prisoners without requiring them to renounce their ideological views; amnesty reportedly includes Woo Yong Gak, believed to be world's longest-serving political prisoner, who has spent almost 40 years in solitary confinement (M)

headline: 40 Years of Opera House Plans, but Still No Music
abstract: Beijing Journal on Government's long-delayed plans to build world-class opera house on empty lot across from Great Hall of the People; photo; plan was first announced 40 years ago, but officials insist this time they have $400-million budget, and work will be completed by 2002 (S)

headline: Market Place; Learning to Live With a Technology Correction
abstract: Outlook for investing in technology stocks discussed in light of recent market correction; analysts are urging portfolio adjustments to prepare for next up cycle; graph of drop in Nasdaq composite index; table of technology stocks that have fallen (M)

headline: Carrefour to Buy Rest of Comptoirs
abstract: Carrefour SA, which already owns 23 percent of Comptoirs Modernes, agrees to buy rest of company for cash and stock totaling maximum of 14 billion francs ($2.38 billion) and assume about 1 billion francs in debt; reports first-half profit rose 27 percent, to 1.79 billion francs ($304 million), from 1.41 billion francs in 1997 period (S)

headline: Compressed Data; The Gartner Group Adopts An Hourglass as Its Symbol
abstract: Gartner Group, computer consulting concern, will make its debut on New York Stock Exchange; company, which has been listed on Nasdaq, is advising some of world's biggest corporations on how to gird their computers for millennium; photo (S)

headline: NATO Threat to Intervene in Kosovo Fades as Rebels Succeed
abstract: Already remote prospect of NATO military intervention in Kosovo Province of Serbia quickly fades as Serbian Government eases crackdown and rebels expand their guerrilla campaign; Pentagon officials say that alliance has not ruled out use of force, but that for now succcess of ethnic Albanian insurgents has significantly undercut such possibility; maps (M)

headline: Blair Sheds a New Layer of Old Labor
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, in his keynote address to Labor Party convention, says people should not lose their nerve as Government confronts 'tough decisions' on economy, welfare and productivity in public sector; party that Blair calls New Labor is ending 70-year-old tradition of gathering in Blackpool; years to come will find delegates meeting in more refined places like Brighton and Bournemouth; map (M)

headline: Cambodia: A New Try
abstract: News analysis: Cambodian royalist leader Prince Norodom Ranariddh, after swearing he would not, is set to join his longtime antagonist, Hun Sen, in a Parliament created by disputed election nearly two months ago; uneasy coalition may achieve some stability because Hun Sen holds lion's share of power; challenge to election results spearheaded by third-party candidate Sam Rainsy received little backing from foreign governments overseeing voting, but protests appeared to tap into deep strain of popular discontent, as residents briefly rose in defiance to end violence and power struggles that have ravaged their country for decades (M)

headline: Financial Post to Become Part of a New Canadian Daily
abstract: Newspaper owner Conrad M Black says he is buying The Financial Post and will use Toronto-based paper as financial section of his planned new national daily newspaper; Post will give Black immediate national distribution network, experienced business staff and circulation base of about 100,000 across Canada for his new newspaper, which is scheduled to make its debut in early October; Southam Inc, subsidiary of Black's Hollinger International, takes control of Sun Media's 80 percent stake in The Post; remaining 20 percent will continue to be held by Pearson PLC of London; Sun Media gets four Southern dailies in Southern Ontario for about $100 million (M)

headline: Doonesbury's Dow
New U.N. Push to Urge Iraq To Cooperate With Inspectors
abstract: Diplomats from Security Council member countries say that countries friendly to Iraq are being asked to try to persuade Government of Pres Saddam Hussein to cooperate with arms inspectors again in return for a new hearing at United Nations (M)

headline: Can the Internet Cure the Common Cold?
abstract: World Wide Web contains over 10,000 sites with medical information, whether from experts, amateurs or quacks; recent survey found that nearly two-thirds of people using the Web have sought medical information and referrals; the information on the Web can better equip people for their interaction with their doctors and even save lives, but it can also waste a doctor's time, dash a patient's hopes and put a life in danger; photo (M)

headline: Japan's Corruption Fighter Is Shunted Aside
abstract: Katsuhiko Kumazaki, prosecutor who led investigation into scandals in Japan involving expensive free entertainment paid for by businessmen who wanted bureaucrats' favor, was transferred in June to relatively remote coastal city, and investigation seems to have fizzled out; apparent collapse of investigation underscores resiliency of Japan's traditional way of governing (M)

headline: Titan to Buy 2 Companies
abstract: Titan Corp, satellite-communications and information-technology company, will acquire closely held Visicom Inc and Delfin Systems Inc for about $47.5 million in stock to expand its computer business (S)

headline: College Rankings Rankle
abstract: Linda Boyd letter on Aug 27 article notes that while Stanford University complains that students should not base their college choice on rankings in US News & World Report, colleges continue to accept students based on grade-point averages, SAT scores and class rankings

headline: Mutual Fund Investors Seek Safer Havens
abstract: Individual investors who formerly bought stocks whenever market took tumble appear to be weakening under weight of monthlong decline in equity prices; individuals have been pouring more new cash into safe haven of money market funds than into any other investment category, and pulling money out of stocks; August is shaping up as weakest month for new purchases of equity mutual funds in several years; there are signs that skittishness has spread to investors in 401(k) and similar retirement plans, who typically are less likely to make quick shifts from one asset class to another; investors' resolve has been weakened by slow and steady decline of stock prices since market indexes hit new highs in late July; in addition, even as Dow Jones industrial average still shows gains for year, growing number of mutual funds, which buy stocks smaller than those in market indexes, have lost money since beginning of year; graphs (M)

headline: International Briefs; ABB Posts 15% Rise In 2d-Quarter Profit
abstract: ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd says second-quarter profit rose 15 percent; net income rose to $380 million from $331 million (S)

headline: Albright Hugs Wary Tokyo Smarting From Beijing Trip
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright stops in Tokyo on her return from China, reassuring the Japanese that US values its ties with them as much as ever and prodding Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to take further steps to bolster Japanese economy; many Japanese are hurt that Pres Clinton would spend nine days in China without even a brief visit to Japan; Japanese scholars have often noted that US has historically tilted either toward Japan or China but has difficulty being friendly simultaneously with both (M)

headline: The Virgin Group tries to appeal to a downtown crowd with a new store and $1 million campaign.
abstract: Virgin Entertainment Group to open its second Manhattan music megastore, 14th Street and Broadway; plans advertising drive of almost $1 million stressing store's downtown site; Virgin Group chief executive Richard Branson comments, phone interview; photo (M)

headline: I.R.A. Cannot Guarantee Disarmament, Adams Says
abstract: Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams says he cannot guarantee Irish Republic Army will agree to disarm during talks in new Northern Ireland Assembly; hard-line stand contrasts with his remarks on eve of Pres Clinton's visit, when he stressed that sectarian warfare is thing of past; Protestant leader David Trimble is unusually positive about outlook for eventual IRA disarmament, BBC interview (M)

headline: Latin America Tells I.M.F. Economies Are Sound
abstract: Officials from nine Latin American nations say their economies are basically sound and should not be penalized indiscriminately by investors panicky over financial turmoil in Asia and Russia; officials, in Washington for two-day meeting with International Monetary Fund, say they are not seeking any international financial help, and that they are taking difficult steps needed to weather storm that is threatening to batter much of world; Clinton Administration praises progress of many Latin American countries; officials from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela attend meeting (M)

headline: Philatelic Diplomacy: Palestinians Join Collectors' List
abstract: Scott Publishing Co's newest catalogue of worldwide stamps will include stamps issued by Palestinian Authority; says international mail centers in Egypt and Jordan routinely process material bearing Palestinian Authority stamps and and postal officials in other countries have not challenged their use; Scott's move raises Palestinian stamps from level of local labels, known as cinderellas, to collectibles, thus increasing their value to dealers; photo (M)

headline: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja
abstract: Article on drug violence in Santa Catarina and neighboring towns in Baja California, Mexico, notes that 18 members of two Mexican Indian families were recently killed in drug-related massacre in El Sauzal; map; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodities column; copper prices decline amid broad selloff in commodities; graphs

headline: Tellabs and Ciena Cut Value Of Stock-Swap Acquisition
abstract: Tellabs Inc, set to acquire Ciena Corp in stock swap, cuts purchase price by 20 percent, to $4.74 billion; investors say price is still too high (S)0

headline: Places to Check Out the Pills for Your Ills
abstract: Array of on-line drug information resources helps medical professionals and consumers deal with avalanche of new drugs; sampling; photo (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Down Slightly on Big Board
abstract: Open positions of short sales on New York Stock Exchange declined slightly last month, to 44.1 billion shares on Aug 14; decrease of 28.7 million shares in open short positions, less than 1 percent, was first monthly decline since January; on American Stock Exchange, short interest rose 3.2 percent, to 200.5 million shares, a new monthly record; charts (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Mostly Dip as Financial Turmoil Eases
abstract: Prices of most Treasury securities slip slightly, as stock markets worldwide stabilize and dollar weakens in currency trading, lessening flight into Government securities; 30-year Treasury bond rises 3/32, to price of 102 17/32; yield slips to 5.33 percent from 5.34 percent; graphs (M)

headline: Clinton Testimony for Sale (Real Cheap) on DVD
abstract: Netflix is selling Pres Clinton's four-hour grand-jury testimony on DVD disk; Clinton's videotaped testimony has been digitized and divided into 99 chapters, allowing DVD owners to search for specific educational highlights (S)

headline: William Piel Jr., 88, Ex-Corporate Lawyer
abstract: William Piel Jr, leading corporate lawyer of his time, dies at age 88 (M)

headline: German Insurer Sells Unit to French Company
abstract: AMB Aachener und Munchener Beteiligungs AG, Germany's third-largest insurer, will sell its Dutch unit, Rodutch Holdings BV, to Assurances Generales de France for 1.35 billion marks ($754 million) (S)

headline: Armani's Great Escape; Prada's Active-Wear Sails Ahead
abstract: MILAN  What's he thinking about, this gray-suited guy off to work? One look at his chest, veiled in a shirt so sheer it looks like an ocean wave, and you know he's dreaming of a summer holiday.

headline: Roland Rowland Dies at 80; Outspoken British Tycoon
abstract: Roland (Tiny) Rowland, British business tycoon dies at age 80; photo (M)

headline: Chic by H.I.S. Names Spike DDB
abstract: Chic by HIS Inc says it named Spike DDB to handle its integrated marketing account; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Ex-South Africa Leader Guilty of Contempt for Refusing to Testify Before Truth Panel
abstract: South African court finds former Pres P W Botha guilty of contempt for repeatedly refusing to testify before country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission about his role in atrocities committed under his rule in apartheid era; magistrate calls Botha's conduct 'unlawful' and 'without remorse'; photo (M)

headline: Browsing in a Herd
abstract: Raj Merchant letter on Sept 17 article on browsing Internet with other people (S)

headline: Radio Wars
abstract: Letter from Lawrence Lipkin comments on Aug 20 article on Federal Communications Commission effort to shut down microradio stations (S)

headline: Communist Hong Kong Has Its First Birthday
abstract: Hong Kong marks first anniversary of its return to China with restrained celebration dampened by its economic woes; Pres Jiang Zemin expresses satisfaction with Hong Kong's first year as semiautonomous city; Hong Kong's chief exective, Tung Chee-hwa, calls for courage to overcome difficulties; police use light hand in dealing with two demonstrations; photo (M)

headline: Best Part of Accuweather Site Is Its Forecasting Accuracy
abstract: Accuweather web site (www.accuweather.com) evaluated; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Prices of cotton rise on expectations that drought in Texas will reduce output; floods in China, big cotton producer, also helps prices; December cotton rises 1.70 cents, to 72.88 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Israel and Palestinians Seem Stuck After Flurry of Talks
abstract: There has been no tangible movement on Israeli-Palestinian front but fear is growing that it could stay that way till fall; Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel has appealed to Americans to return and help break logjam; but Washington shows no eagerness to rush back to assist Israelis after eight months of fruitless efforts to extract decision from Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; there is only one week left to resume negotiations before Israeli Parliament's summer recess, followed by series of Jewish holidays and municipal elections, all of which will impose new restaints on talks for next three months (M)

headline: With Results Faltering At E.D.S., Chief Resigns
abstract: Lester M Alberthal Jr, under pressure from board members and shareholders to turn faltering Electronic Data Systems around, resigns as chairman and chief executive; board plans to recruit outsider to lead company (M)

headline: Stock and Bond Prices Drop In Russia as Investors Bolt
abstract: Stock and bond prices plunge in Russia, jarring hopes that Government can avert depletion of its finances and meltdown of banking system; capping week of ominous declines, blue chip stocks now have lost almost a quarter of their value and demand for Russian bonds seems to have vanished; Central Bank and aides to pres Boris N Yeltsin dismiss suggestion by financier George Soros that the ruble should be devalued, move that would effectively reduce nation's debt, but inflate prices; photo (M)

headline: Air France Revenue Fell in Latest Quarter
abstract: Air France says revenue fell 4.7 percent, to 13.85 billion francs ($2.47 billion), in first quarter ended June 30 (S)

headline: Media Talk; New Technology Raises Questions About Rights
abstract: Technology has potential to keep authors in print forever, but there is hitch: those who want to regain rights to their out-of-print titles may be unable to do so; under current contracts, 'in print' means physically stored in warehouse, not digitally stored on disk (S)

headline: Colombian Rebels Broaden Offensive With Attacks on Symbols of U.S. War Against Coca
abstract: As leftist rebels occupied Albert Schweitzer Hospital in the city of Miraflores 10 days ago, using it as a vantage point to attack a military base across the street, explosions and gunfire rained over the  corrugated-tin roof of the hospital. A plane dropped bombs in the distance. Outside teen-agers fell dead and wounded.     ''How do you like our party?'' a witness recalled a guerrilla as having said.

headline: Avoiding Some Bumps Along the Sector Road
abstract: Article on continuing volatility of sector mutual funds, which concentrate holdings in particular industries; photo (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (M)

headline: Procter & Gamble to Revamp Products
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co, world's No. 2 maker of consumer goods, says it will reorganize along product lines, rather than geographic regions, to improve sales and speed introduction of new products; John Pepper Jr, chairman, has pledged to double company's sales in decade; he says he is making change because growth has been sluggish (M)

headline: Rain in Tunis? On Web, a World of Weather
abstract: Up-to-date information about the weather--including national overview, articles on places where weather is making news, local forecasts, and more detailed information for those who need it--is available on variety of World Wide Web sites; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.51   5.62        3-month T-bills   4.93   4.92   5.10        6-month T-bills   4.92   4.94   5.14        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.80   3.58        10-yr. T-note   5.23   5.28   6.36        30-yr. T-bond   5.43   5.46   6.64        Telephone bd.   7.07   7.05   7.70        Municipal bds.   5.15   5.16   5.56          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: Compressed Data; House E-Mail Effort Raises Censorship Issue
abstract: House subcommittee has approved bill to control junk E-mail, known as spam, by requiring senders of unsolicited marketing material to identify selves in body of message; supporters of Senate-approved bill that would require identification in subject header, where it is easy to filter, hold House bill would force Internet service providers to weed through private communications; drawing (M)

headline: Stocks Ignore Global Fears, Rising Steeply
abstract: Wall Street shrugged off Russia's currency devaluation, another decline in Japanese stocks and saturation news coverage of President Clinton's grand jury testimony yesterday, pushing major market indexes higher and helping the Dow Jones industrial average post its largest one-day gain in two months.    Many investors -- apparently deciding that they had absorbed all the bad news they could handle and that all those negatives were reflected in current share prices -- dived back into stocks, pushing the Dow up 149.85 points, or 1.78 percent. The blue-chip index, led by gains in Merck, Eastman Kodak and American Express, closed at 8,574.85.

headline: Economic Detour in Brazil; Global Crisis Pushes Car Makers Into the Slow Lane
abstract: Brazilian car industry is shutting factories and idling workers as economic crisis hits Latin America; Brazil has been forced to raise interest rates twice in last year to protect currency against attacks by global investors; consumers are reluctant to borrow for big purchases, forcing auto makers in Brazil to cut production; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: ELBIT MEDICAL IMAGING IS SELLING PIECES OF BUSINESS
abstract: Elbit Medical Imaging Ltd of Israel will sell pieces of its medical diagnostic imaging business to Picker International Inc, unit of General Electric Co PLC of Britain, and General Electric Co, for about $375 million in cash; two General Electrics are not related (S)

headline: Spanish Leaders Wary of Basque Rebels' Cease-Fire Declaration
abstract: Spain's conservative Government and Socialist opposition both react cautiously to first 'indefinite' cease-fire ever announced by Basque guerrilla group, ETA, in its 30-year battle for independent homeland; three smaller Basque nationalist parties express optimism for peace; Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar comments from Lima, Peru (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of July 5 quarterly variable-annuity tables in special Mutual Funds Report, which misstated figures for Regatta Gold subaccounts; chart (S)

headline: Some Think Time Is Right for a Market-Calming Rate Cut
abstract: Analysts predict that 12 percent decline in Dow Jones industrial index in last week will help force Federal Reserve to lower its benchmark short-term interest rate soon; long-term interest rates are well below Fed's 5.5 percent target for short-term rates; recent rapid decline in interest rates should provide some offset to drag from Asia, as lower rates spur housing industry; plunge in 10-year note, which is benchmark for mortgage rates, should mean that already low mortgage rates drop further; John Lipsky, economist, says 19 percent plunge in Dow since July 17 is making consumers more cautious, cutting into their strong spending that has kept economy stronger than many forecasters had expected; says slowdown by consumer, plus painful drop in American exports to Asia, should slow economy to no growth in second half of year--further reason for Fed to ease rates; Fed's policy makers are next scheduled to meet on Sept 29; graph (M)

headline: 3 Luxury-Goods Makers Fall Victim to Asia
abstract: Clinton Administration plays down potential risks to financial system from Long-Term Capital Management LP's brush with collapse, but fund's fall raises questions in Congress about whether regulators can keep up with increasingly complexity and speed of the markets; Federal Reserve emphasizes that it has not put any taxpayer money into the deal (M)

headline: Merck Accepts F.T.C. Policy On Procedures at Care Unit
abstract: Merck & Co and its Merck-Medco Managed Care LLC Unit say they reached agreement with Federal Trade Commission that would bar Medco from discriminating against drugs made by Merck's competitors or exploiting private marketing information about other drug makers that Medco receives; Eli Lilly & Co and SmithKline Beecham PLC have similar agreements with commission (M)

headline: Semon Knudsen, 85, Dies; Was Prominent Auto Executive
abstract: Semon E Knudsen, former high-ranking executive at General Motors Corp, Ford Motor Co and White Motor Corp, dies at age of 85; photo (M)

headline: Summer of Trouble Still Doesn't Furrow Consumers' Brows
abstract: University of Michigan consumer sentiment index, barometer of influences on spending, slips to 100.1 in Sept, from 104.1 in Aug; indicates consumer confidence remains exceptionally high by past measures in face of global economic turmoil; graph showing Aug drop in housing starts (M)8

headline: A Bit of Barnum on Broadway; Livent Drew In a New Team Despite Juggling Expenses
abstract: Broadway producer Garth H Drabinsky, former head of Livent Inc, created brilliant but mythical setting for his business, a world where much of his famously lavish spending was visible on stage but somehow rarely hurt company's bottom line; one of Drabinsky's props was Livent's financial books, which are being investigated by securities regulators; company's new owners, Michael Ovitz and Roy Furman, say books appear to have been doctored; person close to Livent says Ovitz and Furman knew before they took control that the company had financial problems, though they did not anticipate what they call 'accounting irregularities'; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     None

headline: INVESTING IT; Good Yield Is Getting Much Harder to Find
abstract: Article on slowing to trickle of stock dividends as stocks continue record upward trend; describes ways to increase portfolio yields; graph; table (M)

headline: Met Life Seeking Advice on Stock Issue
abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co hires Goldman, Sachs to help it decide how to issue stock to investors; Met Life is one of many policyholder-owned, or mutual, life insurers that are planning to sell stock to investors (S)

headline: Television, Past and Future
abstract: Letter from David McKeel comments on Aug 20 article on high-definition television (S)

headline: REPUBLIC TO BUY 7 AUTO DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Republic Industries to buy seven closely held auto dealerships for undisclosed price as it begins expansion in Baltimore and Washington markets; Republic says cash purchases include Fox Automotive Group of Baltimore and Evans Motors in North Miami, Fla; Republic plans to open two Autonation USA used-car megastores in Baltimore and four in Washington area beginning in 1999 (S)

headline: ENTERPRISE FEDERAL STOCK SOARS ON MERGER AGREEMENT
abstract: Stock of Enterprise Federal Bancorp rises 37 percent after it agrees to be bought by Fifth Third Bancorp for $92.8 million (S)

headline: Third-Quarter Results Slide 2% at Disney
abstract: Walt Disney Co's fiscal third-quarter profit fall 2 percent, to $415 million; revenue rises 5 percent, to $5.25 billion (S)

headline: Correction: AIDS in Africa
abstract: Corrected maps depicting spread of AIDS in Africa

headline: CUMMINS SEES REVENUE DROP AND SIZABLE CHARGE
abstract: Cummins Engine Co expects third-quarter revenue to fall as much as 10 percent below second quarter's $1.64 billion because of weak demand in Asia (S)

headline: DRS TO ADD PARTS OF 2 RAYTHEON INFRARED BUSINESSES
abstract: DRS Technologies Inc will acquire parts of two businesses of Raytheon Co to make products that use infrared data to detect, identify and acquire targets (S)

headline: Year-2000 Solutions, Incubated in Israel
abstract: Article on Israeli solutions to Year 2000 computer bug that is being implemented worldwide by software engineers; several small Israeli technology companies are reaping financial rewards as their stocks prosper (M)

headline: Senate Votes to Lift Most Remaining India-Pakistan Penalties
abstract: Senate unanimously agrees to give Pres Clinton authority to temporarily waive most remaining economic sanctions on India and Pakistan; measure passes without dissent as amendment to agriculture appropriations bill; backers say it will give US greater flexibility in dealing with spread of nuclear arms in South Asia (M)

headline: Broadcast.com Faces Risks After Strong Initial Offering
abstract: Investors are overlooking current technical limitations of Internet broadcasting and pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into Broadcast.com Inc, company devoted to putting radio and television programs on Internet; on first day of trading, company's shares showed biggest initial jump in history of stock offerings in United States; Broadcast.com, formerly called Audionet, now offers transmissions of 345 radio stations, flickery images from 17 television stations, games from 350 sports teams and other talk and music programs; supporters say Broadcast.com is in prime position to capitalize on medium that could be far more compelling than text-based Internet is now, but analysts point out that risk in its plans are at least as great as opportunity; photos of founders, Mark Cuban and Todd Wagner (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Are Set
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Worries Over Japan and U.S. Send Treasury Prices Higher
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise; 30-year bond rises 12/32, to 107 31/32, to yield 5.57 percent; table (S)

headline: Yields on Municipal Bonds Make a Haven Look Better Than Ever
abstract: Article assesses narrowing of gap between municipal bond and Treasury securities yields; reasons bonds have become more attractive investment discussed;; graph (M)

headline: An Audio Extra for Sports Cards
abstract: New trading cards from sports memorabilia company Upper Deck look approximately like traditional cards, but contain compact disks featuring recorded interviews with athletes; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Chief's Plan For Sunbeam Is Scrapped
abstract: Sunbeam Corp head Jerry W Levin scraps reorganization plan begun by former chairman Albert J Dunlap; says Sunbeam will decentralize operations, keep open some plants scheduled for closing and retain some businesses it had planned to sell; scales back Dunlap's plan to cut work force by 40 percent; puts in place new management team, including Paul Shapiro as executive vice president and chief administrative officer and Bobby Jenkins as executive vice president and chief financial officer; Jenkins replaces Russell A Kersh, Dunlap aide; Sunbeam suspends quarterly dividend (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Donna Karan International attracts attention as a new chief executive shakes the fashion house up.
abstract: Market Place column on Donna Karan International one year after Donna Karan brought in John D Idol as chief executive after several wretched money-losing quarters with her at the helm; says company has attracted some contrarian investors; holds financial condition of fashion house has improved; company has announced that it narrowed its loss in second quarter by 57.1 percent from year earlier and that revenue rose to $124.9 million, from $111 million in 1997 (M)

headline: Managers in London Given Global Roles
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi promotes Alan Bishop, chairman of London office, to new position of international chairman; Omnicom Group names Michael Birkin, president for European and Asian operations at its Diversified Agency Services division, as president for division; Birkin succeeds Thomas L Harrison, who remains chairman and chief executive of division (S)

headline: Hoechst Announces Sale Of a Drug Subsidiary
abstract: Hoechst AG has sold its generic drug subsidiary, Cox Japan Ltd, to Germany's Hexal AG, effective retroactively to Aug 1; financial details undisclosed; Cox Japan will be renamed Nippon Hexal in January (S)

headline: MOBIL PLANS TO BUY BACK STOCK WORTH UP TO $500 MILLION
abstract: Mobil Corp will spend as much as $500 million to buy back shares of its stock (S)

headline: AMP Makes Bid For an Insurer
abstract: AMP Ltd bids $3 billion (Australian) (US $1.74 billion) in cash and stock for GIO Australia Holdings Ltd; GIO advises shareholders not to sell shares 'at present time' (S)

headline: Tool Orders Rose 16% During May
abstract: Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools rose 16 percent to estimated $795 million in May, compared with April; figure is from joint report from Assn for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Assn; estimated orders for machine tools for first five months of year totaled $3.7 billion, up 3 percent from corresponding period year earlier (S)

headline: At Magellan and Contrafund, Thinner Portfolios
abstract: Article on drastic paring down of number of stocks in two Fidelity Investments fund portfolios over past six months; graphs (M)

headline: T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth Fund
abstract: Profile of T Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth Fund, whose three-year annualized return stands at 29.8 percent; fund's lead manager Larry J Puglia comments; graphs; chart; photo (M)

headline: Falling Prices For Oil Impede Iraq Aid Plan
abstract: Drop in oil prices undermines program under which Iraq can sell its oil to raise money for urgent civilian need like food and medicine; other factors slow distribution of supplies, especially medicine (M)

headline: Nasdaq Tops 2,000 as Dow and S.& P. Gauges Also Hit Highs
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 93.72 points, or 1 percent, to close at record 9,328.19, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 9.18 points, to close at record 1,183.99; Nasdaq composite index closes at record 2,000.56, up 6.02 points; Nasdaq is up 27.4 percent this year, best performance of major indexes; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Influx of Soviet Immigrants and Demise of Defense Industry Fuels High-Tech Explosion : Israeli Entrepreneurs Strike It Rich on Internet
abstract: TEL AVIV  They are probably the youngest self-made millionaires in the Middle East: the four Israelis who founded Mirabilis Ltd., then sold the company and its ICQ software last month to America Online Inc. for $287 million.

headline: Nomura Securities May Face Rating Cut
abstract: Moody's Investors Service weighs cuting ratings of Nomura Securities Co, Japan's largest brokerage firm, on concerns about profitability (S)

headline: British and Irish Pledge to Hunt Ulster Car Bombers
abstract: Governments of Britain and Irish Republic vow to hunt down those responsible for car bomb which exploded in Omagh, Northern Ireland, killing 28 people and wounding more than 200; attack, deadliest in 29 years of sectarian violence, was expected in London and Dublin--sponsors of peace agreement that would give minority Roman Catholics more power and overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republican Army more influence in Northern affairs (M)

headline: U.S., Israel and Arafat Inch Toward Pact
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat reportedly agree on essentials of Israeli withdrawal from additional 13 percent of West Bank, which would leave Palestinians with political control over 40 percent of West Bank, including 98 percent of Palestinian population; flurry of negotiations in New York and meeting of both leaders with Pres Clinton at White House on September 28 failed to clinch final pact because of unresolved issues, such as parallel Palestinian actions to insure Israeli security and to fight terrorism; Netanyahu and US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright express optimism over completing deal in three-way talks in Washington in mid-October; Clinton says substantial progress was made during White House meeting, but warns much more needs to be done before comprehensive agreement can be reached; says both leaders have accepted invitation to meet, perhaps at Camp David; compromise accepted by Israel involves converting nearly quarter of 13 percent withdrawal--or three percent of West Bank--into nature preserve where Palestinians would not be allowed to live; land is uninhabited desert scrubland; photo (M)

headline: BAD TIMING ASIDE, CLINTON RESOLUTE ON YELTSIN SUMMIT
abstract: Pres Clinton will leave for Moscow summit on September 1, hoping to repair scandal-stained image, while offering political support, but no aid, for politically beleaguered President, Boris Yeltsin; with Clinton beset by Monica Lewinsky affair and sickly Yeltsin struggling to manage country in political and financial chaos, few expect substantial progress on any issues; despite bad timning and poor prospects, aides say it is America's interest that Clinton proceed (M)

headline: DVD Leads Race for TV Disks, but It Is Looking Over Its Shoulder
abstract: Nearly 600,000 DVD players, which play feature-length movie on CD-size digital disk, have been sold in little more than year, exceeding initial sales of compact disk players or VCRs; DVD is in race for survival, seeking significant foothold in American homes ahead of rival Divx format and digital pay-per-view movies on cable television; graph (M)/

headline: AT&T Changes Some Fees
abstract: AT&T Corp is offering residential customers long-distance calls within US for 5 cents a minute on weekends, in a bid to add more customers and stem defections; discount is available for six months to customers who sign up for One Rate Plus plan, which charges 10 cents a minute on other days plus $4.95 monthly fee (S)

headline: Cuban Exile Leader Among 7 Accused of Plot on Castro
abstract: Jose Antonio Llama, member of board of Cuban-American National Foundation, is indicted in San Juan, PR, with six other men on charges that they conspired to assassinate Pres Fidel Castro of Cuba when he was on official visit to Venezuela in 1997; others indicted are Jose Rodriguez Sosa, Alfredo Otero, Angel Alfonso Aleman, Angel Hernandez Rojo, Juan Bautista Marquez and Francisco Secundino Cordova; indictment does not mention foundation, principal Cuban exile organization in US; photos (M)

headline: Treasuries Decline Again as World Stock Markets Stabilize
abstract: US bonds fall for second time in three days; price of 30-year bond falls 14/32, to 103 22/32, pushing its yield up 3 basis points, to 5.25 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: As U.S. Open Nears, It's Everything Tennis
abstract: Tennis enthusiasts will have many Web sites to chose from during United States Open; photo (S)

headline: Israeli Arabs And the Police Clash in North On Land Plan
abstract: Israeli riot police clash with Israeli Arabs in northern Israel, wounding scores with tear gas and rubber-coated bullets as youths hurl rocks and set road blocks on fire; melee is provoked by Israeli Army plans to confiscate acres of olive groves in Israeli Arab town of Umm Al-Fahm and use area for firing range (M)

headline: Northrop to Cut 8,000 Jobs In Wake of Failed Merger
abstract: Northrop Grumman Corp says it will cut work force by 8,000 people, or about 15 percent, by the end of 2000 as it tries to remain competitive as independent company in wake of collapse of its acquisition by Lockheed Martin on antitrust grounds; most of cuts will be in Southern California; chairman Kent Kresa comments, interview (M)

headline: Unilever Developing On-Line Programs
abstract: Unilever, British-Dutch consumer products giant, signs agreements with America Online Inc and Microsoft Corp to develop interactive marketing and new media advertising programs (S)

headline: Unusual Commercial From Prudential
abstract: As investors watch CNBC for latest update on stock market, Prudential Real Estate is aiming at that affluent audience by advertising $3.5 million luxury home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla; in what is said to be first national advertisement for single luxury home, Prudential Real Estate Affiliates unit of Prudential Insurance Co of America, began running 60-second TV commercial on Aug 3; ad was created in-house (S)

headline: Islam Is Not the Enemy, U.S. Declares
abstract: Clinton Adm, in explaining decision to strike targets in Afghanistan and Sudan, is careful to say that United States is aiming at terrorist orgns and their bases, not at a religion with adherents worldwide; Pres Clinton declares 'I want the world to understand that our actinos today were not aimed against Islam'; Clinton carefully distinguishes between Muslims--followers of what he calls 'a great religion'--and radical groups that hold to 'a horrible distortion of their religion to justify the murder of innocents;' photo of supporters of Hezbollah outside mosque in Beirut, Lebanon (M)

headline: Two-Day Rally Is Ended As Dow Slides 21.37 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 21.37 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,693.28; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 3.14 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,098.06; Nasdaq composite index falls 12.43 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,842.69; graph of fluctuations in Dow Jones industrial average; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nasdaq Sets a New Record, While Dow and S.& P. Fall  The technology-heavy Nasdaq index jumped to its sixth consecutive new high, closing just shy of the 2,000 level at 1,994.54.

headline: Beyond the Fuss Over Bank Mergers and the New I.R.S.
abstract: Article on August issue of Smart Money magazine and August-September issue of Your Money, both of which focus on bank consolidations and adverse impact on customers; photo (M)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Tact Can Seal A Global Deal . . . But a Little Spunk Works Best in New York
abstract: Arlene B Isaacs describes how business executives can adopt appropriate behavior, tact and finesse when dealing with foreign officials and executives; drawing (M)

headline: MAYTAG SAYS 3D-QUARTER PROFIT WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
abstract: Maytag Corp says third-quarter earnings will beat estimates (S)

headline: Brokerage Firm Wins Approval For Electronic Futures Trading
abstract: Commodity Futures Trading Commission approves Cantor Fitzgerald LP brokerage firm plan for first United States computerized futures exchange, which will trade Treasury futures; Board of Trade of New York is partner in plan, which will compete with Chicago Board of Trade; Chicago board weighs legal action (S)

headline: G.M. and Union Agree to Start Arbitration on Wednesday
abstract: General Motors and United Automobile Workers say they will begin meeting on July 22 with arbitrator Thomas Roberts; at stake is UAW's ability to continue strategy of shutting down GM periodically by striking at just one or two important parts factories (M)

headline: Shake-Up Looms for Bankers In Thailand : FROM BANKS TO UNIONS :ASIA WOES MOUNT
abstract: BANGKOK  One year after the Asian economic crisis began in Thailand, all 15 of the country's commercial banks reported first-half losses Wednesday that were even more severe than the most pessimistic forecasts.

headline: Grey Advertising Opens Media Services Unit
abstract: Grey Advertising in New York says it is opening independent media services company in United States that will be part of its Mediacom Worldwide division (S)

headline: Serbs Attack Kosovo Rebels in Biggest Offensive So Far
abstract: Yugoslav Army and paramilitary police units, in biggest offensive of conflict in Serbian province of Kosovo, attack rebel positions across region in apparent effort to free large sections of major roads that have been under rebel control for months; are reportedly clearing roadblocks and advancing; maps; photo (M)

headline: In Ulster, Still Horror, Still Hope
abstract: Warren Hoge analysis of prospects for political solution to Northern Ireland's troubles in view of persistent antagonism between Protestants and Catholics; says communities across the province continue to flaunt their religious exclusivity and people either identify themselves as Irish (Catholic) or British (Protestant); sees some evidence that religiously polarized politics of province may be breaking down (M)

headline: Strong London Demand For Coke Bottler Shares
abstract: Shares of Coca-Cola Beverages PLC are up on first day of trading on London Stock Exchange (S)

headline: Intervention Props Up Hong Kong Stocks
abstract: Hong Kong stocks were rising today after ending slightly lower on Tuesday as the market was shored up again by purchases by the Government.    At the midday break, the Hang Seng index of 33 leading issues was up 298.08 points, or 4.13 percent, at 7,509.00.

headline: More Schwab Duties For BBDO Worldwide
abstract: Charles Schwab & Company in San Francisco said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with BBDO Worldwide by naming BBDO West in Los Angeles to handle creative duties on its Mutual One Source mutual funds service account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million. The account had been divided between Cohn Godley Norwood in Boston, which handled the print portion, and an in-house team, which handled the television portion.    BBDO West, part of Omnicom Group, was awarded the assignment without a formal review. The decision comes less than two months after BBDO New York was awarded Schwab's consolidated brand advertising account for financial services, with billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million. Suissa Miller Advertising in Los Angeles will continue to handle the Schwab on-line brokerage account, while Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif., will continue to handle media.

headline: Clinton Urges World Action on Terror
abstract: Pres Clinton addresses opening session of United Nations General Assembly, telling delegates that fight against terrorism is at top of US agenda; proposes steps for better international cooperation to prevent and punish attacks; similar sentiments are expressed by number of other world leaders; Clinton says he will ask Congress for more money to strenghten protection for American embassies abroad and for programs to help countries threatened by terrorism to improve lives of people and thus diminish pool for terrorist recruitment; photo (M)

headline: Wealthy Force Behind Murky Militant Group
abstract: Suspicion in the intelligence community concerning bombing of American Embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam is centered on Osama bin Laden, multimillionaire Saudi businessman who fought in Afghanistan against Soviet Union and has a world-wide network of Islamic terrorists; bin Laden is prominent suspect because he has publicly threatened to strike at Americans throught the world and because he has assembled a pan-Islamic coalition of seasoned guerrillas with the sophistication, logistics and motivation to carry out the almost simultaneous attacks (M)

headline: DAMES & MOORE BUYS RADIAN FROM DOW FOR $117 MILLION
abstract: Dames & Moore Group acquires Radian International LLC from Dow Chemical Co for $117 million in cash (S)

headline: Stocks Take Broad Plunge; Dow Off 100
abstract: Stock prices head broadly lower as investors continue to show nervousness about effects of possible global economic slowdown on profits of American companies; Dow Jones industrial average falls 100.15 points, or 1.3 percent, to 7,682.22; it is sixth loss in seven days for Dow, and other market indexes follow it lower; tables (M)

headline: Morse Code Sinks Without an SOS
abstract: PARIS  As the inventor Samuel Morse might have said:

headline: The Have-Nots, at Least, Have Shelter in a Storm
abstract: Louis Uchitelle column notes majority of middle-class American families have lost wealth during economic expansion of 1990's; notes worth of top 25 percent to 30 percent, wealthier families that invested much of savings in stocks, has grown sharply (M)

headline: Textbooks for Sale on Line Are Aimed at College Students
abstract: College students are now able to order their textbooks online from Varsity Books site (www2.varsitybooks.com/textbooks/index.asp) (S)

headline: Fallon McElligott Hires Pair in London
abstract: Well-known British creative team, Richard Flintham and Andy McLeod, is hired as partners at new office of Minneapolis agency Fallon McElligott in London (S)

headline: ESTERLINE TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO BUY KIRKHILL RUBBER
abstract: Esterline Technologies Corp to acquire Kirkhill Rubber Co for $83 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PFIZER INC.,  New York, the nation's No. 4 drug maker, said it would buy back as much as $5 billion of its common shares.    JONES APPAREL GROUP INC.,  New York, a maker of women's apparel, said it planned to buy back as much as $100 million of its common stock, or about 4.1 percent of its stock outstanding.

headline: People
abstract: J Riley McDonough, publisher of Inc magazine, is named partner and executive vice president at Spinner Networks, start-up music World Wide Web site; Gary Mirkin is promoted to succeed McDonough (S)

headline: PEPSICO BUYING OUT BOTTLING COMPANY BASED IN ALBANY
abstract: Pepsico Inc will buy remaining 80 percent of one of its largest US bottlers; terms for Pepsi-Cola Allied Bottlers Inc, based in Albany, NY, are not disclosed; company is considering converting sizable stake in its bottling operations to public ownership (S)

headline: U.S. to Use Its Missile Warning System to Alert Russians to Launchings Worldwide
abstract: Pres Clinton and Pres Boris N Yeltsin plan to sign accord under which US and Russia will instantly share data about launching of ballistic missiles and space payloads; US is concerned that Russia's frayed missile warning system could contribute to accidental nuclear war (M)

headline: Security Council Tells Serbs To Stop Kosovo Offensive
abstract: United Nations Security Council approves resolution warning Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to stop Serbian attacks on ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo or face international intervention; calls for immediate cease-fire and peace talks; does not specify next step if Serbs do not comply, ambiguity that allows Russia to support measure; China abstains, holding crisis is internal matter (M)

headline: Fed Extends Alert on Bank Lending Standards
abstract: Federal Reserve warns banks to keep up their lending standards and not assume unusually favorable economic environment of last few years will last forever; provides detailed review of lending trends, stressing 'forward-looking analysis' of economic conditions (M)

headline: Health Insurers: Middlemen or More?
abstract: John J Schlager letter responds to Aetna executive Richard L Huber's August 9 Viewpoint article on health insurance regulation (S)

headline: Luke Finlay, a General and a Lobbyist, Dies at 91
abstract: Luke William Finlay, retired lawyer, legislative lobbyist for oil industry and general during World War II, dies at age 91 (M)

headline: ENERGEN TO BUY TOTAL MINATOME FOR $192 MILLION
abstract: Energen Resources Corp, unit of Energen Corp, will acquire Total Minatome Corp from unit of French energy company Total SA for $192 million, then sell 31 percent of acquired company to Westport Oil and Gas Co for about $60 million (S)

headline: Political Squabbling Snags a Financial Overhaul in Japan
abstract: Hopes are dwindling for passage this week of landmark series of bills to stabilize Japan's financial system, days before Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi leaves for visit to US; bills have been focus of global attention, because they are seen as litmus test of Obuchi Government's ability to confront Japan's mammoth economic problems; Obuchi had hoped to have them passed by time he meets Pres Clinton on Sept 22, for talks on global financial crisis (M)

headline: Officials Assess Impact Of a Fed-Brokered Deal
abstract: The Clinton Administration played down today the potential risks to the financial system from Long-Term Capital Management L.P.'s brush with collapse, but the fund's fall raised questions in Congress about whether regulators can keep up with the increasing complexity and speed of the markets.
