A day after helping big banks and investment firms work out a rescue package that will give Long-Term Capital some time to deal with its financial problems, the Federal Reserve emphasized that it had not put any taxpayer money into the deal.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CABLE DESIGN TECHNOLOGIES CORP., -- Pittsburgh, a maker of data transmission cables, acquired an 80 percent stake in HEW-Kabel, Wipperfurth, Germany, a maker of specialty cables, for an undisclosed amount.    VITRAN CORP., -- Toronto, a trucking company, agreed to buy the privately held Quast Transfer Inc., a Minnesota-based carrier, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Peterborough Journal; In a New Museum, Canoes Glide Into Mythology
abstract: John Jennings, founder of Canadian Canoe Museum, is on crusade to have canoe recognized as romantic symbol of Canada's founding; map; photo (M)

headline: AFC ENTERPRISES TO PURCHASE CINNABON INTERNATIONAL
abstract: AFC Enterprises, the owner of Churchs Chicken and Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cinnabon International Inc., a retail bakery company, for $65 million. The Seattle-based Cinnabon, which features cinnamon rolls, owns 214 sites and has 144 franchise sites. Its outlets are in malls, airports and supermarkets. The acquisition is the fourth in the last year for the Atlanta-based AFC as the company expands its restaurant formats, building cash flow in anticipation of an initial public offering in 1999. Recent purchases include the Seattle Coffee Company.

headline: U.N. Rights Official, Back From China, Sees Better Attitude
abstract: United Nations Human Rights Comr Mary Robinson, completing first visit to China, says that despite continuing abuses, Chinese leaders show new willingess to discuss nation's rights record, news conference, Beijing; lauds China's willingness to let commission work in nation; rights groups react with cautious optimism (M)

headline: Digital Bread Crumbs Through the Forest
abstract: Web search sites have begun to mold their tools to enhance the often poor search techniques of users; Excite, Infoseek, and Cnet's Snap sites evaluated; photo (M)

headline: Oil Refiner to Buy Back 4.2% of Shares
abstract: Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corp will buy back as much as $100 million in stock, or about 4.2 percent of its shares (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Drop in Hong Kong As Free Market Takes Over  The Hong Kong Government ended a weeklong buying spree to prop up the slumping stock market and let the free market take over, causing stocks to plunge.

headline: Charges Against 2d Suspect Detail Trail of Terrorists
abstract: Federal agents give further details on case against Osama bin Laden, suspect in bombings at US Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, as they bring a second suspect, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, to New York to faces charges in the attack; photo of a concrete bunker being put in place outside Federal courthouse in Manhattan (M)

headline: Americans Fish as Resentful Canadians Observe a Salmon Ban
abstract: Hundreds of Canadian fishermen in communities that dot British Columbia's rugged coastline are observing Canadian fishing ban on fragile northern coho salmon stocks; they resent inability of Fisheries Min David Anderson to reach agreement with Alaska over coho stocks; Alaskan officials say Canada's fishing ban is extreme reaction (M)

headline: Rescuers and Investigators Sent by U.S. Begin to Arrive
abstract: Pres Clinton vows that United States will not buckle under to threat of international terrorism; American Govt personnel arrive in East Africa to begin grim tasks of helping victims and opening investigation into nearly simultaneous bombings of United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania; American officials say that suspect at top of their list is Osama bin Laden, wealthy Saudi-born financier who this year renewed his vow to wage holy war against United States (M)

T-bond   5.74   5.72   6.52        Telephone bd.   7.15   7.15   7.59        Municipal bds.   5.27   5.26   5.49          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge   Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: U.S. Retreats From Vow to Use Force if Iraq Blocks Inspectors
abstract: Clinton Administration backs off its pledge of immediate military action if Iraq interferes with arms inspectors; instead, says act that will bring US retaliation has shifted to Iraqi moves to develop weapons of mass destruction or that pose threat to its neighbors; Administration asks Security Council and Secretary General Kofi Annan to respond to Iraq's violation of Feb 23 to cooperate with inspectors (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: RUBLE DEVALUATION AIDS MARK. Germany's currency partly recovered from last week's selloff on hope that the floating of the ruble would ease the crisis in Russia, a big German debtor. The dollar fell to 1.7946 marks from 1.8014.

headline: A Struggling Adobe Rejects Bid by Quark
abstract: Quark Inc says its offer to acquire Adobe Systems Inc at premium to Adobe's current stock prices was turned down; both companies are graphic software publishers; Quark says it seeks friendly transaction, but holds out possibility of hostile tender offer; Adobe has current market value of $1.65 billion; Quark's offer is unusual in several aspects; Quark is privately held company, and has no stock to offer Adobe shareholders; in computing industry, such unsolicited acquisition overtures are rare; hostile takeover bids are rarely successful, because it is difficult to insure that engineering talent would not leave in face of takeover (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES, Sunnyvale, Calif., a supplier of integrated circuits for computer and communications markets, named Randy Burdick to the new position of chief information officer. He will oversee the company's information technology and business systems organizations.     CONAGRA, Omaha, said its chief executive, Bruce Rohde, had been named chairman. Mr. Rohde succeeds Philip B. Fletcher, who will continue as a member of Conagra's board and become chairman of the executive committee.

headline: It's All False, Exiles Say
abstract: Cuban-American National Foundation denies New York Times report that group's late founder, Jorge Mas Canosa, and other leaders financed activities of Luis Posada Carriles, who said he carried out bombing campaign against Cuba last year (S)

headline: Internet Brokers Chart the European Investor
abstract: About 20 percent of all stock trades in United States are entered over Internet, and now growing number of Europeans are shopping for stocks on-line; result is stock market boom; movement is still in its infancy, but American Internet brokers have begun moving into Britain and are increasingly setting eyes on Continent; their arrival poses challenge for few and fledgling European on-line trading companies; experts expect arrival of Americans to accelerate big changes in securities business; that are already under way as Europe forges itself into single market; photos (M)

headline: Harried Monitors Still Searching for 20,000 Kosovo Refugees
abstract: Diplomats tracking human rights abuses in Kosovo say they are unable to learn fate of more than 20,000 civilians who fled from Yugoslav Government counteroffensive against ethnic Albanian rebels; foreign monitors and aid workers say their movements are being restricted by Serbian authorities; in the past, United States and other Western countries accused Yugoslav Government of brutality against civilians in past offensives; Yugolsav officials, threatened with military action by NATO, agreed to protect civilians and to allow foreign observers to monitor Yugoslav military; officials appear to be breaking that pledge now; map (M)

headline: Offstage Choreographer of the Japanese Economy
abstract: Article on Toyoo Gyohten, who has been appointed special adviser on financial matters to new Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi; photo (M)

headline: Daimler's Profit Is Up Sharply; F.T.C. Clears Deal for Chrysler
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG says profit more than doubled in first half of 1998; profit rose to record 2.01 billion marks, or $1.1 billion, from 992 million marks in first half a year earlier; revenue increased 21 percent, to 67.7 billion marks from 55.9 billion marks; company's purchase of Chrysler Corp is approved by Federal Trade Commission (M)

headline: U.S. Trade Official Says China Market Is Closed Tighter
abstract: David L Aaron, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, criticizes what he calls China's unwillingness to open its markets to foreign companies, and accuses Chinese of tightening some restrictions on foreign businesses; Aaron says China's policies help produce $1 billion-a-week trade deficit for Americans (M)

headline: A Second Look at AOL, the Refurbished Ellis Island of the Net
abstract: Article appraises America Online's new 4.0 version of its software; drawing (M)

headline: WPP Pursues Stake In Company in Japan
abstract: WPP Group PLC is negotiating to acquire stake in Asatsu Inc, Japan's third-largest ad agency; deal will come after Asatsu buys Dai-Ichi Kikaku Co on Jan 1; that deal is valued at $143.3 million; BBDO Worldwide is acquiring 20 percent of I&S Corp (S)

headline: Ruble's Crash Sets Off Boom in Survival Strategies
abstract: Collapse of ruble sets off boom in survival strategies among Russians, affecting everyone, from ordinary citizens to small business owners; many shops have raised prices or simply closed while citizens struggle to withdraw money from banks; many who kept savings under mattresses have gone on wild buying sprees, looking for ways to safely park money before value declines any further; photos (M)

headline: Russia Power-Sharing Deal Settled, Then Seems to Fail
abstract: Power-sharing agreement between Pres Boris Yeltsin and Russia's Communist-dominated Parliament, which is intended to pave way for Viktor S Chernomyrdin's reconfirmation as Prime Minister, appears to break down only hours after it is announced; political leaders resume raucous squabbling in live television debate, in which Communist leader, Gennadi A Zyuganov, denies he authorized party's representative to endorse agreement; says he does not trust Yeltsin to adhere to accord; says he will order Party members to vote against Yeltsin's choice of Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister, contending that he has been accomplice of Yeltsin's in destruction of past years; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COFFEE RISES 4.8 PERCENT. Prices surged after the Green Coffee Association, an industry group, said stockpiles had fallen to the lowest level since February. The September contract rose 5.35 cents, to $1.163 a pound.

headline: Microsoft's Trial Will Begin on Oct. 15
abstract: Federal District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson says trial in Microsoft Corp's antitrust fight with Government will start Oct 15; he denies request by company to throw out case; agrees to dismiss one claim of monopoly leveraging made by 20 states that also sued company (S)

headline: F&M BANCORP PLANNING TO BUY MONOCACY BANCSHARES
abstract: F&M Bancorp will buy Monocacy Bancshares Inc for $82.7 million in stock (S)

headline: Stock and Bond Issuance Falls to a Low for the Year
abstract: Stock and bond issuance for past week fell to spectacular low for year, with just over $14 billion of new securities sold (S)

headline: Lagardere Profit Increases 17.5%
abstract: Lagardere SCA says first-half net rose 17.5 percent; net profit reached 544 million francs ($96.6 million), up from 463 million francs in year-earlier period (S)

headline: First Stop: The Tutorial
abstract: Appraisal of Windows 98 Tutorial packaged with Windows 98, Windows 98 Starts Here from Microsoft Press, and Teach Yourself Windows 98 in 24 Hours by Greg Perry; photo (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY     NONE REPORTED

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls for third day after Moody's Investors Service says it might downgrade Japan's triple-A debt; dollar rises as high as 142 yen before settling at 141.38 yen, up from 141.24; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Lowers Interest Rates To Ease Effects of Turmoil  The Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point in an attempt to keep the financial turmoil afflicting much of the world from derailing growth at home.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Balance of Trade -- June  Consumer Price Index -- July    WEDNESDAY  Housing Construction -- July    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY  None

headline: PROFIT RECOVERY IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL FOR LODER, DREW
abstract: Profit Recovery Group International will acquire Loder, Drew & Associates for $70 million in cash plus 803,535 restricted shares; at current prices, stock consideration would be worth about $24.8 million (S)

headline: W. R. GRACE PLANS TO PURCHASE CROSFIELD DELAYED AGAIN
abstract: W R Grace & Co's proposed $445 million purchase of Crosfield Group, subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, has been delayed for second time because review into whether acquisition will hurt competition is taking longer than expected (S)

headline: Resentment Still Aimed At Chinese In Indonesia
abstract: Ethnic Chinese, who make up little more than 3 percent of Indonesia's population but bulk of its trading class, remain targets of resentment and face threat of new attacks; wealthier have fled, in several waves of panic, amid rumors of new riots; reportedly transferred much wealth abroad, further stalling economic recovery; anger of overseas Chinese in other Asian nations could also pose threat to economy (M)

headline: Texan Tied to Bin Laden Held Without Bail
abstract: Wadih el Hage, Texan who worked as close aide to Osama bin Laden, suspect in United States embassy bombings, is ordered held without bond on charges of lying in probe of bin Laden and his organization, al Qaeda; prosecution links him to other cases of terrorism and murder; holds he tried to buy firearms for Mahmoud Abouhalima, who was convicted in World Trade Center bombing (M)

headline: Congress Is Challenging State Internet Fees
abstract: Proposed legislation that would effectively ban taxes on Internet access includes grandfather clause that would allow eight states with existing taxes to continue to impose them, if legislatures of eight states vote to re-enact their taxes and governors sign bills; state and local government officials in states with taxes call this a back-door route to killing taxes; Frank Shafroth, policy director for National League of Cities, notes that all eight states in question have Republican governors, seven of whom are up for re-election; Shafroth and other critics of bill say its content is being influenced by lobbying campaign dominated by America Online; say AOL is eager to escape liabilities owed to eight states; states are Connecticut, Iowa, Ohio, North Dakota, New Mexico, South Dakota, Tennessee and Wisconsin (M)

headline: Dead Diver From North Puts Seoul on Alert
abstract: South Korean military commanders put troops on country's eastern coast on alert and declare curfew in area after finding body of diver who they say was North Korean commando; map (M)

headline: Airbus in Shift On 100-Seat Jet
abstract: Airbus Industrie says it has dropped costly plan to develop 100-seat jet together with Chinese companies, freeing it to develop is own model to rival Boeing Company's two planes of that size; decision, while a setback to China's aerospace ambitions, is a relief for European plane maker, which never committed formally to the project (S)

headline: Buying the Backbones of the Wireless Age
abstract: Crown Castle International and Pinnacle Tower, which build and own wireless transmission towers for phone, cellular, paging and data transmission companies, plan to go public soon; investment possibilities described; photo; graph (M)

headline: EQUITABLE RESOURCES TO SELL SOME NATURAL GAS UNITS
abstract: Equitable Resources Inc to sell its natural gas midstream operations in Louisiana and Texas for $320 million in cash to American Electric Power Co (S)

headline: A Man With a Plan? Japanese Prefer Premiers Who Speak Softly and Hold a Lot of Meetings
abstract: As Washington yearns for forceful new Prime Minister to emerge in Japan and take charge of economy, history suggests such an occurrence is hardly likely, since over decades and centuries Japan has had good rulers and bad rulers, but only rarely has it had strong leaders (M)

headline: Columbia/HCA Suit Dismissal Is Sought
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says Federal Magistrate William Haynes has recommended dismissal of shareholders' lawsuit because there is not enough evidence to support allegations of fraud against company and its directors; Haynes also recommends to Federal District Judge Thomas Higgins that separate lawsuit against some company board members be discarded; Higgins is not bound to follow recommendation; suits stem from 1997 disclosure of Government probe into company's billing and business practices (S)

headline: For Primakov, Now Comes the Hard Part: Finding a Plan That Will Save Russia
abstract: Celestine Bohlen analysis of the conflicting economic plans and emergency measures that Yevgeny M Primakov has inherited on taking office as Prime Minister; photo (M)

headline: Pilots on Strike at Air Canada as Talks Fail
abstract: Pilots strike Air Canada after failing to agree on new contract (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.38   5.48   5.59        3-month T-bills   4.47   4.55   4.78        6-month T-bills   4.39   4.51   4.94        10-yr. T-infl.   3.62   3.62   3.58        10-yr. T-note   4.62   4.66   6.12        30-yr. T-bond   5.16   5.16   6.39        Telephone bd.   7.01   7.01   7.48        Municipal bds.   5.09   5.09   5.48          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: States Bracing For Northwest Pilots' Strike
abstract: Threatened pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines would shut down single largest airline in seven upper Midwestern states; estimated 8 out of 10 flights in and out of Detroit and Minneapolis are Northwest's; Governors of Minnesota, Michigan, Wisconsin and four other states wrote letter to Pres Clinton, saying their economies would lose hundreds of millions of dollars in first week alone in event of Northwest strike; deadline for strike is one minute past midnight on August 29; latest round of negotiations between Northwest and pilots began on Aug 17 under auspices of Federal mediator; both sides say they are eager to reach settlement, but key issue of pay remains unresolved; pilots agreed to cut their wages and benefits 15.5 percent for 39 months when airline was near bankruptcy in 1993; now that Northwest has rebounded financially, pilots want their share of profits (M)

headline: Flying Through Tumult Of Less-Friendly Skies
abstract: Interview with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst Kevin Murphy, who comments on impact on airline stocks from pilot contract negotiations at Northwest Airlines; photo; graphs (M)

headline: MCCAW FAMILY EXERCISES AN OPTION FOR SHARES IN NEXTEL
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc says Craig McCaw and his family exercised option to buy about 10 million shares in company in cashless transaction (S)

headline: STONE RIVET AGREES TO ACQUIRE ENVIROTEST SYSTEMS
abstract: Stone Rivet Inc acquires Envirotest Systems Corp for $266.3 million; will assume debt of $275 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Macao Journal; A Reputed Mr. Big Upholds Colony's Reputation
abstract: Macao law enforcement officials say Wan Kuok-koi, Chinese man arrested on May 1, is one of most notorious organized crime figures in Southeast Asia; say he is behind many acts of violence that have paralyzed Portuguese colony since last year; map; photo (M)

headline: Fed Voted 10 to 1 in July to Keep Rates the Same
abstract: Minutes of Federal Reserve policy meeting on July 1 show policy makers voted 10 to 1 to leave overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 5.50 percent; Jerry Jordan, president of Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, dissented for third time this year, citing growth in money supply as reason to raise lending rate (S)

headline: SWIFT ENERGY TO BUY OIL AND GAS PROPERTIES FROM SONAT
abstract: Swift Energy Co will acquire oil and gas properties from Sonat Inc's exploration unit for $87.6 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Opryland Hospitality and Attractions Group awards advertising and public relations duties for properties including Opryland Hotel to Buntin Group; Ericson Marketing Communications had handled account (S)

headline: SOLUTIA SAYS IT WILL SELL PHOSPHOROUS CHEMICALS UNIT
abstract: Solutia Inc, specialty chemical and fiber maker, to sell its phosphorous chemicals unit (S)

headline: At Least Psychologically, Moscow's Shadow Is Looming Large
abstract: Stock markets around world close broadly lower as financial crisis in Russia unnerves investors; many economists and Government officials say reaction was driven more by market psychology than economic fundamentals; say Russia's direct economic impact on other countries remains modest; even in Germany, where banks have $30.5 billion in outstanding loans to Russia, 90 percent of them are guaranteed by German Government; Germany is world's biggest exporter to Russia, but that trade accounts for only 5 percent of its total sales abroad; Poland and Hungary, which have maintained strong growth and continue to draw heavy foreign investment, now struggle to avoid guilt by association based on their historic ties to Russia; map (M)

headline: Kellogg to Review Marketing Programs
abstract: Kellogg Co will begin review that might result in adding an agency to roster of shops handling its troubled American ready-to-eat cereal account; Leo Burnett Co, WPP Group PLC, Burrell Communications Group, Young & Rubicam, Interpublic Group of Companies, Omnicon Group and Grey Advertising have been asked to participate in evaluation of its marketing programs (M)

headline: Already-Shaky Markets in Latin America Drop Even Further
abstract: Stock markets in Latin America plunge, raising more doubts about whether region will be able to survive economic crisis that has swamped Asia and is now pulling Russia to its knees; currency declines in Mexico and fear of devaluation in Brazil add to pressure; consumers in Latin America are big buyers of American exports; if their pace slows down that will put another drag on American economy; analysts say equity selling in Latin America is being forced by need of hedge funds to raise cash to pay off loans they took out to make big bets on Russia; photo (M)

headline: That's a Wrap: A Fad's Fade-Out
abstract: Rise and fall of food-fad known as the wrap described; like so many food trends whose allure is their hipness factor, many wrap shops were mowed down by fast-moving competitors or by mainstream food purveyors like Wendy's and Au Bon Pain, which both offered cheaper knockoffs (M) (Special section on entrepreneurs)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls a second day on speculation that next Prime Minister will be Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi, who is relatively reluctant to spur the economy; dollar rises to 141.24 yen from 140.40; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Union and G.M. Reach Pact To End Strikes at 2 Plants  General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union agreed to end nearly eight weeks of strikes at two auto parts plants in Flint, Mich., that had shut down car assembly plants across North America, pushed hundreds of thousands of workers into temporary unemployment and slowed the nation's economic growth.    The settlement, which must be approved by workers at both factories, settles a wide range of local issues at the two factories and at several other G.M. factories where workers had threatened strikes. But it did not address any national issues, such as G.M.'s push to open new factories overseas or its effort to reduce its work force in the United States through attrition. [Page A1.]

headline: DRS TECHNOLOGIES IN $22.9 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR NAI
abstract: DRS Technologies Inc agrees to pay as much as $22.9 million for NAI Technologies Inc (S)

headline: Big Italian Insurer Is Expected To Settle Claims on Holocaust
abstract: US Sen Alfonse M D'Amato says holocaust survivors and Jewish charities are near agreement under which Generali, giant Italian insurance company, would pay at least $65 million to settle claims that it refused to honor policies of Eastern European Jews after World War II (S)

headline: Phnom Penh Journal; Bats Soil Statuary but Pay for Museum's Upkeep
abstract: Guano from thousands of bats roosting under leaking roofs and eaves of National Museum, Phnom Penh, Cambodia, threatens Buddhist and Hindu treasures of ancient Angkor, newly returned to museum after yearlong foreign tour; museum, which gets no Government funding, sells guano to subsidize operations; seeks aid to build new ceiling and keep out bats; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 28 article on financial institutions that cater to professional athletes (S)

headline: Zapata in Deals to Buy 21 Internet Properties
abstract: Avram Glazer and his Zapata Corp plan to buy 21 World Wide Web sites and aggregate them under one site, www.Zap.com, as part of his plan to make company Internet leader; photo (M)

headline: British Cement Giant Expanding in Asia
abstract: Blue Circle Industries PLC's Malaysian unit, Malayan Cement Bhd, to buy stakes in two cement companies for 252 million pounds ($404 million) in cash and assumed debt; will pay 176.5 million pounds for 50 percent of Associated Pan Malaysian Cement it does not already own and buy Pan Malaysia Cement Works Singapore, assuming debt of 75.7 million (S)

headline: That Delicate Balance: What About the Dads?
abstract: Suzanne Keating letter on Aug 23 article on women balancing challenges of work and raising children notes few fathers agonize over issues (S)

headline: Loss in Data Services Keeps GTE Profits Flat
abstract: GTE Corp says second quarter profit was $673 million, up slightly from $671 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 10 percent, to $6.28 billion from $5.69 billion (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Praise for iMac
abstract: Jeffrey Techentin letter says July 23 article on iMac computer and IBM's Aptiva suggests that computer purchasing decisions are no longer rational (S)

headline: GRADING THE SECRETARY: A special report.; Albright, a Bold Voice Abroad, Finds Her Role Limited at Home
abstract: With her bold public stands undermined by irresolution in the White House and her experience rendered less relevant by new economic crises, Madeleine K. Albright has had a tough 20 months as Secretary of State.    Ms. Albright remains the Clinton Administration's principal foreign-policy voice and the liaison with a recalcitrant Republican Congress, and is greeted like a celebrity very popular in the country beyond Washington. But a President averse to military risk, preoccupied by the fallout from his relationship with an intern and unwilling to offend core Democratic constituencies has not supported her on key issues like the Middle East and Kosovo.

headline: Nasdaq Rises to a Record On Momentum From Intel
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 27.28 points, or 1.4 percent, to record 1,935.39; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 11.72, or 1.02 percent, to record 1,166.38; Dow Jones industrial average rises 89.93, or 1 percent, to 9.174.97; graphs; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: 2 Liquor Store Chains May Merge in Britain
abstract: Allied Domecq P.L.C. and Whitbread P.L.C. said yesterday that they were in talks that could lead to the merger of their Victoria Wine and Thresher liquor stores as the two companies seek ways to fight competition from supermarkets. According to George Welham, a spokesman for Victoria Wine's parent, Allied Domecq, the talks are about ''putting their chains into a 50-50 company.''

headline: 7 Southeast Europe Nations Form a Joint Military Force
abstract: Christopher R Hill, US Ambassador to Macedonia, says Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, has no justification for pressing his campaign against insurgents in Serbia's Kosovo province; says Milosevic faces a devastating blow if he refuses to stop (S)

headline: Mired in Recession, Japan Lowers a Rate
abstract: The Japanese central bank has lowered an important interest rate to the extraordinarily low level of one-quarter of 1 percent.     The rate cut is an attempt, by making funds cheaper, to stimulate the economy, the world's second largest, and bring it out of its worst recession since World War II.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Greenspan Suggests Fed May Cut Rates  Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested to the Senate Budget Committee that the central bank would seriously consider cutting interest rates when it meets Tuesday. Although he cautioned that the decision was not his alone, it was Mr. Greenspan's strongest indication yet that he is leaning toward lower rates.    Mr. Greenspan said the global crisis was threatening the nation's long economic expansion, and named developments over the last several months that could slow growth. They included the decline in the stock market, a reduction in lending by banks and a general rise in financial uncertainty. [Page A1.]

headline: Into the Breach; Editor Steps into the Heart of Turbulence at U.S. News
abstract: Stephen G Smith takes over as editor of US News & World Report at difficult time; his predecessor, James Fallows, is still hashing out severance agreement with magazine's owner, Mortimer B Zuckerman, and at least nine staff members are leaving or have already left; morale is low and many reporters and editors wonder how long Smith will last; he is seventh editor at US News since Zuckerman bought magazine 14 years ago; Zuckerman says he wants to move magazine back to more conventional news magazine format, but critics say US News cannot compete with Time or Newsweek on that ground, because it has fewer resources, smaller staff and earlier deadlines; they say US News needs to carve out its own distinct role; photo chart (M)

headline: CLARK USA TO BUY OIL REFINERY FROM BRITISH PETROLEUM
abstract: Clark USA Inc will acquire British Petroleum Co's oil refinery in Lima, Ohio, for $215 million; will pay $175 million for refinery and $40 million for inventory and other working capital (S)

headline: Communists, Remodeled, Keep Trying In Germany
abstract: The red velvet curtain parted and Gregor Gysi rode out on a baby elephant, circling the ring to the thunderous applause of 800 or so supporters jammed into a sweltering circus tent.    With national elections six weeks off, things are going so poorly for Mr. Gysi, 50, the head of eastern Germany's former Communists, that the party has turned to a circus to draw attention. Although the party has been successful locally in eastern German states, Mr. Gysi (pronounced GHEE-zee) said the national vote is the biggest test for the party since 1990, when it renamed itself the Party of Democratic Socialism.

headline: Slower June Growth for Key Part of Economy
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management says its new index of nonmanufacturing business activity fell to 61.5 in June, from 64 in May; says nonmanufacturing industries continued to grow and to increase employment, while cutting inventories and paying less for materials and services (S)

headline: Men's Wearhouse Plans Campaign in New York
abstract: Men's Wearhouse Inc is marking its arrival in metropolitan New York market with television and radio campaign costing over $1 million (S)

headline: No Refuge in Plunging Commodity Prices
abstract: Market Place column examines falling commodity prices, which could prove more worrisome for investors in long run than plunging stock markets; major index of commodity prices has fallen to its lowest level in 21 years; each tick down in price of oil, copper, cotton and gold puts more economic pressure on nations where they are produced; many of major producers are emerging-market countries experiencing deep financial crisis; commodity prices have fallen 20 percent in last year; for American investor, lower prices for commodities from abroad have lowered corporate costs in United States and spurred consumer spending; damage done to commodity producers within US has not had big impact on economy; photo; graph (M)

headline: A Tax-Free Benefit And a Ticket to Ride
abstract: Commuters can get tax cut of $300 to $400 a year if their employers set up transit voucher program available as result of Federal transportation law enacted in July (S)

headline: Press Curbed, Malaysians Go On-Line for News : Mahathir Caught in Web Of Internet Awareness
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia's headlong rush into information technology is receiving strong support these days, although perhaps not among the crowd that Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad had intended when he launched a national Internet awareness program last year.

headline: TEXTRON AUTOMOTIVE UNIT ACQUIRES BRITISH PARTS MAKER
abstract: Textron Inc buys Midland Industrial Plastics of Britain (S)9

headline: Equity Offerings Are Set
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Datalink Corp., Minneapolis, an initial public offering of 2.6 million shares. Needham & Co.

headline: Universal Serial Bus Is Finally Picking Up Some Passengers
abstract: Universal Serial Bus (USBA) technology lets all computer devices, such as printer, scanner and mouse, plug into single connector; USB consists of pair of tiny rectangular ports and software that allows system to recognize devices after they are plugged in; it was devised by industry group led by Intel and Microsoft; down side is that older peripherals that are not configured for USB will not work in these ports; SCSI (small computer system interface) can also handle several pieces of hardware chained to one connector; it is faster portal than USB, but it is an older technology with inherent limitations that can make it difficult to connect and use for multiple low-speed devices; photos (M)

headline: Clinton Trip Fails to Silence Doubt on His Domestic Clout
abstract: Coverage of slow progress of Pres Clinton's penitence over his relationship with Monica S Lewinsky overshadows his trip to Russia, Ireland and Northern Ireland; Clinton remains popular overseas, but foreign leaders are aware that even without scandal, Clinton is lame duck; Clinton's aides insist domestic troubles have not hampered him during trip; Clinton clearly revels in warmth of reception in Ireland and Northern Ireland, where he is hailed as peacemaker; photo (M)i

headline: International Briefs; Dennis Group Accepts Higher Bid From Henlys
abstract: Henlys Group PLC raises its bid for Dennis Group PLC by 63 percent, to 309 million pounds ($501 million) in stock and cash, topping Mayflower PLC bid and winning Dennis board endorsement; graph of rise in Dennis shares (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Maybe the lottery raises a lot of revenue, but as an investment, it's chancier than you might think.
abstract: Economic Scene on growing popularity of state lotteries that are seen as 'good' taxes because they are voluntary; focuses on why lottery players seem to be attracted to games with highest payoffs and how lotteries have become state monopolies in name of civic virtue; holds economists are generally appalled by states' increasing dependence on lotteries (M)

headline: Cambodian Offers to Form A Coalition With 2 Rivals
abstract: Cambodia's leader, Hun Sen, offers to form coalition government with his chief rivals as additional returns in the parliamentary election appear to confirm his predictions of victory; speaks after meeting with King Norodom Sihanouk in ancient capital of Siem Reap and says King approved his plan to share power with Norodom Ranariddh, who is King's son, and Sam Rainsy; the two men say it is premature to talk of coalitions (S)

headline: ZAPATA STOCK DOUBLES AFTER COMPANY SPLITS
abstract: Zapata Corp will split into two entities: Zapata, which includes company's marine protein and food packaging business, and ZAP Corp, consisting of its Internet operations; plans to buy back, over time, up to five million shares, or 21.5 percent, of its stock; split spurs sharp rise in stock price (S)

headline: Going From the Corporate World to Silicon Alley Can Prove Tough
abstract: Scarcity of experienced managers in technology industries is especially acute in New York City's Silicon Alley, where few executives have built company from ground floor; successful initial public offerings by handful of Silicon Alley companies have made industry more attractive to experienced executives, easing shortage, but more recent start-ups are still struggling to find and lure top managers; recruiters reportedly are seeking executives who can make transition from established corporations; Lon Otremba and Lisa Church, who made switch to start-ups, and Peter Kestenbaum, who decided not to, comment; photos; table of biographical data (M)

headline: A 20,000% Bounce: Now That's Volatility
abstract: Article describes volatility in electricity commodity and futures markets; few companies disclose enough to allow analysts to determine whether deregulated electric utilities are risky or not; photo (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: TUESDAY  The Labor Department reports on second-quarter productivity. Forecasts are for an increase of 0.4 percent, down from 1.1 percent in the first quarter.    THURSDAY  The Labor Department releases weekly unemployment claims.  The Commerce Department reports on retail sales for July. They are expected to drop 0.6 percent.

headline: New Tests Dispute U.S. Finding of Iraq Nerve Gas
abstract: Swiss and French tests for poison gas on Iraqi missile warheads appear to have reached results contrary to those from American tests that showed presence of VX, deadly nerve agent; Iraq has admitted loading Sarin on weapons, but not VX, and may argue that US tests were rigged (S)

headline: Key Rates

headline: Breast-Feeding and H.I.V.: Weighing Health Risks and Treatment Costs
abstract: This village is really just a muddy patch of ground in the tall trees near where the Nile flows out of Lake Victoria. The men work on coffee plantations.  The women bear children, fetch water from the well about a mile away and cultivate cassava, potatoes and bananas.    There is no running water, no electricity, no phone. When the long rains come each year they wash out the dirt road for weeks at a time. This is -- and has always been -- a place where people who reach the age of 50 are old, and those who have seen a doctor or swallowed a pill are rare.

headline: Have Laptop, Will Track Each Blip in the Market

So a leading publisher of handwriting materials, seeing the unadorned writing on the wall, is replacing the letter with something more like the printed version.

headline: Retail Sales Fell in July, U.S. Reports

abstract: Fresh wave of panic sweeps through Russia's financial institutions as nation searches for new Government and program to pull it out of tailspin; currency plunges about 9 percent, three major banks announce merger to shore up their stability and Government unveils plan to stretch out repayment of debt; ruble's abrupt drop stokes new fears of inflation similar to spiraling rates that plunged Russia into depression in early 1990's; drop in value of currency is deepest in four years; new Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin tells parliamentary leaders that he is open to coalition Government that could include members of Communist opposition, which has been resolute foe of Russia's now sputtering economic reform program; photo (M)

headline: Relief Falls Short After Storms Ravage Mexican Villages

abstract: WWW.NWS.NOAA.GOV      THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE is probably the most trusted and well-known source of weather information in the country. So naturally, its home page is focused on . . . good government?

headline: Toyota and Nissan Say They Paid Gangsters
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's biggest auto makers, said today that they had made payments to a company that has figured in two recent arrests involving accusations of extortion against the Japan Airlines Company.    The three companies said they paid Taihei, a Japanese company believed to have ties to sokaiya, or corporate racketeers, for the apparent rental of artificial potted plants. In Japan, where company extortion is rampant, it is a violation of the Commercial Code for companies to have dealings with sokaiya.

She said the decision came after a three-month review that had been narrowed to Blau, a unit of Snyder Communications; Devon, and two other agencies: Bozell Direct in New York, part of True North Communications, and Cohn & Wells in New York.

headline: DIARY
abstract: RUSSIA  Floating Like a Butterfly Or Sinking Like a Stone?  The Russian Government moved hastily last week to avert financial collapse with a series of drastic measures, including delaying payments for 90 days on foreign debt owed mostly by banks, a restructuring of Government bonds and the sacrifice of the ruble to market forces. The value of the Russian currency is now free to float as low as 9.5 to the dollar, a risky step -- tantamount to devaluation -- that many people fear could prompt a new round of inflation. It could also wipe out as much as a third of the ruble's purchasing power in an economy heavily dependent on imports. The decision came after a request for $22.6 billion from the West was turned down. Standard & Poor's cut Russia's long-term foreign-currency debt rating by two notches. For this beggar at a McDonald's in Moscow, the collapsing ruble was not of immediate concern.    THE MARKET  A Roller-Coaster Ride  The global economic crisis and the aftermath of United States strikes on Afghanistan and the Sudan ravaged Wall Street stocks on Friday. After rising strongly early last week, the Dow fell slightly on Wednesday, more than 80 points on Thursday, and another 77.76 points on Friday, to close the week at 8533.65. Earlier on Friday the Dow had been down more than 200 points. The ups and downs over the week left some traders holding their heads.

headline: Resignedly, Russians Work Ever Harder for Even Less

abstract: Caterpillar Inc says earnings rose 2.5 percent in second quarter; net income rose to $446 million from $435 million a year earlier; revenue climbed 15 percent, to $5.60 billion from $4.87 billion (S)

headline: Suharto's Son-in-Law, a Much-Feared General, Is Ousted
abstract: Indonesian military discharges Lieut Gen Prabowo Subianto, son-in-law of former Pres Suharto; Prabowo, one of Suharto's most feared generals, has been implicated in abduction and torture of political dissidents; photo (M)

headline: Revision Offered On Sex Bias Pact
abstract: Smith Barney Inc and lawyers for women who sued firm for sex discrimination propose amended settlement to Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley, who rejected their previous agreement; Smith Barney offers to let judge, rather than an arbitrator, decide disputes over how money for Smith Barney's affirmative action program for women should be spent (S)

headline: Rail Services Acquisition
abstract: Progress Rail Services Corp, Florida Progress Corp unit, to acquire most of Kershaw Manufacturing Co (S)g

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 1998: A Year Emerging Markets Seem Synonymous With Anguish
abstract: Market Place column says collapse in world's emerging stock markets has been breathtaking; notes that not since these markets began to attract strong investor interest at end of 1980's have they had such sharp decline; says plunge over last year, worldwide, outranks that during Mexican peso crisis of 1994-95 and Persian Gulf War of 1990-91; also says that without rally, August will be worst month for stock markets in developing economies since 1988; notes near panic selling in disregard of country's economic fundamentals is causing many investors and stock analysts to reconsider whether these markets are even viable for long-term investor (M)

headline: No Crowd for One-Stop Shopping
abstract: Article on apparent investor distrust in life-style and life-cycle mutual funds; graphs (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (M)

headline: Devastation From Explosion Permeates Kenyans' Lives
abstract: Impact of American Embassy bombing, in which at least 247 Kenyans died and 5,000 were hurt, is spreading from Nairobi across nation; mourners gather at park where lists of dead and wounded are posted; many of dead who worked in and around embassy served as breadwinners for extended families; businesses are also suffering, with insurers refusing to cover blast losses; Pres Daniel arap Moi's reputation for corruption seen obstacle to reconstruction aid; photo (M)/

headline: MacManus Loses Out In SBC Consolidation
abstract: SBC Communications has consolidated consumer advertising for its Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell units at ad agencies GSD&M and Goodby, Silverstein & Partners; St Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications is elimated from company's roster after almost 30 years (S)

headline: Japan Stocks Fall 2%, but Rebound From a 12-Year Low
abstract: Stock markets around Asia nose-dive in early trading on Aug 28, as investors fear that deep Russian economic crisis will hinder economic growth in West and slow recovery in Far East; in Japan, benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues plunges 621 points, or 4.3 percent, before recouping to stand down 2 percent by midday; elsewhere, key index in Singapore is off three-tenths of percent, in South Korea it is down 2.87 percent, and in Australia it is down 2.86 percent; Prime Min Keizo Obuchi of Japan says he hopes Russia's problems will not have major impact on world economy (M)

headline: Beyond Personal Faults, The Power of the Office
abstract: Pres Clinton has lost personal stature with many of his fellow leaders and ordinary people around world since investigations into his private life and his admission of inappropriate relationship with former White House intern, but he retain in full the authority and power conferred on him by Presidency; leaders everywhere say his position as leader of world's most powerful economy and only military superpower makes him indispensable in dealing with international problems, such as turmoil in Russia; some Europeans believe visit to Russia during economic and political turmoil is useless, but many agree that worst outcome of Russian crisis would be abandonment by Moscow of commitment to democracy and to free-market economy; many say Clinton is still capable of conveying that West will continue its support if Russia keeps trying (M)

headline: Ketchum Takes The Grand Prize
abstract: Ketchum Adverising takes top honors, winning $100,000 grand prize, in Athena Awards competition sponsored by Newspaper Association of America for creative advertising in newspapers (S)

headline: Web Hears You Knocking But You Can't Come In
abstract: Internet users are often unable to access a particular Web site, and there are numerous reasons why; Diagram of common types of connection messages and what can be done to avoid some of them (M)

headline: G.O.P., IN SWITCH, BACKS MORE FUNDS TO SHORE UP I.M.F.
abstract: House Appropriations subcommittee approves $3.5 billion for International Monetary Fund as Republicans grow worried that economic crises overseas may spread to US; House majority leader, Dick Armey, harsh foe of IMF, virtually concedes fight; $3.5 billion is far below $17.9 billion requested by Clinton Administration, but members of panel signal that they recognize urgency of agency's need for more financing; Asian financial crisis threatens US agricultural exports, intensifying pressure on Republicans to drop objections to fund (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices fall; August crude oil falls 58 cents, to $13.92 a barrel; graphs table (S)

headline: Does a Roach Motel Have 5-Star Potential?
abstract: BancAmerica Robertson Stephens analyst Elizabeth Silverman suggests investors should look toward biotechnology sector for stocks that performed poorly in initial public offerings; drawing (M)

headline: Novartis Says Sales Rose 2.3% in 2d Quarter
abstract: Novartis AG says second-quarter sales rose 2.3 percent and predicts 'marked increase' in full-year net income'; sales rise to 8.58 billion Swiss francs ($5.72 billion) from 8.39 billion francs a year earlier (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Web Company Rides Initial-Offering Wave
abstract: Broadcast.com president, Mark Cuban, comments on wild success of company's July 16 initial public stock offering; photo (S)

headline: Public and Private Debt Issues Set to Be Offered This Week
abstract: In the Treasury's schedule of financing this week are today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as a 52-week bill being auctioned on Thursday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.91 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.00 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 5.04 percent.

headline: A New Worldwide Warning For Americans to Be Cautious
abstract: US issues new worldwide warning to Americans and diplomatic personnel to exercise much greater caution than usual, following cruise missile attacks against suspected terrorist targets in Afghanistan and Sudan; steps by US to remove nonessential diplomatic employees and families from vulnerable embassies following August 7 bombings in Kenya and Tanzania discussed (M)

headline: Lowe and Grey Expand In Health Care Field
abstract: Lowe Group acquires Grob Health & Science and Azure Advertising for its Lowe Health Care and will rename them Lowe Grob and Lowe Azure; Grey Advertising merges its Grey Health Care Group and health care practice of GCI Group into GCI Health Care, under GCI Group; names Ilyssa Levins to head combined unit as chairwoman and chief creative officer; names Bob Pearson executive vice president and managing director of unit (S)

headline: A Mixed Verdict on Texas H.M.O. Law
abstract: Federal Judge Vanessa D Gilmore upholds provision of new Texas law that lets patients sue health maintenance organizations and other insurers for malpractice; strikes down provision to let patients appeal to independent panel when their employee health plan decides treatment is unnecessary; rules in suit by Aetna Life Insurance Co and its Texas unit (M)

headline: A.I.G. Will Put $1.35 Billion Into Blackstone
abstract: American International Group Inc will invest $1.35 billion in Blackstone Group, private New York merchant bank, raising prospect of considerable future cooperation between two companies as traditional barriers between insurance and investment banking continue to erode; AIG is paying $150 million of money to acquire 7 percent limited partnership stake in Blackstone, while remainder, estimated $1.2 billion, will be invested in Blackstone's private equity partnerships, real estate funds and other ventures; AIG's 7 percent stake in Blackstone replaces $100 million that Nikko Securities Inc of Japan had invested in Blackstone in 1988 (M)

headline: Accounting Giant Hires Two Agencies
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers names two advertising agencies to handle domestic and worldwide brand advertsiging jointly for accounting firm; agencies, both owned by Interpublic Group of Companies Inc, are Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus and Ammirati Puris Lintas; Price Waterhouse's agency had been McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising (S)

headline: Workers Bar Hyundai Plant Reopenings
abstract: Workers block attempt by Hyundai Motor Co to reopen factories in South Korea that had been closed for more than a week; production lines remain idle as 2,600 riot police ring five Hyundai factories in southern port city of Ulsan; more than 10,000 union members hold rally at Ulsan headquarters, vowing to stay away from work until management scraps layoff plans (S)

headline: Briton Hanged in 1953 Is Finally Exonerated
abstract: Britain's highest court overturns conviction of Derek Bentley, who was hanged at age of 19 in London in 1953 for murder of a police officer; court rules that trial judge had presented such a one-sided case to jury that Bentley had been denied fair trial he was entitled to; Bentley's family has been pressing Government for reversal for last 45 years; photos (M)

headline: 'I Sinned,' He Says In Apology That Includes Lewinsky : Clinton Vows He Will Stay and Fight
abstract: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton declared somberly Friday that "I have sinned," in a speech so emotional and abject  including his first public apology to Monica Lewinsky and her family  that it brought a group of clergymen to their feet.

headline: Media Talk; German Book Office Is Set Up in New York
abstract: Germany and German Publishers and Booksellers Association have set up German book office in New York to spur sales of English-language rights for translated German books; officers of German media conglomerates that own top United States trade publishing houses are reluctant to join group's board; photo (M)

headline: U.S. to Change Strategy in Narcotics Fight in Colombia
abstract: United States Government shifts course and agrees to help new administration of Pres Andres Pastrana in financing program to help Colombia's coca growers switch to legal crops; US had in past ruled out such aid for Colombia, citing distrust of previous administration of Pres Ernesto Samper and rebel dominance of coca-growing regions (M)

headline: Elite Mexican Drug Officers Said to Be Tied to Traffickers
abstract: American officials say ambitious effort to overhaul Mexico's corrupt law-enforcement system has been thrown into turmoil by disclosure that top investigators of elite American-trained police unit may have ties to drug traffickers; lie-detector tests administered by American experts at Mexican Government request have implicated most of unit's senior officials, raising concern that data shared with unit may have been compromised; photo (M)

headline: Cautious Buyers, Prowling for Bargains, Lift Dow 90.11
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 90.11 points, or 1.1 percent, at 8,552.96; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rises 15.24 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,084.22; Nasdaq composite index climbs 32.83 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,825.53; graph on fluctuations in Dow Jones industrial average; chart (M)

headline: New Agreement Would Allow Joint Exercises and Visits by Warships : U.S. Pushes Manila on Military Pact
abstract: MANILA  The United States sought ratification Monday of an agreement with Manila that would open the way for resumption of large-scale joint military exercises and visits by U.S. warships, six years after the last American bases in the Philippines were shut.

headline: Equity Residential to Acquire Merry Land for Stock and Debt
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust, real-estate investment trust headed by Samuel Zell, is acquiring Merry Land and Investment Co for $1.17 billion in stock as well as $656 million in debt and $270 million in preferred stock (S)

headline: Programming Lessons for Play
abstract: New toy called Logiblocs is designed to let children figure out concepts behind programming computers on their own, minus computer jargon, as they build burglar alarms and lighthouses; Logiblocs is being used in 2,000 British primary schools; it is intended for children 4 to 14; photo (S)

headline: Indonesians Visit U.S. Seeking Help With Debt
abstract: Indonesian Government officials ask international lenders to repackage up to $9 billion of debt, as country's economy worsens; official of International Monetary Fund says he is confident fund would release about $1 billion in aid to country next week; it is uncertain what other lenders and investors will do; Indonesia expects its economy to contract about 13 percent this year, first time economy has shrunk sine 1963; World Bank forecasts that 50 million of country's 200 million people could fall below poverty line by end of year; damage wrought by collapse of Indonesia's currency has been so severe that senior World Bank official said country faces economic crisis unparalleled in post-World War II era (M)

headline: Invasion of the Land Snatchers
abstract: H Wayne Huizenga, Roger Penske and Frank and Kathy Lee Gifford are among latest of famously rich to buy costly homes on Nantucket; photo (S)

headline: Marne-la-Vallee Journal; Mouse No More, It's Militant Mickey
abstract: French employees who play Mickey Mouse and Pluto and other Disney characters at Disneyland Paris have been on picket lines for nearly two weeks, striking for better pay; picketing outside main gate in Marne-la-Vallee is carried out so as not to disrupt park's cheerful operations; are taking place at time when Euro Disney expects to report profit for third consecutive summer, after starting heavily in red in 1992; map; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Plans To Spin Off Parts Division
abstract: General Motors Corp announces plans to spin off auto parts subsidiary, Delphi Automotive Systems, to its shareholders next year, a move that could reignite labor troubles that led to nearly eight-week-long strike; United Automobile Workers union reacts furiously; GM chairman-chief executive John F Smith Jr says GM wants to be company that assembles and markets cars, but does not necessarily make large proportion of parts inside (M)

headline: Talk, Type, Read E-Mail
abstract: Multitasking, word describing how a microprocessor keeps many computer programs running at the same time, has lately become way of life for many Americans; inundated with information and prone to equate productivity with pleasure, many people are becoming adept at simultaneously applying themselves to several computing and communications tasks; photos of Marc Prensky at his work station and Adam Gwosdof talking on one pay telephone while retrieving voice mail from another (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.48   5.64        3-month T-bills   4.89   4.92   5.10        6-month T-bills   4.95   4.96   5.14        10-yr. T-infl.   3.82   3.82   3.54        10-yr. T-note   5.37   5.40   6.32        30-yr. headline: DOBSON COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY SYGNET WIRELESS
abstract: Dobson Communications Corp agrees to buy Sygnet Wireless Inc for $337.5 million in cash and to assume $310 million in debt (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: STORM OVER WALL STREET /Page 7/  For three successful fund managers, the market correction is a time to pick up shares on the cheap. By Noelle Knox.    STORM OVER WALL STREET /Page 8/  The shelters that defensive investors usually seek have proved porous. Value stock-picking may be the best redoubt. By Sana Siwolop.

headline: NEWS WATCH; Even Smaller Notebooks Coming to Market
abstract: At least eight personal computer makers are planning to exhibit their new 'Jupiter-class' mini-notebook computers at annual Microsoft Professional Developer Conference on Oct 12; Jupiter is code name for windows CE 3.0, and is also generic term for new generation of portables that are smaller than conventional subnotebook computers but larger than palm-size computers (S)

headline: Accounting Board Pulls Back on Stock Plans
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board steps away from proposal that threatened to end certain lucrative employee stock plans; rule relates to stock purchase plans in which employees can buy company stock at discount of more than 15 percent; board's proposal had drawn controversy because it was aimed at stock plans that under Federal law must benefit all employees; in 1994, board backed away from similar proposal that would have made it more costly for companies to grant stock options--perk given only to top executives (M)

headline: Imaging in Orthodontics; Straighter Teeth in Mere Moments, at Least on Screen
abstract: Increasing number of orthodontists and oral surgeons are using computer imaging to let patients envision treatment results; respond as technology improves and costs drop; latest technology 'morphs' picture of patient's face to show how braces or surgery will change appearance; photo (M)

headline: Fueled by Drought and War, Starvation Returns to Sudan
abstract: Famine is worsening and has taken significant number of lives in southern Sudan; more than million people are said to face food shortages, despite huge airlift of more than 12,000 tons of food over last three months; famine was born of drought and overpopulation, and also incessant civil war and cold calculations of combatants, who have used both hunger and relief operation for their own tactical ends; photos; map (L)

headline: Stock Options at Hughes
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp is giving about 14,000 employees stock options to promote teamwork after its reorganization into communications company by its parent, General Motors Corp (S)

headline: If the Tune Is Beethoven, Surely That's My Pager
abstract: Philips Consumer Communications introduces new pager that alerts owners with nine-note melody of their choosing; photo (S)

headline: Gemstar Move Against United Video's Bid
abstract: Gemstar International Group Ltd announces shareholder rights program aimed at making $2.8 billion hostile takeover bid by United Video Satellite Group more difficult to complete (S)

headline: Philips to Help Build Chip Factory in Asia
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics NV to join Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and EDB Investments of Singapore to build $1.2 billion semiconductor plant in Singapore; Philips will own 48 percent of venture, with Taiwan Semiconductor owning 32 percent and EDB Investments owning 20 percent (S)

headline: A Pressman of Barneys Is Moving to Lauren
abstract: Bonnie Pressman, wife of Gene Pressman, whose grandfather founded Barneys New York, says she will step down as executive vice president and director of women's fashions to become senior vice president and women's fashion director at Polo Ralph Lauren Corp; Judy Collinson, general merchandise manager for women's division at Barneys, will replace Ms Pressman (S)

headline: France Blocks Coke's Bid For Orangina
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's plan to acquire French brand Orangina, unit of Pernod-Ricard SA, is blocked after French Government rejects merger, saying it will hurt consumers and give Coke too much dominance in French market; in February, Pepsico Inc filed objection to takeover with French Government, contending that it would stifle competition; it is unclear whether Coke, which has been under pressure from French Government to guarantee jobs and make other concessions to win approval, will pursue negotiations; Pepsi-Cola spokesman Brad Shaw says his company is pleased with decision (M)

headline: Northwest Says Its Final Offer Really Is Final
abstract: Northwest Airlines sets stage for what could be long stand off, refusing to alter dollar value of final offer made to pilots before they struck airline; fears that to do otherwise would adversely impact negotiations with about 45,000 other union workers (M)

headline: PHOTOBITION OF BRITAIN TO BUY KATZ DIGITAL IN CASH DEAL
abstract: Katz Digital Technologies Inc to be acquired by Photobition Group PLC for $50 million in cash (S)

headline: In Videotape, Ousted Deputy Blasts Mahathir For Corruption
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR  In a videotape that was recorded before his arrest and broadcast throughout East Asia on Thursday, Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's ousted deputy prime minister, leveled broad allegations of corruption against Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

headline: Rebels Closing In on Blacked-Out Congo Capital
abstract: Rebels knock out all electrical power to Kinshasa, Congo, and tighten their hold on a strategic region outside the capital city; observers say that if rebels gain control of supply routes, capital could fall with little or no fighting; map; photo of new recruits being enlisted for Pres Laurent Kabila's forces (M)

headline: IN BREAKTHROUGH, MEXICAN OFFICIAL TESTIFIES IN TEXAS
abstract: Mexican law-enforcement officials allow Adrian Carrera Fuentes, imprisoned former head of country's national police, to testify before grand jury in US about drug payoffs at high levels of Mexican Government, a ground-breaking collaboration between both countries; he reportedly tells Federal grand jury in Houston that he collected nearly $2 million in drug bribes in 1993 and 1994 and turned money over to former colleague, Mario Ruiz Massieu; American investigators say Carrerra's account could be evidence they have long sought in frustrating effort to prosecute Ruiz Massieu, who was arrested in New Jersey in 1995, or to extradite him to Mexico to face charges there; are hopeful testimony and other new witnesses may eventually force him to testify himself about allegations of corruption in inner circle of former Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari; discovery of $130 million in Swiss bank accounts of Salinas's elder brother, Raul, has led to corruption investigations in Europe, US and Mexico; photos (M)

headline: A Record Pace For Viagra Sales
abstract: IMS Health says prescriptions for Pfizer Inc's Viagra, drug to correct male impotence, totaled 2.9 million between April and June, enough for estimated sales of record $259.5 million; predicts United States sales will reach $1 billion in full year (S)

headline: Arafat Adds Ministers, but Defies Calls for a Cabinet Cleanup
abstract: Palestinian Authority chmn Yasir Arafat announces cabinet shuffle, but he defiantly keeps in place ministers whom lawmakers had wanted dismissed after allegations of mismanagement; appoints 10 additional ministers to what had been 18-member Executive Council (M)

headline: INTEL STOCK FALLS 4 PERCENT AS ANALYST LOWERS RATING
abstract: Shares of Intel Corp fall 4 percent after Merrill Lynch & Co analyst Tom Kurlak cuts his investment rating on company to 'neutral' from 'accumulate' (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Proposed Transmission Companies Could Reward Investors
abstract: Several Midwest utilities, using argument that extra electricity threatens to overload their systems, refuse to allow competitors to transmit power over their high-voltage lines; problem intensifies debate over how to restructure recently deregulated transmission business (M)

headline: Volvo May Buy Stake In Mexican Bus Maker
abstract: Volvo AB, world's second-largest bus maker, says it is in talks to buy stake in Mexicana de Autobuses SA, Mexico's biggest bus maker, with its British partner, Henlys Group PLC, to gain access to North American market (S)

headline: A Model Career Path For a Self-Starter
abstract: Profile of South Bronx resident Cesar Pacheco 3d, shot in chest during botched 1994 robbery attempt, who took truck driving lessons at Model Training Center, worked over-the-road for two years and now instructs other drivers; photo (M)

headline: PIERCE LEAHY BUYS FOUR RECORD-MANAGEMENT COMPANIES
abstract: Pierce Leahy Corp buys four records-management companies, Kestrel Data Management & Storage, Data Protection Services Inc, Bender Records Management and Keystone Records Storage, for $57 million in cash (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES, Oak Brook, Ill., a maker of plastic packaging for meat and cheese, said it would eliminate 350 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, in closing manufacturing operations in Chicago and eliminating administrative jobs.    PHYTOPHARM P.L.C.,  London, the drug maker, signed an agreement with Pfizer Inc. to develop a plant-derived obesity drug to tap the growing market for weight-loss treatments. Pfizer will pay Phytopharm as much as $39 million to develop the drug.

headline: Blast Suspect Held in U.S. And Is Said to Admit Role
abstract: Federal authorities bring suspect in bombings of United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania to United States, saying that he had admitted that he was trained at terror camps in Afghanistan run by Osama bin Laden, Saudi-born multimillionaire suspectged of having inspired, organized and financed bombings; suspect, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, arrives in New York and appears in court; another suspect, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, who provided one of first breaks in case, is expected to arrive in New York on August 28; al-'Owhali is said to have acknowleged that he rode as passenger in truck that carried massive bomb to embassy in Nairobi; photos of suspects and FBI Dir Louis Freeh, with State Sec Madeleine Albright and national security adviser Samuel Berger (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices fall more than 7 percent as concerns ease that port strike in Brazil will disrupt exports at a time of abundant supplies; coffee for September delivery falls 9.75 cents, to $1.245 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Marketers are at the top of their windups as they prepare pitches for McGwire and Sosa.
abstract: Race to cash in on Mark McGwire's 62d home run is already under way as marketers as disparate as Walt Disney Co and maker of baseball caps called Twins Enterprises scramble to celebrate his record; contest has not been as frenetic as other recent efforts to capitalize on athletic achievement; that is because McGwire and Sammy Sosa, other player vying for single-season home run mark, have been devoting far less time to marketing aspects of chase than to actual task facing them; estimates are that McGwire may land $2 million worth of deals and Sosa $1 million (M)

headline: In Slick Cyberfilm, 'Star Wars' Meets 'Cops'
abstract: Troops, Kevin Rubio's 10-minute movie on Star Wars themes, has become immensely popular as an underground film distributed at no cost on Internet; photo (M)

headline: Seeking to Expand, Korn Ferry Files for Initial Public Offering
abstract: Korn Ferry International, the giant executive search firm, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, the proceeds of which it plans to use to expand its business.    The company, which is based in Los Angeles, expects to raise about $230 million from the offering to repay debt, redeem preferred stock, expand to the Internet and make acquisitions, according to the filing.

headline: The Sellers? Hint: They Don't Live Around Here
abstract: More sellers than buyers. That's the glib explanation for why stocks couldn't keep a good head of steam going last week. After a fine showing on Tuesday, when the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 380 points, sellers took back the reins. The Dow ended the week mustering a 2 percent gain.    Where is all the selling coming from? Anecdotal reports have had institutional investors bailing while individuals hang tough in their portfolios. Robert Adler at AMG Data Services concurs, reporting that money continues to head into stock mutual funds, despite recent market volatility.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Energy prices retreat on forecasts that Hurricane Georges will bypass key Gulf of Mexico producing areas; crude oil falls 23 cents a barrel, to $15.75, natural gas ends little changed, losing early gain; graph; chart (S)

headline: BINKS SAMES TO SELL SOME ASSETS TO ILLINOIS TOOL
abstract: Binks Sames Corp to sell certain assets and product lines to Illinois Tool Works Inc for $80 million plus assumption of $26 million of debt (S)

headline: Palestinians Threatening To Withdraw From Talks
abstract: Prospect for new accord between Israel and Palestinians dims further as senior Palestinian offficials say they are prepared to pull out of peace talks unless Israel shows swift willingness to consider new ideas (M)

headline: Proud Sydney Is Aghast: Its Tap Water Is Unsafe
abstract: Water supply of Sydney, Australia, is declared unsafe after the parasites giardia and cryptosporidium are discovered in its largest treatment plant; news hurts pride of city that regards itself as perhaps the most livable on earth; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Time to Set The Millennium Clock
abstract: Budd Goldman, inventor in Mineola, NY, develops the Millennium Clock, desktop clock that counts down remaining hours, minutes and seconds until the arrival of Jan 1, 2000; has already sold a million millennium clocks, mostly to department stores and corporate clients; price is $24.95 each; clock photo (M)

headline: From Germany, Albright Escorts Home the Bodies of '10 Brave Americans'
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright escorts home from Germany bodies of 10 of 12 Americans killed in bombing of United States Embassy, Nairobi, Kenya; earlier visited Kenyan State Department employees and American staff member being treated at American military hospital, Landshut, Germany; met with Foreign Min Klaus Kinkel and thanked him for Germany's help (M)

headline: Amid a Downturn, Another Internet Company's Initial Offering Catches Fire
abstract: Investors clamor to buy stock of Geocities, despite falling stock market and fact that company has yet to prove it can make money by giving its two million members free pages on Internet's World Wide Web; Geocities shares close at $37.3125, more than double offering price of $17; that values company, which had loss on revenues of less than $5 million last year, at $1.1 billion (M)

headline: Successful Searching
abstract: Erik T Mueller letter on Sept 3 article offers simple tricks for searching Internet

headline: Aiming to Thwart Theft Behind the Counter
abstract: Retailers' efforts to thwart thefts by employees, particularly cashiers, discussed; employee theft has now eclipsed shoplifting as main cause of lost cash and merchandise; graph; surge linked to robust economy which compels stores to hire marginal workers and part-timers (M)

headline: In Seoul, Strong Currency Is a Concern
abstract: South Korea's currency, which plunged late in 1997, has risen so much against dollar in recent weeks that economists fear its strength is hurting efforts to revive economy; is up 38 percent against dollar in last six months; has gained largely because South Korean companies are importing so few raw materials and other goods there is little need to buy dollars to pay for imports (M)

headline: Kenyan Who Charged 4 Officials With Graft Is Suspended
abstract: John Harun Mwau, head of Kenya's new anticorruption authority, is suspended by Pres Daniel arap Moi after disagreement with Finance Min Simeon Nyachae in case that underscores how difficult it is to root out graft in Kenya; Moi suspends Mwau just four days after Mwau had filed charges against four high-ranking Treasury Dept officials, accusing them of scheme to evade $3.9 million in import duties on wheat and sugar (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY

headline: A Case Study In Instability Hurts Stocks
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 152.42 points, or 1.87 percent, to 8,001.99; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 23.37 points, or 2.19 percent, to 1,042.72, and Nasdaq composite index declines 39.93 points, or 2.27 percent, to 1,720.34; graph; chart (M)

headline: First Step for Social Security
abstract: Richard B Du Boff letter urges extending the 6.2 percent FICA tax to all income above the present ceiling of $68,400 in order to improve monthly Social Security benefits

headline: Agencies to Compete In Airtouch Review
abstract: Airtouch Cellular says it is searching for ad agency to handle creative portion of its coonsolidated account, which had previously been divided among six agencies in three regions (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.63   5.51   5.68        3-month T-bills   4.43   4.38   4.93        6-month T-bills   4.45   4.32   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.57   3.59   3.63        10-yr. T-note   4.58   4.57   6.09        30-yr. headline: Road to Seat At the U.N. Is Paved With Perks
abstract: Greece invites United Nations delegates to fly to Greece but insists that trip is not related to its campaign for a seat on Security Council, which is also sought by Canada and Netherlands; the Dutch like to think they can win the seat on their sober record for good international works, but they have hosted a cruise for delegates on the East River (M)

headline: In-House Competition From Web News Team
abstract: Cable channel E! Entertainment is in competition with its sister Web site E! Online (www.eonline.com); 55 full-time E! employees work on the Web site, 40 of whom are producing the content, such as updated news, gossip and Webcasts of movie premieres; site appears to be getting heavy traffic; Lee Masters, president and chief executive of E! Entertainment, says he did not intend E! site to compete with network so much as to complement it; says he intends for on-line site to have its own identity (M)

headline: F.C.C. Would Cut Call Cost Abroad
abstract: Federal Communications Commission approves draft proposal that could help cut cost of Americans' international phone calls; plan would give US and foreign phone companies more flexibility in some cases to negotiate terms for completing each other's calls (S)

headline: Greenspan's Hint of Rate Cut Sends Value of Dollar Down
abstract: Dollar falls 2 percent against Japanese yen and slumps against German mark after Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan suggests United States might cut interest rates in coming months (M)

headline: Clinton Vows to Help an Asia in Crisis
abstract: Pres Clinton arrives in Hong Kong Kong, one day after first anniversary of Hong Kong's return to Chinese rule; meets with Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive; says 'cronyism, corruption and overextended credit,' unchecked by competent financial regulation, are responsible for economic maelstrom now sweeping Asia and spreading to Hong Kong, plunging it into its deepest recession in decades; praises Hong Kong and China for being anchors of stability in region-wide economic storm; Clinton photo with Tung; map shows Clinton's itinerary (L)

headline: That Delicate Balance: What About the Dads?
abstract: Adrienne Tannenbaum letter on Aug 23 article on women balancing challenges of work and raising children urges that fathers be expected to share responsibilities (S)

headline: Auction of Kia Canceled After Low Bids
