abstract: Auction of two South Korean auto makers, Kia Motors Corp and its truck-making affiliate, Asia Motors Co Ltd, is canceled because none of four initial bids meet sellers' minimum price; most of world's 33 mass-production auto makers are losing money despite robust auto sales in North America and Europe; losing bids came from Ford Motor Co, Daewoo, Hyundai and Samsung; terms of auction go far beyond conventional sale to highest bidder, because some of Kia's largest creditor banks are themselves financially troubled and effectively controlled by South Korean Government; each bidder was required to submit business plan to maintain exports and invest more cash; American, European and Japanese auto makers fear that large numbers of low-priced Kia cars will be dumped on international markets, in possibly futile attempt to keep up with interest payments (M)

headline: Gingrich Questions Clinton's Policy on Iraqi Arms Inspection
abstract: House Speaker Newt Gingrich says resignation of William S Ritter Jr as senior American weapons inspector in Iraq, raises 'disturbing questions' about Pres Clinton's policy and suggests that Clinton has misled Congress about his commitment to uncovering the extent of Saddam Hussein's nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs (M)

headline: SYSTEM SOFTWARE PLANS TO TAKE A $120 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: System Software Associates Inc is expected to lose money and take $120 million charge in its third quarter and cut about 300 jobs, or 12 percent of its staff, in effort to become profitable (S)

headline: For Richer, for Poorer
abstract: Long-Term Capital Management partner Myron S Scholes is planning to marry Jan Blaustein next week; partner Robert C Merton has taken break from teaching at Harvard Business School this semester, but he will resume his duties in January (S)

headline: A Different Type Of Computer Monitor
abstract: Win What Where, Kennewick, Washington, software firm, has developed program that keeps record of every keystroke, mouse click and command; software permits third-party observers, such as employers, to record not just which Web sites employees browse, but also which programs they use, memos they write and E-mails they send; program costs $285 for each desktop computer in which it is installed (M)

headline: First Union Forming an Asset-Backed Unit
abstract: First Union Corp forms investment management unit specializing in securities backed by corporate loans or bonds; new unit is named First Union Institutional Debt Management Inc; Mark Mahoney is named president (S)

headline: Joint Document Management System for I.B.M. and Xerox
abstract: IBM and Xerox Corp will jointly market an officewide document management system, comprising Xerox's Document Centre line of digital products that do triple duty as printers, copiers and scanners, and IBM's Lotus suite of document management software (M)

headline: Communists Still Seeking True Identity
abstract: Even though Russia's Communist Party, largest in Parliament, contemptuously rejected for second time Pres Boris Yeltsin's choice of Viktor S Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister--demanding restoration of some of its old power and threatening to block new government--it is not clear to party members what needs to be done to alleviate economic and political crisis; some unreconstructed radicals yearn to oust Yeltsin's administration and restore monopolistic control of Soviet days, others want state control of major industries and banks but would leave part of private sector untouched; some are so house-trained that Yeltsin long ago invited them to join his Cabinet (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas futures rise; gas for Oct delivery rises 7.1 cents, to $1.783 for 1,000 cubic feet; graphs; table of commodities prices

headline: Massacres by Serbian Forces in 3 Kosovo Villages
abstract: Ethnic Albanians in Gornji Obrinje and neighboring villages bury 34 people who were killed on Sept 26, two days after villages came under siege by Yugoslav Army and Serbian forces; killings appear to show that forces of Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, have been conducting campaign of terror and destruction against ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo that is intended to intimidate them, but which appears instead to be inspiring even stronger defiance; map; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: X-CEED INC.,  New York, a provider of corporate travel services and data to the health care industry, acquired the privately held Zabit & Associates Inc., Sausalito, Calif., an integrated communications company, for $28.2 million in cash and stock.    COGENERATION CORP. OF AMERICA,  Minneapolis, a producer of electricity and thermal energy for industry, agreed to buy a 10-megawatt power plant in Oklahoma from Mid-Continent Power Co. for about $25 million.

headline: Top Opposition Leader in Malaysia Is Jailed in Sex Case
abstract: Anwar Ibrahim, top opposition leader and rising star in Malaysian politics, is jailed after long, bitter struggle against his one-time mentor, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad; had led mass rally calling for Mahathir's resignation; Ibrahim's arrest, apparently on charges of sexual indecency, follows his September 2 ouster as Deputy Prime Min; photo (M)

headline: In a Maze of Bomb Rubble, One Family Managed a Remarkable Reunion
abstract: James Huskey, political officer at US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, his wife Joanne Grady-Huskey and their two young children survived terrorist bombing at embassy (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: YEN STRENGTHENS.  The dollar plunged to an 11-week low against the yen in Asian trading before recovering later as United States stocks rose. In New York, the dollar traded at 139.25 yen, down from 140.78 yen on Monday.

headline: A.M.D., Motorola to Develop Copper Chips
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc and Motorola Inc will announce alliance to develop new semiconductors; industry analysts expect it to involve use of new copper technology to make faster chips, to compete with International BusinessMachines Corp's own copper technology, announced in September; use of copper is expected to become widespread as chips become smaller and more powerful (S)

headline: UAL Names New President In Wake of Unions' Actions
abstract: United Airlines' parent company, UAL Corp, names James A Goodwin, longtime senior executive, as its new president and chief operating officer, only a few days after his predecessor, John A Edwardson, is forced out by carrier's powerful unions; appointment immediately vaults Goodwin into race to succeed Gerald Greenwald, UAL's chairman and chief executive, whose five-year employment contract expires next summer (M)

headline: Apple Endorses Some Achievers Who 'Think Different'
abstract: Advertising column on Apple Computer Inc's campaign featuring some of world's most-admired achievers under slogan, 'Think different'; goal of campaign is to further polish once-tarnished Apple brand name, asserting that company nurtures creativity by behaving as unconventionally as accomplished thinkers and doers like Albert Einstein, Bob Dylan and Muhammad Ali; ads, created by TBWA Chiat/Day, have won several industry awards and Allen Olivo, marketing official at Apple, credits campaign with major role in recent improvement in Apple's fortunes; photos (M)

headline: CADENCE SAYS IT WILL PAY $260 MILLION FOR AMBIT DESIGN
abstract: Cadence Design Systems Inc, which makes software to speed design of microprocessors, to buy Ambit Design Systems Inc for $260 million (S)

headline: An annual survey finds relations deteriorating between clients and their agencies.
abstract: Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations conducted by Nancy L Salz Consulting finds relationship between agencies and advertisers is deteriorating; surveys for 1996 and 1997 had brought surprisingly better responses from executives at agencies and client companies when asked about nature of their relations (M)

headline: Bear Stearns Reports Rise in 4th Quarter
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies says earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter rose nearly 47 percent; profit rose to $239.3 million from $162.9 million in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: U.N.'s Impatience Grows Over Afghan Restrictions on Aid Workers
abstract: Lakhdar Brahimi, special United Nations envoy for Afghanistan, says patience is running out with Taliban, militant Islamic movement that controls most of country; says its disruptive stream of edicts has jeopardized all international aid programs there; Taliban renews ultimatum to nearly all private aid organizations to move collectively into abandoned and broken down student hostel outside capital of Kabul, or leave country (M)

headline: Hyundai Offers Early Retirement
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co of South Korea to begin another early retirement program as part of push to cut work force by 20 percent (S)

headline: Analysts Warn of Dangers to Brazil's Economy
abstract: Economists warn that despite strengths of Brazil's economy, investor flight from emerging markets could plunge region into decline; stocks prices are dropping sharply, spurred in part by downgrading of nation's bonds and notes; International Monetary Fund director, Michel Camdessus, says many of problems faced by Brazil and Latin America stem from panic elsewhere in world, but calls situation 'dangerous'; Finance Min Pedro Malan has ruled out devaluation and nation reportedly spends heavily to defend currency (M)

headline: Stocks Surge As Fed Offers Hint on Rates
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average surges 3.26 percent, as Federal Reserve officials hint strongly at interest-rate cut to arrest global economic skid that is threatening to turn into worldwide recession; more than half of market's gain comes in final hour of trading, after Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan renews investors' hopes of rate cut; Dow Jones industrial average gains 257.21 points, to close at 8,154.41; Nasdaq composite index is up 3.68 percent, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 3.54 percent; stocks show strong gains in Europe, Latin America and Asia; graph; chart (M)

headline: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE REACTION -- U.S. Raids Provoke Fury in Muslim World; Russia Is Critical
abstract: Russia denounces United States for its cruise-missile attacks on Afghanistan and Sudan; but it also declares attacks will have no affect on Pres Clinton's trip to Moscow 10 days from now (S)

headline: World News Briefs; 3-Cultures Foundation Opened by Shimon Peres
abstract: Former Prime Min Shimon Peres of Israel inaugurates Foundation for the Three Cultures in the Mediterranean, Seville, Spain; organization aims to promote cooperation among Jews, Christians and Muslims (S)

headline: World Bank, A Bit Nervous, Resumes Aid To Indonesia
abstract: World Bank resumes aid to Indonesia for first time since Pres Suharto was forced from office; approves $1 billion loan and predicts that major industrial nations will soon announce another $6 billion in aid; $1 billion loan is part of $4.5 billion contribution from World Bank that was promised earlier this year (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.42   5.50        3-month T-bills   4.95   5.00   5.11        6-month T-bills   5.04   5.02   5.17        10-yr. T-infl.   3.77   3.77   3.66        10-yr. T-note   5.46   5.50   6.25        30-yr. T-bond   5.71   5.74   6.54        Telephone bd.   7.16   7.15   7.59        Municipal bds.   5.26   5.27   5.49          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Some new fashion campaigns have gone retro-happy.
abstract: Some fashion advertising campaigns are lifting scenes from 1950's television shows that are meant to reflect that happy days are here again; campaigns by Kenar Enterprises Ltd and Barney's Inc discussed; photo (M)

headline: Tiny Neighbor Gives South African Army Rude Surprise
abstract: South African forces, entering tiny mountainous kingdom of Lesotho in bid to bring quick end to political turmoil, meet surprisingly fierce resistance from Lesotho soldiers rebelling against Government; some 30 people are killed, including as many as 10 South Africans; presence of South African soldiers sets off day of looting and burning that destroys much of capital, Maseru; fighting continues around city; South Africa says it sent over 600 soldiers at request of Prime Min Pakalitha Mosisili, who feared coup; map; photo (M)

headline: Harvard's Endowment Has A Flow of Crimson Ink
abstract: Harvard University's endowment has been decimated over past 10 weeks, as $1.3 billion was shaved off its $13 billion portfolio; Jack R Meyer, presdient of Harvard Management Co, comments (S)

headline: PRATT & WHITNEY TO ELIMINATE 900 JOBS IN CANADA
abstract: Pratt & Whitney to cut 900 jobs in Canada as it trims research and development efforts (S)

headline: Executive Quits at Saks
abstract: Saks Inc says Jeanne B Daniel has resigned as executive vice president of merchandising for its flagship Saks Fifth Avenue stores; Philip B Miller, chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue, will take over her responsibilities (S)

headline: DAVEL BOARD VOTES TO END DEAL TO ACQUIRE PHONETEL
abstract: Davel Communications Group Inc says its board voted to end its agreement to buy pay phone operator Phonetel Technologies Inc for $51 million in stock (S)

headline: U.S. and India Meet on Standoff Over Nuclear Tests and Sanctions
abstract: US and Indian officials hold talks in New Delhi to ease standoff that developed after India carried out underground nuclear tests in May; officials on both sides say there were no breakthroughs that could lead to early end of remaining American sanctions; most important ban, on Indian grain purchases, has already been waived (M)

headline: A Sales Pitch Right Under Your Nose
abstract: Jordan's Furniture stores in Massachusetts and New Hampshire are among many retail stores that encourage purchases with aromas, pine in country-style section and bubblegum in children's area; photo; suitability is all-important, which is why Victoria's Secret does not smell like pot roast, and Thomas Pink shirtmaker fills shops with aroma of 'line-dried linen' (S)

headline: International Officials Say Elections in Bosnia Were a Success
abstract: International oficials laud recent parliamentary and legislative elections in Bosnia as success and tribute to progress toward democracy, despite glitches that may have left voters skeptical over outcome; elections are crucial to Western hopes of replacing hard-line nationalist politicians with moderate leaders; photo (M)

headline: Three Marketers Select Agencies
abstract: Cars.com, Internet automotive data base service, names Stein Rogan & Partners as first agency to handle its on-line and traditional advertising account; Weight Watchers International names Seiden Group to handle account of its weight-loss centers, which Seiden had handled on project basis; Texas Department of Economic Development names McCann-Erickson Southwest to handle its Texas tourism account, which had been handled by GSD&M (S)

headline: South Korea Cuts Bank Loan Rate
abstract: South Korean central bank says it will cut its discount rate to 3 percent from 5 percent, in hope this will spur lending to small and medium-size companies (S)

headline: 2 Top Family Business Groups Cede Large Stakes to Indonesia
abstract: Indonesia says Salim and Gajah Tunggal groups agree to settle $7 billion in debt at failed banks they control by ceding to Government shares in almost all their global investments; move may lead to realignment of commercial power in Indonesia, with two dominant families--in particular, the Nusalims, who control Gajah Tunggal--likely to lose their firm grip on parts of country's business; agreement is first major step toward recovering 141 trillion rupiah ($14 billion) that Indonesia pumped into banking system in last year after plunge in value of rupiah and soaring interest rates pushed most of country's banks to brink of collapse; Salim family's Bank Central Asia and Nursalim family's Bank Dagang Nasional Indonesia are country's largest debtors; owners of 12 other banks have failed to reach deal with Government and face possible criminal prosecution (M)

headline: Yeltsin, in Reversal, Will Attend Rite for Czar and Family
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin reverses himself, saying he will attend elaborate and much-debated interment of Czar Nicholas II, most of his family and four servants in Czar's imposing riverside fortress in St Petersburg; after Yeltsin changes his mind, leaders of upper house of Parliament say they will also send official delegation; lower house, the Duma, is ignoring event, and Duma's Communist leader claims Yeltsin is acting under political pressure from his advisers, charge Yeltsin's spokesman denies; photo (M)

headline: At Hong Kong Airport, Reputations Are Lost, Too
abstract: HONG KONG  The first home-grown crisis in Hong Kong under Chinese rule  the vastly expensive and malfunctioning new airport  is threatening to cost much more than the government has estimated and may also hurt the political future of at least one prominent government figure.

headline: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY U.S. RIGHTS TO 3 DRUGS
abstract: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc will acquire US rights to three lines of birth control drugs produced by G D Searle & Co for $120 million in cash; it is buying rights to Tri-Norinyl, Norinyl and Brevicon (S)

headline: Another Kosovo Village, Burned Down by Serbs
abstract: Serbian security forces torch homes of ethnic Albanians in village of Polcic in Kosovo Province in methodical system of destruction, repeated during past three months, to crush Kosovo Liberation Army, which is fighting for province's independence; map; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     None

headline: RESCUING RUSSIA: A special report.; The Bailout of the Kremlin: How U.S. Pressed the I.M.F.
abstract: Special Report: Rescuing Russia describes how Clinton Administration pressed International Monetary Fund to reverse itself, leading IMF to announce bailout package for Russia that will provide $17.1 billion in new loans to beleaguered nation over next 18 months; Clinton Adm was driving force behind reversal, impelled by specter of Russia's financial collapse; United States Treasury officials were worried that while negotiations with Russians dragged on over forcing real economic change, political peril to Govt of Pres Boris N Yeltsin was growing; they pressed fund to double amount of money it was willing to lend to Russia, even though it depleted IMF's own resources for fighting economic contagion that is spreading beyond Asia; chronology of events leading to finanical rescue package for Russia; photos; charts (L)

headline: Qaddafi Says 'Negotiation' Is Needed on Lockerbie Suspects
abstract: Col Muammar el-Qaddafi says that Libya would have to negotiate certain guarantees before he could feel confident about turning over for trial two suspects wanted in 1988 bombing of Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, interview with CNN, Tripoli; is seen obsessed with fears of British and American trickery; experts say he may be afraid that two suspects, who are intelligence agents, will be kidnapped by West or pumped at trial for mor information than he wants to see made public; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: FLEMING COS., Oklahoma City, said Robert E. Stauth, its chairman and chief executive, had retired.    JONES APPAREL GROUP INC., New York, a maker of women's name-brand apparel, said Herbert J. Goodfriend, its vice chairman and a director, had resigned.

headline: As the Yen Falls, Markets Fear Japanese Savers Will Look Elsewhere
abstract: Ordinary investors are fleeing to other currencies as yen falls to new lows against dollar, heightening concern that fundamental shift in sentiment is under way against yen; among factors mentioned by currency traders as immediate causes of yen's fall are faltering stock market, doubts about new Government's commitment to dealing with problems in banking sector and possibility that China might devalue its currency; biggest worry among currency traders is that yen is reaching level where Japanese housewives, who control vast pool of savings, are swapping their yen for dollars, German marks and pounds sterling (M)

headline: China Loosens Controls Over Foreign Banks
abstract: China's central bank, People's Bank of China, announces that it will allow foreign banks to start yuan operations in Shenzhen for first time and that it will license more foreign banks to take deposits in yuan and lend out yuan in Shanghai's Pudong district; central bank also says it plans to increase limit on yuan-denominated working capital allowed for foreign banks to 100 million yuan ($12 million) from 30 million yuan, to ease controls on interbank borrowing and to allow foreign banks to engage in yuan-based consortium lending; analysts say new measures are sign that China's Government recognizes benefits that foreign competition can bring to financial industry (S)

headline: SMITHFIELD FOODS BUYS FRENCH PACKAGED-MEAT CONCERN
abstract: Smithfield Foods Inc acquires Societe Bretonne de Salaisons, French packaged-meat company; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Judge Permits State Charges To Apply in Securities Trial
abstract: New York State Supreme Court Justice Edward J McLaughlin rules in support of approach taken by Manhattan District Attorney Robert M Morgenthau in prosecuting securities cases, allowing state insider-trading charges to proceed against traders Robert Breed, Jennifer D'Antoni, Mark Nogid and Vincent Napolitano; McLaughlin, in rejecting defense motions to stop case, says state prosecutions are not pre-empted by Federal securities laws and that District Attorney's office can prosecute insider trading cases under Martin Act, as well as under state's general business laws, as it is seeking to do; defendants are charged with trading on insider information provided by Marisa Baridis, who obtained confidential market-sensitive information about companies through her work as compliance officer first at Smith Barney Inc, now part of Travelers Group, and then at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co, now Morgan Stanley Dean Witter (M)

headline: The Allies Of Samper Eye Asylum
abstract: As court investigation opens in Colombia into 1996 decision by Congress to clear then-Pres Ernesto Samper of criminal charges, group that championed him in Congress is trying to obtain asylum in Europe; in meetings over several weeks, 17 senators and deputies, led by Martha Catalina Daniels, map plan to request asylum in Germany, Britain, France and Italy on gound of political persecution (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- If the Price Isn't Right, Just Change It; Why Companies Tinker With Options Packages
abstract: Slashing the price of an executive or employee stock option when the stock price declines appears to be more widespread than even critics of the pratice imagined; companies that do it say they risk losing talented people if they cannot offer potentially lucrative options; new data show that once companies reprice stock options, there is a good chance they will do it again, becoming serial repricers; critics, who include institutional investors whose holdings are diluted by stock options, note that stock options are supposed to be a reward for a performance that causes stock price to rise; repricing of stock options at Ascend Communications discussed; chart shows companies that have changed price of their stock options at least three times in last decade in response to drop in share prices; drawing (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Steel Trader's Woes Hurt Japan Stocks
abstract: Japanese stocks are lower after Okura & Co, trading company that sells steel products and machinery, says it will seek protection from creditors; company has $2.1 billion in liabilities and its bankruptcy would be second-largest in Japan this year; at midday recess in trading, Nikkei index of 225 issues is down 100.55 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 15,290.86; in early trading in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index is down 100.18 points, or 1.3 percent, at 7,642.35 (S)

headline: Compressed Data; P.G.A. Earns Points With Internet Broadcast
abstract: Professional Golfers' Assn will broadcast final half of AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am tournament on Web; it was rained out five months ago (S)

headline: Ford July Car and Truck Sales Off 4.3% Amid Discount Curb
abstract: Ford Motor Co's domestic car and truck sales fell 4.3 percent in July as lower car sales and cutback in price discounts offset modest rise in demand for trucks; truck sales rose 5.2 percent from period a year earlier, to 214,235 vehicles, while car sales fell 16.8 percent, to 128,948; Volkswagen AG's American sales more than doubled, to 24,056 vehicles from 11,301 in July 1997; Mercedes unit of Daimler-Benz reports 53 percent rise in sales and Volvo says sales dropped 18 percent (M)

headline: How to Crack The File Code
abstract: Q. Can you tell me what some of those three-letter abbreviations mean on the end of file names in Windows? I would be less afraid of the system if I knew what some of these cryptic things meant.    A. Knowledge is power, as the saying goes. Those alphabetic trios, called file extensions, tell the operating system the roles the files play. The DOS and Windows 3.1, 95 and 98 systems all use file extensions that follow the old eight-dot-three DOS convention (eight-letter name with a three-letter file extension separated by a period).

headline: A Wasteland, and Proud of It; E! Succeeds With Reruns and Short Attention Spans
abstract: As the new television season approaches, broadcast networks have spent hundreds of millions of dollars developing new series in hopes of finding the next Seinfeld or ER; exception to this annual ritual is niche cable channels, like E! Entertainment, which has often succeeded by spending far less and attracting relatively small but loyal audiences; these so-called narrowcase cable channels have built highly profitable businesses by thinking small and keeping programming budgets tight; Lee Masters, E!'s president, describes his strategy; photo; chart on E! channel's broadcast schedule (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices rise on worries that flooding from Hurricane Georges could ruin beans in New Orleans, where coffee for contracts traded in New York is stored; December coffee rises 3.7 cents, to $1.0835 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Hotelier for Jaded Boomers
abstract: Article on hotel interior designer Ian Schrager describes his different styles at Delano hotel in Miami Beach, Morgans and Royalton in NYC and Mondrian in Los Angeles; photos (M)

headline: Usti nad Labem Journal; A Wall Not Yet Built Casts the Shadow of Racism
abstract: Usti Nad Labem, Czech Republic, plans to build 15-foot wall separating prim Czech homes from two dilapidated apartment blocks occupied by Gypsy families, whose voices are often loud and celebrations boisterous; Gypsies and Czech human rights groups score effort to create ghetto; Mayor Ladislav Hruska defends effort to protect 'moral' Czechs from 'indecent' Gypsies; Czech Government has come under increasing criticism for its failure to address growing discrimination; Rep Christopher H Smith scores Czech Cabinet for remaining silent in face of continuing attacks and discrimination against Gypsies and other minorities; map; photo (M)

headline: International Briefs; Mannesmann Net Income Rose 42% in First Half
abstract: Mannesmann AG says first-half net income climbed by 42 percent; profit rose to 443 million marks ($249 million), from 311 million marks a year earlier; first-half sales climbed 22 percent, to 21.13 billion marks (S)

headline: Jobs Going Begging, Companies in Florida Adapt
abstract: Pool of qualified applicants for both skilled and unskilled jobs continues to shrink in Florida as state's unemployment rate is at low 4.3 percent, many companies have largely abandoned normal recruiting procedures such as classified advertising to rely on signing bonuses, putting notices on the Internet and offering prizes to employees who bring in new workers (M)

headline: U.S. Offers More Details On Attack in the Sudan
abstract: Clinton Administration seeks to justify cruise missile attack against pharmaceutical plant in Sudan it says was involved in manufacture of chemical weapons; officials say that in weeks leading up to strike, US obtained sample of critical element used in making VX, deadly nerve agent; Government of Sudan says factory was benign commercial venture, and has called on UN to investigate US attack (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice prices rise 2.5 percent on speculation that Hurricane Georges will damage orange crop in Florida; November contract gains 2.55 cents, to $1.0585 a pound; graph; charts (S)

headline: Arafat Likely to Declare Statehood in '99
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Araft seen increasingly likely to declare Palestinian state, probably on May 4, as peace talks with Israel remain stalled; implications of move are unclear; Israel views upgrading of status of Palestine Liberation Organization's observer delegation at United Nations as test run for eventual full membership (M)

headline: LIBRARY/GRAMMAR TUTORS; At High End, Fancy Design
abstract: SKILLSBANK 4 (The Learning Company; $249 single user, $1,492 unlimited site license; Windows 3.0 and later and NT, with Macintosh version expected in the fall.)  CAREER ENGLISH SERIES (Tutorsystems; $395 single user, $3,750 unlimited site license; Windows 3.0 and later and NT, with Macintosh version expected later this summer.)

headline: F.T.C. Says Merck Deal Cut Competition
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says Merck & Co reduced competition in pharmaceuticals market for time after it bought Medco Containment Services, managed-care drug sales company, in 1993; Merck announced it has agreed to antitrust safeguards requested by commission; FTC says new agreement would insure that Merck and Medco do not revert to earlier practices; under new agreement, Medco must offer wide range of products by all drug makers, on lists selected by independent committees of doctors and pharmacists (M)

headline: Making a Good Idea Her Own
abstract: Profile of Dalia Almanza-Smith, who came up with idea for a business that changed her life, and helped to introduce postcards as new form of advertising in America; photo (Special section on entrepreneurship in America) (M)

headline: Genesis Direct Buys Edge
abstract: Genesis Direct Inc purchases Edge Co catalogue for $21 million in cash and notes and $1.7 million in stock to expand its line of gift and collectibles for middle-aged men (S)

headline: Anti-Americanism Suspected As Cape Town Club Is Bombed
abstract: At least one person is killed and 24 injured when bomb explodes in Planet Hollywood restaurant in Cape Town, South Africa; caller tells Cape Town radio reporter that group called Muslims Against Global Oppression had set off bomb in retaliation for US cruise missile attacks on Sudan and Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Three Early Adopters, of Sorts
abstract: Three states, Kentucky, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, have implemented automobile insurance reforms limiting damage suits in exchange for lower premiums (M)

headline: House Votes Small Fraction Of Money Sought for I.M.F.
abstract: US House approves only $3.4 billion of nearly $18 billion that Pres Clinton is seeking for International Monetary Fund; action, which prompted Presidential veto threat, leaves agency in limbo as IMF's reserves dwindle and economic crises spread; Senate has approved full amount, and there is still chance that when both houses meet in next few weeks to iron out their difference, they will agree to provide Clinton Administration's full request; many in House say they have doubts about IMF's internal integrity and use of American taxpayer money for what they say are risky overseas investments the agency makes without proper accountability (M)

headline: Great Brington Journal; At Diana's Shrine, All's Not Adoration
abstract: Crowds throng shrine to Princess Diana at Althorp, Diana's childhood home, at Great Brington, England; $5 million museum, cafe and gift shop are opened by her brother, Earl Spencer; by far biggest number of visitors are women, old and young; photos; map (M)

headline: Computer Associates' Drop Stuns Managers
abstract: Many investors are stunned when stock in Computer Associates International loses 31 percent of its value following warning that Asian economic crisis is cutting into earnings of its large multinational customers; chart (M)

headline: ESTERLINE TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO ADD KIRKHILL RUBBER
abstract: Esterline Technologies Corp to buy Kirkhill Rubber Co for about $80 million (S)

headline: KINGSWAY FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY WALSHIRE ASSURANCE
abstract: Kingsway Financial Services Inc acquires Walshire Assurance Co for more than $42 million (S)

headline: Aliens Have Landed and Heads Will Roll
abstract: J C Herz assesses Hedz computer game, developed by VIS; photo (M)

headline: Ally or Foe? A Complaint On Microsoft
abstract: Robert Glaser, former Microsoft Corp executive and chairman of fast-growing software company Real Networks Inc, testifies at Senate Judiciary Committee hearing that Microsoft introduced competing product that crippled his company's most recent technology; complaint appears particularly intriguing because it comes from a company with close ties to Microsoft--and one that is engaged in promising niche of Internet software market in which Government is investigating Microsoft tactics; photo (M)

headline: Three Leave One Big Bank For Another
abstract: Frank Quattrone, Bill Brady and George Boutros, leaders of Deutsche Bank's global high-technology investment banking business, are leaving bank to join Credit Suisse First Boston (M)

headline: The Dow Declines by 36.05 as Other Gauges Post Gains
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 36.05 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,897.20; Nasdaq composite index closes up 17.37 points, or 1.03 percent, at 1,697.80; Standard & Poor's 500-index rises 5.74 points, to 1,029.63; graph; charts (M)

headline: Damage Control Helps Avoid Surprise Endings to Auto Leases
abstract: Consumer advocates and lease experts say two largest unexpected charges when leased cars are turned in are for excessive wear and tear and excess mileage; advise leasees to read paperwork thoroughly and document vehicle's condition; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises on reports that Seiroku Kajiyama, a former Cabinet secretary who favors economic stimulants, will seek prime minister's job (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/James H. Gipson; Clipper Fund
abstract: Interview with Clipper Fund founder and lead manager James H Gipson on his investment strategy; table of fund data; photo (M)

headline: Stunned by Floods, China Hastens Logging Curbs
abstract: China bans cutting of old-growth forests in Sichuan province, where loss of forests after a half-century of clear-cutting has intensified this year's devastating flooding downstream along Yangtze River; thousands of former farmers or workers who scaped together a small fortune to buy logging trucks will be chief casualties of policy change; Government promises Sichuan $121 million a year in aid to ease transition from a logging economy; logging in upper reaches of Yellow River also faces curbs; photo; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies column; German mark rises sharply on report that George Soros is dumping dollars; graphs (S)

headline: How Much Courtesy?
abstract: Rita K Farrelly letter disputes Arlene B Isaac's July 26 article on inequality of American female executives in dealing with foreign counterparts (S)

headline: Clinton to Penalize Russian Companies
abstract: The Clinton Administration said  yesterday that it would impose trade sanctions on nine Russian companies and institutions that have been helping Iran with its missile program.    The Administration's action comes as the Russian Government announced an investigation into the nine enterprises for violating new export control laws worked out in cooperation with the United States.

headline: Citing Low Chip Prices, Intel Earns Less Than Forecast
abstract: Intel Corp reports 29 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, a greater-than-expected decline, which company attributes to weakened prices for computer chips; earnings for quarter are $1.17 billion, compared with $1.645 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue total $5.93 billion; chart (M)

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments and assignments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: African Opportunity
abstract: R W Apple Jr analysis state that Nigeria's pledge that it will release all political prisoners is most gratifying news from Africa since establishment of multiracial Government in South Africa under Nelson Mandela; notes that if Nigeria could take even a few steps along path toward democracy, it could encourage other African governments to follow (M)

headline: Iraq Assembly Threatens End To All Inspection Cooperation
abstract: Iraqi Parliament threatens to stop all remaining cooperation with United Nations over weapons inspections; demands that Security Council reverse recent decision to stop all reviews of sanctions until Iraq allows on-site inspections to resume; photo (M)

headline: Mozambique's Austerity Puts It on Brink of a Boom
abstract: Mozambique's monuments to faded eras are still pretty shabby. The bullring left from the days of Portuguese colonialism is a wreck. The grass around the memorials on the Avenue of Popular War goes untrimmed, and corn planted by starving urbanites still sprouts in parks.    The children sitting in classrooms on the concrete floors scuffed smooth by their bare, sandy feet could as easily be in Cuba or anywhere else where tropical breezes let socialist decay creep through less harshly than it did in Eastern Europe.

headline: Ousted Malaysian, in Court, Denies Sex and Graft Charges
abstract: Malaysia's ousted Deputy Prime Min Anwar Ibrahim denies charges of corruption and sexual misconduct; appears in court visibly bruised and says he has been beaten by his jailers; it is Anwar's first public appearance since he was arrested nine days ago in political confrontation with Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad that has convulsed nation; photo (M)

headline: Administration Staying Out Of G.M. Strikes, for Now
abstract: Clinton Administration is staying out of General Motors Corp strikes; Pres Clinton has not mentioned dispute publicly for more than a month; Pres Clinton has not spoken directly with leaders of United Auto Workers or GM; neither UAW nor GM has asked Government to step in and they never have in past; Labor Sec Alexis M Herman has offered parties use of Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, but they have not taken her up on offer (M)

headline: Russia Crisis Leaves Yeltsin Pushed Aside
abstract: As Russia's new Prime Minister struggled to patch together a coalition Cabinet last week, Boris N. Yeltsin seemed to fade into the background, adding to the growing impression that the country's crisis has left the once-powerful President with a largely ceremonial role.

headline: Tellabs Is Said To Be Near New Deal for Ciena
abstract: Tellabs Inc is expected to announce it has renegotiated its agreement to acquire Ciena Corp; under new terms, Ciena shareholders are expected to receive eight-tenths of share of Tellabs for each Ciena share they own; this would value deal at more than $4.8 billion; previous value of deal, based on one-for-one swap, was estimated at $7.1 billion, but that was before two setbacks: on Aug 14, Ciena said its third-quarter profit would be less than half of expectations, and then AT&T Corp said it changed its mind and would not buy Ciena's technology for expanding capacity of fiber optic networks (M)

headline: Lockheed to Buy Comsat, Satellite Access Seller, for $2.7 Billion
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp, moving away from military business and toward global telecommunications, will acquire for $2.7 billion Comsat Corp--communications satellite company created by Government three decades ago (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     None

headline: Ex-Im Bank Chief, in Asia, Urges Priority on China Lending
abstract: Export-Import Bank chairman, James A Harmon, wants China to become its largest recipient of loans to buy American products and equipment; promises to push for increase in lending to China, which currently has loans and trade guarantees of $5.5 billion and is Ex-Im Bank's second-largest borrower; urging of new loans to China is sign of new emphasis US is placing on China as economic engine for Asia (M)

headline: TV Ads Nominated For Emmy Awards
abstract: Five commercials have been nominated for Emmy Awards by Academy of Television Arts and Sciences; nominees noted; winner will be announced in September (S)

headline: Pepsico to Pay $3.3 Billion For Tropicana
abstract: Just when you thought the breakfast table had been left unspattered by the cola wars, Pepsico announced yesterday that it was buying the Tropicana juice business from the Seagram Company.     The $3.3 billion cash purchase pits Pepsico against its archrival, the Coca-Cola Company, which owns Minute Maid, in the one part of the day that is not traditionally given over to carbonated soft drinks. The giants will now compete on the orange juice front, among others, and in a sign of things to come, both Coca-Cola and Tropicana yesterday claimed to be the world's biggest branded juice company.

headline: A new public service campaign from the Ad Council will ask people to 'Give a kid a hand.'
abstract: Ad Council is joining forces with International Advertising Association to distribute new public service campaign from international group to encourage adults to do volunteer work with children; campaign, carrying theme 'Give a kid a hand,' was created by Barry Day, director of creative development at Interpublic Group of Companies and worldwide creative director for international ad group (M)

headline: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; A Lighthearted Approach, But a Solid Information Base
abstract: Matt Resnicoff assesses computer guitar course from Alfred Publishing; photo (S)

headline: Wall Street Itself Is Feeling Plenty of Pain
abstract: Stock prices of Wall Street's brokerage firms and investment banks are down sharply on concerns that equity underwriting and bond trading will not be as lucrative this year; August has been worst month in years in terms of demand for initial public offerings (M)i

headline: Credit Suisse Selling Reinsurance Business
abstract: Credit Suisse Group says it agreed to sell reinsurance business of its Winterthur Insurance Co unit to Partnerre Ltd for $750 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Markets Bounce Back On Record-Setting Volume  The stock market regained more than half of the value it lost on Monday as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange set a record, with 1.21 billion shares changing hands. Big institutions, like pension funds and insurance companies, bought shares of both big and small stocks.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gulf of Mexico storms raise speculation that natural gas producers will face problems amassing winter supplies; November contract rises 17.8 cents, to $2.123 for 1,000 cubic feet, a two-month high; graph; chart (S)

headline: SCOTTS AGREES TO PURCHASE OF RHONE-POULENC UNIT
abstract: Scotts Co to buy Rhone-Poulenc SA's law and garden unit, Rhone-Poulenc Jardin, and ASEF for total of about $220 million (S)

headline: Troops Occupy Ulster Town on Eve of Protestant March
abstract: British soldiers ring the Drumcree neighborhood of Portadown, Northern Ireland, in effort to prevent sectarian violence on July 5, when Orange Order says it will try to march down down a Catholic street to celebrate 1690 Battle of the Boyne; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Rally Surges Ahead While Stocks Continue Slump
abstract: Long-term Treasury rates fall to lowest level in 30 years, while stock prices continue to slide; 30-year bond rises 26/32, to 99 15/32, to yield 5.54 percent; Dow Jones industrial average drops 34.50 points, to 8,425; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 12.16 points, to 1,062.75; Nasdaq composite index drops 12.35 points, to 1,790.19; graphs of 30-year Treasury bond yields and Dow Jones average; tables of key rates, hot and cold stocks and favorite stocks (M)

headline: People
abstract: Recent promotions and appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: As Floods Rage, Relief Efforts Just Beginning in China
abstract: Relief workers in China begin herculean task of providing food, water, health care and housing to millions who have been displaced by floods, even as battles against raging waters continue in parts of China; photo; map (M)

headline: Holderbank Buys Stake In Thai Cement Seller
abstract: Holderbank Financiere Glarus Ltd (Holderbank) acquires 25 percent stake in Siam City Cement PLC for 6.3 billion baht, or $150.3 million; Holderbank will buy 37.5 million shares from Ratanarak family, major shareholder of Siam City Cement (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.44   5.45        3-month T-bills   4.91   4.94   5.00        6-month T-bills   5.01   5.02   5.09        10-yr. T-infl.   3.75   3.75   3.65        10-yr. T-note   5.40   5.42   6.24        30-yr. T-bond   5.60   5.62   6.56        Telephone bd.   7.07   7.08   7.63        Municipal bds.   5.21   5.22   5.56          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge   Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Mistakes Hobble Venezuelan Economy, Experts Say
abstract: International market analysts say Venezuela's economy has been crippled by overvalued currency, government interference in monetary policy and irresponsible spending that relies too heavily on oil revenues; Col Hugo Chavez Frias, leading presidential candidate, supports measures that are seen as hostile to investors; photo (M)

headline: ACCUSTAFF TO SELL STAFFING UNIT TO RANDSTAD
abstract: Accustaff Inc to sell its Strategix Solutions Inc to Randstad Holdings NV for $850 million in cash, ending plan to take unit public (S)

headline: The British Are Coming, and Going; Many Retailers Come Up Short in the Trans-Atlantic Leap
abstract: Many British retailers have tried establishing stores in US and failed, like Conran's Habitat, housewares chain that is now defunct, and Next, a trendy clothing store; others struggling are Laura Ashley Holdings PLC, which has been through management turmoil in last two years, and Body Shop International, which was recently forced to form joint venture with Bellamy Retail Group LLC to stay in business in US after bleeding cash for years; one exception to trend is Virgin Group; reasons for lack of success have been many, ranging from Americans' desire for a bargain to real estate mistakes by British retail companies; graph; photos (M)

headline: G.M. Chairman Urges Rate Cut
abstract: General Motors Corp chairman John F Smith Jr urges Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates; says spreading economic troubles overseas could cause a recession in US if Fed does not lower rates soon (S)

headline: Economic Scene; A new project will measure the cost and effect of regulation.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on new Joint Center for Regulatory Studies sponsored by American Enterprise Institute and Brookings Institution; says center will act as nonpartisan watchdog, assessing big-ticket initiatives and producing annual report on effect of regulation; drawing (M)

headline: Strange Things Happening? Blame Your Biorhythms
abstract: Internet offers number of Web sites devoted to pseudoscience of biorhythms; are based on theory that biological rhythms affect emotions, alertness and readiness to mate; photo (M)

headline: Japan May Launch a Satellite In Response to North Korea's
abstract: Prime Min Keizo Obuchi says that Japan might launch its own reconnaissance satellite, move that would improve country's military capacity and make it easier to monitor missile deployments in North Korea; such a move would cause deep unease in neighboring countries; it would add to perception that Japan is running circles around its 'peace constitution' and quietly constructing building blocks for a powerful modern army (M)

headline: ALLSTATE SELLS OFF REAL ESTATE TO WESTBROOK
abstract: Allstate Corp sells what remains of its real estate portfolio to closely held investment fund Westbrook Partners LLC for about $965 milion (S)

headline: Charlestown Journal; On the Whole, Caribbean Isle Is Not Part of a Sum
abstract: Barely two miles of water separate pair of islands that make up tiny Caribbean nation of St Kitts and Nevis; if 10,000 or so people who live on Nevis vote as predicted on Aug 10 in referendum on secession, smallest country in Western Hemisphere will soon be severed in two; map; photo (M)

headline: UTILICORP RAISES STAKE IN NEW ZEALAND POWER COMPANY
abstract: Utilicorp United Inc will pay $206 million to increase its stake in Power New Zealand Ltd; Utilicorp will increase its ownership to 78.6 percent from 37.5 percent; will buy shares from Mercury Energy Ltd and WEL Energy Group Ltd (S)

headline: A Place for Cell Phones?
abstract: Samuel A Bleicher letter, responding to July 16 article, notes that nickel-cadmium batteries that power cellular phones can be returned to major retail electronic chains and manufacturers' service centers for recycling

headline: DUPONT TO RECEIVE $7.5 BILLION FROM CONOCO OFFERING
abstract: DuPont Co will receive $7.5 billion as part of its plan for sale of stock in its Conoco Inc oil and gas subsidiary to the public; Conoco plans to raise at least $3.5 billion in initial public offering (S)

headline: End of Line for Mob's Shuttle Over the Hong Kong Border
abstract: Chinese police disbands brazen gang of mobsters that has operated in Hong Kong for years, committing robberies, kidnappings and murders and fleeing across border to hide in Guangzhou, where local police have been either too inept or corrupt to care; arrests ringleader, Cheung Tze-keung, and 32 accomplices; seize nearly $5 million, as well as 11 luxury cars and cache of explosives and firearms; gang's downfall is latest chapter in curious evolution of lawlessness that straddles border--area rich with history of secret societies, pirates and criminal intrigue; photo; map (M)

headline: Broadcast Industry Draws Fire Over Digital TV
abstract: Senate Commerce Committee lambasts broadcast industry, cable companies and television manufacturers for failing to cooperate on crucial technical and political issues that threaten smooth transition to high-definition television, three months before scheduled rollout of digital TV; committee's chairman, Sen John McCain, erupts in anger and frustration at hearing called to measure progress in moving American industries and consumers to digital TV (S)

headline: Palestinian Youth Shot Dead As Jewish Settler Opens Fire
abstract: Palestinian teen-ager is killed and second one wounded in West Bank when Jewish settler fires at group of youths who reportedly were throwing stones at his car; settler surrenders to police; photo (S)

headline: WING INDUSTRIES BUYING 80% OF ATRIUM FOR $180 MILLION
abstract: Wing Industries agrees to buy 80 percent of Atrium Companies for $180 million; Atrium says its controlling shareholders, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc, agrees to sell its stake to Wing, which is controlled by Ardshiel Inc and GE Investment Private Placement Partners II, unit of General Electric Co; R G Darby Co, which is controlled by GE Investment and Ardshiel, will be combined with Wing and Atrium (S)

headline: EMERGING COMMUNICATIONS CHAIRMAN RAISES BUYOUT BID
abstract: The chairman of Emerging Communications Inc., Jeffrey Prosser, offered yesterday to buy the 48 percent of the company that he does not already own for $10.25 a share, or $54.9 million. Mr. Prosser offered $9.13 a share in May, but a group of holders sued to block the transaction, saying his offer was too low. Emerging, which was spun off from Atlantic Tele-Network Inc. in December, provides local phone services on the United States Virgin Islands of St. John, St. Thomas and St. Croix and wireless services on St. Martin. Emerging's shares rose $1.625 yesterday, or 19 percent, to $9.9375. Mr. Prosser will own Emerging through his wholly owned company, the Innovative Communication Corporation.

headline: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Remarks in Congress
abstract: Excerpts from report on economy by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, to Senate Banking Committee

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US Treasury prices rise for second day; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 2/32, to 105 6/32; yield remains at 5.16 percent; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (S)

headline: A Campaign Secret:The Emergence of Right-Wing Extremism
abstract: DRESDEN  Throughout their campaigns, Helmut Kohl and Gerhard Schroeder kept clear of the issue of emerging right-wing extremism with an agility they usually reserved for avoiding specifics on how they would create new jobs, save money and sustain Germany's enormous social welfare system all at the same time.

headline: THREE THERMO ELECTRON SUBSIDIARIES TO CUT JOBS
abstract: Thermo Electron Corp says three of its units will cut at least 750 jobs in revamping that is expected to produce savings of $30 million next year (S)

headline: Overheard Between Floors
abstract: What is it about an elevator? Everyone knows that it's impossible not to overhear or be overheard in what is really just a walk-in closet with wanderlust. But on any given workday you might hear all or part of some extraordinary conversations on the office elevator: bizarre tales, stunning revelations, head-scratching non sequiturs. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: LIBRARY/PERSONAL-FINANCE SITES; Motley Fool Has Visitors Chiming In
abstract: Motley Fool Web site on personal investing features bulletin boards that attract comments from 750,000 visitors monthly, offering opinions, experience and tips on personal financial decisions (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chancellor Media Is Buying Lin TV for $902.7 Million  Shares of Chancellor Media, the nation's second-largest radio company behind CBS, fell after it announced that it was expanding into television with the acquisition of Lin Television for $902.7 million in stock.    The combined company will have Lin's 12 network-affiliated television stations and minority stakes in NBC affiliates as well as Chancellor Media's 108 radio stations. [Page D2.]

headline: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS IN DEAL FOR HOT-BEVERAGE BUSINESS
abstract: Chock Full o' Nuts Corp will acquire hot-beverage business of closely held Park Foods for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Current Account Surplus Triples in Taiwan
abstract: Taiwan records current account surplus of $753 million in second quarter, more than triple surplus of $232 million in first quarter; surplus was $1.4 billion in same period last year (S)

headline: Volkswagen Yields on Nazi-Era Payments
abstract: Volkswagen A.G. has reversed itself and agreed to set up a fund to compensate workers forced into slave labor in World War II.    It said that its decision was ''in recognition of the historical and moral obligations'' to those who were forced to work in its factories under the Third Reich. The company has been threatened with a lawsuit over the issue. Company executives had insisted that compensating victims was a Government responsibility.

headline: CINCINNATI MILACRON TO BUY UNIT OF JOHNSON CONTROLS
abstract: Cincinnati Milacron Inc to acquire Johnson Controls Inc's plastic machinery unit for about $210 million (S)

headline: Media Talk; Milken's Latest Venture: Co-Writing a Cookbook
abstract: Former junk bond financier Michael R Milken co-authors with his personal chef, Beth Ginsberg, cookbook of recipes he used to fight prostate cancer; Cap Cure, prostate cancer charity Milken founded, will get all profits; he comments, phone interview; photo (M)

headline: Big Web Sites to Track Steps of Their Users
abstract: Some of largest commecial sites of World Wide Web have agreed to feed information about their customers' reading, shopping and entertainment habits into system developed by CMG Information Services, Massachusetts company that is already tracking moves of over 30 million Internet users, often without their knowledge; agreement calls for participating Web sites to track their users so that advertisements can be precisely aimed at most likely prospects for goods and services; while this system guarantees anonymity of individual users, underlying technology disturbs privacy-rights advocates, who have long worried about growing ability of on-line companies to collect and store personal data about people who use Web; this new industry cooperative represents most ambitious effort yet to gather disparate bits of personal information into central data base containing digital dossiers on potentially every person who surfs Web (M)

headline: For Wall Street, Increasing Evidence that Green Begets Green
abstract: Article on shift by stock analysts toward eco-efficient companies that recapture raw materials from waste, for example, while making profits; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Mystery Sites Easy To Deduce
abstract: Femmes Fatales Web site opens window on hundreds of mystery-related Internet sites where people can chat, read about their favorite mystery authors, buy gifts and books, solve whodunits and answer trivia questions; photo (M)

headline: Focusing on Fundamentals
abstract: Web site www.tennisserver.com features extensive coverage about fundamentals of tennis (S)

headline: Two Former Stratton Officials Indicted on Fraud Charges
abstract: Two former principals of defunct brokerage firm, Stratton Oakmont Inc, are indicted in an international securities fraud and money laundering scheme that Federal prosecutors say tried to manipulate the stock of two small companies; indictment charges Jordan Ross Belfort, 36, Stratton's former chairman, and Daniel Mark Porush, 41, its former president, with 27 counts of securities fraud, conspiracy to commit securities fraud, money laundering and obstruction of justice (S)

headline: Jury Awards $760 Million in Chemical Trial
abstract: Los Angeles Superior Court jury assesses punitive damages of more than $760 million against five oil and chemical companies for injuries suffered by workers building Stealth fighter at Lockheed Corp; decision by jury follows finding that companies had not provided adequate warning about toxic effects of chemicals like solvents that were used in manufacture of radar-evading aircraft in 1960's, 1970's and 1980's; punitive damages are levied against Exxon Corp, Shell Oil Co, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Ashland Inc, Unocal and DuPont (M)

headline: U.N. Tribunal, in First Such Trial Verdict, Convicts Rwandan Ex-Mayor of Genocide
abstract: United Nations tribunal investigating mass killings in Rwanda hands down first guilty verdict by international court for crime of genocide, and for first time defines rape as genocidal; decision, against former Taba Mayor Jean-Paul Akayesu, is first verdict after trial by Rwanda tribunal, which has been plagued by mismanagement and corruption since its inception in 1994; map; photo of Akayesu arriving at UN court in Arusha, Tanzania (M)

headline: Avon Expands Ties With MacManus Units
abstract: Avon Products Inc expands its relationship with N W Ayer & Partners and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications; billings, estimated at $65 million in past, are expected to increase (S)

headline: Vague Charges Accuse Korean Official of Letting Economy Fall : From Finance Ministry to Cell No.3
abstract: EUWANG, South Korea  Suffering from high blood pressure and losing sight in one eye, Kang Kyong Shik has no desire to read the fine print of newspaper articles about South Korea's financial crisis.

headline: SCHOOL SPECIALTY PURCHASES ITS RIVAL BECKLEY-CARDY
abstract: School Specialty Inc. acquired a rival, the closely held Beckley-Cardy Group, yesterday for about $76 million in cash, expanding its business in the South and Southwest. School Specialty, an educational supply company based in Appleton, Wis., also assumed Beckley's credit facilities, valued at about $60 million. Beckley, based in Mansfield, Ohio, had sales of about $176 million in its 1998 fiscal year. The acquisition expands the company's presence in California, Florida and Texas, the company said. School Specialty's stock jumped $2.9375 a share, or 26 percent, to $14, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For Trading in Livent, an Indefinite Intermission
abstract: Market Place column on Livent Inc, which is under investigation for possible accounting irregularities; focuses on trading in company's stock, which has been halted since Aug 10 by US and Canadian regulators; adds Canadian securities regulators on Aug 28 ordered ban on all trading of stock, even for shareholders who may have been able to find shares outside exchanges; says result is hundreds of frustrated investors have y been left wondering just how much, if anything, their Livent shares are worth (M)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO BUY SIX AUTO DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Republic Industries to buy six franchised auto dealership groups in separate deals (S)c

headline: Lucent Has Loss After Charges
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc says earnings before charges more than doubled in fiscal third quarter ended June 30, exceeding expectations, lifted by 14 percent sales gain; profit increased to $435 million from $213 million a year earlier; revenue rose to $7.23 billion from $6.34 billion (S)

headline: DATABANK: September 21-25; Stocks' Gains Mask Traders' Anxieties
abstract: The market's numbers for the past week look better than its shaky performance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose a respectable 133.11 points to close at 8,028.77, and the Nasdaq composite advanced nearly 80 points to close at 1,743.59. Even the small-capitalization Russell 2000, which has been battered this year, climbed nearly 6 points to 369.02.

headline: CIRRUS LOGIC PLANS LAYOFFS AND A $500 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Cirrus Logic Inc will lay off as much as 28 percent of its work force and take $500 million charge to get rid of its weakest businesses; Cirrus will cut 400 to 500 of 1,800 employees (S)

headline: Belden Associates To Media Advisors
abstract: Media Advisors International acquires Belden Associates, newspaper research and strategy company, from VNU/USA Marketing Information Services Inc unit of VNU NV; terms undisclosed; Thoams J Holbein, senior consultant at Belden, will become chairman; Deanne Termini, president at Belden, continues in that role (S)

headline: An Upstart With Friends In the Highest of Places
abstract: Profile of Icos Corp, biotechnology company that has yet to market a product or profit from operations but whose board includes major business executives; company hopes to produce alternative to popular impotence drug Viagra; photos (M)

headline: Intern Invasions: Survivors' Tales
abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder column offers responses from readers to inquiry about office interns; cartoon (M)

headline: Jacek Kalabinski, 59, Journalist Who Fled Poland for West in '83
abstract: Jacek Kalabinski, Polish journalist and former opposition figure who worked in US after fleeing his native land in 1983, died on July 24 at age 59 (S)

headline: Summer Rally?
abstract: Wall Street has experienced some stock price surges during summer months, but look at the performance in last decade indicates that while the market rallies more often than not, it is not always the time of the year that brings out the bulls; graph on S&P 500 from May 31 to August 31 for last 10 years (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls as lawmakers argue over bank-reform package, delaying passage of measure viewed as critical to economic revival; dollar rises to 136.25 yen from 135.10; graph; chart (S)

headline: DUANE READE AGREES TO ACQUIRE ROCK BOTTOM STORES
abstract: Duane Reade Inc, largest drugstore chain in New York, will buy Rock Bottom Stores Inc, another drug retailer, for about $61 million in cash; with addition of Rock Bottom chain, Duane Reade will operate 122 stores (S)

headline: America West Airlines Gets a Contract
abstract: America West Holdings Corp's America West Airlines Inc unit reaches contract with its teamsters' union, alleviating some labor tension airline says hurt its third-quarter profit (S)

headline: Art CD-ROM's Hard to Find
abstract: Robert Barrett letter says CD-ROM's on art and architecture (July 23 article) are poorly marketed

headline: Business Travel; Northwest Is Pressured To Reduce Some Fares
abstract: Northwest Airlines, bowing to pressure from North Dakota politicians and local airport managers, says it will cut business fares to and from the state as part of six-month trial to stimulate passenger traffic; fares, discounted as much as 60 percent on connecting flights and 42 percent on nonstop flights, are available immediately for travel from Sept 14 through March 31, 1999; Cathay Pacific is offering round-trip flights to Hong Kong from New York and Los Angeles for $399 plus taxes and fees through end of August; American Express survey of business travelers has found that 65 percent of respondents always or almost always use laptop computer on overnight trips; new security gates at United Airlines' Terminal 7 at Los Angeles International Airport, scheduled to open in early September, will allow passengers to go through without switching on their computers (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Malaysia Output Down 6.8%; Nation Formally in Recession
abstract: Malaysia's economy contracts for second consecutive quarter, confirming that country has fallen into recession; central bank reports gross domestic product shrank 6.8 percent in second quarter from year earlier; bank also revises first quarter's contraction to 2.8 percent from 1.8 percent; recession is Malaysia's first in 13 years; country has delayed efforts to raise money abroad because its credit ratings have been lowered by Moody's Investors Service, requiring debt issuers to pay higher yields (M)

headline: Work and Stress Lead to 'Depressive Reaction' : Norway Rallies Around Its Ailing Prime Minister
abstract: OSLO  When Kjell Magne Bondevik took over as prime minister of Norway last year, his ready smile and youthful vigor appeared to symbolize the sunny fortunes of this country's booming, oil-driven economy.

headline: South African Official Freed From Prison in Mozambique
abstract: Robert McBride, South African Foreign Ministry official, is released from prison in Mozambique, six months after arrest at border town, where he was said to be carrying thousands of dollars and trying to buy cache of assault weapons (S)

headline: Bergen and Sprint Part Company
abstract: Candice Bergen's eight-year run as spokeswoman for Sprint Corp is ending by mutual agreement (S)

headline: Dimac Is Merging Four Units Into One
abstract: Dimac Corp has consolidated its four direct-response operations and spun them off into single agency named DMW Worldwide (S)

headline: Less Than Meets the Eye?
abstract: Article on steller one-day performance, on May 11, of Investment Advisers Inc's IAI Balanced and IAI Value mutual funds; graphs (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (M)

headline: OFFICEMAX IS IN TALKS ABOUT A POSSIBLE COMBINATION
abstract: Officemax Inc says it is in talks about possible combination; company, whose stock is valued at $1.15 billion, says it stopped buying back its shares because of preliminary discussions with undisclosed party (S)

headline: EARNINGS TO FALL BELOW ANALYSTS' ESTIMATES
abstract: Union Carbide Corp warns its third-quarter earnings will fall below analysts' estimates and as much as 35 percent below second quarter (S)

headline: Confidence Dips; Home Resales Rise
abstract: Conference Board says consumer confidence fell in August to 133.1 from revised July reading of 137.2; index set 30-year high in June of 138.2; National Assn of Realtors says home resales rose 4 percent in July, to record annual rate of 4.93 million, after June decline of 1.9 percent; mortgage rates averaged 6.95 percent in July for 30-year loans, compared with 7 percent in June (S)

headline: Judith Albert, 59, Toy Designer Whose Doll Led to Buyer Frenzy
abstract: Judith F Albert, toy designer who created Cabbage Patch doll, dies at age 59 (S)

headline: Lucent Licenses Its Software For Speech Recognition
abstract: Lucent Technologies is licensing its speech-recognition technology to developers who want to create speech-recognition programs for consumer use on Windows operating system (S)

headline: 2 New Suspects Linked by U.S. To Terror Case
abstract: Federal authorities charged that US Embassy bombing in Kenya was orchestrated by Islamic terorrist from Comoros, Haroun Fazil, who reported directly to Osama bin Laden, Saudi exile who operating from Afghanistan; $2-million reward is posted for Fazil, who has eluded arrest since warrant was issued late in August; Fazil is accused of murder and conspiracy to murder and could face life in prison or death penalty; Wadih el Hage, Texas man described as aide to bin Ladin in Sudan in 1994, is charged with making false statements and held in New York without bail; US Atty Mary Jo White says Fazil was 'major player' in Kenyan cell of bin Laden's terrorist group; Fazil is accused of driving truck that led vehicle carrying bomb to embassy site; el Hage, who was questioned about bin Laden last year, reportedly shared house in Nairobi with Fazil, having moved there from Sudan, before returning to US in 1997; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft's Windows 98 Sells Much Better Than Expected
abstract: PC Data reports Microsoft Corp's new Windows 98 operating system is selling briskly, despite antitrust concerns and lack of major marketing drive; Microsoft has positioned software as 'tune-up' of predecessor, not ground-breaking new product (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Outspoken and Out the Door; A Director Quits, Breaking 'the Code' in a Parting Blast
abstract: Market Place column examines Agnes Varis's reasons for resigning from board of Copley Pharmaceutical Inc; Varis has publicly accused Hoechst AG, majority owner of Copley, of mismanaging company and not acting in best interests of all shareholders; says Hoechst expected outside directors on board to rubber-stamp its decisions regarding Copley; Varis's story illustrates how little power directors often have; Varis's major complaint against Hoechst is that it seemingly thwarted efforts to sell Copley, even after losing interest in it; Copley stock has lost 40 percent of its value in last two years; photo; graph (M)

headline: FOSTER WHEELER TO REVAMP A UNIT AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: Foster Wheeler Corp says it plans to revamp its Power Systems Group and post third-quarter charge of $175 million for its Robbins Resource Recovery operations (S)

headline: Surprisingly, You May Be Hard to Find : Netsearching Yourself
abstract: PARIS  I was lying awake at 4 A.M., so I decided to find myself.

headline: Brash Russian Tax Chief Takes On Land of Evasion
abstract: Russia's new tax chief Boris G Fyodorov faces daunting challenge in country where tax evasion is rampant; the economic reformer turned wealthy investment banker is a veteran of Russia's rough-and tumble politics, and boasts of his delight in stepping on toes; in his first month in office, Fyodorov has taken on Gazprom, Russia's most powerful company and one of its biggest tax delinquents; he has drawn up a list of Russia's 1,000 wealthiest citizens, put himself on the list, and declared that everyone will be audited; and in effort to scare tax deadbeats, he has begun series of highly publicized raids; Fyodorov has put his stamp on Yeltsin Government's plans to overhaul the tax law, lobbying for lower corporate tax rates to stimulate economic growth and encourage compliance, and pushing for flat tax on personal income; with only one million Russians, out of population of 147 million, having filed taxes in 1997, plenty of skeptics think Fyodorov will fail; but with Russia trying to contain a budget deficit and struggling to prop up its currency, collecting revenues has never been more critical; photo (M)

headline: PHARMACY SERVICE PROVIDER GETS $2 BILLION CONTRACT
abstract: McKesson Corp wins five-year contract to deliver over $400 million a year of pharmaceuticals directly to stores of American Stores Co's American Drug Stores unit; will also provide $1.5 billion of pharmaceuticals to unit's warehouses (S)

headline: Applied Materials Offers Warning on Profit
abstract: Applied Materials Inc, world's largest maker of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment, says its fiscal third-quarter results would fall below analyst forecasts, hurt by delayed orders and cutbacks in capital spending by chipmakers (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Woes in Russia Send Global Markets Down  Investors around the world sold stocks yesterday. In this country, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.19 percent, to 8,165.99, a loss of 357.36 points. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.62 percent, or 81.72 points, to 1,686.41, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 3.81 percent, or 41.60 points, to 1,042.59. With the Dow average now 12.5 percent below its July 17 high of 9,337.97, investors are into what Wall Street calls a correction.

headline: Greens Hope for Place in the Sun When Germans Vote
abstract: Interview with Joschhka Fischer, head of Germany's Green Party, which could win enough votes in September elections to enable Gerhard Schoder, leader of Social Democrats, to oust Chancellor Helmut Kohl, winning a place for Greens in Schroder's Cabinet; Green Party's position on energy taxes and conservation has recently led to friction between it and its Social Democratic allies (M)

headline: Goldman's Faltering Profits May Delay an Offering
abstract: Sharp falloff in profits at Goldman, Sachs & Co could delay partnership's initial public offering in November (S)

headline: Russia Again Cracks Down on Corporate Tax Deadbeats
abstract: Tax collectors swoop down on three of Russia's biggest oil companies, seizing executives' cars, apartments and other assets to hammer home its demand for payment of more than $150 million in back taxes; seizures copy highly successful raid six weeks ago on offices of natural-gas monopoly Gazprom, single biggest tax delinquent at that time; seizures are latest indications that Pres Boris N Yeltsin's current economic advisers, unlike his previous ones, are serious about carrying out latest last-ditch program to stave off fiscal collapse (M)

headline: Except for Israel, Mideast Is Notably Silent on Strikes
abstract: Israel is quick to congratulate US for missile attacks on suspected terrorist bases in Afghanistan and Sudan, but early reaction from many other governments in Middle East has been silence; only Libya and Iraq, declared US foes, are explicit in condemnation; Britain is alone among European leaders in expressing support; Japan gives qualified backing; Israelis, who have suffered more recent terrorist attacks than any other country, sees US strikes as vindication of their own calls for controntation toward Islamic militants (M)

headline: Estimates of Toll in Afghan Missile Strike Reach as High as 50
abstract: Number of people killed by American missile strikes in eastern Afghanistan, to avenge terrorist bombings of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, may be higher than first thought; new estimate puts death toll at 50 or higher; Taliban official says 21 people died in attacks; photo (M)

headline: Mutts by the Megabyte; Helping to Save a Few Good Doggies From Death Row
abstract: Pet Finder maintains searchable data base of adoptable animals on World Wide Web; co-founder Betsy Saul says site was first to link unrelated animal shelters on single site; individuals can also offer pets for adoption; photo (M)

headline: Despite Confusion, Clinton Will Keep Date With Yeltsin
abstract: Clinton Administration is concerned over dismissal of reformist Cabinet by Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin so close to September 1 summit with Pres Clinton in Moscow; officials acknowledge they were taken by surprise, but say move will not affect trip; comments by former national security adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski and other prominent Russian scholars noted (M)

headline: Paris Journal; La Ministre? Over the Immortals' Dead Bodies
abstract: French Government has proposed feminizing women's titles to reflect their growing role in society; French Academy, male bastion founded by Cardinal Richelieu in 1635, opposes plan because rules of French grammar would have to be bent; Prime Min Lionel Jospin has appointed commission to study proposal; photo (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic Is Planning a Revamping
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp says it will create new office of chairman and reorganize its business units to adjust for rapid changes in communications marketplace; some appointments noted (S)

headline: F.C.C. Takes a Harder Look at 'Microradio' Stations
abstract: Federal Communications Commission crackdown has led to closure of 250 unlicensed low-power radio stations, which FCC views as 'pirates' who interfere with licensed programming as well as air traffic control frequencies, creating safety hazard; at same time, FCC is considering licensing radio stations that broadcast below 100 watts of power; William E Kennard, FCC chairman, sees nothing inconsistent in his efforts to crack down on unlicensed stations and to find room for low-power stations on radio dial; Richard Edmondson, who pulled his 40-watt station off air, fearing FCC's wrath, says agency does not support free speech; photo (M)

headline: Investments in Stock Funds Slow, But Remain Ahead of '97 Pace
abstract: Fund companies and industry analysts say mutual fund investors slowed their purchases in equity funds in second half of July; cash flows into stock funds so far this year remain well ahead of last year's record pace despite recent slowdown; Mutual Fund Trim Tabs estimates that $18 billion went into stock funds in July; Investment Company Institute says stock funds received $19.2 billion in net new investments in June; holds $126.3 billion was invested in equity funds in first half of year, up 16 percent from year-earlier period (M)

headline: 2 Sides Prepare to Battle Over Congo's Capital
