abstract: Congolese forces loyal to Pres Laurent Kabila and rebel forces begin furious preparations for what may be critical fight for control of capital of Kinshasa, after several days of relative quiet; rebels are reportedly in firm control of strategic western port city of Matadi and nearby Inga Dam and are said to have cut off fuel and most food supplies to Kinshasa; are massing about 150 miles west of city; Government, vowing to fight to end, rushes 8,000 recently trained troops toward capital; Kabila, in last-minute effort to shore up positions, flies to Angola for meetings with Pres Jose Eduardo dos Santos; returns amid heavy security; maps; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: S.E.C. Takes Close Look At Accounting of Web Deals  The Securities and Exchange Commission may be voicing subtle warnings about the unusually high prices of Internet industry stocks by reviewing how acquisitions are accounted for on the buyers' financial statements.    The most prominent example is America Online, which was not able to release its quarterly and full-year earnings last week because it is still wrestling with the S.E.C. over the accounting for two recent acquisitions. The issue is how much of the price the on-line service paid for the acquisitions can be written off now versus how much must be deducted over many quarters. Market Place. [Page D2.]

headline: Gore, Ending Moscow Visit, Is Confident About Reform
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore ends two days of talks in Moscow by declaring his confidence that Prime Min Sergei V Kiriyenko will be able to carry out fiscal reforms needed to make Russian Government solvent; financial experts and some Russian officials say Government has only three to five months to make major improvements in its tax system and budget or face another fiscal crisis like one that nearly bankrupted Government early this month (M)

headline: Aetna to Expand In Chilean Deal
abstract: Aetna Inc agrees to pay $100 million for 75 percent stake in Chilean health insurer Cruz Blanca Isapre SA, country's third-largest insurer; purchase by Aetna, largest United States health insurance company, would create company with about 319,000 customers, or 18.6 percent of Chile's private health insurance market; Chile has one of best-developed health insurance markets in Latin America because by law companies are required to set aside part of every employee's salary for private insurance (S)

headline: Washington Casts Wary Eye at Missile Test
abstract: American officials say that Iran's test of medium-range missile apparently blew up in later stages of its flight, but they say they do not know whether it had blown up on its own or whether Iranians had detonated it on purpose before impact; missile travels far enough to sharpen concern in Washington, Israel and Persian Gulf countries about Iran's growing capacity to deliver weapons of mass destruction in an arc that encompasses Israel, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and parts of Egypt and Russia; map (M)

headline: When Things Go Wrong
abstract: Appraisal of Windows 98 Resource Kit by Microsoft Corp and Windows 98 Secretsby Brian Livingston and Davis Straub; photo (M)

headline: CLINTON PROPOSAL TO AID ECONOMIES MEETS OBSTACLES
abstract: Pres Clinton's push to quell global financial turmoil runs into several obstacles, including discord within Group of Seven industrial nations about global interest rate cuts and political obstacles to rescue package for Brazil; Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan tells House panel that world's big economies have no plans for coordinated interest rates cuts; hints global crisis could lead Fed to cut domestic rates, noting deflationary forces are continuing to emerge in much of world and are moving toward United States; Treasury Sec Robert Rubin tells panel that Brazil is main focus of US concern in Latin America; Brazil seems hesitant in talks with International Monetary Fund and major industrial nations to seek aid and agree to unpopular budget cuts before its Presidential elections in two weeks; photo (M)

headline: Possible Cyanide Food Poisoning at Festival Startles Japan
abstract: Police in Wakayama, Japan, continue to investigate mystery surrounding mass poisoning that left four people dead after they had eaten at a festival; police spokesman says that although investigators strongly believe that cyanide had been deliberately introduced into curry at festival, they could not rule out possibility that food had been accidentally tainted (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Microsoft's Apple Stake Is Hardly Altruism
abstract: Microsoft Corp's $150 million investment in Apple Computer last August, viewed then as act of kindness, appears to have been shrewd investment for Microsoft; Apple's shares have outperformed Microsoft's in last year; graph (S)

headline: Memphis Bank In Indiana Move
abstract: First Chicago NBD Corp, Banc One Corp and Union Planters Corp agree that Union Planters will acquire 51 NBD Bank branches and associated deposits and loans in Indiana from First Chicago; sale will more than meet conditions set by Justice Department for acquisition of First Chicago by Banc One (S)

headline: 30-Year Treasuries Advance On Suggestions of a Rate Cut
abstract: Price of 30-year Treasury bond rises; bond is up 4/32, to 104 4/32; yield falls to 5.22 percent, from 5.23 percent on Sept 11; graph on 3-month Treasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Akzo Nobel Shares Slide on Profit News
abstract: Shares of Akzo Nobel NV drops 14 percent after company posts lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings; net income rose 5 percent, to 483 milion guilders (S)

headline: Consulting Firm In Acquisition
abstract: Metzler Group Inc to buy LECG Inc, economic analysis and consulting group, for $274 million in stock, to expand services to customers (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall St. View Of Saks Sale: No Big Bargain
abstract: Shares of Profitt's Inc fall 9.6 percent after company announces plans to acquire Saks Holdings Inc; investors apparently fear that price negotiated by R Brad Martin, chairman, is too high, that acquisition may depress earnings and that Saks is too big to be easily absorbed; graph of Proffitt's stock price (M)

headline: 1,800 Injured Overwhelming Kenya Hospital
abstract: Kenyatta National Hospital in Nairobi is overwhelmed by the grievously maimed and walking wounded; treats 1,600 people in hours after blast; doctors, nurses and technicians are strained to their limits to treat victims of car-bomb attack; hospital is running out of basic supplies; photo (M)

headline: Iraq Televising Tapes of Talks With U.N. Arms Inspector
abstract: Iraq experiments with television propaganda blitz against United Nations arms inspectors; its video footage of standoff between Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz and chief UN inspector Richard Butler, intended to court world opinion, is getting mixed reviews and could backfire with Security Council; Butler says tape showing him abruptly ending meeting was edited, interview; says Iraqis falsely pledged tapes were for record, not media; photos (M)

headline: ING Income Rose 63% In the 2d Quarter
abstract: ING Groep NV reports second-quarter profit rose 63 percent to $930 million from year earlier (S)

headline: Media Talk; In Los Angeles, It's Paper vs. Paper
abstract: Los Angeles Daily News reports that Los Angeles Time publisher, Mark H Willes, paid $40,000 to join 26-member Los Angeles Business Advisers, group that opposes giving newly created 'neighborhood councils' more power; Willes defends membership and contribution; inquiries by Los Angeles Times recently prompted Daily News to disclose its support of group seeking to have San Fernando Valley seceed from City of Los Angeles; photo (M)

headline: RUSSIA ACTS TO FIX SINKING FINANCES
abstract: The Russian Government moved hastily today to avert financial collapse with a series of drastic measures, including delaying payments for 90 days on foreign debt owed mostly by banks, restructuring Government bonds and sacrificing the ruble to market forces.    Holding tonight at 6.43 rubles to the dollar, off slightly from Friday's level, the value of the Russian currency is now free to float as low as 9.5, a risky step -- tantamount to devaluation -- that many fear could set off a new round of inflation. It could also wipe out as much as a third of the ruble's purchasing power in an economy heavily dependent on imports.

headline: DIARY
abstract: BIG OIL  A British Amoco  In the biggest foreign takeover ever of an American company, British Petroleum announced that it would buy Amoco (the name once stood for American Oil Company) for $48.2 billion, eclipsing Daimler-Benz's $40.5 billion deal for Chrysler. The agreement, subject to regulatory and shareholder approval, would create the world's third-largest multinational oil company in net income, after Exxon and Royal Dutch/Shell. The combination is expected to create a formidable competitor. B.P. is known for its skill at finding oil in the North Sea and elsewhere around the world, while Amoco's strength is in refining its products into oil and chemicals and distributing them to consumers. (Article, page 10.)    BELL ATLANTIC  Score One for Workers  Proclaiming victory, 73,000 members of the Communications Workers of America ended a two-day strike and returned to work at Bell Atlantic. The company, which serves telephone customers from Maine to Virginia, agreed to guarantee job security to its union workers -- even in digital technologies only now being developed. Experts in labor relations called it a significant union victory. Kate Bronfenbrenner, director of labor education research at Cornell University, said workers in other industries were likely to be inspired by Bell Atlantic's agreement to phase out a nonunion customer service operation in Virginia.

headline: Media Talk; Mother Jones Returns To Roots With New Look
abstract: Mother Jones, counterculture magazine founded in 1976 and proclaimed for hard-nosed investigative reporting, fell on hard times in 1980's and 1990's; it is undergoing makeover, and will feature more articles about technology and corporate misfeasance, which hold more interest for younger readers than tales of political corruption; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Coming This Week: A Web Hair Transplant
abstract: America's Health Network plans to cover hair-transplant operation live on Internet; plans monthly medical Webcasts; drawing (M)

headline: Compressed Data; A Combined Phone-Palm Pilot Impresses the Techno-Elite
abstract: Paul E Jacobs, top executive for Qualcomm Inc, demonstrates digital wireless phone fully integrated with a Palm Pilot hand-held computer at annual Telecosm conference, sponsored by George Gilder and his libertarian friends from Forbes magazine; photo (S)

headline: Bombed Embassies Did Not Meet Toughened Security Standards
abstract: State Department officials acknowledge that United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania did not meet security standards that had been ordered for State Department overseas posts after separate terrorist attacks against US Embassy and Marine barracks in Beirut, Lebanon, in the 1980's; say Clinton Administration and Congress have provided less than one-third of funds necessary to pay for a worldwide conversion of all US embassies; diagram of Nairobi facility, which was scheduled to undergo $3 million rehabilitation in January 1999 (M)

headline: Chrysler's Chief Will Fare Quite Well in Daimler Merger
abstract: Chrysler Corp's chairman-chief executive Robert J Eaton is guaranteed to do well whether merger of Chrysler and Daimler-Benz AG succeeds or not; to persuade Eaton to stay on for three years under combined Daimler-Chrysler, he can earn nine extra years on his pension; those nine years alone are worth $30,000 a month for rest of his life; but if he quits or is dismissed during two years after merger, he will be paid $24.4 million, with DaimlerChrysler paying 'golden parachute' tax for him and taxes on compensation paid to cover tax; he will also get stock appreciation rights worth almost $23 million for each $10 rise in price of company's shares; no compensation details are disclosed for Jurgen Schrempp, chairman of Daimler-Benz, and nine other top executives there because their compensation packages are not being changed in deal (M)

headline: S.E.C. HALTS AN INQUIRY ON ICN STOCK TRADING
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission drops probe into charges that ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc chief executive Milan Panic sold $1.24 million of ICN stock in 1994 after learning that Food and Drug Administration would not approve new drug; plans enforcement action against company and Panic for failing to disclose news to other shareholders (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Mark weakened against dollar on July 1, closing at 1.8187, as currency traders remained concerned over Russia's economic crisis; graph; chart

headline: People
abstract: Richard Monturo, senior vice president and strategic planner at Lowe & Partners/SMS, is promoted to executive vice president and strategic planning director; he succeeds Stephani Cook, who becomes consultant; Michael Parise is named to vacant position of senior vice president and management director on Mattel account at Foote, Cone & Belding (S)

headline: APS HOLDING TO SELL 142 BIG A AUTO PARTS STORES
abstract: APS Holding Corp, owner of Big A auto-parts chain, is selling 142 stores and 10 distribution centers for more than $100 million as part of its bankruptcy reorganization; APS is selling centers and stores to General Parts Inc, BWP Distributors Inc and Parts Source Inc (S)

headline: Nasdaq Uncovered Short Sales Decline
abstract: National Assn of Securities Dealers reports open positions of short sales on Nasdaq market fell 1 percent in month ended Aug 15, to 2.13 million shares; decline is first since 30-day period ended May 15 (S)

headline: Consumer Marketers Name New Agencies
abstract: Ricola USA Inc names Ciociola & Company in New York to handle its creative account; H J Heinz Co names DGWB Advertising to handle Nature's Recipe Pet Foods account, formerly handled by Goldberg Moser O'Neill (S)

headline: Few Federal Web Sites Observe U.S. Privacy Guidelines
abstract: Few Clinton Administration World Wide Web sites post kind of privacy guidelines Federal Trade Commission wants businesses to post and none offer special protections for children that Government recommends for commercial sites; White House Web site collects E-mail and some home addresses without providing any notice about how data will be used; site does not ask visitors to its special children's pages to consult their parents before divulging personal data; critics say that while Federal Web sites do not collect or sell personal data for marketing purposes, Federal agencies should lead by example; table; photos (M)

headline: Beijing Students and Women, Defying Ban, Protest Anti-Chinese Violence in Indonesia
abstract: Defying a ban by Government officials, students and women's groups held emotional protests today over the looting, killing and rape directed against ethnic Chinese during riots in Indonesia in May.    The rioting in Indonesia originally received only cursory media coverage in China. It was not until this month, when two Chinese newspapers published photo essays showing  the violence, that the issue was thrust before the Chinese public.

headline: VARIAN ASSOCIATES PLANS TO SPIN OFF TWO DIVISIONS
abstract: Varian Associates Inc says that it will reorganize its health-care systems, semiconductor equipment and instruments businesses into three public companies (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors Shrug Off Talk of Global Rate Cut
abstract: American investors shrug off suggestion by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan that no global interest cut is immediately in store to help world's weak economies; Dow Jones industrial average finishes day 65 points higher; just a week ago, stock market soared on Greenspan's suggestion that global financial problems posed as great a threat to US as inflation did, suggesting that rate cut to stimulate economy might be on horizon (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Carl Loeb Kempner, 74, Broker And Educational Philanthropist
abstract: Carl Loeb Kempner, managing senior partner at Wall Street firm of Hamershlag, Kempner & Company and educational philanthropist, dies at age 74; photo (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 6/  Kevin C. O'Boyle of the Meridian Value fund has built an attractive performance record on ''busted growth'' stocks. By Carole Gould.    INVESTING IT /Page 6/  Amway, the multilevel marketer of products like detergent, wants to build a family of mutual funds. By Edward Wyatt.

headline: A Movie Producer's Own Cinderella Story
abstract: Interview with Tracey Trench, former 20th Century Fox executive who took over as creative producer of Fox's film Ever After when studio decided to cut budget and change script; photo (M)

headline: Earnings at Kmart and Gap Are Better Than Expected
abstract: Kmart Corp and Gap Inc report quarterly earnings that are better than expected; Saks Holdings Inc reports narrowing of losses; Kmart says profit before charge rose to $93 million in quarter ended July 29, up from net income of $31 million a year earlier; revenue rose 3.4 percent, to $8.12 billion from $7.85 billion; Gap says net income in second quarter ended Aug 1 rose to $136.9 million from $69.5 million a year earlier; revenue rose 42 percent, to $1.91 billion from $1.35 billion; Saks says loss before charge narrowed in quarter ended Aug 1 to $7.29 million from $8.6 million a year earlier; revenue rose 12 percent, to $509.6 million from $454.7 million; net loss was $11.1 million from $14.2 million a year earlier (M)

headline: ADOBE SHARES SLIDE 11% AFTER WARNING ABOUT RESULTS
abstract: Shares of Adobe Systems Inc fall 11 percent, one day after company says it might report third-quarter loss and will cut its work force by 10 percent; shares fall $3.4375, to $27.375 (S)

headline: Insurers Set $17.8 Billion Stock Deal
abstract: American International Group, world leader in corporate insurance, agrees to buy SunAmerica Inc, pioneer in selling investments for retirement, for stock valued at $17.8 billion; deal brings together a pair of chief executives--Maurice R (Hank) Greenberg of American International and Eli Broad of SunAmerica, with Greenberg continuing as chairman and chief executive and Broad becoming member of the board of merged company; chart (M)

headline: Tillman Durdin, 91, Reporter In China During World War II
abstract: Tillman Durdin, longtime foreign correspondent for The New York Times who was one of the first to write about the Japanese atrocities in China that became known as the Rape of Nanking, dies at age of 91; photo (M)

headline: Weaker Dollar and Debt Sale Help Keep Securities Depressed
abstract: Weaker US dollar and third part of Treasury's quarterly debt auctions keep prices of Government securities depressed; price of benchmark 30-year bond drops nearly a half-point, to 107, while its yield rises to 5.63 percent, from 5.60 on Aug 12; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: For Clancyland, a Game-to-Novel Pipeline
abstract: J C Herz column assesses Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six CD-ROM, a counterterrorism strategy action game that will be released in August in conjunction with a hardback novel of the same title, baed on the game; they are products of Clancy's new media venture, Red Storm Entertainment; photo (M)

headline: Signs Show 'Wintel' Axis Is Beginning To Wobble
abstract: Analysis of signs that industry-dominant alliance between Microsoft Windows personal computer operating system and Intel Corp computer chip may be unraveling; changes in computer technology and explosive growth of new consumer electronics products may be driving deeper wedge between companies than recently disclosed frustration of Intel executives about pressure from Microsoft chairman, Bill Gates (M)

headline: Worries About Loans Revive Ghost of 1980's Bank Debacle
abstract: Federal regulators and members of banking industry are concerned that banks may be lending too freely, either to rack up one-time fees or to generate other business; are criticizing freewheeling practices in certain markets, including trillion-dollar business of syndicated lending, dominated by Chase, Citicorp, J P Morgan, BankAmerica, Nationsbank and other big banks; Comptroller of the Currency reports that in 1995 only about 12 percent of syndicated loans went to companies already carrying heavy debt and subpar credit ratings, whereas fully 17 percent of syndicated loans in 1997 were to such indebted borrowers; figure soars to 31 percent at end of first-quarter 1998; Federal Reserve expresses concern that lending standards are slipping, presenting dangers in event economy stalls or borrowers have trouble paying what they owe; says only 20 to 30 percent of several hundred loans reviewed earlier in year were thoroughly screened by banks to see how well they would hold up during slump; graphs (M)

headline: Financial Unit Spun Off, British American Tobacco Rises 38%
abstract: Shares in renamed British American Tobacco PLC soar far ahead of rest of London's lackluster stock market in first day's trading since company sold its financial services arm to Zurich Group; at same time, newly merged Allied Zurich PLC loses ground, reflecting stock analysts' pessimism about combined financial unit; decision to spin off financial operations of what had been BAT Industries PLC was interpreted by some analysts as effort to court investors who had been troubled by tobacco-related litigation in US; Michael Prideaux, spokesman for British Tobacco, dismisses those assessments; British American Tobacco gains 1.285 pounds, or 38 percent, to 4.66 pounds (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VALERO ENERGY CORP.,  San Antonio, an independent oil refining and marketing company, said it would buy back as much as $100 million of its common stock, or about 9 percent of its 56 million outstanding shares.    COCA-COLA CO.,  Atlanta, signed an agreement to spend $36 million to build a bottling plant and 10 distribution depots in Angola, part of its strategy to double its soda sales in Africa by the end of 2003.

headline: Journalism Goes Hollywood, and Hollywood Is Reading
abstract: Tina Brown's announcement that she is quitting as editor of The New Yorker to develop magazine, television shows and movies with Miramax Films unit of Walt Disney Co, puts her in middle of one of hottest fashions in media industry: melding of journalism and Hollywood; Peter Bart, editor of Daily Variety, calls magazine articles 'the source du jour for movies'; situation has heightened concerns about how need to generate movie ideas has potential to warp journalistic principles and to create conflicts of interest within media conglomerates; there have been allegations, usually denied, that entertainment companies like Disney and Time Warner have used publications they own to promote films or other projects produced by their studios (M)

headline: For Macintosh Users, the Little How-To Book That Grew
abstract: Michel Marriott reviews The Little Mac Book, Fifth Edition, by Robin Williams; photo (M)

headline: Even as Asians Worry, China Is Unlikely to Devalue
abstract: Analysis: Many economists who understand peculiar characteristics of China's half-reformed economic system agree that China will not devalue in coming year; weaker Chinese yuan could spur export growth at a time that economy is weakening, foreign investment is falling, and millions of urban workers are facing unemployment; China is in middle of wrenching shift from state-run to market-driven economy, trying to sell bulk of Government-owned industries, and last thing its leaders want is further cause of disruptions; many economists argue that making Chinese exports cheaper is inefficient way way to strengthen economy; in long run, maintaining currency makes economic sense by providing stable environment for investment, foreign and domestic; photo (M)

headline: Governing Party Seems to Hold Pivotal Mexican Statehouse
abstract: Miguel Aleman Velasco, wealthy television executive and son of former President, appears to be winning victory by broad margin as candidate of governing Institutional Revolutionary Party in gubernatorial elections in Mexican state of Veracruz; party also seems victorious in Oaxaca, but may suffer defeat in Aguascalientes (M)

headline: MEDIAONE GROUP TO BUY BACK UP TO 4.1% OF SHARES
abstract: Mediaone Group Inc will buy back up to 25 million shares, or 4.1 percent, of its common stock; buyback is worth more than $1.2 billion (S)

headline: V.A. Coopersmith, An Entrepreneur Of Apparel, 51
abstract: Victor A Coopersmith, fashion entrepreneur who in July closed company that made women's wool suits and other clothes designed by his wife, Andrea Jovine, drowned Sept 9 while swimming in Lake Powell near Page, Ariz; he was 51; photo (S)

headline: A Time-Delay Virus Skips Catastrophe Date
abstract: Symantec Anti-Virus Research Center says CIH computer virus, which was supposed to affect machines running Windows 95 and 98 on July 26, does not appear to have struck (S)

headline: U.N. Team Lays Most Blame in Algeria on Islamic 'Terrorists'
abstract: United Nations panel of political leaders who visited Algeria to study violence that has killed tens of thousands of people blames terrorists for most of deaths; holds Government deserves world's sympathy; team, led by former Portuguese Pres Mario Soares, also cites 'excesses' by Government forces against civilians; Amnesty International scores 'whitewash' of Government abuses, noting team did not meet with leaders of outlawed Islamic Salvation Front; Pof Donald McHenry, team member, says team did not try to conduct human rights probe, interview (M)

headline: ENRON OIL AND GAS TO BUY INTEREST IN NATURAL-GAS FIELD
abstract: Enron Oil & Gas Co agrees to buy 19 percent stake in Gulf of Mexico natural-gas field from Union Pacific Resources Group for $158 million (S)

headline: The Holders of Russian Debt Begin Blocking Overseas Assets
abstract: Foreign holders of Russian debt, struggling to recover some of their billions in losses, have begun blocking Russian bank accounts and other assets overseas, resorting to courts to unravel tangled skein of loan, bond and currency-contract defaults; Lehman Brothers Holdings wins court battle in London, freezing British bank accounts of two big Russian banks, Inkombank and Unexim Bank; Lehman contends two banks defaulted on $110 million of obligations to Lehman and Lehman clients; consortium of 17 banks led by Deutsche Bank are pressing Russian Government to offer better terms to holders of defaulted bonds (M)

headline: Rome Journal; Italy Is Speechless: Movies Lose Their Voices
abstract: Two-month strike by dubbers in Italy, where over 75 percent of all new releases are imports, has all but paralyzed television and movie industry; threatens to block release of over dozen long-awaited films; could prove very costly to movie studios and television networks; dubbers seek national contract, better wages and share in royalties; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Corrections of Favorite Funds table on Data Bank page on Sept 20, which misstated basis for selecting funds; footnote with Bank Savings Rates table missted scale for strength ratings of listed banks; Favorite Funds table used outdated price and performance figures

headline: Finding A Gauge Can Be Tricky
abstract: Article describes potential mistakes in gauging mutual fund performance against wrong benchmark; charts (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (L)

headline: International Briefs; Singapore Eases Grip On Its Currency
abstract: Singapore says it will loosen its grip on its currency by allowing companies to use it overseas, unlocking potentially huge market for new securities denominated in Singapore dollars (S)

headline: You Can Surf Together But Who Gets to Drive?
abstract: Hip Bone Software releases Co-navigator, software that eanbles two or more individuals sitting at separate computers to surf Web together and see same Web pages; photo (S)

headline: F.H. Wheaton Jr.,85; Headed Glass Works
abstract: Frank Hayes Wheaton Jr, former head of Wheaton Industry, dies at age 85 (S)

headline: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Clearing Genetic Drug
abstract: Advisory committee to Food and Drug Administration recommends approval of Isis Pharmaceutical Inc's drug called Vitravene, first drug using new technology that blocks genes from performing their functions; drug treats viral infection that can cause blindness in people with AIDS; analysts expect drug to be marked by Ciba Vision subsidiary of Novartis AG (M)

headline: New Title on the Cutlass Edge of Software
abstract: J C Herz asses Cyberflix's new computer game Red Jack: Revenge of the Brethren; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.38   5.51        3-month T-bills   4.63   4.48   4.90        6-month T-bills   4.61   4.61   5.04        10-yr. T-infl.   3.64   3.65   3.55        10-yr. T-note   4.66   4.69   6.05        30-yr. T-bond   5.12   5.14   6.35        Telephone bd.   7.08   7.03   7.45        Municipal bds.   5.07   5.10   5.43          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Media; The Internet news audience is young, male and hungry for facts. And it's checking in from work.
abstract: Internet news sites are drawing small fraction of news consumers, but it is a fraction advertisers find desirable--younger men with college degrees and professional jobs; biggest difference between Internet and other news outlets is that Internet is read less at home and more at workplace, although home consumption of on-line news is also rising; chart (M)

headline: International Briefs; Unilever Says Profit Was Flat in 2d Quarter
abstract: Unilever says its second-quarter profit was little changed; net income before exceptional items edged up to 472 million pounds ($769 million), from 466 million pounds a year earlier; sales for period ended June 30 fell to 7.4 billion pounds, from 7.9 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: Shares Continue to Retreat as Investors Lose Direction
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 23.17 points, to 8,574.85; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 6.31 points, to 1,083.14; Nasdaq composite index falls 7.56 points, closing at 1,839.21; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; chart (M)

headline: In AT&T-TCI Deal, Cost and Logistical Problems
abstract: As executives of AT&T and Tele-Communications Inc scramble to sell Wall Street and American consumer on wisdom of ambitious $31.8 billion merger, it is becoming clear that technology needed to bring high-speed Internet access and low-cost telephone calls into American homes over television cables by year 2000 will tread costly path from laboratory; in addition to $1.8 billion that TCI will spend to upgrade one-way cable network to two-way service capable of carrying digital video and sound, AT&T must persuade customers to buy advanced set-top boxes, and must install new generation of advanced Internet routers capable of offering clear voice quality, at its own expense; final cost for entire project could run additional $10 billion or more, and consumers could face sundry logistical problems once digital phones arrive in homes; AT&T's chief technology officer David Nagel voices confidence; says problems are very solvable, noting company's experience working with cable industry on challenges of digital telephony over past decade; diagram (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SOVEREIGN BANCORP, Wyomissing, Pa., said it had bought First Home Bancorp, Pennsville, N.J., for $86 million. First Home has $523 million in assets.    LIBERTY CORP., Greenville, S.C., said its Cosmos Broadcasting unit had acquired WALB-TV in Albany, Ga., an NBC affiliate, from a unit of Gray Communications Systems Inc. in a deal valued at $78 million.

headline: Security Fears Still Plague Cybershopping
abstract: Fears about giving one's credit-card number over the Internet inhibit growth of on-line shopping; some on-line retailers will allow customers to give their card numbers over the phone; other will not store credit-card numbers or will assign identification numbers to their customers for on-line use while keeping credit-card numbers behind a fire wall (M)

headline: Creditors Unhappy With Marvel Plan
abstract: Unsecured creditors and investors oppose Marvel Entertainment Group plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection by combining with Toy Biz Inc, Federal court (S)

headline: American Topics: Hagers-Town Almanack Offers Advice,Weather Forecasts and a Family Tradition
abstract: It may not be quite as well-known as Poor Richard's Almanac, first published in 1733 by Benjamin Franklin, or as the Farmer's Almanac, but the Hagers-Town Almanack, a slice of pure Americana, has been published by the same family longer than any of its rivals.

headline: Consumer Prices Barely Rose Last Month
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of a percent in June, down from rise of three-tenths of a percent in May; Commerce Department reports retail sales rose one-tenth of a percent, to $225.691 billion, after surging revised 1.2 percent in May (S)

headline: Chief of Packard Bell NEC Steps Down
abstract: Co-founder Beny Alagem resigns as Packard Bell NEC Inc chief executive and president, citing differences with company's main investor, NEC Corp, and Groupe Bull, minority shareholder (S)

headline: Finding Family Roots on Line
abstract: David A Podmajersky letter comments on successful genealogical research he did on the internet (Aug 6 article)

headline: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO BUY NORTHLAND UNIT
abstract: Associates First Capital Corp says it will buy insurance business of privately held Northland Co; terms not disclosed, but Associates reportedly agreed to pay $700 million (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Issues a Stern Warning on Kosovo
abstract: The American envoy leading efforts to resolve the conflict in Kosovo said today that the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, had ''no justification'' for pressing his campaign against insurgents and warned that he faced a devastating blow if he refused to stop.    The envoy, Christopher R. Hill, who is Ambassador to Macedonia, said that the United Nations Security Council's resolution calling for an end to the fight and NATO's threats of using military force could help forge a diplomatic resolution.

headline: Treasury Prices Dip, in Unusual Tandem With Wall Street
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities fall for first time in five days; 30-year bond's price falls 19/32, to 105 8/32; yield rises to 5.15 percent, from 5.12 percent on Sept 21; graph on yields of selected Treasury securities; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: TUESDAY    The Commerce Department reports on retail sales for June; an increase of 0.1 percent is expected; excluding auto sales, economists expect flat results.  The Labor Department reports on the Consumer Price Index for June; an increase of 0.2 percent is forecast.    WEDNESDAY    The Commerce Department reports on business inventories for May.

headline: U.N. Aide Quits Iraq Relief Post
abstract: Denis J Halliday, Irish official who ran United Nations program that lets Iraq sell oil and buy food, has decided to leave post after less than year (S)

headline: North Korea Draws Anger With Test Of a Missile
abstract: Congressional leaders, already angered at reports that North Korea may be building new underground nuclear weapons plant, respond to firing of new medium-range missile across Japan with threats to cut off all food aid and other assistance to North Koreans (M)

headline: Merger Talks by Makers Of Armored Vehicles
abstract: GKN PLC is in talks to merge its armored-vehicles unit with Alvis PLC to create military company with annual sales of about 300 million pounds ($500 million) (S)

headline: Scientists Say Pakistani Defector Is Not Credible
abstract: Scientists who questioned Iftikhar Khan Chaudhry, who claims to be defector from Pakistan's nuclear arms program, say he know nothing about nuclear physics; Khan, seeking asylum in United States, claimed he was present at meeting at which Pakistan's military high command authorized preemptive nuclear attack on New Delhi (M)

headline: Stocks Rise as a Result of Guarded Optimism, Analysts Say
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 149.85 points, or 1.92 percent, to 7,945.35,; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 20.66 points, or 2.05 percent, to 1,029.72; Nasdaq composite index increases 24.05 points, or 1.46 percent, to 1,665.69; Russell 2000 index of small stocks rises 4.10 points, or 1.16 percent, to 357.72; graph; chart (L)

headline: House Panel Blocks New Funds for I.M.F.
abstract: US House Appropriations Committee, rejecting pleas by Clinton Adm, votes against full financing for IMF; action appears to doom efforts by Adm and Senate, which has already approved full funding, to replenish fund's reserves (S)

headline: Controversy Over the Death Of a Serb War Crime Suspect
abstract: A lawyer for a Bosnian Serb who died this month in a cell while being tried by the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague bled to death because he did not get proper medical care, his lawyer says.    The lawyer, Dusan Vucicevic, said the tribunal was guilty of negligence and of causing the ''wrongful death'' of his client. He said he would demand that it pay damages to his client's family in Bosnia.

headline: Media Talk; Globe's Ex-Columnist Defends His Work
abstract: Mike Barnicle, former Boston Globe column, said on Sept 18 he hoped to buy full-page ad in Sept 22 Globe to defend authenticity, if not accuracy, of 1995 column that led to his forced resignation last month; Globe has refused to run Barnicle's defense on its op-ed page (S)

headline: Business Travel; Fliers are coping with the Northwest strike, but things could get much tougher after Labor Day.
abstract: Business Travel column finds pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines has not caused tremendous disruption so far for business travelers, since many carriers are temporarily increasing service at Northwest's primary hubs in Detroit and Minneapolis-St Paul; although disruptions for travelers have so far been minimal, industry officials predict they could become quite severe if strike extends into two weeks after Labor Day, when business travel normally picks up; scramble by American Airlines, Delta, TWA, United, Kiwi International, Sun Country Airlines, Japan Air Lines and Cathay Pacific to handle disruptions discussed; move by corporate travel companies, such as American Express, Carlson Wagonlit Travel and Rosenbluth International to help stranded clients noted (M)

headline: Injunction Denied in Cantor Fitzgerald Suit
abstract: Delaware judge acknowledges in decision released July 12 that Cantor Fitzgerald LP is likely to prevail in at least part of legal battle over use of bond-trading technology; he denied company's request for injunction to stop introduction of Market Power, interactive electronic trading system that is scheduled to start on July 31; Cantor Fitzgerald has sued Iris Cantor, widow of its founder, and her nephew, Rodney A Fisher, as well as Market Data, a company that they control; suit contends that Cantor family members violated partnership agreement spelling out their continuing interest in Cantor Fitzgerald (S)

headline: Pakistani Says A-Strike Was Planned On India
abstract: Dr Iftikhar Khan Chaudhry, who claims to be defector from Pakistan's nuclear arms program, says in New York that Pakistan's top military leadership, fearing imminent Indian nuclear attack, decided on April 25 to launch pre-emptive nuclear strike on New Delhi within 48 hours; says he was dismissed for opposing attack and his wife is being held by internal security forces; seeks asylum in United States; Pakistan says Khan is fraud who made up story to win US citizenship (M)

headline: Italians Recover 3 Paintings Stolen in a Brazen Robbery
abstract: Italian police recover two Van Gogh paintings and one Cezanne that were stolen from National Gallery of Modern Art in Rome by three armed robbers on May 19; arrest eight suspects in pre-dawn raids in Turin and Rome; photo (M)

headline: Pakistan's Debt Rating Is Lowered by S.& P.
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp downgrades credit rating of Pakistan to CCC from B-, which is lowest assessment of any country rated by firm (S)

headline: Elections in 3 States Are an Early Test for Zedillo's Party
abstract: Governing party of Mexican Pres Ernesto Zedillo coasts to victory in gubernatorial balloting in Chihuahua, but more important contests in neighboring Durango and Zacatecas remain too close to call; elections are seen as crucial early test of opposition chances to defeat Zedillo's Institutional Revolutionary Party in Presidential balloting in 2000; map; photo (M)

headline: 30-Year Treasury Unchanged As Fed Holds Line on Rates
abstract: Bond prices remain unchanged on July 1 following Federal Reserve decision not to hike interest rates; Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond closes at 107 6/32, yielding 5.62 percent (S)

headline: WILLIAMS SCOTSMAN AND SPACE MASTER TO MERGE
abstract: Williams Scotsman Inc to buy Space Master International Inc for some $270 million, using bank debt and equity investments from Cypress Merchant Banking Partners LP, Keystone Inc and Odyssey Investment Partners Fund LP (S)

headline: U.S. Faults Depositions of Microsoft Executives
abstract: Justice Department, in court document made public, charges top executives of Microsoft Corp, including its chairman, William H Gates, of 'an astonishing lack of recall' when they were questioned under oath for Government's antitrust suit against Microsoft; assertion, along with several pieces of new evidence to support Government's case, is submitted to Federal District Court, Washington, in response to Microsoft's request that case be dismissed; Microsoft spokesman says it is unfortunate that Government has 'resorted to this kind of name calling'; notes Gates receives hundreds of pieces of E-mail every day and cannot be expected to remember every one of them (M)

headline: Russia and U.S. Plan to Guard Atom Secrets
abstract: Russian and American officials agree on program to discourage Russia's nuclear scientists from leaving for Iraq, Iran or other aspiring nuclear powers; plan to create commercial, non-military projects in Russia's closed nuclear cities; United States Sec Bill Richardson and Russian Min Yevgeny Adamov sign accord, Vienna (M)

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens; Consumer Prices Up 0.2%
abstract: Commerce Department reports trade deficit widened 2 percent in July as exports fell for fourth consecutive month; deficit grew to $13.9 billion in July after having narrowed in June to revised $13.6 billion; exports fell 1.3 percent, to $75.4 billion, lowest level since February 1997; imports fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $89.3 billion; Labor Department says consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in August; in first eight months of 1998, consumer prices rose at 1.6 percent annual rate; Labor Department report shows that 299,000 workers filed for state unemployment benefits last week, down from 314,000 a week earlier; workers' average weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, rose half a percent in August (M)

headline: Holier Than Thou: Behind the Iranian-Afghan Rift
abstract: Analysis of tension between conservative Islamic Governments in Iran and Afghanistan; Iran's Shiite Muslim clerics and Sunni Muslim clerics of Afghanistan's Taliban militants are on opposing sides of great Islamic divide; Iran has accused Taliban, whose curbs, particularly on women, are far more rigid than those enforced in Iran, of giving Islam bad name and has backed rival Afghan militia; threatens action unless Taliban discloses fate of diplomats and other Iranians caught up in Aug fighting in Afghanistan; all-out war seems unlikely; map; photo (M)

headline: SCHEIN IN $145.5 MILLION DEAL FOR MEER DENTAL SUPPLY
abstract: Henry Schein Inc to acquire Meer Dental Supply Co for $145.5 million in stock (S)

headline: Mark Strengthens
abstract: Mark gains on unexpectedly large decline in German unemployment and signs of tax reform in Russia; unemployment falls by 120,000 persons in June, double previous month's decline; in London trading, dollar declines to 1.8189 marks from 1.8205 in New York on Thursday (S)

headline: How Laser Shows Get Their Dazzle
abstract: Article describes how laser light shows are produced; diagrams (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Existing-Home Sales -- July  Consumer Confidence    WEDNESDAY  Durable Goods -- July    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims  Gross Domestic Product -- 2d Qtr. revised.    FRIDAY  Personal Income -- July

headline: HICKS, MUSE MAY BUY 35 PERCENT STAKE IN TRITON ENERGY
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc agrees to buy as much as 35 percent of Triton Energy Ltd; Hicks, Muse will pay $130 million to Triton initially and then invest up to $220 million more (S)

headline: Congo Replay
abstract: Howard W French analysis says that when rebellious Congolese troops announced their intention of overthrowing Pres Laurent Kabila and seized two large cities in eastern part of country on Aug 3, many people had impression that they were reliving familiar drama; says in almost every detail, Central African nation is witnessing replay of events in late 1996 and early 1997 that brought down dictator Mobutu Sese Seko and propelled Kabila to power; says reports that rebels are receiving reinforcement from across Rwandan border echo those of last uprising, and there are once again accusations of witch hunt unleashed against Rwandans by Government in Kinshasa; says immediate trigger for conflict was Kabila's expulsion of Rwandan military advisers from Congo, but at that point Rwanda had already apparently concluded that Kabila was unlikely to deliver what it wants most: quiet on their common border and protection for Tutsi minority living in eastern Congo; map (M)

headline: Steven Myers Acquisition
abstract: Steven Myers & Associates Inc plans to acquire Decision-Science Applications Inc for $30.9 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: F.B.I. Is Invited to Join Inquiry Into Bombing
abstract: South African Government asks Federal Bureau of Investigation to join its inquiry into explosion at Planet Hollywood restaurant in Cape Town that killed one person and wounded 26 others; FBI is invited not so much to assist local investigators, but to see if there are any links between Planet Hollywood bombing and others against US institutions around world; map; photo (M)

headline: Dutch Investigate an Internet Ring; Belgians Seize Video Cassettes : 2 Pedophilia Cases Stir Action by EU
abstract: BRUSSELS  Two major pedophilia cases in Europe have broken into the open, with Dutch police confirming Friday that they were investigating an Internet pornographic network and a report in Belgium that police were seeking to identify 340 children and adolescents shown in seized pornographic video cassettes.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: CENDANT CORP., Parsippany, N.J., promoted Mary Mahoney to president and chief executive of its Howard Johnson hotel chain, succeeding Stephen Phillips, who will become chief executive at the AFM Hospitality Corp. in Toronto.    CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON, New York, hired Jack Kirnan of Salomon Smith Barney Inc. as a managing director and deputy head of United States stock research.

headline: Judge Asks G.M. and Union to Set Arbitration Date
abstract: Federal Judge Paul V Gadola Jr asks General Motors Corp and United Auto Workers to schedule a date for arbitration of strikes at two parts factories in Flint, Mich, as top negotiators from GM and union talk face to face for first time in three days; Gadola does not grant GM's request for order that arbitration begin immediately; urges both sides to agree by July 21 on date to meet with arbiter Thomas Roberts; UAW vice president Richard Shoemaker says arbitration process will slow a settlement in Flint (M)

headline: Cleaned-Up Computers
abstract: Steven A Ludsin letter on Aug 27 article urges cautious, gradual approach to purging old computer data

headline: Patents; The inventors of board games pursue the serious business of fun, games and learning.
abstract: Patents column discusses several new board games that have recently won patents; some variants to common methods players use to advance their positions in games noted (M)

headline: Compact Disk Pictures Offered By Kodak and Intel Partnership
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co and Intel Corp introduce compact disk for pictures; Picture CD combines digital versions of prints photographers receive when they submit film for processing with software to enhance, crop and E-mail those photographs; new disk will cost consumers $8.95 to $10.95 on top of regular processing costs (S)

headline: MOTIVEPOWER TO BUY YOUNG RADIATOR FOR $70.5 MILLION
abstract: Motivepower Industries to acquire Young Radiator Co, a closely held maker of heat transfer products, for $70.5 million (S)

headline: In Florida's Fires, A Test for a New Insurance Policy
abstract: Immense summer wildfires across central Florida are resulting in scaling back of homeowners insurance by limiting most payments to 120 percent of insured value rather than full replacement cost; photos (M)

headline: I.M.F. Resists 'Blackmail' by Russia and U.S.
abstract: Senior official of IMF warns that he will neither submit to 'blackmail' of Russian leaders who threaten national default if they are denied billions of dollars in aid, nor let Congress 'impose conditions' on fund in return for $18 billion in new contributions from United States (M)

headline: Medicine at the Click of a Mouse; On-Line Health Files Are Convenient. Are They Private?
abstract: Medical industry is rapidly going on line, propelled by soaring popularity of the Internet plus shifting economics of health care; growing number of insurers and doctors are using Internet to provide members and patients with personal medical information, from lab results to payment records; new on-line services raises serious questions about privacy of highly personal information; issue fits squarely into broader debate about privacy and security on the Internet; graph; photos (M)

headline: Experts Question Roving Flow of Global Capital
abstract: Many experts say one factor behind economic crisis that is reverberating around world is fantastic increase in pool of capital that is moved from one country to next and one currency to next in search of safety and profit; the sums are so gargantuan, far greater than amount government can wield, that many economists are calling for steps to control these capital flows or at least soften their impact; topic is expected to be widely discussed at upcoming special meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from Group of Seven countries (M)

headline: China Attacks 'Hidden' Crime: Smuggling
abstract: China's leaders, after years of tolerating steady growth of lawlessness at their borders, announce war on smuggling; announces that new anti-smuggling police force will be formed, in sharp indictment of how corrupt and ineffectual Chinese Customs officials have become (M)

headline: LIBRARY/GRAMMAR TUTORS; All Write: A Versatile Coach
abstract: ALL WRITE (McGraw-Hill; $27.50; Windows 3.0 and later and NT.)

headline: MET LIFE ANNOUNCES PLANS TO CUT 1,950 NONSALES JOBS
abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co plans to cut 1,950 jobs, or up to 10 percent of its work force, in positions not related to sales; Met Life says planned reductions are part of its effort to lower overall expenses (S)

headline: SUHARTO REBUILDS HIS POLITICAL BASE TO SHIELD FORTUNE
abstract: Former Pres Suharto of Indonesia is maneuvering to rebuild political power base to shield his family's financial empire from scrutiny by future Governments and help his children keep their top posts in ruling Golkar party; he and his six children are offering to underwrite political campaigns of legislators who vow loyalty to family; Suharto does not seem to be seeking reinstatement as President, but remains chairman of party's patrons board and retains close ties to military; two of his children are on seven-member organizing committee for congress and four are members of highest legislative body (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Bringing Extra Passion to a Fine Romance
abstract: Description and assessment of Ceremony of Innocence CD-ROM, which is based on Nick Bantock's Griffin and Sabine books; photo (M)

headline: Allied Domecq Sets Reductions to Earnings
abstract: Allied Domecq PLC to take added 115 million pounds ($186 million) in one-time charge in fiscal 1998 to reflect moves to shed some assets and revalue its British pub holdings (S)

headline: Kosovo Assault Steps Up, Making Thousands More Homeless
abstract: Fear grows over fate of tens of thousands of refugees in Serbian province of Kosovo who have been fleeing what appears to be huge Government military offensive; large columns of terrified civilians emerge from combat zones; authorities block international monitors from area; international relief officials estimate 20,000 to 30,000 ethnic Albanians have fled Yugoslav Government forces trying to take areas back from rebels; foreign diplomats say Govt may be trying to clear ethnic Albanians from areas of military importance; maps; photo (M)

headline: NEWS WATCH; With a Ball-Point Scanner, Cupboards Need Never Be Bare
abstract: Symbol Technologies introduces the Infopen, ball-point pen that is also portable bar-code scanner; users can scan bar-codes of products they need, upload the data into personal computer and place on-line order; photo (S)

headline: Can Football Revive CBS?; Network Places A $4 Billion Bet That Its Deal With the N.F.L. Will Bring Back Days of Glory
abstract: CBS is betting heavily on football to restore it to profitability, having agreed to pay $500 million a year for eight years for package of American Football Conference games; football broadcasts come at critical time for CBS and its president, Mel Karmazin, driving force behind deal; CBS executives defend deal, which they expect to boost prime-time shows by attracting young male viewers; table of data on CBS; photos (M)

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; An Open Internet Helps Business, Too
abstract: Article by Sendmail Inc co-founder Greg Olson holds Microsoft, embroiled in controversy over its Windows operationg system, poses even greater threat in its practice of developing proprietary, vendor-controlled software and its encrouchment on Internet (M)

headline: Toyota to Raise Its Stake in Mini-Vehicle Maker
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp to spend 37.1 billion yen ($259 million) to raise its stake in Daihatsu Motor Co, Japan's second-largest mini-vehicle maker, to 51.2 percent from 34.5 percent (S)

headline: Abuja Journal; Marble Mogul Caters to the Nigerian Capital's Elite
abstract: Abuja, Nigeria's capital-under-construction, is home to military officers who ruled country for two decades, and siphoned off good share of its oil revenue; they are building vast mansions, with gold-inlaid basins in bathrooms, Jacuzzi baths, sophisticated water purifiers and huge quantities of Italian marble; Nigeria has huge reserves of marble and granite, but mismanagement has led domestic industry to ruin; Theodore Luttwak, a naturalized Italian citizen, is making fortune importing marble to adorn mansions of Abuja; photo; map (M)

headline: Executive Group Is Formed at Lehman
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings establishes executive committee of its top managers, which Lehman's chairman and chief executive, Richard Fuld, says should squash market speculation that a president will be appointed (S)

headline: Three Marketers Name Agencies for Accounts
abstract: Motley Fool names Martin Agency as first advertising agency to handle its account; Miller Brewing Co names UNO Communications to handle advertising aimed at Spanish consumers for Miller Lite beer brand; account had been handled by Lucero/Bentz; Advance America names BBDO South to handle its account, which had been handled by Bazil-Victory (S)

headline: GULFSTREAM BUYING KIMBERLY-CLARK AVIATION UNIT
abstract: Gulfstream Aerospace Corp to acquire K-C Aviation from Kimberly-Clark Corp for $250 million (S)

headline: BAXTER TO TAKE CHARGES AND DISCONTINUE A PRODUCT
abstract: Baxter International Inc will take third-quarter charges of $293 million, mainly to settle breast-implant lawsuits, and will end production of blood substitute Hemassist; it will continue to develop experimental blood substitute acquired with its $188 million purchase of Somatogen Inc in May; it will cut about 100 employees as it closes Hemassist operations (S)

headline: BankBoston Deal Is Backed by Fed
abstract: Federal Reserve approves BankBoston Corp's pending purchase of Robertson Stephens from BankAmerica Corp (S)

headline: Meciar Turns Out the Stars to Get Votes
abstract: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  As Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar of Slovakia cut the ribbon on a short stretch of highway near here last week, the German supermodel Claudia Schiffer flashed her million-dollar smile and said Slovakia was a beautiful country.

headline: Raids by U.S. Agents and Tirana Police Reportedly Thwarted Attack on Embassy
abstract: American intelligence agents, teaming up with Albanian secret police, may have thwarted bomb plot against Embassy in capital of Tirana; seem to have broken up ring of Egyptian Islamic terrorists, using nation's anarchy to set up base; US national security adviser, Samuel R Berger, ties threats to various embassies to cruise missile strikes against targets in Afghanistan and Sudan; other officials say Embassy in Tirana was one to those threatened (M)

headline: New Party Chief Gets Low Ratings on Tokyo Streets
abstract: Japanese seem almost unanimously dissatisfied with Liberal Democratic Party's choice of Keizo Obuchi as party leader and future Prime Minister; see him as bland and overly cautious; governing party is especially unpopular in urban areas like Tokyo, where economic troubles have exacted highest toll (M)

headline: Indonesia, Shaken but Determined, Looks to 53d Anniversary
abstract: JAKARTA  Overshadowed by a deepening recession and fears of renewed riots, Indonesia marks its 53d anniversary of independence Monday under a president who is battling to revive confidence in the government's ability to rebuild the economy, maintain order and carry out political reform.

headline: Kazimierz Dziewanowski, Ambassador of Poland
abstract: Kazimierz Dziewanowski, Ambassador of Poland to United States from 1990 to 1993, dies; photo (M)

headline: Rivals Have Found Little to Fight Over In German Election
abstract: German voters will elect Chancellor on Sept 27; one of most striking features of hard-fought election campaign is that Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his opponent, Gerhard Schroder, are fighting about very little; voters may be eager for change of Government, but there is little popular pressure for sweeping changes in policy or in Germany's protective social-market economy; this may explain why race between Kohl and Schroder remains far too tight to call, with polls showing many voters still undecided (M)

headline: TMP WORLDWIDE TO BUY AUSTRALIAN RECRUITER
abstract: TMP Worldwide Inc., one of the world's largest recruiters and the owner of the Monster Board job-search Internet site, will buy the Australian recruiter Morgan & Banks Ltd. for $209 million in stock. The stockholders of Morgan & Banks will get no more than 0.1124 share and no less than 0.07025 share of TMP stock for each share held, based on the currency exchange rate at closing. Shares of TMP jumped $2.3125 yesterday, to $36.125; they have soared more than 51 percent in the last 12 months. TMP, based in New York, is betting that buying Morgan & Banks will bolster its intern-to-chief-executive strategy as more people turn to the Internet for jobs and employees.

headline: Demand Surge Costs Utilities Huge Losses on Open Market
abstract: Firstenergy Corp and Illinova report suffering huge losses from having to buy electricity on open market when prices surged during recent Midwest heat wave; say losses will result in much lower earnings; other utilities have also reported large losses stemming from jump in demand that drove spot prices to as high as $7,000 a megawatt-hour from usual price range of $30 to $50 (M)

headline: German Trade Surplus Surges to $8.2 Billion
abstract: Germany's merchandise trade surplus widened in May to record 14.6 billion marks, or $8.2 billion, from 11.4 billion marks, or $6.4 billion, in April (S)

headline: Hip but Not Haughty At Barneys New York; A Store in Transition Works to Expand Its Base Without Losing Its Character
abstract: Barneys New York, luxury retailer with reputation for snootiness, has undergone enormous business changes as it prepares to emerge from bankruptcy; has subtly altered image and adopted disciplines, back-office controls and service standards of more traditional retailers; Thomas C Shull, new chief executive, seeks to lure more customers, make stores more profitable and spur growth while retaining wealthy, hip customers; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Auto Tariff Pact Eludes South Americans
abstract: Argentine and Brazilian officials, in potentially serious blow to $15 billion auto industry in South America, have failed to complete long-awaited agreement for common car tariffs that auto executives had hoped would be ready for signing at regional economic summit meeting in Ushuaia, Argentina; officials of two countries say they might still be able to draw up common auto trade policy by end of year, but independent analysts say presidential campaign politics in two countries could stall progress until end of 1999; South American auto executives are concerned that major auto companies might delay planned investments valued at more than $500 million until Argentina and Brazil iron out their trade differences (M)

headline: GLUT FORCES CHIP-EQUIPMENT MAKER TO CUT STAFF BY 20%
abstract: Ultratech Stepper Inc cuts 120 full-time jobs, about 20 percent of its work force, to cut costs; will require remaining workers to take two days off a month for rest of year (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: C. Beth Cotner; Putnam Investors Fund
abstract: Article assesses performance of Putnam Investors, large-capitalization growth fund; lead manager C Beth Cotner comments on strategies that lead to high return rate; photo; graphs; charts (M)

headline: As Rebels Near, Congo's President Scrambles for Support
abstract: Pres Laurent Kabila of Congo scrambles to obtain foreign military support to repel final assault by rebels closing in capital of Kinshasa; wins pledges of military and other support from Zimbabwe, Kenya and Angola; is unable to win larger political cover of group of 14 African nations; photo; maps (M)

headline: Crisis Batters Emerging Economy, Sending Rand to New Lows
abstract: Economic crisis in Russia has hit South Africa hard, dealing sharp blow to emerging economy already hurt by Asian crisis; rand, worth about 15 cents, is touching new lows; Russia exports many of same commodities that South Africa does; economists say South Africa is concerned that Russia may sell all it can, driving prices down (M)

headline: The 'Buys' Have It: Beware the Pollyanna Message From Brokers
abstract: Mark Hurlbert article offers advice to investors on developing stock selling discipline despite bullishness of some brokers; chart (M)

headline: Watch what the Internet asks children, sponsors are warned, or see the government step in.
abstract: Advertising column on conference sponsored by Children's Advertising Review Unit, during which advertisers and agencies involved in aiming on-line sales pitches at children were warned to toughen their policies for protecting privacy or suffer consequences of growing demands from parents and government officials for restrictive regulation (M)

headline: State regulators announce a series of blows against 'boiler room' securities operations.
abstract: Securities regulators from more than 29 states bring enforcement actions against 75 brokerage and investment firms across country for using high-pressure sales tactics to mislead and defraud investors; actions amount to one of biggest crackdowns ever on 'boiler rooms' of telephone salespeople who prey on gullible or naive investors (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Chief Investment Strategist: Paine Webber Inc.
abstract: Article on investment strategies of Edward M Kerschner, chief investment strategist at Paine Webber Inc; Kerschner says many of his stock picks are linked to needs of baby boomers; photo (M)

headline: S.A.S. PLACES $400 MILLION ORDER FOR 737-600 AIRCRAFT
abstract: Scandinavian Airlines System orders 13 new 737-600 aircraft worth about $400 million from Boeing Co; contract brings number of 737-600 planes that SAS has on order with Boeing to 55 (S)

headline: Banana Republic, Discover Card, ABC, Kraft Foods and Sears start the fourth-quarter flood.
abstract: Week after Labor Day always brings torrent of advertising intended to stimulate consumers to step up their shopping during important fourth quarter; several big advertisers in categories from retailing to media to packaged goods are beginning multimillion-dollar marketing blitzers; ad campaigns by Banana Republic, Discover Card, ABC, Kraft Foods and Sears, Roebuck & Co discussed (Advertising column) (M)

headline: It's a Video Game, It's TV, and You're the Star
abstract: New series of video games developed by Radical Entertainment under the aegis of ESPN Digital Games have the look and feel of live ESPN sports broadcasts, but with the user as star player; first three games, to be released this fall, feature hockey, basketball and snowboarding; photos (M)

headline: Telefonica Names Alcatel as Supplier
abstract: Telefonica SA of Spain selects Alcatel SA of France as primary supplier for wireless telecommunications equipment; Alcatel says equipment supply contract covers Spain, Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru (S)

headline: For Navajos, Charity Begins at the Post Office
abstract: Article on Southwest Indian Foundation in Gallup, New Mexico, which sells merchandise nationwide via mail-order catalog, provides jobs for as many as 60 people during peak holiday season and sponsors local reservation's social service programs; photos (L)

headline: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs
abstract: Twenty people are killed or wounded in apparent drug-related massacre in Ensenada, Mexico, 60 miles south of US border; photo; map; victims were forced out of homes, lined up against wall and shot by gunmen with assault rifles; dead include women and young children; authorities say Fermin Castro, shot with his family, was under investigation as part of drug smuggling ring (S)

headline: Are Small-Cap Stocks Ready for a Rally?
abstract: Article explores possibility that small-cap stock values will rally; graph (M)

headline: Dow Moves 65.39 Higher in Its Fourth Straight Advance
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 65.39 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 8,089.78; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 7.80 points, to 1,045.48, while Nasdaq Composite gains 11.80, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,689.91; Government bonds climb; 30-year bond increases 17/32, to price of 104 7/32; yield slips to 5.22 percent, from 5.25 percent on Sept 15; graphs on Dow Jones industrial average and average for Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp participation certificates; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: NEXSTAR CONSIDERS SPINOFF OF DRUG UNIT
abstract: Nexstar Pharmaceuticals Inc says its board is considering spinning off its drug-discovery business, prompting president-chief executive Patrick Mahaffy to quit in disagreement; Mahaffy also leaves company's board; company will be led by its management committee, consisting of its chairman, Larry Gold, and four vice presidents (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS INC., Parsippany, N.J., the maker of Bumble Bee tuna and Pam cooking spray, said it had bought Libby's canned meat business, which has revenues of $139 million, from Nestle S.A., for undisclosed terms.

headline: Decrease in Exports Slows Growth in France
abstract: French economic growth slowed in first quarter as recession in Japan and other Asian economies cut exports; economy expanded six-tenths of a percent from fourth quarter, slowest pace for a year and down from gain of eight-tenths of a percent in fourth quarter (S)

headline: Pepsico to Post a $200 Million Tax Gain
abstract: Pepsico Inc plans to post third-quarter tax gain of at least $200 million from its Puerto Rico concentrate operations; company say it has decided to take gain because it has made satisfactory progress in dispute with Internal Revenue Service (S)

headline: The Economy: Signs of Health And Rays of Hope
abstract: Item on slow decline in stock values on US exchanges and impact it may have (M)

headline: Colombia Installs New President Who Plans to Talk to Rebels
abstract: Andres Pastrana, Conservative planning to begin peace talks with increasingly aggressive rebels, takes office as President of Colombia, ending scandal-ridden presidency of Ernesto Samper by declaring, 'Change begins today' (M)

headline: X-ceed Acquires Mercury Seven
abstract: X-ceed Inc acquires Mercury Seven Inc, development and consulting company that specializes in on-line services for Internet industry professionals; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Parliament Testily Backs Parts of Plan Yeltsin Seeks
abstract: Russia's lower house of Parliament hastily approves parts of Pres Boris N Yeltsin's latest economic austerity plan after members criticize plan at length; approves 20 percent value-added tax, new flat tax on small businesses, cut in corporate profits tax and repeal of tax on companies forced to sell products at loss (M)

headline: QUARTERLY DIVIDENDS TO GIVE WAY TO ANNUAL PAYMENTS
abstract: Walt Disney Co says its board has decided to pay dividends to shareholders on annual basis instead of quarterly, beginning next year, as a way to cut costs; Disney also says that because large number of investors own 10 or fewer shares, company is spending more on processing and postage than actual dividend payments to those stockholders are worth; Disney will make annual payments in November of each year (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS, Dallas, a provider of account management and data base services to retailers, bought the privately held Loyalty Management Group Canada Inc., a data base services and marketing company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.    DOMINION RESOURCES INC., Richmond, a utility holding company, said it would buy back up to $650 million in common stock, or about 8.25 percent of its shares outstanding. The company had 195.6 million shares outstanding as of April 30.

headline: HBO & COMPANY AND MCKESSON END MERGER TALKS
abstract: HBO & Co, nation's largest maker of health-care company software, and McKesson Corp confirm that they held talks about possible business combination and that talks ended on July 14 (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.56   5.49   5.64        3-month T-bills   4.82   4.91   5.07        6-month T-bills   4.85   4.90   5.14        10-yr. T-infl.   3.79   3.80   3.58        10-yr. T-note   5.06   5.19   6.29        30-yr. T-bond   5.34   5.42   6.57        Telephone bd.   7.09   7.05   7.61        Municipal bds.   5.12   5.13   5.53          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: Global Turmoil Leaves Europe Wondering How to Shield Economy
abstract: Debate grows in Europe about how to shield its economies from effects of economic turmoil elsewhere; Europe is proving remarkably resilient and is expected to sustain reasonable growth despite pressure on corporate profits (M)a

headline: Dell's Earnings Surge; PC Maker Says It Trails Only Compaq
abstract: Defying the inventory glut and macroeconomic woes that have waylaid its competitors, the Dell Computer Corporation reported a 62 percent gain in earnings for its second fiscal quarter yesterday, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates.     The computer maker, based in Round Rock, Tex., also announced another stock split.

headline: EMI Considers Bidding For Polygram Film Unit
abstract: EMI Group PLC weighs buying Polygram Filmed Entertainment, unit of Polygram NV, which Seagram Co is acquiring; graph of EMI stock price, which tumbles on news (S)

headline: Chiquita Case Illustrates Vulnerability of Voice Mail
abstract: Article discusses importance of maintaining voice-mail security in light of accusations that Cincinnati Enquirer reporter stole 2,000 messages from Chiquita Brands International's voice mail; photo of John Guinasso at ICG Netcom, company that has tightened security since voice-mail was penetrated by hacker a year ago (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL CORP., Dallas, said its president and chief operating officer, Harold D. Marshall, would resign next year.    HICKS, MUSE, TATE & FURST INC., Dallas, said Alan Menkes, a partner at the buyout firm, had resigned to pursue other opportunities.    SPELLING ENTERTAINMENT GROUP INC., Los Angeles, promoted Ross G. Landsbaum, its treasurer and vice president for finance and business development, to senior vice president and chief financial officer. The positions had been vacant since August 1997, when William P. Clark resigned to pursue other interests.    SPORTS AUTHORITY INC., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the sporting goods retailer, said Richard Lynch had resigned as president and chief operating officer. He also resigned from the company's board. Sports Authority's new chief executive, Martin Hanaka, will handle Mr. Lynch's duties until a replacement is named.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRINET CORPORATE REALTY TRUST INC., San Francisco, a real estate investment trust, bought a Dallas-area office building from Koll Real Estate Group for $45.7 million.    ASYST TECHNOLOGIES INC.,  Fremont, Calif., a maker of automation tools for the semiconductor industry, said it would buy closely held robot maker Hine Design Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., for $24 million in cash and assumed debt.    THYSSEN INC. NORTH AMERICA,  Detroit, a unit of Thyssen A.G., received a 10-year contract worth more than $300 million to supply Boeing Co.'s commercial airplane group with aluminum flat-rolled products and small and intermediate press extrusions.

headline: France to Sell Up to 30% Of Thomson Multimedia
abstract: French Government agrees to sell as much as 30 percent of Thomson Multimedia, one of Europe's largest consumer electronics makers, to industrial partners including Microsoft Corp, which is expected to use investment to expand its push into delivering Internet services via television; Government says Microsoft and DirecTV unit of Hughes Electronics Corp along with NEC Corp of Japan and Alcatel SA of France will each be allowed to buy 7.5 percent (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper futures prices slump to 10-year low on commodities markets on July 1, with July delivery falling 1.35 cents, to 72 cents per pound; graphs (S)

headline: THOMAS & BETTS IN DEAL FOR TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEVICES
abstract: Thomas & Betts Corp says it will buy closely held Telecommunications Devices Inc for about $74.4 million in stock (S)

headline: Two Senators Say Evidence Of Plotting Is Compelling
abstract: Pres Clinton's top national security advisers begin showing small group of lawmakers evidence they have to justify missile attacks on terrorist targets; lawmkers interviewed say they agree that case against Osama bin Laden is as compelling as Adm contends; Sen Gordon H Smith, Oregon Republican on Foreign Relations Commitee, and Sen Charles S Robb, Virginia Democrat on Select Committee on Intelligence, say Adm officials had laid out 'irrefutable' evidence from variety of sources; table, map shows links between bin Laden and various terrorist activities (M)

headline: Stock of Grupo Televisa Falls After News of Loss
abstract: Shares of Grupo Televisa SA reports worse-than-expected earnings and declining TV ratings; second-quarter operating income fell 9.3 percent, to 358.4 million pesos ($39.9 million); graph (S)

headline: Glaxo and Warner-Lambert to End Joint Venture
abstract: Glaxo Wellcome PLC and Warner-Lambert Co will dissolve joint venture formed five years ago to sell over-the-counter products; they say they want greater flexibility in pursuing their own strategies; Glaxo regains rights to sell Zantac 75, over-the-counter version of its drug for treatment of ulcers, outside US and Canada; Zantac lost is US patent protection in 1997 (S)

headline: CRESCENT AND RECKSON IN JOINT VENTURE FOR TOWER
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Co, led by billionaire investor Richard Rainwater, and Reckson Associates Realty Corp agree to buy Tower Realty Trust for $445 million (S)

headline: Leslie B. Worthington, 96, U.S. Steel President in 1960's
abstract: Leslie B Worthington, who as president of United States Steel Corp guided company out of prolonged steelworkers' strike and into confrontation with Pres John F Kennedy over industry's attempt to raise steel prices, dies at age 96 (M)

headline: Different Way to Look At the Browser Wars
abstract: Survey by Positive Support Review, a Web design and consulting company, finds that Microsoft Internet Eplorer has greater share of Web browser market than Netscape Navigator in terms of how much time peope spend using the respective browsers (S)

headline: Korea Slump 'Full-Blown' After 6.6% Quarterly Fall : For Asians, Recession Reality
abstract: SEOUL  The battered economy of South Korea shrank at a 6.6 percent rate in the second quarter, pushing it officially into recession, the Bank of Korea said Thursday. It was the worst quarter since 1980.

headline: A Challenge To Immunity Of Lobbyists At the U.N.
