abstract: Arundhati Ghose, India's envoy to UN, begins campaign to alert United Nations and Swiss officials to danger of suspected criminals and terrorists taking advantage of legal immunity granted to certain interest groups while in Switzerland on UN business; acts after Indian separatist group took responsibility for kidnapping of her nephew, Sanjoy Ghose, head of private development agency helping villagers in northeast India; his body has never been found; Anup Chetia, leader of United Liberation Front of Assam, which took responsibility for kidnapping, had gained entrance to UN grounds in Geneva as member of nongovt orgn attending session on human-rights abuses, where Arundhati Ghose spotted him; thousands of such nongovt reprs enter UN headquarters in Geneva and New York each year; Switzerland automatically provides visas to members of groups accredited to UN (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., named Fran Barton chief financial officer and senior vice president to succeed Marvin Burkett, who left the company in March after 26 years. Mr. Barton had been executive vice president and chief financial officer at Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, a wholly owned subsidiary of Fujitsu Ltd.

headline: Year 2000 Data Can Be Shared
abstract: Justice Department signals that companies will be allowed to cooperate and share information about how to fix year 2000 bugs in computer systems without violating nation's antitrust laws; states position in response to proposal by securities industry to allow Wall Street firms and their computer services suppliers to share information on how to handle so-called millenium bug (S)

headline: Envoy Rejects Accusations Americans Acted Selfishly
abstract: Amb Prudence Bushnell seeks to defuse charges that Americans were more concerned about protecting own people and guarding embassy than helping Kenyans killed or hurt in terrorist bombing of Nairobi embassy, interview on Kenyan television; United States has rushed in support teams to help both Kenyans and Americans (M)

headline: Japanese Banks Cutting Back on U.S. Presence
abstract: Japanese banks and other financial institutions are in broad retreat from US market, closing offices and cutting back on their lending to American companies; Japanese banks are pulling out of US altogether or consolidating operations in New York; number of Japanese banks with offices in New York has fallen to 55 from 70 in last few years; number with offices in Los Angeles has dropped to 17 from 25, and to 16 from 21 in Chicago; Japanese banking crisis is also accelerating sale of Japanese-owned hotels, office buildings and golf courses in US, many of which were bought at exorbitant prices in late 1980's; graphs (M)

headline: Rubin Hoping Thais Back Requirements Of the I.M.F.
abstract: Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin, after meetings in Bangkok with Prime Min Chuan Leekpai, senior officials and business executives, expresses optimism that political leaders of Thailand will be able to marshal public support for difficult work of reforming economy; disputes contention that International Monetary Fund's rescue packages for region have raised risk of social unrest, with emphasis on high interest rates (M)

headline: Close Ally Of Iran Chief Is Sentenced To Jail Term
abstract: Iranian court convicts Teheran Mayor Gholamhossein Karabaschi on charges of corruption and mismanagement, sentences him to five years in prison and bars him from public office until 2018; Karabaschi is close ally of Pres Mohammad Khatami, and conviction is new setback for Khatami; trial was widely seen in Iran as politically motivated; photos (M)

headline: Norsk Hydro Profit Falls 36% in Quarter
abstract: Norsk Hydro ASA's second-quarter profit fell 36 percent, which was less than expected; profit fell 954 million kroner ($127 million), from 1.496 billion kroner a year earlier; sales fell to 24.932 billion kroner from 25.042 billion (S)

headline: Durable Goods Orders Grew 2.4% in July
abstract: Commerce Department reports total durable goods orders rose 2.4 percent in July, biggest gain in almost a year; also revises June data to show increase of two-tenths of 1 percent (S)

headline: STOCK OF USA NETWORKS UP 11.3% AS LOSSES NARROW
abstract: Shares of USA Networks Inc rise 11.3 percent after company says that second-quarter loss narrowed more than expected and that it plans to buy back as many 10 million shares in next year; company has pro forma loss of $1.3 million compared with $10.5 million a year earlier; revenue rise 15 percent, to $689.9 million from $601.1 million (S)

headline: TRION TO BE ACQUIRED BY MCLEOD RUSSEL FOR $52 MILLION
abstract: Trion Inc. said yesterday that it would be acquired by the British-based McLeod Russel Holdings P.L.C. for about $52 million in cash. Owners of Trion stock will receive $7.27 a share. Trion, which makes equipment to improve air quality, including humidifiers and air filters, had 1997 sales of $65 million. McLeod Russel, which has United States and British subsidiaries, said Trion's products would help it expand its air-cleaning business. Shares of Trion, based in Sanford, N.C., jumped 39 percent, gaining $1.875 a share, to $6.625, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: British Petroleum Planning 'Firm' Cuts in Emissions
abstract: Chief executive Sir John Browne says British Petroleum Co will cut emissions of greenhouse gases by 10 percent of their 1990 levels of 40 million tons by 2010; says emissions would have risen by 18 million tons over next 12 years if no steps were taken to cut them; notes cuts are deeper than those promised by industrialized nations; cites mounting evidence of global warming (M)

headline: Edward F. Preston, 79, Ex-O.M.B. Executive
abstract: Edward F Preston, former executive with Office of Management and Budget who helped develop Senior Executive Service, dies at age 79 (M)

headline: NATIONAL VISION AGREES TO ACQUIRE NEW WEST EYEWORKS
abstract: National Vision Associates Ltd will acquire New West Eyeworks for $75 million and assumption of $2 million in debt (S)

headline: LIBRARY/GRAMMAR TUTORS; Writing and Grammar Help That Is Designed to Be Bland
abstract: MASTERING ENGLISH GRAMMAR (Queue; $225 for a single user, $1,125 for a network license; Macintosh, with Windows version expected in the fall.)   DEVELOPING WRITING SKILLS (Queue; $150 for a single user, $750 for a network license; Macintosh, with Windows version expected in the fall.)

headline: U.S. HOPES ARREST IN EMBASSY BLASTS WILL BREAK CASE
abstract: Law enforcement officials investigating bombings at American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania are optimistic apprehension of Mohammed Sadik Howaida, seized by Pakistan and turned over to Kenyan authorities, will help in unraveling plot behind deadly attacks; US officials are almost certain he played direct and possibly key role in simltaneous bombings on August 7, which killed more than 200 people; say one or two other men in custody in Pakistan are suspected of complicity in bombings, possibly by helping to arrange clandestine passage for Howaida and other confederates through Pakistan to relative safety of neighboring Afghanistan; State Department orders departure of all nonemergency American personnel and families from Pakistan, and warns visitors against traveling there out of fear they may be targets of terrorist attack (M)

headline: Aer Lingus Names Chief
abstract: Aer Lingus names Gary Cullen chief executive, effective Oct 1; he takes over from Gary McGann, who resigned (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Allstate Is Expected to Sue For Repeated Overbilling  Allstate was expected to sue about a dozen Southern California doctors and chiropractors and their assistants today for $25 million for repeatedly overbilling or billing for services they never provided in hundreds of accident cases over the last several years.    The Insurance Research Council, an industry organization in Illinois, contends that nearly 40 percent of the claims for auto accident injuries now involve fraud. And insurers say some doctors and clinics are capitalizing on real accidents and real injuries by seeking reimbursement for procedures not required and never performed.   Page D2    Concerns Cut Newspaper Stocks  Stock prices of newspaper companies flourished in 1997 and the first half of 1998, but have declined this summer. The Standard & Poor's index of newspaper stocks has plunged more than 13 percent since it peaked on July 14, largely because of concerns about the economy and an expected drop in advertising revenue. Market Place.   D5    A Fill-In Producer Creates a Film Hit  Tracey Trench joined the Fox Family Films unit of 20th Century Fox as a fill-in producer on her first feature film, ''Ever After.'' The movie, a retelling of the Cinderella fable with Drew Barrymore as the heroine, opened to mixed reviews on July 31, but it is a box-office success and has taken in more than the $24 million it cost to make the film.   D5    Computer Users Call Up News Sites  Traffic to news sites on the World Wide Web soared last week, suggesting that more people than ever turn to the medium to follow breaking stories.   D4    Time Prints Its Aug. 31 Edition Early  Time magazine printed its Aug. 31 issue several days early to get out its coverage of President Clinton's grand jury testimony. But the early printing will cause the news of the American cruise missiles hitting targets in the Sudan and Afghanistan to be delayed until the next issue.   D5    F.C.C. Chairman Seeks a Solution  William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has written a letter to cable industry leaders demanding that they solve a technical problem that could impede the start of digital television.   D4    Farmers Buy Cattle on the Web  Cattle Offerings Worldwide is an on-line Web site for buying cows at auction. The site includes snapshots of the donor cows and their vital statistics and ancestry. Although farmers are using the Internet mainly for breaking news, many industry experts believe that on-line auctions could eventually make the Internet a vital farming tool.   D3    On-Line Banking Is Starting Slowly  Consumer banking via personal computers has not proved to be as popular as earlier expected. Instead mergers of financial institutions and preparation for the year 2000 software problem have been the center of attention.   D3    A Patent Awarded to Stop Cavities  Dr. Israel Kleinberg has won a patent for an anti-cavity compound that mimics the natural tooth defenses found in saliva. Patents.   D2    Venture Lets Consumers Make CD's  A five-year-old company called CD World has formed a venture with Sprint to create interactive kiosks that allow consumers to create their own compact disks.   D3

headline: The Purple Moon Store
abstract: Purple Moon, software company whose 'friendship adventures' cater to pre-teen-age girls, will post on-line shopping center on its Web site to entice budding shoppers (S)

headline: LIBRARY/PERSONAL-FINANCE SITES; Yahoo Offers a Place to Start
abstract: Assessment of Yahoo's Personal Finance page on World Wide Web (S)

headline: Judge May Change Lawyer in Embassy Bombings
abstract: Magistrate Judge Kevin N Fox moves to change lawyer for Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, one of two defendants charged in bombing of United States Embassy in Kenya; lawyer, Jack Sachs, says he was told judge questions his ability to carry two potential death penalty cases at same time; on same day Sachs was assigned to represent Odeh, he was also appointed to defend man in unrelated capital case; Sachs says he hopes to continue to represent Odeh, whom he has met with four times and interviewed extensively; if convicted, Odeh could face maximum term of life in prison or death; prosecutors have said Odeh has denied having direct role in embassy bombings but has admitted to being member of terrorist group run by Osama bin Laden, who authorities suspect is behind bombings (M)

headline: NEW CONGO RULER FACING REBELLION BY FORMER ALLIES
abstract: Rebellious troops seized control of several cities in eastern Congo today, and fought gun battles in the capital, as the alliance that brought President Laurent Kabila to office last year unraveled, threatening his hold on power.    Diplomats, aid workers and the Congolese Government suggested that the mutinies were led by members of Congo's small Tutsi minority, which provided the backbone of the rebel force that propelled Mr. Kabila to power.

headline: Columbia/HCA Staff Shift
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp names Scott L Mercy chairman and chief executive of its America's Group; he will join Jim Fleetwood, president and chief operating officer of unit, to form leadership team in anticipation of spinoff of unit to form new public company (S)

headline: Investors May Buy Daily Racing Form
abstract: Daily Racing Form is expected to be sold by Primedia Inc, formerly called K-III Communications, to group of investors led by Alpine Capital Group (S)

headline: MGM to Record Loss in Quarter
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc expects significant third-quarter loss after it takes about $33 million in charges for movies that did not do well and for cost of cutting jobs (S)

headline: Bar Codes: Reading the Patterns of Commerce
abstract: Most retailers have come to rely very heavily on bar codes; most widely used type is Universal Product Code, found in most groceries and retail stores; UPC is 12-digit code, whose digits identify category of product, product's manufacturer, individual item and check digit used to make sure code is scanned correctly; UPC allows store's computer to pull up other information about product, like price, inventory count and taxes; diagrams; charts (M)

headline: A Long-Horizon Mantra, With a Chorus of 'Diversify'
abstract: Excerpt of interview with Frank Leon of Coral Springs, Fla, member of one of three families who describe their investment philosophies; financial experts offer recommendations; photo (M)

headline: NEW YORK ACCOUNTING FIRM BOUGHT BY AMERICAN EXPRESS
abstract: American Express Co acquires accounting firm Goldstein Golub Kessler & Co; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Trade Deficit Sets a Record As Exports Sag
abstract: Commerce Department reports that United States trade deficit rose to $15.8 billion in May, from $14.3 billion in April, far bigger increase than economists had expected; exports declined to $76.2 billion, lowest level in 15 months, primarily because of weak demand from Asia; chart (M)

headline: Travelers Buyback Grows
abstract: Travelers Group increases size of stock-repurchase program by $1 billion (S)

headline: Losses Pile Up On Wall Street As Markets Keep Eroding
abstract: Profound changes can be expected on Wall Street if financial markets continue to deteriorate; firms could start cutting back on expenses, and jobs; any sweeping job cuts would have significant effect on New York City's economy, which has come to rely heavily on its brokerage firms, banks and insurance companies for tax revenues and well-paid jobs; Salomon Smith Barney, one of country's biggest investment banks, says it lost $360 million after taxes in last two months alone in its arbitrage and Russian-related credits businesses; says it expects its overall after-tax loss for last two months to be $150 million after allowing for profits from private client and funds management business (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Telephone privatization tests economic will of Puerto Rico.
abstract: Economic Scene column on economic issues involved in privatization of telephone system in Puerto Rico; says more is at stake in Puerto Rico than political symbolism, or even efficiency of telephone system; holds Puerto Rico is under enormous pressure to hew more closely to capitalist road, in part because it is losing special tax breaks and welfare subsidies from US Government, and, in part because no island can remain island in increasingly integrated global economy; BT Wolfensohn director Jose Berrocal says Puerto Rico's welfare state has provided good jobs for minority and adequate living standard for majority; he adds it has also robbed island of opportunity to break out economically; drawing (M)

headline: Hush Puppies Co. Chooses Arnold
abstract: Hush Puppies Co division of Wolverine World Wide announces it has chosen Arnold Communications in Boston to create global branding and integrated marketing campaign for Hush Puppies footwear brand; billings estimated at $4 million (S)

headline: Latin America Is Buffeted, but Seems Stronger Than in '94
abstract: Demons of financial crisis are again haunting Latin America, unleashed by tumult in Russia, Japan and stock markets in US; markets and currencies across region are sinking as panicky investors retreat to safe haven of American Treasury bonds and dollars; most major economies are far better fortified than four years ago, when disastrous devaluation in Mexico engulfed several countries; Mexico and Brazil have since taken steps to build foreign reserves and control inflation, while Argentina and Chile persevered in tough programs already in place; among big players, only Venezuela has failed to buckle down to austerity, and is paying price; analysts caution that even though turmoil may have milder effects in Latin America, outcome could be devastating if markets outside region continue to dive for long or if investors flee emerging markets en masse without regard to strengths of individual countries; photo (M)

headline: To focus on brand-building, 2 big marketers will consolidate portions of their accounts.
abstract: H J Heinz Co and Hewlett-Packard Co say they will consolidate portions of their advertising accounts; announcements are indicative of constant consolidations of agency assignments that have been remaking Madison Avenue for most of decade; they are also emblamatic of continuing efforts by large marketers to focus on brand-building (M)

headline: Treasuries Are A Bit Higher In Short Session
abstract: Treasury securities prices are mostly higher in short session; 30-year bond rises 8/32, to 103 8/32, to yield 5.28 percent; table of key rates (M)

headline: International Briefs; Thailand Approves Plan To Rescue Lenders
abstract: Thailand approves new rescue program for its financial system, devised in conjuction with World Bank, International Monetary Fund and Asian Development Bank; seizes two of smallest lenders, Laem Thong Bank and Union Bank of Bangkok and orders Bangkok Bank of Commerce shut; moves leave Government in control of half of nation's 16 commercial banks; plan requires strongest banks to increase their capital or write off shareholder equity (S)

headline: Pearson Says Profits Rose 81% in First Half
abstract: Pearson PLC says first-half net income adjusted for one-time items rose 81 percent; net income for six months ended June rose 62.3 million pounds ($101 million) from 34.4 million pounds a year-earlier (S)

headline: Chrysler Sales Rose 3% in July, After Even Busier Spring
abstract: Chrysler Corp says sales of cars and trucks totaled 206,018 in July, up 3 percent from level in July 1997; sales figures for Toyota, Honda, Mercedes-Benz, Subaru, Saab and Mitsubishi noted (M)

headline: Las Vegas will shift its promotional strategy to emphasize entertainment as well as gambling.
abstract: Advertising column outlines first-ever multiyear advertising and marketing plan adopted by Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, which will extend through fiscal 2003; ambitious plan is intended to reposition Las Vegas as entertainment destination, rather than primarily a gambling mecca; city ad advertising budget of $27 million last year; R&R Advertising is its longtime agency (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: National Weather Service forecasts for end to searing Midwest heat pushes down corn 2.5 percent, erasing most of previous session's gain; December contract falls 6 cents, to $2.3625 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Prices Retreat As Stocks Find Some Stability
abstract: Treasury securities prices fall; 30-year bond drops 13/32, to 106 9/32, to yield 5.68 percent; table of key rates (S)9

headline: Archer Executive Testifies To Fixing Citric Acid Prices
abstract: Barrie Cox, executive with Archer Daniels Midland Co, testifies that he and Terrance Wilson, former head of company's corn processing division, participated in global conspiracy with competitors to fix price of citric acid, widely used food additive; testimony of Cox comes in criminal trial of three former officers of company who were charged with fixing price of lysine, additive in animal feed (M)

headline: Philippine Airlines Says It Will End Service
abstract: Philippine Airlines, Asia's first national flag carrier, says it will cease opeartions because of heavy losses; carrier's loss quadrupled to $50.2 million in recent quarter; in fiscal year ended March 31, company lost $184 million (S)

headline: Earnings Rise 59% At British Airways
abstract: British Airways PLC says pretax profit for three months ended June 30 rose 59 percent; airline earned pretax profit of 145 million pounds ($236 million), up from 91 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: Accounting Firms Facing More Pressure From S.E.C.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission wants auditors to meet annually with company directors to explain why consulting services have not harmed the accountants' independence; agency is concerned about millions of dollars of consulting that Big Five accounting firms now do at companies they audit; worry is that auditor who finds accounting problem may not force management to correct it if accounting firm also has lucrative consulting job with company (M)

headline: It's Official: '60 Minutes' Gets Double
abstract: CBS says 60 Minutes, oldest and most successful news program in history of television, will expand to second edition early next year; new program, to be called 60 Minutes II, will include many elements of the original; no new correspondents are named, but executive producer will be Jeff Fager, currently executive producer of Evening News With Dan Rather; Fager will be replaced at evening news by Al Ortiz; Don Hewitt, creator and executive producer of 60 Minutes, will serve as consultant on new edition (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybean futures slump to nearly four-year lows on expectations of record crop at time of weak US exports; soybeans for November delivery fall 6.5 cents, to $5.4125 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Hedge Fund Debacle Offers A View of a Secret World
abstract: Near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management has provided rare chance to view world of John W Meriwether's cloistered financial brain trust; early indications are that, though his financing was often exotic, his trades were more garden-variety; Long-Term Capital bet on minor price differences between similar sorts of securities that, according to financial history, should not have existed (M)

headline: Cashing In on a Programming Trend
abstract: HBO, pay-cable network best known for sophisticated movies, R-rated comedy and big-time boxing, is moving into rapidly expanding market for family programming with 24-hour, commercial-free supplementary cable channel called HBO Family, scheduled for February debut; in competitive terms, HBO may already be a little late; HBO Family is being developed at same time as several other family-oriented cable services have already begun; Shelia Nevins, HBO's senior vice president of original programming comments; her photo (M)

headline: Moscow Memo; Yeltsin and Crew Are Sinking Like the Ruble
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin, already deeply unpopular, now seems to have sunk even lower in political and public esteem than his country's ruble; Duma, Russia's lower house of Parliament, votes 245 to 32 to ask him to resign; political experts say that week's events all but abort prospects that Yeltsin, now 67, might seek third term in 2000; his top aides, best-and-brightest crew widely admired abroad, are now so tarred by failure at home that their own political prospects are slight; photo (M)

headline: Sales Pitches In an Unlikely Place
abstract: Interactive Advertising Network plans to install over 3,000 television screens in check-cashing offices and seeks to attract advertisers who want to aim sales pitches at consumers waiting in line to cash checks or pay bills; will begin with 250 screens around New York metropolitan area (S)

headline: China Military Chief Gives Pledges to U.S.
abstract: Chinese Gen Zhang Wannianmeets with Defense Sec William S Cohen, Washington, and pledges China will move ahead with modest joint military exercises and exchanges agreed to at Pres Clinton's summit meeting with Pres Jiang Zemin; he and Cohen sign pact to share data on tackling environmental problems caused by armed forces; meets with national security adviser Samuel R Berger, meeting briefly attended by Clinton (S)

headline: Zedillo Tells Mexico Painful Economic Policies Are Farsighted
abstract: Pres Ernesto Zedillo makes his first major statement about effects of world financial crisis on Mexico; he acknowledges that plunging oil prices had forced painful budget cuts (M)

headline: HUNTSMAN PACKAGING SEEKS APPLIED EXTRUSION
abstract: Huntsman Packaging Corp offers about $117 million to buy Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc (S)

headline: Boston Beer Chooses McCann-Erickson
abstract: Boston Beer Co names McCann-Erickson to handle its ad account, which had been handled by Carmichael Lynch Inc; billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million (S)

headline: DURA AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY TOWER'S AUTO HINGE BUSINESS
abstract: Dura Automotive Systems Inc will acquire Tower Automotive Inc's auto-hinge business for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: DQE DROPS OUT OF ALLEGHENY ENERGY'S PROPOSED BUYOUT
abstract: DQE Inc will not go through with plans for buyout by Allegheny Energy Inc because of conditions imposed on buyout by Pennsylvania regulators; Allegheny said in April 1997 that it would buy DQE for $2.5 billion in stock and $1.7 billion in assumed debt (S)

headline: Franklin B. Pollock, Businessman, 95
abstract: Franklin B Pollock, self-made businessman who rose to become vice chairman of Dart Industries, dies at 95 (S)

headline: Outsmarting a Quiz
abstract: Cynthia Rothstein letter comments on question in July 16 How Smart Are You quiz

headline: The media wait anxiously as G.M., in wake of strikes, cuts back substantially on spending.
abstract: Media are nervously assessing how much they may suffer as result of labor problems hampering operations at General Motors Corp; GM is nation's largest advertiser, having spent $2.2 billion last year on sales pitches (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Selling uranium plants to enrich the private sector?
abstract: Peter Passell (Economic Scene) examines decision by Federal Government to privatize United States Enrichment Corp, which operates Government's uranium-enrichment plants, despite warnings that sale will undermine key initiative for containing nuclear proliferation; says once company is privatized it will have powerful financial incentives to back away from agreement to import 500 tons of bomb-grade uranium from Russia; drawing (M)

headline: Trials Halted, Danish Drug Stock Falls
abstract: Shares in Novo Nordisk, world's number 1 diabetes-care company, fall 12 percent after Novo abandons osteoporosis drug it was developing to reduce its reliance on diabetes treatment; Novo Nordisk is no longer developing levormeloxifene (S)

headline: Vu Van Mau, Last Premier Of South Vietnam, Dies at 84
abstract: Vu Van Mau, who was briefly South Vietnam's Prime Minister, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC., -- Pasadena, Calif., said its Rocky Flats Closure Site Services had received a $225 million contract from Kaiser-Hill Co., Denver, to provide support services for a cleanup of the defunct Rocky Flats nuclear-weapons plant in Colorado.  REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO., -- Dayton, Ohio, received a five-year, $200 million contract to be primary vendor for information management services at Kaiser Permanente, the health maintenance organization based in Oakland, Calif.

headline: It's a Dark and Stormy Night . . . and Here's Hong Kong Trying to Line the Clouds With Silver
abstract: Hong Kong Government spends at least $8 billion in day to prop up stock prices and foil speculators it accuses of manipulation; benchmark Hang Seng index drops 93.23 points, or 1.2 percent, to 7,829.74, despite intervention; Government officials hold intervention stabilizes Hang Seng as markets around world plummet; say Hong Kong is ready to continue effort, which has already cost 10 percent of its $100 billion in foreign reserves; analysts question move; graphs of world stock prices; photos (M)

headline: Karl Schirdewan, 91, Maverick Among East German Officials
abstract: Karl Schirdewan, high-ranking figure in old East German Communist Government, dies at age 91 (S)

headline: VERITAS AGREES TO BUY PEI, A TEST-EQUIPMENT MAKER
abstract: Veritas Capital Fund LP to buy PEI Electronics (S)7

headline: Accountants' Rules Approved
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission approves new legal standards for accountants' conduct; SEC adopts legal definition for 'improper professional conduct' that will let agency take action against accounts who commit intentional 'reckless' violations of professional standards; commission will also be allowed to sanction accountant who engages in single act of 'highly unreasonable' negligent conduct (S)

headline: Peter H. Kaminer: Legal Aid Society Official, 83
abstract: Peter H Kaminer, litigator who was senior managing partner of law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts from 1963 to 1983, commits suicide; he was 83 years old (S)

headline: Doctors Powerless as AIDS Rakes Africa
abstract: First article in series Dead Zones discusses AIDS epidemic in Zimbabwe; death from every type of disease has become so common in Zimbabwe, as in much of Africa, that it no longer seems to matter that country has become center of world's AIDS epidemic; recent studies suggest that Zimbabwe may have highest AIDS infection rate on earth; savage virus has left few people untouched; it has devastated families and communities; seen through weary eyes of doctors and nurses who must attend to sick people around them, AIDS is just another word for dying, and it is just another disease; with average of $10 to spend on each person's health every year, most African countries have no money for tests, fancy drugs or complicated support networks; Zimbabwe once had health system that was envy of southern Africa, fueled by AIDS and also by increasing poverty and instability, illness has begun to overcome country; maps; photos (M)

headline: Japan's Tale of 2 Brothers: Does Best Man Rise to Top?
abstract: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's brother, Daijiro, is widely hailed as example of kind of dynamic leadership that Japan needs; he is Governor of Kochi Prefecture, one of poorest and most backward parts of country; he has shaken up prefecture and made it testing ground for nation, winning public aproval ratings of more than 70 percent; meanwhile, Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's approval rating has slumped below 30 percent, and he could even be forced to resign if his Liberal Democratic Party loses ground in Parliamentary elections; tale of two brothers underscores weaknesses of Japan's political system; under rigid seniority system in Liberal Democratic Party, Daijiro and others like him stand almost no chance of ever playing major role in national politics; moreover, Daijiro is convinced that Japanese people do not want fundamental change; photo; map (M)

headline: REPUBLIC ENGINEERED IN TALKS WITH BLACKSTONE AFFILIATE
abstract: Republic Engineered Steels Inc is in talks to be acquired by affiliate of Blackstone Group (S)

headline: Students in Jakarta Continue Protests
abstract: Hundreds of students, ringed by soldiers, stage noisy but peaceful demonstration across from Presidential Palace, Jakarta, in third day of protests aimed at Pres B J Habibie and his Cabinet (S)

headline: Videotapes Take Star Role at Archer Daniels Trial
abstract: Prosecutors play tape of ex-Archer Daniels Midland officials Michael D Andreas and Mark E Whitacre meeting with businessmen from Ajinimoto Co of Japan arguing over accuracy of data they were providing each other about their companies' sales of feed additive, price-fixing trial, Chicago; if prosecution is right in its contentions, videotape offers unique view into price-fixing conspiracy on giant scale, involving every major company in business of producing lysine; photo (M)

headline: MODTECH BUYING SPI MANUFACTURING FOR $109 MILLION
abstract: Modtech Inc to acquire SPI Manufacturing Inc for about $109 million (S)

headline: FRESENIUS TO SELL UNITS AND TAKE $100 MILLION WRITE-OFF
abstract: Fresenius Medical Care AG is sellling its US diagnostics and home care businesses for $100 million; diagnostics unit is sold to Navix Radiology Systems; Fresenius hopes to sell home care unit in third quarter (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Proposal to Curb Discounts On Stock Plans is Dropped  Faced with opposition from the technology industry and other companies, accounting rulemakers have stepped away from a proposal that had threatened to end certain lucrative employee stock plans. The rules relate to stock purchase plans in which employees can buy company stock at a discount of more than 15 percent.     The Financial Accounting Standards Board had proposed that if companies wanted to give employees what is effectively more than a 15 percent discount, they would have to treat the discount as an expense. To avoid that expense, many companies were expected to limit their stock programs. But the board has decided to drop the proposal. [Page D2.]

headline: Guides to Unfamiliar Rivers
abstract: Rodes Fishburne describes software packages that can be used as river encyclopedias by anglers: Flywater Interactive, and Hatch Master; photo; map (S)

headline: The Case Of the Contested Coins; A Modern-Day Battle Over Ancient Objects
abstract: Turkish Government's long-running suit against William I Koch and his associates for obtaining trove of ancient Greek coins, that Turkey contends partners knew were illegally excavated, is about to go to trial; decade ago, Connoisseur magazine reported that treasure hunters near Elmali, Turkey, unearthed trove of ancient coins that included rarest and most valuable Greek coins ever found; magazine reported that coins were smuggled out of Turkey and sold to Koch; Koch and his partners in $3 million coin venture--Jonathan H Kagan, managing director at Lazard Freres, and Jeffrey Spier, academic living in London--say their coins are not ones sought by Turkey; court documents suggest that partners learned even before they bought coins that Turkish officials were apparently looking for recently excavated trove of coins; in July 1984, Silvia Hurter, manager at Bank Leu, a Swiss bank that is major dealer in coins, wrote Cornelius C Vermeule 3d, then curator of department of classical art at Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, who authenticated coins for Koch; Hurter wrote that Turkish authorities reportedly were aware of coins; case is one of most intrigue-filled antiquities battles in recent years; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Premier Of France To Be Tried In Blood Case
abstract: Former Prime Min Laurent Fabius, now Speaker of French Parliament, is ordered to stand trial with former ministers Georgina Dufoix and Edmond Herve on charges of manslaughter in deaths of hundreds of patients who received transfusions in 1985 from Government blood stocks contaminated with HIV (M)

headline: Relax. Stocks Rarely Steer the Economy.
abstract: Michael M Weinstein Economic Scene column explores fear that plunging stock prices are harbinger of economic crisis; Prof Peter Temin examined every recession this century and concluded that even Great Depression of 1930's did not stem from plummeting stock prices; nevertheless, stock market plunges can slow an economy as consumers react to their shrinking wealth by cutting purchases, and companies, fearful of uncertainty, react by cutting investment outlays; trillion-dollar stock market plunge in recent weeks could cause $40 billion drop in annual consumer spending, about one-half percent of total spending; Prof Benjamin Friedman points out that it would take spending cut four times that size to bring on recession; drawing (M)

headline: PUBLIC OFFER FILING FOR PCS GROUP IS SET
abstract: Sprint Corp files with Securities and Exchange Commission for initial public offering of $603.75 million of common shares for its PCS Group (S)

headline: CENTEX HOME-BUILDING UNIT TO ACQUIRE CARLTON HOMES
abstract: Centex Real Estate Corp unit of Centex Corp says it agreed to acquire Carlton Homes Inc for $50 million plus assumption of $34 million of debt (S)

headline: Digital Employees Tell of Threats by Gates Over Product
abstract: Five current and former employees of Digital Equipment Corp say their company was forced to drop planned Internet product last year under threats from Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates; allegations appear to support Government's contention that Microsoft routinely suppresses competition in any new market that might threaten its monopoly in personal computer operating systems; Digital Equipment employees say company disbanded product development group after Gates told Robert Palmer, who was Digital's chief executive at the time, that a product the group was developing with Microsoft rival, Oracle Corp, would threaten earlier deal for Microsoft to develop version of its Windows NT operating system for Digital's powerful new processor; Microsoft spokesman calls his company's relationship with Digital a 'model partnership' and insists that no improper pressure was applied to force it from any new business (M)

headline: Is It Morning in Indonesia Or the End of an Eclipse?
abstract: Interview with Indonesia's Finance Minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, who expresses guarded optimism about one of world's bleakest economies; he says rupiah, country's currency, has strengthened more quickly than expected and that economy could show positive growth rate in two years (M)

headline: BET to Establish a Film Unit Aimed at Black Urban Market
abstract: Robert L Johnson, chairman and founder of Black Entertainment Television, says his company will start venture to make low-budget films with black stars, financed and produced by African-Americans and aimed largely at black urban market; says operation would be first black-owned company to completely own films and have authority to put them into production on such a scale; says he has not decided who will run new company (M)

headline: Buck Mickel, 72, an Executive Who Aided Expansion of Fluor
abstract: Buck Mickel, retired Fluor Corp top executive, dies at age 72; photo (M)m

headline: Rebel Terror Forcing Minority Serbs Out of Kosovo
abstract: Foreign diplomats and human rights workers say ethnic Albanian rebels have begun wave of kidnappings and terror intended to drive out small Serbian population of Kosovo Province; nearly every ethnic Serbian family that has lived in areas controlled by rebels has fled or disappeared; more than 80 civilians are missing, and human rights workers believe they have been killed; photo; map (M)

headline: YELTSIN COURTING COMMUNIST FAVOR
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin, day after dismissing Prime Min Sergei V Kiriyenko, signals new approach to government by giving greater voice to Communist-led forces in Parliament that have sought to frustrate economic reform; new power-sharing arrangement is intended to build support for Yeltsin's new Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin; move raises fresh questions about whether Kremlin is retreating from urgent economic reforms demanded by Kiriyenko; under Chernomyrdin, Yeltsin's previous Prime Minister who enjoys good ties across political spectrum, Government will be more receptive to appeals by Communist opposition and more solicitious of demands of Russia's powerful bankers and financiers; photos (M)

headline: Business Travel; The I.N.S. is expanding its automated system for clearing travelers into the United States.
abstract: THE Immigration and Naturalization Service is expanding its automated immigration inspection system, which speeds up processing time for certain travelers arriving in the United States from overseas.    The system is currently available at Kennedy International Airport in New York, Newark International Airport, Miami International Airport and Los Angeles International Airport, as well as at I.N.S. preclearance sites at Pearson International Airport in Toronto and Vancouver International Airport in British Columbia. It will be offered at San Francisco International Airport by early October, and at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, Washington Dulles International Airport and Honolulu International Airport by early 1999.

headline: Short-Term Ratings Of Itochu Cut by S.& P.
abstract: Itochu Corp's short-term ratings are cut to one notch above 'junk' status by Standard & Poor's Corp, amid concern about exposure of general trading companies to troubled economies of Asia and rising risks faced by their other businesses (S)

headline: Indonesia Considering More Help for Banks
abstract: Bank Indonesia governor Sjahril Sabirin says Indonesia might pump more money into sick banks to keep them afloat; Indonesia's economic collapse has pushed most of nation's banking system into arms of central bank (S)

headline: U.S. to Send North Korea Food Despite Missile Launching
abstract: United States reportedly agrees to send unusually large shipment of emergency food aid to North Korea, despite North's recent launching of medium-range missile over Japan; agreement, which angers Japan, comes amid growing signs that North Korea was trying to launch satellite, as it claims, when it shot off missile; if this is so, it would mean that initial portayal of firing as clearly hostile act was partially incorrect; State Dept is interested in keeping North at negotiating table because of growing fears that Communist Government may be looking to break out of 1994 accord containing North's nuclear weapons ability; photo (M)

headline: Iraqi President, Altering Tone, Predicts Slow End to Sanctions
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein, in first public hint that Iraq's hopes for an early end to sanctions have been set back by discoveries of nerve gas in Iraqi warheads, says in televised speech that the embargo was instead more likely to erode over time; photo (M)

headline: Missile Strikes Are Seen As New Strategy for U.S.
abstract: US and Western officials say Clinton Administration's decision to use missile strikes against suspected terrorist facilities in Afghanistan and Sudan, in retaliation for bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, is significant departure from past practice of seeking international support and UN authorization; say Clinton was less inclined to wait and allow US to again appear weak or irresolute, citing ambivalence of Muslim allies, UN delay in dealing with Iraq and mounting evidence of plans for impending attacks on more American embassies (M)

headline: Taliban Releases 5 Iranian Prisoners but Teheran Says Move Is Insufficient to Ease Tensions
abstract: Taliban movement of Afghanistan, in gesture of good will, releases five Iranian prisoners, but Iranian news accounts say move is not enough to ease tensions that have raised prospect of military conflict; Iranian officials say many more Iranians remain in Taliban custody, and express anger at Taliban suggestion that it is time for Iran to make some gesture in return (M)

headline: 21 Nations Seek to Limit the Traffic in Light Weapons
abstract: US and 20 other countries will meet in Oslo, Norway, on July 13 to try to stop spread of assault rifles, pistols, and other light weapons, in what diplomats say is first endeavor of its kind; conference reflects growing realization among governments that in post-cold-war world it is not jets and tanks but small arms that are prime contributors to regional instability (M)

headline: Serb Forces Are Said to Abduct and Kill Civilians in Kosovo
abstract: Serbian forces turn increasingly to abduction and execution of small groups of civilians in their fight against ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo; photo; map (M)

headline: Friend of Rabin's Assassin Is Sentenced
abstract: Margalit Har-Shefi, friend of Yigal Amir, assassin of Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin, receives nine-month prison sentence from Israeli court for failing to prevent slaying (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Trimming Stock Options' Sails; Accounting Proposal Would Lift the Cost of Repricing
abstract: Tentative decision reached by Financial Accounting Standards Board last week may be beginning of end of repricing stock options; board took first step toward forcing companies that reprice options to consider as operating expense difference between new lower price and any subsequent increase in share price; board did not act to quash repricing practice, rather it moved to make practice too expensive for many companies to handle; decision came as accounting board set about to clear up continuing cloud over how companies account for stock issued to employees; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: SUNSTONE SELLS FIVE HOTELS IT ACQUIRED FROM KAHLER
abstract: Sunstone Hotels Investors Inc agrees to sell five hotels acquired in its purchase of Kahler Realty Corp last year for $41.3 million; Sunstone sells hotels to Cavanaughs Hospitality Corp for $30.3 million (S)

headline: Nestle to Acquire Rest Of Unit in Philippines
abstract: Nestle SA agrees to acquire 45 percent stake in Nestle Philippines Inc held by San Miguel Corp for $640 million (S)

headline: Fuengirola Journal; Britons Pine in Exile, Ever Faithful to Their Dogs
abstract: Britain's 77-year-old rabies law is causing dilemma for expatriates who would like to return home, but are reluctant to subject pets to six months in quarantine; pet advocates, including former Hong Kong Gov Christopher Patten, are pressing for Britain to scrap law; are bitterly opposed by quarantine kennel industry; map; photo (M)

headline: New Shares to Finance Purchase of MCI Unit
abstract: Cable and Wireless PLC will sell new shares to raise 887 million pounds ($1.5 billion) after expenses to pay for most of its acquisition of MCI Communications Corp's Internet business (S)

headline: THE LEARNING COMPANY SELLS A CANADIAN BUSINESS
abstract: Learning Co says its Canadian unit, Softkey Software Products, sold its Canadian income tax software business to CCH Canadian Ltd, a unit of Wolters Kluwer NV, for $45 million in cash (S)

headline: Fierce Fighting as Serbs Try to Push Rebels From Kosovo Town
abstract: Fighting between Serbian forces and separatist rebels in Kosovo Province is heavy as senior Serbian officials vow to drive rebels from Belacevac and open roads obstructed by rebel barricades; map (M)

headline: Advice for Playing Better Plus Lots of Gear and Gab
abstract: Web site www.tennis.com devotes considerable coverage to teaching average players how to improve their tennis strokes, strategy and fitness (S)

headline: The 30-Year Treasury Price Moves Higher
abstract: Bonds continue to benefit from turbulence in stocks, managing modest gain; 30-year Treasury gains 15/32, to 103, on yield of 5.30 percent, down from 5.33 percent on Wednesday (S)

headline: Michael Palm, 47, Innovator In Method of Reinsurance
abstract: Michael D Palm, former English teacher who made fortune in reinsurance and then contributed millions to benefit the arts, gay rights and AIDS treatment, dies at age 47; photo (M)

headline: I.R.A. Denies Link to Bombing in Northern Ireland and Rejects Calls for Disarmament
abstract: Irish Republican Army, which has observed cease-fire for 13 months, makes rare public statement denying any connection to recent bombing in Omagh that killed 28 people; rejects demands that it disarm soon and declare end to its war against British sovereignty; statements are seen as attempt to improve its image and help its political wing, as well as to improve image before Pres Clinton's arrival (M)

headline: Firm Offers On-Line Trading For Chinese-Speaking Investors
abstract: Chinese speakers can buy and sell shares on stock market through Web site run by Charles Schwab, which allows them to communicate with brokerage in traditional or simplified Chinese (S)

headline: TELEFONOS DE MEXICO TO BUY STAKE IN PRODIGY SERVICES
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico SA, or Telmex, Mexico's largest telephone operator and largest Internet service provider, plans to buy 20 percent stake in Prodigy Services Corp for $49 million to secure presence in US Internet service provider market; Prodigy is controlled by Carso Global Telecom SA of Mexico (S)

headline: Border Clash Heightens Yemen-Saudi Tensions
abstract: Border dispute between Yemen and Saudi Arabia heightens tensions between neighbors following military clash on disputed Duwaima Island that left three Yemeni coast guards dead; fighting was followed by claims and counterclaims about who holds rights to island; territorial disagreements between Yemen, one of poorest countries in Arab world, and Saudi Arabia, most powerful Arab country in Persian Gulf, extend along 1,300-mile border; map (M)

headline: The Joys And Perils Of Betting On a Fall
abstract: Short selling helps some mutual funds ride unscathed through the plunge in stock prices; risks keep many fund managers from taking big short positions; strategies of shorting seem as varied as they managers who are willing to much such bets against the market; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LANDSTAR SYSTEM INC., Jacksonville, Fla., a transportation company, said it would sell its Landstar Poole Inc. trucking unit to the privately held Schneider National Inc., for about $41 million in cash.    B. F. GOODRICH CO., Richfield, Ohio, a maker of aircraft parts and specialty chemicals, will lay off 150 workers as it reorganizes its specialty chemicals division after acquisition of Freedom Chemical Co.

headline: Why 6-Hour Batteries Conk Out in 40 Minutes
abstract: Q. The batteries for my Macintosh Powerbook 1400c seem to last for only about 40 minutes each, even though the user's manual says they can each last up to six hours. How can I get my Powerbook to run longer on battery power?    A. Apple Computer says that with that particular laptop model, the user shouldn't be too quick to give up.  In an article from the Tech Info Library area of the company's Web site (til. info.apple.com), users are advised: ''There are three warnings before the battery completely runs out. To truly test the battery life, you should run the computer from the battery until the third (and last) warning appears.''

headline: Remembering Diana, but Moving On
abstract: LONDON  The flowers are back, glazed under cellophane, laid at the railings of Kensington Palace and bearing the familiar moving or mawkish messages.

headline: International Briefs; Hyundai to Shut Plants Blockaded by Strikers
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co says it will shut five Ulsan, South Korea, plants indefinitely after failing to break blockade by striking workers; some 127 managers reportedly were hurt in scuffles with workers (S)

headline: Brazil Plans Modest Steps to Spur Exports and Limit Spending
abstract: Brazilian Government announces modest measure to stimulate exports and contain spending; Government says it will simplify cumbersome bureaucratic procedures for exports worth less than $10,000, and will allow foreigners to pay for Brazilian exports with international credit cards; plan's goal is to increase exports by 15 percent a year in hope that they will reach $100 billion a year by 2002; also announces 20 percent across-the-board budget cut for national agencies for rest of 1998; step represents about-face as capital for emerging markets grows scarcer (M)

headline: AIDS BRINGS A SHIFT ON BREAST-FEEDING
abstract: United Nations, which has long promoted breast-feeding of infants, is issuing recommendations aimed at discouraging nursing by women infected with AIDS virus; cites concern about soaring HIV infection rates in much of world and mother-to-child transmission of virus; fears move may spur women who are not infected to stop nursing, needlessly exposing babies to risks posed by formula mixed under unsanitary conditions; advises governments to weigh bulk purchases of formula and other milk substitutes and to dispense them mainly through prescriptions; fact that some 90 percent of infected people in developing nations do not know they are infected complicates policy; graph of number of children newly infected with HIV through mother-to-child contact (M)

headline: Unusual Characters Converge at Spiff
abstract: Spiff, on-line game site, was designed by Jason Zada and Greg Hipwell; photo (M)

headline: Aargh! You, Too, Can Play the Role of a Pro Wrestler
abstract: Review of World Wrestling Federation's video game, WWF Warzone; photos (M)

headline: LIBRARY/LEARNING SPANISH; A Serious Package With Gaps
abstract: Appraisal of Webster's New World Spanish Tutor from Macmillan Digital Publishing (S)

headline: Media Talk; Time's Speeded-Up Issue Missed Some of the News
abstract: Time magazine prints its latest issue several days early, while Pres Clinton's grand jury testimony is still fresh news, but move keeps it from covering later United States missile strikes on terrorist targets in Afghanistan and Sudan; photo (M)

headline: Clinton's Words: 'There Will Be No Sanctuary for Terrorists'
abstract: Transcript of Pres Clinton's statement regarding missile attacks against suspected terrorist facilities in Afghanistan and Sudan; Clinton photo (M)

headline: Taking on New Forms, Electronic Books Turn a Page
abstract: Three 'electronic books' products are scheduled to be introduced later this year; all are essentailly portable computers with touch-activated screens and special modifications for downloading, storing and displaying digital versions of printed books; features of Rocketbook produced by Nuvomedia, EB Dedicated Reader by Everybook, and Softbook by Softbook Press described; photos (M)

headline: Their Quiet Lives, Rendered Stark and Bold by the Manner of Their Deaths
abstract: Profile of Sherry Lynn Olds, US Air Force master sergeant who died in bombing of US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya; photo (S)

headline: Jungle Outpost Offers Beer, Mayan Ruins and the Net
abstract: Eva's, cybercafe in remote corner of Belize, links people living in bush to outside world; ever since proprietor installed several second-hand computers, Eva's clientele has included local Belizeans, coming from remote villages, many with no phones or electricity, to correspond with friends and business connections all over world via e-mail; Eva's has come to resemble plugged-in analog to Wild West outpost; photos (M)

headline: Yen Hits Seven-Week Low Against the Dollar
abstract: Japanese yen falls to its lowest level against dollar in seven weeks, as currency traders test new Japanese Government's resolve to let market determine currency's value; at 5 PM on Aug 3, one dollar could buy 145.63 yen, up from 144.79 yen when trading opens in morning from 144.70 yen on July 31 in New York; Japan Automobile Dealers Association says domestic vehicle sales fell 8.4 percent from year earlier, 16th consecutive month that sales have fallen; Honda Motor Co and Mazda Motor Corp report 3.5 percent and 4.5 percent sales increase, respectively; graph; chart (M)

headline: Hearst magazines 'get milk' to promote a literacy program aimed at children and mothers.
abstract: Hearst Magazines division of Hearst Corp is joining forces with National Fluid Milk Processor Promotion Board to encourage children to read--and to encourage their mothers to buy milk; multimillion-dollar program exemplifies what are known as cause-related marketing campaigns, sponsored by advertisers seeking to do well by doing good (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Let Your Least Favorite Know What You Think
abstract: Site on World Wide Web called forkinthehead.com offers Web surfers opportunity to 'fork' sites they deem boring, cumbersome, or otherwise unsuitable; to give feedback to offending site owners, critics fill out fork forms sent as E-mail; for the really annoyed, there are Mud Brick Awards; photo (M)

headline: Malaysia Postpones $2 Billion Bond Sale
abstract: Malaysia postpones international sale of $2 billion in bonds because two credit-rating agencies lowered their assessment of country last week; delay in fund-raising effort could prolong nation's economic problems (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Finding Cellular Callers in an Emergency
abstract: Snaptrack Inc, Silicon Valley start-up company, is beginning first public safety trial of system that will enable cellular telephone users to broadcast their locations to 911 emergency-system operators, using special software inside cellular handset in combination with central office system employing global positioning, or GPS, technoloy to determine caller's location; trial is being undertaken by officials of city of Denver, Denver County and Adams County, Colo; system has implications, as well, for commercial enterprises (M)

headline: Sales of Digital Copiers Bolster Results at Xerox
abstract: Xerox Corp says earnings before charge rose 17 percent in second quarter as company sold more service contracts and high-priced digital copiers while it cut costs; profit before charge rose to $395 million from $337 milion in second quarter a year ago; revenue rose 9 percent, to $4.74 billion from $4.35 billion (M)

headline: Judge Approves Plan for Marvel
abstract: Toy Biz Inc wins approval from US District Judge Roderick McKelvie for its plan to reorganize Marvel Entertainment Group Inc, clearing the way for Marvel to emerge from bankruptcy protection as early as August; decision means Marvel will merge with Toy Biz (S)

headline: The Story of a Failed Merger Proves to Be a Page Turner
abstract: Article on Tellab Inc's decision to call off $7.1 billion acquisition of Ciena Corp; focuses on intrigue, charges of corporate sabotage, and lost fortunes as stock market plummeted; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar falls against yen as United States stocks plunge; graph (S)

headline: Iran Drops Rushdie Death Threat, And Britain Renews Teheran Ties
abstract: Iran drops death threat imposed on British author Salman Rushdie in 1989 by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and Britain responds by restoring full diplomatic relations; Foreign Min Kamal Kharrazi asserts that Govt 'has no intention, nor is it going to take any action whatsoever, to threaten the life of the author of The Satanic Verses or anybody associated with his work, not will it encourage or assist anybody to do so'; although an Iranian foundation continues to offer $2.5 million bounty for death of 51-year-old Indian-born British author, whose novel Kharrazi says still offends Iranians, Kharrazi says his Govt dissociates itself from any reward that has been offered; Rushdie, interviewed in London, says 'It's over' and 'The fatwa will be left to wither on the vine' (M)

headline: READ-RITE SAYS IT WILL SHUT OPERATIONS IN MALAYSIA
abstract: Read-Rite Corp says it will lay off 4,000 employees in Malaysia and move its disk-drive recording heads manufacturing operations there to existing plants in Thailand and the the Philippines (S)

headline: Prime Minister Accused of Favoring Lobbyists : Blair Beset in Scandal Over Money for Access
abstract: LONDON  Of all the forces that swept Tony Blair's Labour Party into government last year, few were as powerful as the string of bribery scandals involving Conservative politicians that allowed Mr. Blair to campaign against "Tory sleaze."

headline: With All of the Hoopla, U.S. Envoy's Star Rises
abstract: James R Sasser, United States Ambassador to China, is taking great satisfaction in Pres Clinton's visit to China; new warmth in Chinese-American relations is in part a personal victory for Sasser, 61, who came to China in early 1996 as a very political appointee after loss of his seat as Democratic Senator from Tennessee, and at a time when China and United States were all but hostile; Sasser's Southern style--polite, charming and attentive--was evident hit with Pres Jiang Zemin; photo (M)

headline: Coming in September: 3 New Features
abstract: Beginning next month, Money & Business will publish a group of new features that invite readers' participation.     Each week, Working will respond to a reader's query or quandary about a career, job, management or workplace issue. Have a question about how to get ahead? How to ask for a raise? How to deal with a difficult employee or boss? How to resolve tensions between work and family demands? Send it by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

headline: Russia's New Leaders Plan to Pay Debt by Printing Money
abstract: Russia's new Communist-influenced Government plans to satisfy old debts and bail out old friends by printing billions of new rubles; central bank deputy says bank intends to bail out bankrupt financial institutions by buying back their multibillion-ruble portfolios of bonds and bills; US Deputy Sec Lawrence H Summers, in swift rebuke from Washington, warns that new leadership cannot repeal 'basic economic laws'; tells House subcommittee that Russia is heading toward return of four-digit inflation that savaged consumers and almost toppled Pres Yeltsin in 1993; speaks out pointedly against pervasive corruption, and doubts IMF will pay $4.3-billion aid installment; photo testifying with Strobe Talbott and George Shultz; German and other western European ministers, in Moscow, say West should wait before passing judgment (M)

headline: Big Board Votes to Abandon Mandatory Job-Bias Arbitration
abstract: New York Stock Exchange board votes to no longer require industry arbitration of job-discrimination claims, deciding that it will hear such claims only when they are submitted and after dispute has arisen (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Custom-Made CD's On Demand at Kiosks
abstract: CD World forms joint venture with Sprint to create interactive kiosks where consumers can create own custom-mixed compact disks from list of songs; plans to set up kiosks in about 400 sites in New York and Los Angeles; photo (M)

headline: Berlusconi Gets 2d Conviction in Week
abstract: ROME  Silvio Berlusconi, the media tycoon and Italian opposition leader, was convicted Monday of using an offshore company to channel $12 million in bribes to former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi and his defunct Socialist Party.

headline: Iraq Might Be Tempted to End 'Oil for Food' Plan
abstract: Officials and diplomats say oil for food program, aimed at softening effects of economic sanctions against Iraq, is reaching level of success that could, paradoxically, tempt Pres Saddam Hussein to try to end it; recent decision by Hussein against further visits by private foreign delegations with donations and offers of help noted; as UN compiles reports of rising nutrition rates, better health care, additional medicines and increasaing agricultural production, Iraqis are telling foreigners, especially Americans, to stay hoime and lobby Government to lift embargo (M)

headline: Boeing to Shift Some Jet Output to Long Beach to Ease Strain
abstract: Boeing Co, aiming to ease strain on one of its most troubled production lines in Seattle, plans to announce that it will begin building some of its single-aisle 737 jets in Long Beach, Calif, beginning in 1999; decision is good news for workers at former McDonnell Douglas operations in California, who have seen three of four airplanes currently built there canceled by Boeing since it bought McDonnell Douglas last year (M)

headline: AFTER EARNINGS FALL SHORT, ORION PLANS TO SELL A UNIT
abstract: Orion Capital Corp plans to sell its Colorado Casualty unit after disappointing second-quarter earnings; Orion says profit rose 15 percent, to $23.4 million from $20.3 million in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: London Journal; Lords of the Manor, but Maybe Not of the House
abstract: Britain's Labor Government may introduce legislation in 1999 that would strip country's estimated 700 hereditary peers, such as Lord Raglan, of right that has been theirs for centuries, namely, to sit and vote in House of Lords; peers are routinely derided and lampooned for being out of date and out of touch; photo (M)

headline: Drug Maker Set To Cut 350 Jobs
abstract: Schein Pharmaceutical Inc says it will cut 350 jobs at its Steris Laboratories generic-plant in Phoenix; on Sept 10, 1997, Federal agents armed with Food and Drug Administration seizure order halted all manufacturing and distribution at the plant; FDA said plant had failed to correct quality-control problems despite numerous warnings, a $1 million fine and guilty pleas to five misdemeanors (S)

headline: EDISON INTERNATIONAL SETS $500 MILLION STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Edison International says it will buy back as much as $500 million of its stock, or about 4.7 percent of 352.2 million shares outstanding (S)

headline: Taking its inspiration from the past, Mobil sends its familiar flying horse on animated new flights.
abstract: Pegasus, classic red flying horse icon that has served as symbol of Mobil gasoline for 77 years, is being brought to life as part of comprehensive image campaign; animated, 3-D version of Pegasus is start of television commercials designed by Mobil's roster agencies (M)

headline: ANCHOR FINANCIAL SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE BAILEY FINANCIAL
abstract: Anchor Financial Corp to acquire Bailey Financial Corp for $56 million in stock (S)

headline: CENTURY TELEPHONE TO SELL ALASKA OPERATIONS
abstract: Century Telephone Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its operations in Alaska for $415 million in cash. Century Telephone said the buyers -- Fox Paine & Company, an investment fund company based in Foster City, Calif., and former executives of Pacific Telecom Inc. -- would also assume $43 million in debt. Pacific Telecom Inc., a unit of the electricity company Pacificorp of Portland, Ore., was purchased in December by Century Telephone for $1.5 billion and the assumption of $725 million in debt. Century Telephone, based in Monroe, La., said it would use the proceeds from the sale to reduce debt and to finance its acquisition of telephone access lines in Wisconsin from the Ameritech Corporation. Its shares rose 56.25 cents each, to $49.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Jobs Look Steady on a Leaner Wall St.
abstract: Article on cautious attitude of Wall Street firms toward their employees as they move through current downturn; average industry pay has risen to $181,900; securities firms are likely to reduce costs by lowering compensation before instituting layoffs; photo (M)

headline: Northrop Limps As Lockheed Walks Away
abstract: Day after Lockheed Martin Corp terminated its $8.3 billion takeover of Northrop Grumman Corp, Locheed's shares rise slightly, but Northrop's tumble, reflecting differing assessments of what the future holds for the two companies (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: As Expected, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged  After a two-day meeting, the Federal Reserve decided not to change interest rates, which had been widely expected.     Several new economic reports indicate that the economy is cooling, which might be the reason for the move. The National Association of Purchasing Management index for June fell to 49.6 from 51.4 in May, the first time in two years that the level has dropped below 50. The Commerce Department also reported that construction slumped 1.5 percent in May, the worst drop in more than four years, and the Conference Board's indicator of future economic activity remained unchanged from April to May at 105.2. [Page D4.]

headline: For 3 Drug Makers, F.D.A. Makes Their Day
abstract: Advisory committee to Food and Drug Administration recommends approval of taxmoxifen as means to reduce risk of breast cancer, and Genentech Inc receives FDA advisory committee approval for Herceptin, drug to treat metastatic breast cancer; shares of Zeneca Group PLC, which makes taxmoxifen, and Barr Laboratories, which sells its generic form, rise sharply, as do shares of Genentech Inc, which makes Herceptin (M)

headline: U.S. Urged Arms Monitor to Back Off From Clash With Iraq
abstract: Senior American and British officials say United States and Britian urged chief United Nations arms inspector Richard Butler not to confront Iraq by trying to hold surprise inspection after Iraq suspended cooperation with inspectors on Aug 3; say they earlier backed Butler's plans for surprise inspections of two sites; say they wanted to avoid clash focusing on Butler instead of on Iraq's breach of inspection accord and military crisis on Iraq's timetable, before United States could prepare political and diplomatic ground; State Sec Madeleine K Albright denies urging Butler to avoid confrontations, news conference (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HYDROCHEM INDUSTRIAL SERVICES INC., Houston, agreed to acquire Valley Systems Inc., Canal Fulton, Ohio, an industrial cleaning company, for $29.8 million plus assumed debt and certain liabilities.    MUELLER INDUSTRIES, Memphis, a maker of plumbing fixtures, agreed to acquire Lincoln Brass Works Inc., Jacksboro, Tenn., a maker of valve systems for gas appliances, for an undisclosed price.

headline: GROUP BUYS REMAINING 49% OF DUCATI MOTOR
abstract: Investors including Texas Pacific Group and Italian unit of Deutsche Bank acquire remaining 49 percent stake in Ducati Motor SpA, Italian motorcycle maker; price undisclosed (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Monterey Bay Aquarium, Monterey, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its account, which had been handled internally. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

headline: Stocks Plunge, And Russia Moves to Sell Energy Stake
abstract: Russian stock prices plummet as investors doubt whether Government can make good on pledge to climb out of its seemingly bottomless hole of domestic and international debt; Russian Trading System, which declined 17 percent during past week, declines additional 9.1 percent (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.38   5.47   5.45        3-month T-bills   4.67   4.63   4.85        6-month T-bills   4.67   4.61   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.65   3.64   3.57        10-yr. T-note   4.71   4.66   6.09        30-yr. T-bond   5.15   5.12   6.38        Telephone bd.   7.05   7.08   7.49        Municipal bds.   5.09   5.07   5.46          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: A Bear Sees the Return Of 'the Reality Principle'
abstract: Michael Metz, one of stock market's leading bears, describes why he supports recent 10 percent decline in stock market prices; photo (M)

headline: STAFFMARK AGREES TO ACQUIRE BRITISH SEARCH CONCERN
abstract: Staffmark Inc., a recruiter of executives and corporate managers, said yesterday that it would buy Robert Walters P.L.C., another search firm, for $178.8 million in stock. The price values Robert Walters at 429.5 pence a share. Staffmark, which recruits mainly for the computer and pharmaceutical industries, wants the London-based Walters for its strength in placing people in financial services companies and accounting firms. Staffmark, based in Fayetteville, Ark., has offices in 29 states and in Canada, Britain, South Africa and Thailand. Under the agreement, Staffmark will exchange 0.272 share for each Walters share. Walters rose 93.5 pence a share yesterday, to 372 pence, in London trading. Staffmark fell $1.4375, to $24.25.

headline: Long Island PBS Channel To Get Live BBC Newscasts
abstract: British Broadcasting Corp enters three-year contract with WLIW/Channel 21, Long Island-based PBS station, that will provide three half-hour BBC World news programs, live from London, every day to WLIW and about 25 other public television stations; WLIW has carried evening newscast from ITN, another British network, but that contract ends Nov 1 (M)

headline: Ernst & Young decides to consolidate its global account at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.
abstract: Ernst & Young names D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications to handle its advertising account; while selection of agency is no surprise, amount of business that shop received is more than expected; agency receives accounting firm's entire worldwide advertising and branding account, with billings estimated at more than $100 million (M)

headline: BankBoston in Brazil
abstract: BankBoston Corp plans to open 19 additional branches in Brazil by end of year, bringing its total network to 64 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Mutual Fund With the Heft to Move Markets
abstract: Market Place column on how Vanguard Group moves big-stock indexes, like Standard & Poor's 500, when it places big buy or sell orders; says on May 21, when Vanguard began funneling $137 million into stocks that make up Standard & Poor's Small Cap 600 index, the index surged higher, even as every other major stock index declined; chart (M)

headline: Irwin (Sonny) Bloch, 61, Dies; Bilked Radio Show Listeners
abstract: Sonny Bloch, radio talk show host who persuaded listeners to invest in worthless securities and bilked them out of $21 million, died March 10 at relative's home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich; he was 61, and had been released from Federal prison five months earlier with terminal lung cancer; he had been serving tax-evasion sentence, but had not been sentenced in New Jersey for fraud scheme; most of victims were retirees, some left penniless after listening to Bloch for years, in New York on WOR (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  Almost any reasonable investment strategy can work if it's followed with discipline. But that is more difficult than it sounds. By Mark Hulbert.

headline: Delta Reports 20% Profit Gain, But Investors Are Still Unhappy
abstract: Delta Air Lines posts 20 percent gain in earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter, to $362 million, exceeding analysts' expectations; stock price falls 1.2 percent because investors are disappointed that results are not even better; revenue rises 6 percent, to $3.76 billion (S)

headline: Pepsico Completes Tropicana Purchase
abstract: Pepsico Inc completes its $3.3 billion purchase of Tropicana Products Inc from Seagram Co and choses Gary Rodkin as chief executive of Tropicana; Rodkin, formerly president of Tropicana's North America division, replaces Ellen Marram, who is leaving Tropicana (S)

headline: Albright in Bosnia Urging More Reconcilation Efforts
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright spends night in Sarajevo, Bosnia, in what American officials call dramatic symbol of the distance Bosnia has come since US intervention ended Balkan conflict in 1995; presses Serbs, Croats and Muslims to make still-artificial and bitterly divided Bosnia closer to multi-ethnic democracy envisioned in Dayton Accords; openly campaigns Biljana Plavsic, Bosnia Serb president, and other candidates in upcoming elections who are considered supporters of Dayton Accord; photo (M)

headline: Miramax Goes Back To Previous Agency
abstract: Miramax Films renames Harvest Communications to handle media portion of its tristate New York area advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million; cites problems with the agency that handled those duties for only a month, Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shareholders may have recovered from merger fever.
abstract: Shareholders are reacting with increasing skepticism to ongoing merger frenzy, driving down stocks of companies making big acquisitions; table (M)

headline: Acquisition Gives Roche Big Jump in Revenue
abstract: Roche Holding AG's implied second-quarter sales rose 37.7 percent, to 6.69 billion Swiss francs ($4.33 billion) (S)

headline: Year 2000 Compromise Bill Is Opposed by Trial Lawyers
abstract: Compromise effort by Congress and Clinton Administration to promote candid information about year 2000 problems in nation's computers is being assailed by trial lawyers because a cornerstone of plan would grant computer and chip makers immunity from liability suits (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: 100 Black Men of America Inc names Muse Cordero Chen & Co to handle advertising for organization (S)

headline: One-Woman Fashion Show
abstract: Interview with fashion entrepreneur Elaine Kim, who started with one boutique, and then became overinvolved with department stores, causing sales to plummet; she comments on pitfalls of running a one-woman show; photo (Special section on entrepreneurship) (S)

headline: CHASE MANHATTAN TO BUY MELLON MORTGAGE NETWORK
abstract: Chase Manhattan Mortgage Corp to acquire Mellon Mortgage Co's Western retail mortgage network (S)

headline: Rumors of the Death of Bears Were, It Seems, Exaggerated
abstract: Market Place column on selloff on Wall Street, which erased market gains for 1998 and sent stock prices down more than 19 percent from peak of six weeks ago in sharpest decline in eight years; selling hammered stocks both in and out of favor with investors, and marked first time three most popular market indexes--Dow Jones, Nasdaq Composite and Standard & Poor's 500--actually lost ground for year; investors, who stayed ahead of game in previous declines, now face prospect of giving up some of their own (M)

headline: Claims Against Liz Claiborne Dismissed
abstract: Federal Judge Harold Baer Jr throws out parts of suit by workers at Mademoiselle Knitwear Inc, Brooklyn sweater factory, charging Liz Claiborne improperly conspired with Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees leaders to betray their interests; workers hold union improperly agreed to let Claiborne renege on commitment to buy sweaters from Mademoiselle in exchange for payment to union; Baer dismisses all claims against Claiborne; refuses to dismiss two key complaints against union (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., the largest natural-gas shipper in the United States, has agreed to buy a gasoline and diesel fuel terminal in Georgia from Phillips Petroleum Co., Bartlesville, Okla., for an undisclosed amount.

headline: W. L. Morgan, Finance Pioneer, Dies at 100
abstract: Walter L Morgan, pioneer of finance who founded Wellington Fund and headed it for 42 years, dies at age 100 (M)

headline: Mexico Promises Full Inquiry Into Tainted Elite Drug Unit
abstract: Mexican Atty Gen Jorge Madrazo Cuellar promises 'profound' investigation of possible corruption of elite US-trained police unit; insists antidrug cooperation with US should continue without interruption, and bristles at US suggestion that Mexican unit may be responsible for betrayal of important information to traffickers (S)

headline: Richard McDonald, 89, Fast-Food Revolutionary
