abstract: Richard McDonald, who with brother founded McDonald's fast food chain, dies at age 89; photo (M)

headline: New Executives Named At Advertising Offices
abstract: Calvin Klein Inc promotes Dawn Jacobs to head its CRK Advertising in-house agency; Pagano Schenck & Kay names Beau Fraser as president succeeding Woody Kay (S)

headline: NATO Approval Renews Threat of Force in Kosovo
abstract: US says NATO has approved plans for use of military force in separatist crisis in Serbian province of Kosovo; plans reportedly center on use of air power, rather than ground troops; announcement is intended to push Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to end current offensive against ethnic Albanians (M)

headline: Columbia/HCA to Pay $2.5 Million Penalty
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp will pay $2.5 million civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it did not move quickly enough to sell hospitals in Utah and Florida; penalty is product of 1995 settlement that resolved FTC antitrust concerns over Columbia's $3.3 billion acquisition of Healthtrust Inc (S)

headline: British to Allow March, This One in Belfast
abstract: British Government gives permission for a Protestant parade past Catholic area in Belfast one day after banning another group from marching through a Catholic area of Portadown; says further ban would have inflamed passions among pro-British Protestant loyalists who already feel aggrieved at what they regard authorities' eagerness to placate Catholics; photo (M)

headline: Bond Prices Gain as Stocks Also Post Rise
abstract: Bond and stock prices rally; 30-year Treasury bond rises 18/32, to 105 15/32, to yield 5.14 percent; Dow Jones industrial average rises 21.89 points, to 7,895.66; Nasdaq index jumps 17.52 points, to 1,663.77; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rises 1.22 points, to 1,020.09; graphs of Dow Jones average; tables of hot and cold stocks and favorite stocks and of key rates (M)

headline: ABC TV Gets a New President With Wider Duties
abstract: ABC appoints Patricia Fili-Krushel, president of daytime division, as president of ABC Television Network, with additional oversight of ABC's news and entertainment divisions; 44-year-old Fili-Krushel becomes highest-ranking woman executive in television business; photo; she succeeds Preston Padden, who is now Washington lobbyist for ABC's parent, Disney Company; Fili-Krushel, who has helped ABC maintain daytime lead, recalls role in developing all-women's programming format at Lifetime, cable channel where she previously worked; her husband, Kenneth B Krushel, is NBC executive (M)

headline: Credit Suisse's Bank Unit Sale
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada agrees to buy Credit Suisse Group's North American private banking unit; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Fed Reports Decline in Loans to Large Businesses
abstract: Federal Reserve survey of banks finds business loans to large customers fell in second quarter, first drop since 1996 first quarter (S)

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments and assignments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Technology; As Web search engines mutate into portal sites, the idea is to get and keep your selective attention.
abstract: Technology column on questionable worth of 'portal,' scheme whereby handful of mostly money-losing enterprises band together to form mega-Web site that combines searching, content, E-mail, chat and other services; advertisers have been drawn to portals at level that defies reason; top nine portals account for mere 15 percent of all Internet traffic, but they attract 59 percent of all advertising revenue on Internet; critics claim portals steer users to members of their own Web sites, and are not, as advertised, an open gateway to Internet; drawing (M)

headline: In Seoul, Too, Rubin Urges Japan to Move on Economy
abstract: Treasury Sec Robert Rubin, in South Korea on six-day, four-country sweep of Asia, repeatedly stresses importance of getting Japan back on track to support growth in Korea and region in general; expresses deep concern about slide of yen against dollar; exhorts Japan to devise credible banking system overhaul; his decision to talk great deal about Japan without visiting nation is subject of intense discussion in Asia; Pres Kim Dae Jung, in heavily veiled expression of concern about China's power, asks Rubin whether US and China forge 'special relationship'; Rubin also meets with business and labor leaders; photo (M)

headline: Brazil Sees Record Drop In Markets
abstract: Brazilian markets, caving in under international financial crisis and Government's failure over last four years to make crucial changes, reports record losses, with emergency measures over last week proving futile to end slide in investor confidence; Sao Paulo exchange closes down record 15.8 percent; Standard & Poor's lowers its country rating on Brazil to negative; market sources say $1.7 billion in foreign reserves have poured out of country; Brazil is seen as bellwether for region, and country most capable of ushering in Latin version of turbulence that has roiled Asia and Russia; markets fall 9.8 percent in Mexico, 13.3 percent in Argentina and 7.4 percent in Chile; Brazil's Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who faces re-election in less than a month, strikes defiant note, saying no further interest rate increases and spending cuts will follow those of last week (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Two-day rally in coffee futures is snapped after Brazil's dock workers end strike, allowing resumed shipments from top coffee bean grower; September contract falls 3.9 cents, to $1.1395 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: A 72-Year-Old Young Turk in Japan's Premier Race
abstract: 72-year-old Seirou Kajiyama, one of three candidates vying to become Prime Minister of Japan, moves to burnish image in West as reformer and to influence choice by leaders of governing party; holds rare news conference, at which he fielded questions about policy proposals, addressed issue of his age and otherwise explained himself (M)

headline: Outsmarting a Quiz
abstract: Edwin A Rosenberg letter comments on question in July 16 How Smart Are You quiz

headline: Biggest German Bank Admits and Regrets Dealing in Nazi Gold
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG, biggest bank in Germany, admits dealing in Nazi gold and 'regrets' injustices that occurred; declines to say whether wartime officers knew that some of gold may have come from concentration camp victims; independent report commissioned by bank has found that bank channeled gold through branches in Austria and Turkey; 744 of 4,446 gold kilograms consisted of dental gold from Jews, wedding bands and other jewelry amassed in Berlin by SS officer; findings strength class-action suit by Holocaust survivors against Deutsche and Dresdner Bank (S)

headline: Top Catholic Leader In North Faults I.R.A.
abstract: Seamus Mallon, highest-ranking Roman Catholic in Northern Ireland Assembly, accuses Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, of impeding peace effort in British province (S)

headline: AVIATION SALES IN DEAL FOR PRIMARK'S MAINTENANCE UNIT
abstract: Aviation Sales Co to acquire Triad International Maintenance Co from Primark Corp for about $70 million in cash (S)

headline: The Toronto-based Wolf Group acquires shop after shop in its quest to meet twin goals.
abstract: Article on growth of Toronto-based advertising agency Wolf Group Integrated Communications Ltd through acquisitions; says chairman-chief executive Larry Wolf has been acquiring ad shops with twin goals of becoming top-20 agency company in billings and going public (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is little changed against Japanese yen on expectations that Japanese Government will not quickly clean up nation's banking mess; dollar rises as high as 146.70 yen, before falling to 146.30 yen in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: Two Top Executives to Quit Recently Formed Hotel Chain
abstract: Promus Hotel Corp, formed eight months ago by merger of Promus Hotel Corp and Doubletree Corp, says chairman-chief executive Raymond E Schultz and Richard M Kelleher, president and chief operating officer, will resign and that it will seek new leadership from outside company; Richard J Ferris and Michael D Rose, directors affiliated with two formerly independent companies, will resign from new company's board when new chairman and chief executive is named (M)

headline: Lucent on the Loose: Come October, It Can Swallow Bigger Fish
abstract: Speculation discussed as to Lucent Technologies' acquisition plans (S)

headline: Web Shopping Tangles
abstract: Letter from Joseph Lowery comments on July 30 article on Internet shopping (S)

headline: A Federal agency starts a paid campaign today to influence young people to stay away from drugs.
abstract: Clinton Administration's drug policy agency will introduce its first paid national advertising as part of its fight against drug use among young people; Pres Clinton will join Gen Barry R McCaffrey, director of Office of National Drug Control Policy, in Atlanta to introduce campaign; it will have initial budget of $195 million, appropriated by Congress, and will involve all forms of media; ads for paid campaign are being donated by agencies through Partnership for a Drug-Free America, which is serving as unpaid consultant and will receive no Federal money (M)

headline: THE MARKETS -- Asia's Tigers Lick Wounds And Worry; Long Lean Spell Brings Talk About a Depression
abstract: Asia's recession is deepening, along with economic and social devastation it brings; number of people out of work is rising, and economic output is sinking at fastest rate in years--in leading countries like South Korea and Japan; it has been decades since there has been a decline so severe and so widespread; banks in many nations are shaky, and corporate failures are feeding a sense of gloom; stock markets in much of region have fallen by more than half from their peaks; unemployment has soared; soup kitchens and rice lines are appearing around the region, and parks and boulevards are filling up with new homeless; drawing; graphs of total gross domestic product for 1997 in major Asian nations (M)

headline: Malaysia's No. 1 Bank to Cut Key Rate
abstract: Malayan Banking, Malaysia's biggest bank, said today that it would cut its key lending rate for the third time in six weeks, to 10.9 percent from 11.4 percent. The cut, effective Tuesday, came 10 days after the previous one.    Malaysia's leaders, including Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, have been urging banks to lower interest rates to ease tight credit and the burden of debt on the country's businesses. The conditions are crimping banks' profits at a time when their borrowing costs have increased.

headline: Name That Fare! (And Other On-Line Challenges for Travelers)
abstract: Article on Internet sites that offer bargain-priced airfares; describes Priceline.com, which promotes 'name your own price' on-line auction service for buying tickets; photo; list (M)

headline: S.E.C. Settlement In Insider Case
abstract: Joseph Penna, associate of former AT&T labor relations executive, Charles Brumfield, settles Securities and Exchange Commission allegations that he earned $36,671 in illegal profits on call option contracts bought with insider information about planned acquisition by AT&T Corp; Penna agrees to return his profits and neither acknowledges nor denies liability (S)

headline: TRINET AND MENLO BUY SUBURBAN PROPERTIES
abstract: Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc and Menlo Equities LLC buys five suburban office and research and development properties in San Jose, Calif, for about $50.4 million (S)

headline: Clinton Signs Off on Digital Advance
abstract: DUBLIN  When President Bill Clinton applied his digital signature to a joint communique with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland in Dublin on Friday, the two not only made a little bit of digital history, they also gave an unwitting lift to the cause of strong encryption.

headline: COOPER DISCLOSES BUYBACK AND FATE OF AUTO PARTS UNITS
abstract: Cooper Industries plans to buy back as much as $500 million in stock and to register to sell as much as 19 percent of its auto parts business in stock sale as it focuses on selling electrical products and hardware (S)

headline: Water Divides Haves From Have-Nots in West Bank
abstract: Israel, which controls West Bank water, is supplying little to Palestinians during unusually hot summer, while Jewish settlers have ample supplies; water rights are supposed to be part of final peace accord; photo (M)

headline: The Business of Child Care
abstract: Lorraine Mesagna letter supports June 21 article Rosemary Jordano and Marie Oates on need to pay child care workers higher wages (S)

headline: R. Gerwe, 94, Chemist and Food Scientist
abstract: Raymond D Gerwe, chemist and developer of two US patents, dies at age 94 (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Rich nation, poor nation. Is anyone even looking for a cure?
abstract: Economic Scene column by Peter Passell on bounty of America's economic growth going to educated, enterprising and already-affluent in last quarter of century; says since 1970's, economists have learned that while labor still captures about two-thirds of national income, only skilled workers have benefited; holds phenomenon of 'winner take all' has increased gaps between successful and also-rans in diverse occupations; says little is being done to right imbalance; suggests some ways to correct trend; drawing (M)

headline: Swiss Recount Key Drug Role Of Salinas Kin
abstract: Swiss police investigators, after three-year probe of drug corruption in Mexico, report former Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari's brother Raul raked in upwards of $500 million in bribes for arranging elaborate network to protect flow of cocaine into United States; hold he channeled drug money into brother's presidential campaign and assumed control over practically all drug shipments through Mexico after brother took office in 1988; report apparently is based on interviews with almost 90 former drug traffickers, Salinas associates and other witnesses; will be basis for planned seizure of $130 million Raul Salinas deposited in Swiss banks; his lawyers see Swiss crusade to confiscate funds they insist client earned legitimately; photos (M)

headline: TEAMSTERS TOLD THAT PROMISED JOBS ARE HALTED
abstract: United Parcel Service of America Inc tells teamsters' union it will not create 2,000 full-time jobs as promised in accord that settled national strike last year because number of package deliveries has not returned to pre-strike levels (S)

headline: Senators Back Sale of Wheat To Pakistanis
abstract: Senate unanimously agrees to exempt food exports from sanctions that United States imposed on India and Pakistan after two countries conducted nuclear tests in May; vote, in response to pressure from American wheat farmers, lifts largest and most painful economic penalty Washington inflicted and leaves almost no meaningful sanctions in place to punish two countries for tests; India and Pakistan are small markets for American non-farm goods; Senators express concern about threat of new arms race, but they have important farming constituents to consider, and wheat prices have plunged to seven-year low because of excess supply; bipartisan bill was rushed to floor in advance of Pakistan's planned purchase of 350,000 metric tons of wheat in next week (M)

headline: Stocks and Social Security
abstract: Stacey Chan letter responds to Herbert Barchoff's July 19 article on Social Security privatization proposal (S)

headline: QUAKER FABRIC SHARES DECLINE TO A 52-WEEK LOW
abstract: Shares of Quaker Fabric Corp fall 44 percent to 52-week low after it says fiscal third- and fourth-quarter earnings will be significantly below expectations (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Union Pacific Railroad Tries To Stop Tougher Regulation  Seeking to fend off demands for tougher Federal regulation, the Union Pacific Railroad said that traffic congestion was easing, capacity expanding and competition with rival carriers intensifying.

headline: Seeing More Mergers As an Industry Adjusts
abstract: Interview with Cambridge Energy Research Associates chairman Daniel Yergin on implications on oil industry of British Petroleum's agreement to purchase Amoco; photo (M)

headline: In Landmark Settlement, a Question of Fees
abstract: Federal Judge Robert Sweet considers more than $174 million in claims by lawyers who filed novel antitrust case, and won settlements of more than $1 billion from Wall Street brokerage houses that were found guilty of illegally fixing prices on stocks traded on Nasdaq market; case helped push Nasdaq into radical overhaul of its trading practices; fees are sought by attorneys who led vast legal team; John C Coffee Jr of Columbia Law School supports claim, with Lawrence Schonbrun among opponents; photos (M)

headline: STRONGMAN'S BLOC DECLARES VICTORY IN CAMBODIA VOTE
abstract: Post-election battle lines begin forming in Cambodia with party of incumbent strongman, Hun Sen, claiming victory, and his two opposition rivals crying fraud and threatening to block formation of new government; with only a tiny fraction of vote count released, country appears to be entering a tense and possibly chaotic period of protests and maneuvering by all sides, including two main opposition candidates, Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy; photo of Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy (M)

headline: Coming Soon: Three New Features
abstract: Money and Business section of The New York Times will add new features encouraging reader participation: Working column on job issues, So to Speak feature on marketplace gobbledygook and monthly My Money, My Life stories (S)

headline: Rongcheng Journal; As Floods Rage, Bitter Choices Over What to Save
abstract: Rongcheng, China, and other towns along overflowing Yangtze River have suffered some of worst damage of summer's floods; 100,000 people have lost their homes in Jianli County; all of damage in county resulted from decisions to spread swelling waters by breaching inner dikes to relieve pressure on vital main dikes and provincial capital of Wuhan downstream; map; photo (M)

headline: Ushuaia Journal; Argentina Battles Plague: All Too Eager Breeders
abstract: Tierra del Fuego, Argentina, is being overrun by beavers that have proliferated since 1946, when 25 pairs were introduced from Canada to promote local fur industry; animals have cut down hundreds of acres of forests to build dams, creating hundreds of artificial lakes that cause flooding, threatening livelihoods of cattlemen and farmers; biologists are concerned that beavers may one day cross Strait of Magellan to mainland, where they could pose threat to Andean forests; animals have thrived in Tierra del Fuego like nowhere else on earth because of absence of natural predators; map; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE MARKETS -- Market Place; Less U.S. Ability This Time To Halt Falling Yen's Damage
abstract: US finds itself with few options as Japanese yen falls to eight-year lows, helping to pull down financial markets around the world; US can intervene in currency markets to support yen's value, as it did in June, or jawbone Japanese Government into stimulating its economy; yet neither tactic is likely to be effective in absence of drastic measures by Japan; chart; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: ECONOMY    Confidence Is Not High . . .  The nation's manufacturers have slowed production to the lowest rate of growth since 1995, the clearest impact so far of the Asian crisis on the American economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing activity weakened in June for a majority of the companies that it surveys each month. It was the first time in 22 months that a majority had reported weakening instead of strengthening in their businesses. Manufacturing employment has fallen in recent months, and industrial production has slowed to an annual growth rate of less than 2 percent, down from 6 percent last year. Production is slowing in large part because stockpiles of unsold goods have surged, but also because companies are becoming worried that the economic boom cannot continue at the fervent pace of the last two years. Separately, the index of leading economic indicators was flat in May, a sign that growth will moderate in the coming months.

headline: Fox Drops Drama Based on Charge Against Justice Thomas
abstract: Television drama about sexual harassment charges against Clarence Thomas is scrapped after Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corp and owner of Fox Television, objects to project; program was to be based on Strange Justice, book written by reporters Jane Mayer and Jill Abramson; it was finalist for National Book Award; book concluded that Anita F Hill told truth in her charges against Thomas during Senate hearings on his nomination to Supreme Court; Murdoch reportedly told associate that Thomas is friend of his who shares at least some of Murdoch's own conservative views; two years ago, Ted Turner, vice chairman of Time Warner Inc, stalled TNT television production of same book, reportedly fearing to offend Thomas during Supreme Court's deliberations over cable regulation case; photos (M)

headline: In Silicon Valley, Big Swings In Share Price Are Ho-Hum
abstract: Stock options have fueled boom in Silicon Valley and in other regions of country where high-technology and Internet businesses are congregated, more than in almost any other industry; have allowed start-up companies to pay smart, ambitious workers relatively low salary, along with promise of great riches if efforts and creativity help ventures succeed; phenomenon seems to have ignited singular brand of investment psychology in which employees exhibit ho-hum attitude in dealing with stock volatility that shakes even most hardened investor; many Silicon Valley employees regard fluctuations as way of life, calculating value of options solely on potential; feel swings matter very little as long as fundamentals are sound; options, which essentially represent agreement by company to make shares available to employee for specified price in future, can yield great profit when company's stock soars, or be worth nothing if it plunges; while not commonly offered in many industries, they are virtually standard in places like Silicon Valley; photo; graph (M)

headline: CADENCE DESIGN BUYING BELL LABS UNIT FROM LUCENT
abstract: Cadence Design Systems Inc to buy Bell Labs Design Automation Group from Lucent Technologies Inc (S)

headline: Airbus Receives $5 Billion Order
abstract: Airbus Industrie receives order from United Parcel Service of America Inc with value of as much as $5 billion, its first order from United Parcel; 30 A300 planes have list price of about $90 million each (S)

headline: Cosmo's editor moves to Glamour, heating up the competition between two ad-rich magazines.
abstract: Ruth Whitney retires as editor of Glamour magazine; Bonnie Fuller, editor of Cosmopolitan, to succeed Whitney; Cathleen P Black, president of Hearst Magazines, says Kate White, editor of Redbook, will succeed Fuller as editor of Cosmopolitan (M)

headline: Wal-Mart's Net Income Climbs by 30%
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says earnings rose 30 percent in quarter ended July 31; net income rose to $1.03 billion from $795 million a year earlier; revenue rose 18 percent, to $33.5 billion from $28.4 billion (S)

headline: Treasuries Drop in Price As Dollar Dips
abstract: Treasury securities prices drop; 30-year bond falls 9/32, to 107 6/32, to yield 5.62 percent; table of key rates (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 7 article on challenges to power of mutual fund directors which attributed quote erroneously (S)

headline: For U.A.W., Huge Price and Tiny Victory at G.M.
abstract: Analysis of settlement of United Automobile Workers strike against General Motors Corp; says after eight weeks on strike, auto workers can boast that they achieved their main goal: GM agreed to proceed with $180 million investment at metal stamping plant in Flint, Mich; holds workers achieved that small victory for huge price: loss of $1 billion in wages; photo (M)

headline: Calling All Radio Buffs
abstract: Bud Weisberg letter on Sept 10 article on radio call letters (S)

headline: In a Period of Losses, Some Funds Find Gains
abstract: Article on best- and worst-performing US difersified mutual funds as stock market dips; chart (M)

headline: Iraqi Deal With Sudan On Nerve Gas Is Reported
abstract: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE CONNECTION: Iraqi Deal With Sudan On Nerve Gas Is Reported**Foreign diplomats and former Sudanese Government official say that Iraq and Sudan struck bargain at end of Persian Gulf War in 1991; say Sudan, in return for Iraqi financial help and assistance by military and civilian experts, agreed to allow its installations to be used by Iraqi technicians for steps in production of chemical weapons; say military complex on outskirts of Khartoum, not plant that was attacked by US, was most likely place for production of chemical weapons; photo (M)

headline: Congo Says It's Reversing Rebel Gains
abstract: Congolese officials, claiming Government's first major success against week-old insurrection, say their troops have succeeded in beating back rebels who captured several strategic towns in southwest of country; map; photo (M)

headline: Successful Searching
abstract: Joseph J Esposito letter on Sept 3 article holds people searching Internet will in future use branded sites that specialize in particular subject area, bypassing general search-engine sites

headline: Raids Are Seen As One Battle In a Long Fight
abstract: US leaders say missile attack on Afghanistan and Sudan was small battle in war without foreseeable end; US military, intelligence and diplomatic services are charting contours of new battlefield as they brace for Osama bin Laden's reply; his organization is unlike any other; it has no real headquarters and no fixed address to target; it is coalition of like-minded warriors living in exile from their homes in Egypt, Sudan, Pakistan and other Islamic nations riven by religious and political battles; bin Laden organization is global and stateless and more theological than political; it is driven by millenial vision of destroying US, driving all Western influences from Arab world, abolishing boundaries of Islamic nations and making them one without borders (M)

headline: Microsoft and U.S. at Odds Over Testimony
abstract: Justice Department's pretrial motion accuses Microsoft of resisting requests to make senior exectives available for depositions and to turn over data as part of antitrust case (S)

headline: Stockholm Journal; In Years Since Palme Killing, a Loss of Innocence
abstract: Certain fatalism that took hold of Sweden following assassination of Prime Min Olof Palme in 1986 has been deepened by hapless performance of police, which has left case still unsolved; inquiry has been repeatedly sidetracked by disputes and scandals that has forced resignations of Justice Minister, police chief and other officials; Martin Palme, who was with father night he was shot, and other members of Palme family say they are convinced killer was confessed drug addict and alcoholic Christer Pettersson, who was convicted of murder but later freed by appellate court; common view is that assassination profoundly altered Sweden's view of itself as unassailable guardian of world's social conscience; photo (M)

headline: Covering the Territory; On the Web, Titans Battle for Turf
abstract: Home Advisor, run by Microsoft, and Realtor.com, operated by Real Select for National Assn of Realtors, are battling for supremacy on Web; photo (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    The Agriculture Department reports on 1998 crop conditions.

headline: Bad Debt Held by Japan's Banks Now Estimated Near $1 Trillion
abstract: Japan's banking crisis is thought to be far worse than Tokyo has publicly acknowledged, with bad debts approaching $1 trillion, or nearly twice the official estimate; American officials and private financial experts who reached that conclusion warn that their estimates are rough, in part because Japanese banks have used accounting tricks to hide debts that are not being repaid; higher figures complicate challenge facing Keizo Obuchi, Japan's new Prime Minister; he has little experience in financial sphere and has offered only vaguest of plans about how he will deal with what appears to be largest banking crisis in history; Clinton Administration and Wall Street have long assumed that Japanese were understating problems they face; new estimates suggest bailing out Japanese banks could cost Japanese taxpayers far more than $314 billion that Tokyo set aside (M)

headline: Japan Voters Send Message: No Change
abstract: Candidates for Parliament in Kochi, Japan, a remote fishing center, do not tell voters about how the nation can shake off its worst postwar depression but rather about how they can win more national funds for local dam, roads and other pork-barrel projects; campaign suggests that Japanese voters, at least those in rural areas, want more of the same and are not interested in the kind of fundamental restructuring urged on Japan by US; map (M)

headline: Phone Wars Leave F.C.C. In a Political Combat Zone
abstract: Analysis: Local Bell telephone companies are winning battles of influence at Federal Communications Commission; biggest victory came last week when commission recommended that the Bells, along with GTE Corp, be allowed to keep their local data networks to themselves instead of having to resell them to competitors; William E Kennard, commission's chairman, described proposal as bid to jump-start deployment of high-speed data services to American homes; proposal reflects complex and powerful set of political pressures that have come to bear on FCC; political influence of the Bells seems to have combined with Kennard's relative vulnerability, impatience in Congress with pace of communications revolution, and Washington's native partnership to push FCC in its current direction (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: MARKETS  A Global Unraveling  Stock market investors around the world rushed to sell, frightened by economic problems in Russia and Asia. On Thursday, the worst trading day of the year, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.19 percent, or 357.36 points, to close at 8,165.99, some 12.5 percent below its July 17 high of 9,337.97. Investors are well into what Wall Street calls a correction. And a bear market -- defined as a price decline of 15 to 20 percent -- appeared to be at hand. The Dow ended the week at TK.TK, down TK.TK, and the Nasdaq composite fell TK.TK points, to TK.TK. The rate on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.34 percent, the lowest long-term yield in three decades.    MICROSOFT  Was Intel Bullied?  In its continuing antitrust investigation of Microsoft, the Government is looking into whether the company used its market muscle to force Intel, its only real peer, to shelve new-technology efforts that conflicted with Microsoft's ambitions. Federal and state investigators were said to have taken depositions from key Intel employees, including Andrew S. Grove, the chairman, left. Microsoft contends that the investigators are trying to portray routine business meetings as attempts to forge an anti-competitive conspiracy.

headline: As Cambodia Nears Election, Leader Has Most of the Cards
abstract: Cambodian intellectuals, human rights monitors and diplomats say Hun Sen's ruling party has so intimidated electorate and so thoroughly controls election levers that no opposition group stands fair chance of dislodging him in July 26 election; say since violent coup one year ago that gave Hun Sen complete control of Government, over 100 people have been killed in campaign to consolidate ruling party's power; for all of Hun Sen's advantages, outcome of election is far from certain; some 39 parties are vying for votes, and no single party is expected to win two-thirds majority in 122-seat Parliament that is required to form Government; Parliament will then select Prime Minister, who is expected to be one of three nationally known politicians now leading field: Hun Sen, Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy; map; Hun Sen photo (M)

headline: Fierce Run on the Rand by Speculators Shocks South Africa
abstract: Speculators have driven South African rand down 13 percent in last few days, forcing nation's central bank to seek help from United States and Britain and raise interest rates sharply; rand had gradually fallen 12 percent against dollar since Jan 1 before speculators began attack; buying by Federal Reserve Bank and Bank of England gave rand only short-lived lift after it became clear that central banks were using South African Reserve Bank's dollars to buy rand; Reserve Bank raises over-night lending rate to over 20 percent, from 18.311 percent, spurring most banks to raise prime rates by two percentage points, to 22.25 percent; economists, citing nation's strong economic fundamentals, are suprised by fierceness of attack; graph (M)

headline: Japanese Bank Compromise Frays Already
abstract: Broad-based banking compromise measure that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi had hailed as foundation for Japan's economic recovery begins to fray, just as Obuchi prepares to meet with Pres Clinton in US; banking deal was intended to help stabilize Japan's shaky financial system and to be basis for legislation to restore international confidence in nation's economy; stocks fall sharply in Japan; major bond-rating agency, Fitch IBCA of London, lowers Japan's long-term foreign currency debt; says with nation's deteriorating banking system, increasing Government debt and slow response by policy makers, risks of lending to Japan by overseas investors can no longer be ignored (M)

headline: BANKNORTH AND EVERGREEN SET $291.2 MILLION MERGER
abstract: Banknorth Group will acquire Evergreen Bancorp Inc of Glen Falls, New York, for $291.2 million (S)

headline: For Yahoo, the Growth Mantra Goes On and On and On
abstract: Strong performance of Yahoo stock noted in face of stock market slump; company tells portfolio managers that its operating profit margin is likely to rise sharply (S)

headline: Rose Blumkin, Retail Queen, Dies at 104
abstract: Rose Blumkin, who founded Nebraska Furniture Mart in 1937, helped her son and grandchildren build it into nation's largest home furnishings store and continued selling carpet there well past her 100th birthday, dies at age 104; photo (M)

headline: SEARS TO SELL AUTO PARTS UNIT'S CREDIT CARD PORTFOLIOS
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co agrees to seek buyer for credit card portfolios of Western Auto, auto parts business it is selling to Advance Stores Company (S)

headline: Templeton Likes Prospects for Asia
abstract: Franklin Templeton Group money managers, attending annual shareholders meeting in Toronto, express optimism over Asian investments (M)

headline: People
abstract: Jack Laschever is named publisher of GQ magazine, succeeding Richard Beckman (S)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Are 3.7% Higher on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers reports uncovered short positions rose 3.7 percent on Nasdaq market in month ended July 15, to 2.17 billion shares, up from 2.09 billion in previous month; tables (S)

headline: Group Proposes Voluntary Guidelines for Internet Privacy
abstract: Online Privacy Alliance, in continuing effort to head off new laws governing how companies can collect and use personal information gathered on Internet about consumers, proposes voluntary enforcement program to certify World Wide Web sites that comply with privacy guidelines; Clinton Administration applaudes proposal (M)

headline: Lloyds Deal to Create Big New Zealand Bank
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group PLC plans to buy Countrywide Banking Corp from Bank of Scotland and merge it with its New Zealand banking unit; merger will create bank with 23 percent of New Zealand banking market (S)

headline: Inquiry on Lobbying Delays Holbrooke U.N. Nomination
abstract: Nomination of Richard C Holbrooke as US Ambassador to UN is delayed indefinitely while Justice Department reviews his financial disclosure statements and probes his contacts with former State Department colleagues after leaving department in 1996 for Wall Street job; review follows allegations that Holbrooke may have violated Federal ethics laws by lobbying American diplomats overseas on behalf of his investment banking firm, Credit Suisse First Boston; photo (M)

headline: Public Face of Terror Suspect: Low-Key Family Man
abstract: Wahid el Hage, the man accused of being a leader of Osama bin Landen's terrorist organization in Kenya, and Haroun Fazil, who is accused of being one of his top aides, have been leading lives of middle-class family men, not young, unemployed firebrands usually associated with terrorism; el Hage is linked indirectly to mysterious 1991 murder of Mustapha Shalabi in Brooklyn; Shalabi had been Sheik Abdel-Rahman's sponsor when he entered US, but they fell out when Sheik demanded that part of the money they were raising for Islamic rebels fighting Russians in Afghanistan be diverted to effort to overthrow Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt (M)

headline: Virginia E. Rice, A Reader's Digest Editor, 53
abstract: Virginia E Rice, former Reader's Digest executive, dies at age 53 (S)i

headline: Ex-F.C.C. Chief Named to Board
abstract: Ascend Communications Inc, No. 4 computer networking company, says that it named Reed E Hundt, former FCC Chmn, to its board (S)

headline: CABLEVISION TO PAY $160 MILLION FOR CLEARVIEW CINEMA
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp to buy Clearview Cinema Group Inc for $160 million in cash and stock in its first move into movie-theater business (S)

headline: Kohlberg Kravis-Led Group To Buy Big Insurance Broker
abstract: Investor group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co announces deal to buy Willis Corroon Group PLC, world's fourth-largest insurance broker, for 851 million pounds, or $1.4 billion, in cash; investor group includes Chubb, Hartford Financial Services and Travelers Property Casualty, all of US, and Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group and Guardian Royal Exchange of Britain; Kohlberg Kravis will own 76 percent of Willis Corroon, five insurers, 19 percent and management, 5 percent (M)

headline: (Loosely) Managed Care Is in Demand; Provider Plans Zooming Over Restrictive H.M.O.'s
abstract: Popularity of loosely managed medical plans, called preferred provider organizations, or PPO's, is surging, as they take customers away from traditional unlimited fee-for-service plans as well as from more restrictive health maintenance organizations; members of PPO's can go to any doctor without asking permission, although it cost them more to go to physicians and hospitals outside organization's network; as more people reject restrictive HMO's for relative freedom of PPO's, questions arise as to whether quality health care can be delivered at reasonable cost; some HMO's that have tried to compete by being more flexible have run into serious financial trouble; graph; photo (M)

headline: International Briefs; Aerospatiale to Buy A Lagardere Unit
abstract: Aerospatiale says it will buy Lagardere SCA's military unit and that it plans to sell a fifth of new company on stock market before January (S)

headline: Operating Results Up 7% at Bankers Trust
abstract: Bankers Trust Corp says operating earnings rose 7 percent in second quarter; profit from operations rose to $228 million from $213 million a year ago; net income was $164 million, down 23 percent from 1997 quarter (S)

headline: For Pakistan And India, Atom Pact Is Hard Sell
abstract: Celia W Dugger analysis of willingness expressed by Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee of India and Prime Min Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan to sign nuclear test-ban treaty; says the two leaders will need to convince their restive publics that they got something substantial in return; notes that response to their speeches at United Nations, in which they said their countries were ready to sign treaty within year if sanctions against them were lifted, was optimistic in US; maintains that Sharif and Vajpayee face politically insecure futures and would pay high price with voters if they signed treaty without bringing home goods (M)

headline: In July, Industrial Production Fell for 2d Consecutive Month
abstract: Federal Reserve reports industrial output fell 0.6 percent, July; Labor Department reports producer prices rose 0.2 percent, July; University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment falls to 104.5 in Aug from 105.2 in July; graph (M)5

headline: Lehman Expects Russian Turmoil to Help Cut Net by $60 Million
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc says that financial turmoil in Russia and other developing countries will reduce its net income by $60 million for three months ended on Aug 31; estimates third fiscal quarter income at $151 million (S)

headline: VALSPAR TO BUY PACKAGING COATINGS UNIT OF DEXTER CORP.
abstract: Valspar Corp agrees to buy Dexter Corp's packaging coatings business for undisclosed price (S)

headline: British Telecom Cites Pretax Profit From Sale
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC says it will record pretax profit of 1 billion pounds ($1.68 billion) in quarter ending on Sept 30 from sale of its 20 percent stake in MCI Communications Corp to Worldcom Inc (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Tact Can Seal A Global Deal . . . But a Little Spunk Works Best in New York
abstract: Laurie Joan Aron article recalls spunkiness she used when a business client from North Carolina visited her offices in New York City; drawing (M)

headline: Calculated Risk: U.S. and I.M.F. Lead Push for Brazil Bailout Plan
abstract: Clinton Administration and International Monetary Fund are arranging package of more than $30 billion in loans for Brazil to limit damage to Latin America's biggest economy from Asian financial crisis, even though bailout plan is calculated risk that could sink country into deep recession; package is aimed at preserving value of Brazilian currency and reversing withdrawals by increasingly nervous foreign lenders; Brazil has become front line in struggle to halt spreading financial crisis, because of its power to pull down markets and plunge countries into recession; stakes for US are considerable since its economy dominates Latin America, which accounts for 20 percent of America's exports, and is home to thousands of American-owned factories; looming opposition to financing plan, both in Republican-controlled Congress and among private lenders, discussed (M)

headline: Russian Derivatives May Burn Investors
abstract: While Russia's devalued ruble raises concerns about country's ability to manage its $40 billion in ruble-denominated debt, 25 percent of which is held by foreigners, Western investors and banks could face even greater losses from Russian derivatives; these complex financial instruments could pose greater risk becuse lack of public disclosure makes estimates of investments difficult; some currency traders and emerging-market specialists have set value of derivatives at risk in Russia as high as $100 billion, but many analysts believe figure is probably much lower than that; large American banks have relatively little exposure in Russia given their size--about $7.68 billion--but other undisclosed positions could add to banks' derivatives worries (M)

headline: Some Inflation Protection For U.S. Savings Bonds
abstract: Treasury Department announces that interest paid on Series I savings bond will be pegged partly to changes in Consumer Price Index effective September 1 (M)

headline: Overseas Markets Send Wall Street Reeling
abstract: Stock markets in Asia and Europe record sharp drops; Dow Jones plunges 280 points just before noon, than bounds back to end day at 8,533.65, loss of only 77.76 points; chart (M)

headline: BISYS TO BUY MAKER OF CHECK IMAGING SOFTWARE
abstract: Bisys Group Inc to acquire Greenway Corp for $47.5 million in stock (S)

headline: Argentine Leader Vows to Retain Currency Peg to Dollar
abstract: Most Argentine economists and Wall Street analysts believe Pres Carlos Saul Menem when he pledges not to retreat from Government's fixed exchange rate that pegs value of Argentine peso to American dollar one to one; all five presidential candidates vying to replace Menem in elections next year have promised not to replace peg because of fears that change of policy could mean return to economic mismanagemet; Menem installed currency peg in 1991, when Argentina's inflation rate was 2,300 percent and there was run on banks; within weeks, inflation rate plummeted and has stablized at around 1 percent in last three years; currency peg is set by law that prohibits Government from printing new pesos unless they are backed by dollars or gold reserves in central bank (M)

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES ORDERS 15 MORE LONG-RANGE JETLINERS
abstract: American Airlines orders 15 more 777 long-range jetliners from Boeing Co (S)g

headline: Misnamed User's Guide
abstract: Franklin Steinfeld letter comments on Michelle Slatalla's User's Guide column; says ordinary consumers cannot not call a performer or president of a company with questions and expect the same reception given to a New York Times writer

headline: Takeover Rumors Send Olivetti Shares Higher
abstract: Shares of Olivetti SpA surge for third day on talks that British Telecommunications PLC or another foreign rival is plotting to acquire Italian telephone and office equipment company; British Telecom denies speculation (S)

headline: International Briefs; Revenues Rise 5.3% At France Telecom
abstract: France Telecom SA says revenue rose 5.3 percent in second quarter, to 40.14 billion French francs ($6.7 billion), after gain of only 1.6 percent in first quarter (S)

headline: Adding Up the Pluses and Minuses of Buying or Leasing a PC
abstract: Peter H Lewis assesses merits of leasing personal computer at time of rapid obsolesence and falling prices; table (M)

headline: International Briefs; Data Communications Unit to Be Sold by Racal
abstract: Racal Electronics PLC will sell its unprofitable computer communications business, taking charge of 127 million pounds ($207 million) that will leave it with loss for its latest fiscal year; Racal will sell its data communications unit to Platinum Equity Holdings Inc for $47.5 million; because of charge from sale, Racal reports pretax loss of 207.2 million pounds for year ended March 31 (S)

headline: SCHERING-PLOUGH TELLS OF STOCK SPLIT AND NEW CHAIRMAN
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp, encouraged by expected 20 percent jump in earnings for 1998, says it will split its stock 2 for 1; company names Richard Jay Kogan its chairman, replacing Robert P Luciano, who is retiring; Kogan will maintain his position as chief executive but resign as president; Raul E Cesan will become president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: Russia Told to Implement Tough I.M.F. Reform Plan
abstract: Finance ministers of Germany, France, Italy and Britain warn Russia that the only way out of its current crisis is to make the tough economic changes long urged by International Monetary Fund, including enforcing tax laws and hewing to a monetary policy that keeps inflation in check (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Earnings Decreased 29% At Intel in Second Quarter  Shares of Intel fell 2 percent yesterday. After the stock market closed, the chip maker reported a 29 percent decrease in second-quarter earnings, a greater-than-expected decline.    Intel also said it did not expect an improvement in the third quarter. Its earnings have suffered from price cuts and a glut of personal computers. [Page D2.]

headline: AUTODESK SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE DISCREET LOGIC
abstract: Autodesk Inc will buy Discreet Logic Inc for about $520 million in stock (S)

headline: What Happened to Those Global Rate Cuts?
abstract: Analysis of recent statement by Pres Clinton that hinted at global interest rate cuts and testimony by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan before House Banking Committee that there is no coordinated effort among world's central banks to cut interest rates; questions whether world is relying on four leaders--in Japan, in Germany, in US and in Russia--who see unfolding world economic crisis in very different terms, and are each holding on to power by a thread (M)

headline: Bonn  Says Sudanese Faces U.S. Extradition
abstract: German officials prepare to extradite to US Mamdu Mahmud Salim, Sudanese suspect arrested in connection with bombing of American of US embassy in Nairobi, Kenya (S)

headline: AVX DISMISSES 700 EMPLOYEES AFTER EARNINGS DROP 50%
abstract: AVX Corp has dismissed about 700 employees in last three months as company profits fell 50 percent (S)

headline: Patents; An appeals court says a mathematical formula can be patented, if it is a moneymaker.
abstract: Patents column examines recent ruling by United States Court of Appeals, upholding patent held by Signature Financial Group for data-processing system for mutual fund partnership; ruling seems to bolster software patenting guidelines issued by Patent and Trademark Office three years ago, which expanded definition of what kinds of software are patentable; critics say court has gone too far in allowing what is in essence a mathematical formula to be patented; Papyrus Technology Corp patents system using handheld devices that allow brokers on floor of New York Stock Exchange to receive and execute orders electronically (M)

headline: Debt Offerings Expected During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the  regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.72 percent and on the six-month bill, 4.78 percent.

headline: Parliament In Russia Fails To Pass Bills Tied to Loans
abstract: Russian Government effort to line up preconditions for $17 billion in new loans falls short when Communist-dominated Parliament fails to adopt series of measures required by International Monetary Fund (M)

headline: Leader Exits, but It May Be Too Soon to Invest in Japan
abstract: Article on Japanese press reaction to political woe resulting from resignation of Japanese Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto; economists, fund managers and stock experts are still cautious about investing in Japan (M)

headline: A September Selloff? Yes, if History Is a Guide
abstract: Stock market has performed worse on average in September over last 50 years than in any other month; Wall Street Companion newsletter notes market performance is especially poor in those Septembers that follow poor-performing Augusts; drawing (M)

headline: Commuters Take Up Digital Arms to Battle Traffic Snarls
abstract: Federal Transportation Department conducts pilot projects in Seattle and other areas to test digital equipment to help computers avoid traffic snarls; devices include pagers and palmtop computers to access Internet traffic sites; Toni Wilbur, who runs programs, comments; photo (M)

headline: In West Africa, a Grisly Extension of Rebel Terror
abstract: Rebel movement in Sierra Leone is waging campaign of butchery and murder against civilians; survivors report that hundreds of men, women and children have been shot, disemboweled or mutilated by having limbs hacked off; some victims have been disfigured and sent away bearing letters warning Pres Ahmad Tejan Kabbah and African peacekeeping troops who restored him to office that armed resistance, led by remnants of former military junta, will continue; several hundred thousand people have fled their homes for Government-controlled areas or refugee camps outside Sierra Leone; hospitals in Sierra Leone are treating steady stream of mutilated victims; Kabbah, civilian and first democratically elected President, tells UN Secretary General Kofi Annan that Foday Sankoh, rebel leader, has been returned home from Nigeria for trial on charges of treason and crimes against humanity; photos; map (M)

headline: British Prudential's Pension Sales at Issue
abstract: Prudential Corp, Britain's largest insurer, is sharply criticized by members of Parliament for misleading people when selling pensions in 1980's (S)

headline: A Double-Edged Scalpel
abstract: Letter from Jeff Behm agreeing with July 9 article on high price of hi-fi equipment (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Post Modest Gains In Advance to New Records  Stocks drove farther into record territory, again bolstered by second-quarter earnings reports that were strong or better than expected. The gains, however, were modest: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.79 points, to 9,337.98; the Standard & Poor's 500 index advanced 2.70, to 1,186.69, while the Nasdaq composite climbed 8.20, to 2,008.76.    Still, yesterday was the third time this week that the Dow, S.& P. and Nasdaq set records on the same day; before this week, the last time the three measures reached highs together was on April 21. For the week, the Dow rose 2.6 percent; the S.& P. 500, 1.9 percent, and the Nasdaq, 3.4 percent. [Page D4.]

headline: Fast-Growing Market : Men Wake Up To Accessories
abstract: LONDON  Not so long ago, most men's idea of an accessory was a flashy tie or a clunky watch. Now men's accessories are one of the fastest-growing sectors in fashion, and the customer has become a more discerning species.

headline: Coke's Earnings Down; Pepsi Reports Early With a Gain
abstract: Coca-Cola Co reports decline in earnings for second quarter, while Pepsico says its earnings rose; Pepsi's earnings rose 19 percent, to $494 million on revenue of $5.26 billion, compared with earnings of $414 million on revenue of $5.09 billion a year earlier; Coca-Cola earned $1.19 billion on revenue of $5.15 billion, compared with earnings of $1.31 billion on revenue of $5.07 billion in second quarter of 1997; chart on Coca-Cola figures (M)

headline: Seagram in Polygram Deal
abstract: Commission of European Union grants regulatory approval for Seagram Co's proposed acquisition of Royal Philips Electronics NV's 75 percent stake in Polygram NV (S)

headline: LIBRARY/ASTRONOMY SOFTWARE; Real Sky CD: Rich Resource And Window on the Universe
abstract: REAL SKY CD (Astronomical Society of the Pacific; $250 for each of Northern or Southern sky, $450 for both; Windows 3.1, 95 and NT, and Macintosh.)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: DuPont May Be Seeking To Sell All of Conoco  DuPont, which in May announced plans to sell 20 percent of its Conoco oil subsidiary to the public, may be looking to sell the whole thing.    The company declined to comment on a report in a London newspaper that the French oil company Elf Acquitaine wants to buy Conoco for $24 billion, but analysts said a sale to Elf would make strategic sense for DuPont. The report comes less than a week after British Petroleum said it would buy Amoco for $48.2 billion, setting off speculation that more oil companies may merge.   [Page D2.]

headline: Clinton Enjoys Radio Stint: No Violence, Drugs or Sex
abstract: Pres Clinton appears on radio talk show in Shanghai, fielding questions from callers who are polite and not confrontational; photo (M)

headline: Myanmar Again Blocks Pro-Democracy Leader From Traveling
abstract: Myanmar authorities again stop pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi from traveling to countryside after she drives 15 miles west of capital in van well-stocked for another protest against military repression (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PSS WORLD MEDICAL INC., Jacksonville, Fla., a distributor of medical supplies, said its Diagnostic Imaging Inc. unit had agreed to acquire Gilbert X-Ray Co. of Texas Inc., Dallas, a closely held imaging-distribution concern. Terms were not disclosed.    GP STRATEGIES CORP., New York, a technical and management training company, agreed to sell some assets of its Five Star Group unit to American Drug Co., for about $17.5 million in cash and a $5 million unsecured note.

headline: Cambodian Power Struggle Heats Up Ominously
abstract: Thousands of people have filled Phnom Penh park for last 10 days to protest outcome of Cambodia's parliamentary election over month ago in which strongman Hun Sen was official winner; Hun Sen's two challengers, Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy, who are usually bitter rivals, have joined forces to lead protests; they say they will block formation of new government unless election irregularities are investigated; photo (M)

headline: FUND AMERICAN ACQUIRES REST OF FOLKSAMERICA HOLDING
abstract: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc acquires 50 percent of FolksAmerica Holding Co that it does not already own for $169.1 million in cash; Fund American buys stake from Folksam Mutual General Insurance Co of Sweden, Wiener Staeditsche Allegmeine Versicherung AG of Austria, P&V Assurances SC of Belgium and Samvirke Skadeforsikring AS of Norway (S)

headline: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS HOLDINGS TO BUY SPD TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings will buy SPD Technologies Inc for $230 million (S)

headline: A.C. NIELSEN BUYS BASES GROUP, A TEST-MARKETER
abstract: A C Nielsen Corp buys Bases Group for initial $65 million payment and possible future payments (S)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Are 0.8% Higher on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers reports open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in month ended Sept 15 to 2.15 billion shares, compared with 2.13 billion in previous month; charts (M)

headline: International Briefs; China's Investment In Fixed Assets Surges
abstract: China reports its fixed-asset investment rose 22.8 percent in July over July 1997; puts fixed-asset investment for Jan-July period at 736.2 billion yuan, up 15.6 percent from same 1997 period (S)

headline: Fed Approves Huge Bank Deal
abstract: The $57 billion acquisition of BankAmerica by Nationsbank won approval today from the Federal Reserve, clearing the way for them to join forces and become the largest United States banking company.    The banks agreed to sell 17 branches with $492 million in deposits in New Mexico, the only region where the two companies overlapped enough to concern regulators.

headline: Living With Windows 98
abstract: David A Karp letter agrees with June 25 article evaluating Windows 98

headline: Test Pushes Wall St.'s Computers Into 2000 Without Mishaps
abstract: Wall Street's 10-day-old project to test how its computers will cope with transition to new millennium moves forward to Jan 3, 2000, first trading day of next century, with no major glitches; John Panchery, Year 2000 project manager for Securities Industry Association, says test is going much better than anticipated (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen slips against US dollar as currency traders show their disappointment with lack of details in Japan's pledge to cut taxes; dollar trades at 139.27 yen, up from 138.75 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Europeans Act To Clear Way For Air Pacts, Conditionally
abstract: European regulators propose preliminary conditions that appear to clear way for approval of alliance between American Airlines and British Airways PLC that will dominate air traffic across Atlantic; European Commission angers UAL Corp's United Airlines, Lufthansa and Scandinavian Air System by proposing retroactive restrictions on their two-year-old alliance; moves sharpen tensions between European Commission and Clinton Administration as well as between commission and its own member states concerning international aviation competition at a time when increasing number of world's airlines have entered into cross-border alliances that have received exemptions from US antitrust laws (M)

headline: Many Think Kohl's Heir Would Run Better Race
abstract: Polls that show German Chancellor Helmut Kohl leads Christian Democrats to defeat in forthcoming election show his designated successor, Wolfgang Schauble, would be stronger candidate against Social Democratic leader Gerhard Schroder; Schauble seems uneasy with role but not prepared to challenge mentor, interview; has been paralyzed from waist down since he was shot by assailant in 1990 (M)

headline: Dow Plunges 93.46, and It Could Have Been Far Worse
abstract: Dow Jones indusrial average closes at 8,934.78, down 93.46 points; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 17.03 points, to 1,130.24, a 1.5 percent decline; Nasdaq composite index falls 36.73 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,896.53; Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index gains 170.18 points; graph; chart (M)

headline: Malaysian Police Break Up Protests on Arrest
abstract: Malaysian riot police officers, acting to quell biggest show of dissent faced by Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad in his 17 years in office, fire tear gas and water cannons to disperse thousands of people protesting arrest of former Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim; former deputy is being held under Internal Security Act, which allows indefinite imprisonment without charges or trial of people deemed threat to national security; photo (M)

headline: In Texas, a Laboratory Test on the Effects of Suing H.M.O.'s
abstract: Texas, where procedures are in place to appeal insurance decisions and sue HMOs, is test ground for proposed Federal legislation to protect patient rights; insurers have issued dire warnings of detimental effects on health care, but actual increase in premiums in Texas has been only 0.1 percent, compared with projected nationwide costs of 1.2 percent under Democratic proposal; Texas doctors do report that HMOs are showing more willingness to accept treatment decisions, and costs are not spiraling; several Texas cases reviewed: Leon Hand suffered stroke after managed-care doctor refused to admit him to hospital, and later settled with Humana; Dora Cisneros successfully appealed health plan's denial of pain-management therapy; phtoos (M)

headline: Operating Net Rises At Rhone-Poulenc
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc SA says second-quarter profit from operations rose 29 percent in second quarter; profit rose to 1.2 billion francs ($202 million) from 934 million francs a year ago; sales fell 5 percent, to 22.3 billion francs (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY     Frontier Ins Grp    Stewart Info Svcs    Synovus Finl

headline: U.S. Welcomes Kurdish Leader Who Betrayed C.I.A. in Iraq
abstract: Clinton Administration invites to Washington Massoud Barzani, Kurdish leader who betrayed Central Intelligence Agency's covert action program against Pres Saddam Hussein two years ago; he will attend high-level talks, a sign of pragmatism that now rules United States policy toward Iraq; another Iraqi Kurd planning to attend meeting is Jalal Talibani, leader of Patriotic Union of Kurdistan and Barzani's bitter rival for leadership of Iraqi Kurds; Clinton Administration hopes to unify Iraqi opposition, and to demonstrate to Hussein that he still cannot exercise control over northern Iraq; US officials say Barzani never formed permament alliance with Hussein, and they hope now to strengthen relations with Barzani to make sure he continues to stay out of Hussein's orbit; they say betrayal of CIA was temporary 'tactical move' on Barzani's part (M)

headline: This Elephant Can Remember All of Those Lost Web Pages
abstract: New downloadable program Elephant Tracks watches where a Web browser goes and allows users to retrace their footprints; program was written by Ed Staub (S)

headline: Dassault Reports Rise In Operating Earnings
abstract: Dassault Systems SA, world's number 2 maker of design software, says second-quarter operating earnings rose 59 percent; company earned 112 million French francs ($18.7 million) before charge to write off research costs at Productmanager, unit of IBM that it bought in April; earnings fell to 55.7 million francs from 70.5 milion francs in year-earlier period (S)

headline: New Acquisitions By SunAmerica
abstract: SunAmerica Inc to spend $430 million for several businesses of MBL Life Assurance Corp, successor to Mutual Benefit Life Insurance (S)

headline: It's Official: U.S. to Consider Dutch Trial in Lockerbie Case
abstract: Clinton Administration says that US and Britain will consider creation of special court in Netherlands to try Abdel Basset al-Mehgrahi and Lamin Khalifah Fhimah, Libyans suspected of planting bomb aboard jumbo jet that exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, in Dec 1988; announcement represents turnaround for Administration, which has said in past that Libyans would have to be tried in US or Britain (M)

headline: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft
abstract: New drug case raises friction between American and Mexican law enforcement officials; in case, two Mexican drug enforcement agents are in jail in Tijuana on kidnapping charges that appear to have been trumped up by corrupt police officers working with traffickers (M)

headline: BREED TECHNOLOGIES PLANS HIGHER WRITE-DOWNS
abstract: Breed Technologies Inc to report increased write-downs and higher operating income in its restated fiscal second-quarter earnings; company says write-down of good will will rise to $81.9 million from previously reported $77.6 million in quarter ended Dec 31, 1997 (S)

headline: G.M. Workers Expected A Much Better Vacation
abstract: Strikes idling most of General Motors Corp's hourly employees continue into what was supposed to have been paid companywide two-week shutdown, so only GM's salaried workers will be paid for vacation; GM says strikes will cost company $1.18 billion after taxes in second quarter; strikers comment on financial pinch (M)

headline: Thousands in Streets of Phnom Penh Cheer for Peace
abstract: Thousands of Cambodians surge through streets of Phnom Penh clapping, cheering and chanting over and over 'Hooray for peace,' in an extraordinary and largely spontaneous outpouring that takes city by surprise; for more than two hours no police officers or soldiers are seen; streets belong to the people; crowds seem unanimous in their sentiment that strongman, Hun Sen, must go, despite his Govt's declaration that he won election; photo (M)

headline: Patents; A proxy parent, in image and voice, stands ready to turn itself on in response to a baby's demands.
abstract: Donald Spector receives patent for sound-and-light box that attaches to baby's crib, with sound-activated switch that turns on soothing message from parent when baby cries; Gregory Fitzpatrick and Marvin Williams receive patent for electronic calendar that monitors other electronic calendars to detect when free dates are available for meetings; Hiroshi Ootsuka, employee of Minolta, receives patent for camera that picks up image of intended photo and displays it on monitor; Todd Housely receives patent for doorbell that triggers voice message instead of chime; Patent and Trademark Office will make patent and trademark data available free on its Web site before end of year (M)

headline: Hong Kong Stocks Lower Yet; Tokyo Is Up
abstract: Stocks continue to fall in Hong Kong early on Aug 7 after declining sharply on Aug 6; benchmark Hang Seng index hits three-and-a-half year low on Aug 6; in early trading on Aug 7, Hang Seng is down 121.16 points, or 1.67 percent at 7,133.20; Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 86.87 points, or little more than half of 1 percent, at 15,963.09 (S)
