headline: In Upbeat Farewell, Clinton Hails Jiang and Sees Democracy for China
abstract: Excerpts from news conference by Pres Clinton in Hong Kong at end of his nine-day trip to China; photo (M)

headline: GE CAPITAL BUYING CONSUMER LENDING UNIT IN JAPAN
abstract: General Electric Capital Co to buy consumer finance business of Japanese consumer lender Lake (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: EMC CORP., Hopkinton, Mass., the maker of corporate computer-storage systems, said John Egan, its executive vice president for products and offerings, would leave the company after 15 years to pursue other interests. Paul Noble Jr. was named to succeed Mr. Egan, who is the son of the company co-founder Richard Egan.    T. ROWE PRICE ASSOCIATES INC., Baltimore, said it had hired Alan D. Levenson as chief economist, replacing Paul Boltz, who retired in April after 15 years with the company.    TRUMP HOTELS AND CASINO RESORTS INC., Atlantic City, which has seen its stock price fall 67 percent over the last year, said its chief financial officer, Bruce McKee, had resigned.

headline: SPENDING IT; Medical Accounts: Mixed Reviews
abstract: Medical savings accounts, one-year old program under which individuals can save tax-free dollars for medical expenses, has mixed results; participants discuss pros and cons; photos (M)

headline: UNITED RENTALS TO BUY 2 MORE EQUIPMENT COMPANIES
abstract: United Rentals Inc, company formed to consolidate equipment-rental business, to acquire Rental Tools and Equipment Co and McClinch Equipment Services Inc (S)

headline: Many Sites To Confess One's Sins
abstract: Internet offers users variety of sites where they can confess their sins; paradoxical combination of anonymity and intimacy provides fertile ground for admissions; photo (M)

headline: FPA Medical Files for Protection Under Bankruptcy Laws
abstract: FPA Medical Management files for protection under Chapter 11 of bankruptcy laws; twenty-one banks, headed by BankBoston Corp, agree to inject up to $50 million to keep company afloat and make overdue payments to doctors, nurses and hospital emergency rooms (M)

headline: I.B.M. Opens the Doors of Its Research Labs to Surprising Results
abstract: IBM launches massive effort to expand commercialization of its research product; business criticism of IBM has been that its labs are too insular, with too little payoff for company; internal analysis at start of 1990's found only 2 to 5 percent of research division's work went toward products and services for IBM customers; new approach includes more collaborative work with leading universities, recruiting more outsiders, and gatherings of IBM researchers, summer interns and executives in day-long exercises in free-range futurism, unfettered discussions of where technology may be heading by year 2020; musings, debates and product ideas are all recorded, and research staff later pores through record, panning for nuggets; college interns' main reservation seems to be that even new IBM moves too slowly in getting its research to marketplace; photos (M)

headline: As Tension Rises in Cambodia, Troops Fire Into Crowds
abstract: Cambodia's post-election standoff erupts into turmoil and gunfire after Prime Min Hun Sen orders arrest of his opponents and after security agents fire into crowds of protesters in capital of Phnom Penh, killing at least one person; Sam Rainsy, organizer of protests and chief target of Hun Sen's threats, takes refuge at UN office in capital; has led increasingly assertive protest against result of July Parliamentary election, which he says was marred by irregularities; has threatened to block formation of new Government by denying Hun Sen chance to put together coalition of two-thirds of Parliamentary seats; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: YEN AT 6-WEEK LOW.  Traders sold yen for dollars on new evidence of strength in the United States economy and confidence that Japan will not defend its currency. The dollar rose to 144.65 yen from 143.66.

headline: Kosovo Strife Brings U.S. Warning to Serbs
abstract: Clinton Administration, faced with step-up in violence against civilians in Kosovo province and reports of new mass grave, warns Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic that his tactics are unacceptable and could prompt NATO air strikes (M)

headline: Unsolicited Junk E-Mail Now Officially Defined as Spam
abstract: Latest edition of New Oxford Dictionary of English's defines word spam as 'irrelevant Internet messages sent to a large number of people' (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: F.T.C. Surfs the Web and Gears Up to Demand Privacy Protection
abstract: Federal Trade Commission has all but decided it will part company with Clinton Administration over contention that business can regulate itself when it comes to Internet privacy; FTC survey last spring showed that more than 90 percent of roughly 4,000 Web sites examined by lawyers collected personal information from visitors, but only 14 percent of them disclosed how that information would be used, convincing FTC that formal regulation would probably be necessary; photo of FTC lawyer Dean Forbes search for Web site privacy abuses (M)

headline: Media Talk; Networks Find Old News Can Become New Hits
abstract: Hottest trend in television news programming is taking previously reported stories, adding updated material and perhaps new title, and putting them back on air; summer is ideal time to bring out repackaged news show, because of alarmingly low ratings that repeats of entertainment programs have been getting; photo (S)

headline: Rome Journal; Religion's in Vogue, and the Vatican Is Scandalized
abstract: Italian designers sprinkle religious symbols throughout fall-winter fashion shows in Rome, drawing protests from Vatican; Roman Catholic Church has always been irresistible theme for those seeking to make a spalsh, and offending it is one of surest ways of attracting attention in Italy; photos (M)

headline: New Delhi Journal; Trying to Wreck India's Romance With the Bomb
abstract: Article on Arundhati Roy, internationally acclaimed novelist from India who has criticized her nation for testing nuclear weapons; map; photo (M)

headline: Profit Increases 23% at Philips Electronics
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics NV says operating profit increased 23 percent in second quarter; profit rose to 854 million guilders, or $423 million, from 693 million guilders a year earlier; net income rose to 1.03 billion guilders from 747 million guilders (S)

headline: KPMG Peat Marwick is using a brand campaign to set itself apart from the accounting herd.
abstract: KPMG Peat Marwick LLP has created brand campaign intended to set firm apart in industry in which potential clients often view competing accounting firms as largely one and the same; campaign was created by Lowe & Partners/SMS; it represents initial phase of $60 million worldwide branding effort for KPMG, which operates in 155 countries (M)

headline: Russian Musicians Find Playing Doesn't Pay, at Least Not in Money
abstract: Article on impact of Russia's economic crisis on artists and musicians, who have never had it easy; members of The Seasons chamber orchestra earn as little as $2 to $3 per day, even though their concerts are always sold out; all ticket sales must go to pay rent for concert hall in Moscow; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Jones Average Plunges 299 Points, or 3.41%  Investors stampeded out of stocks, and the Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 300 points, or 3.41 percent. The tumble, paced by financial and technology stocks, came after months in which traders shrugged off bad economic news from Asia and a slowdown in corporate profits at home.    Still, while the Dow's point drop was the third largest in history, in percentage terms it did not even make the top 20. And because of the forceful bull move in stocks this year, many investors still have considerable profits year-to-date. The Dow has climbed 7.32 percent since January. [Page A1.]

headline: CBS to Sell 5 Boston-Area Radio Stations
abstract: CBS Corp agrees to sell five Boston-area radio stations to Entercom for $140 million to satisfy Government requirements related to CBS's purchase of American Radio Systems; CBS will also buy WYUU-FM and WLLD-FM in Tampa, Fla, from Entercom for $75 million; CBS is selling WEEI-AM, WRKO-AM, WWTM-AM, WAAF-FM and WEGQ-FM in Boston (S)

headline: AMBER REJECTS BID FROM ALBERTA AND EXPLORES OPTIONS
abstract: Amber Energy Inc rejects offer from Alberta Energy Co of $750 million (Canadian), or $499 million (US), and establishes board committee to seek alternatives (S)

headline: Chernomyrdin Tries to Calm Fears of Return to Soviet-Style Economic Policies
abstract: Russia's acting Prime Minister, Viktor S Chernomyrdin, says neither economic crisis nor political bargaining with Communist legislators foreshadows a return to Soviet-style fiscal policy; says he intends to take steps urged by Western economists to stem Russia's slide toward insolvency; promises to crack down on illegal export of dollars and other foreign currency and to keep the ruble convertible on Russian and world markets; Western leaders make clear thet Chernomyrdin will receive no further help unless he remains faithful to reforms (M)

headline: Stocks Tumble 1.3% As Asian Fears Grow
abstract: Stocks buckled as investors grew increasingly fearful over world financial developments: the yen plunged on news that Japan's economic slump was deepening, and markets elsewhere in Asia and in Russia also tumbled, leading to fears that the malaise abroad would drive down corporate earnings in the United States.

headline: Waste Management to Buy Trash Hauler
abstract: Waste Management Inc. said today that it would buy Eastern Environmental Services Inc. for about $1.3 billion in stock as Waste Management, the largest United States waste-disposal company, increases its business in a region from New York to Florida.    Waste Management, based in Houston, will pay 0.6406 share for each share of Eastern Environmental. The agreement values Eastern Environmental at about $33.75 a share, based on Waste Management's closing price on Friday.

headline: Nissan Sets More Halts In Truck Production
abstract: Nissan Diesel Motor Co, truck-making affiliate of Nissan Motor Co, says it might stop output for up to 12 days in October-December quarter because of plunging sales in Japan (S)

headline: Education Board of Texas Votes to Sell Disney Stock
abstract: Texas Education Board votes, 8-4, to sell $46.4 million of Walt Disney Co stock, holding films distributed by Disney's Miramax unit are offensive; board chairman Jack Christie says he backed move after seeing American Family Association video of extremely violent and sexually explicit scenes from Miramax films; says board does not endorse boycott of Disney; move opponents cite school fund's big gain on stock (M)

headline: Europe Gets A Bit Jumpy Over Russia
abstract: Concern grows in European capitals that monetary crisis in Russia could throttle economic growth in their own countries or weaken Russia's commitment to democracy; few see much chance of quick, decisive action during United States-Russian summit meeting planned for next week in Moscow, given weakened political positions of Russian Pres Yeltsin and American Pres Clinton, and with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany in fight of his life for re-election; publicly, European political leaders are telling Pres Yeltsin and his Prime Min-designate, Viktor S Chernomyrdin, that without radical changes in Russian financial and economic system, more Western help will not work; real concern of European leaders is not about economic stability but political stability in Russia, which is still nuclear power with army bigger than all European armed forces put together (M)

headline: UBS Posts 5% Gain in Operating Earnings
abstract: UBS AG posts 5 percent increase in operating earnings for first half; net income rose 22 percent; UBS aims to double earnings by 2002 as it slashes costs and dismisses about 13,000 people (S)

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; In Ethics, a Columnist as Case Study
abstract: Essay by Dawn-Marie Driscoll and W Michael Hoffman on ethics crisis involving Boston Globe columnist Mike Barnicle and how it can be used as business ethics teaching tool; photo (M)

headline: James Fletcher, 63, a Banker In Poor Chicago Areas, Dies
abstract: James Fletcher, chairman of South Shore Bank, a pioneering lender to some of poorer neighborhoods in Chicago, died on Sept 16 at age 63; photo (M)

headline: Cola War II: The Bottler Battle; On Pepsi Front Line, It's Getting Dangerous to Go Solo
abstract: Twelve years after Coca-Cola Co moved to centralized 'anchor bottling' model, Pepsico Inc is planning to spin off its company-owned bottling operations; new bottling company may then acquire small independent bottlers; many small bottlers are already consolidating: there were 180 independent Pepsi bottlers in 1987 while today there are 121; Pepsi is considering spinoff at a time when Coca-Cola is facing increased scrutiny over the way it has moved its expensive bottling factories to its own spinoff, Coca-Cola Enterprises; operations of family-owned Minges Bottling Group, Pepsi's bottler in Kinston, NC, for last three years, and competition from Coca-Cola Bottling Co Consolidated, which covers 12 states in the South, discussed; graph; photos (M)

headline: Motion Denied In Juice Dispute
abstract: Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc says that a judge has denied its request for preliminary injunction preventing Pepsico Inc from selling or distributing any single-serve Tropicana beverages; Ocean Spray cooperative sued Pepsico last week, claiming its distribution contract with world's No. 2 soda maker would be violated after Pepsi acquires rival juice company, Tropicana Products Inc (S)

headline: BBDO Worldwide Gets Three Big Accounts
abstract: Dell Computer, Nissan Corp and Allied Domecq award offices of BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $170 million (S)

headline: CBL & ASSOCIATES TO BUY TWO MALLS IN THE MIDWEST
abstract: CBL & Associates Properties Inc, one of largest owners of shopping centers in Southeast, agrees to buy two malls in the Midwest for $68 million in cash and partnership units valued at about $53 million, as well as assumption of $17.1 million in debt; seller is Samuels & Associates Inc; malls are Meridian Mall near Lansing, Mich, and Janesville Mall near Milwaukee, Wis (S)

headline: U.S. SEEKS MEANS TO BRING SUSPECT FROM AFGHANISTAN
abstract: US weighs strategies for negotiating with Taliban, Afghanistan's fundamentalist Islamic rulers, for capture of Osama bin Laden, wealthy Saudi who is prime suspect in August 7 bombings of American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania and who has been sheltered by Taliban since 1996; Wakil Ahmed Mutawakil, second highest-ranking member of Taliban's Supreme Council, says if US provides hard evidence of bin Laden's involvement in bombings, Taliban would be willing to meet with American officials to discuss what to do about him; contradictory comments from mullah who leads movement raise American worries that there is rift and that Taliban may ultimately be unwilling to deliver bin Laden; Taliban have nearly defeated their opposition and are desperate for international recognition and economic support; bin Laden photo (M)

headline: Pet Sites to Love
abstract: Mark A Finkelstein letter on Sept 10 article on Web sites for pet owners suggests site to teach children how to care for pets (S)

headline: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE IS IN $71 MILLION DEAL FOR GLOBALINK
abstract: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products NV will acquire Globalink Inc for about $71.1 million in stock (S)

headline: Media Talk; Electronic Shopping For the Good Life
abstract: Ivana Trump and Tel-Com Wireless Cable TV Corp will start combined video and Internet venture, 5th Avenue Channel, that will offer luxury goods to TV viewers and World Wide Web surfers; television service is expected to be available to as many as five million homes but Melvin Rosen, president of Tel-Com, says emphasis will be on Internet; photo (S)

headline: Juan Metzger, 79, Is Dead; He Put the Fruit in Yogurt
abstract: Juan E Metzger, man credited with turning yogurt into fruit-flavored staple, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: Can a Generation Learn to Share?
abstract: James Schembari's comment on whether baby boomer generation can be philanthropic; says until pressures of college and retirement are relieved, boomers probably will not increase their giving, but that will change someday because history shows most generous givers tend to be 65 to 74 years old; drawing (M)

headline: SBC and Ameritech, Awaiting a Merger, Beat Earnings Estimates
abstract: SBC Communications Inc says operating profit rose 20 percent in second quarter from year earlier; Ameritech reports increase of 11 percent in earnings; SBC reports net income of $966 million compared to loss of $787 million a year earlier; revenue increased 11 percent, to $6.59 billion from $5.92 billion; Ameritech had net income of $1.7 billion, up from $537 million a year ago; revenue rose 7.6 percent, to $4.29 billion from $3.99 billion (M)

headline: BankAmerica and 2 Other Big Banks Suffer Russia Losses
abstract: Three more big banks, BankAmerica, BankBoston and J P Morgan report trading losses in Russia; BankAmerica posts pretax trading loss of $220 million over last two months, mostly from Russia; BankBoston puts pretax trading losses at $30 million, only $10 million of which is related to Russia; J P Morgan puts Russia exposure at $160 million; table of big banks' foreign exposures (M)

headline: Deals to Move Global Positioning Technology Toward Everyday Use
abstract: Nokia of Finland plans $3 million investment in Sirf Technology Inc, Silicon Valley start-up that plans to make global positioning system chips inexpensive enough for use in cellular phones; Ericsson and Hitachi set partnerships with Sirf to develop global positioning systems for consumer products; GPS devices use satellite signals to pinpoint location anywhere on globe; photo (M)

headline: Thousands of Refugees Flee Serb Mountain Attack
abstract: Thousands of ethnic Albanian refugees, many of them children, are fleeing Serbian Government forces in Kosovo but finding almost no place to hide in broiling heat; map; photo (M)

headline: Snooping on Fish Causes Cry of Foul
abstract: Aqua-Vu video camera invented by Jeff Zernov gives the angler a detailed picture of a lake's water, bottom and inhabitants; camera, which is small enough to fit inside a coffee mug, sets off an renewed debate about the use of technology in pursuit of game fish; photo (M)

headline: Philips Electronics Sees a Drop in Profit
abstract: Shares of Royal Philips Electronics fall 17 percent after company warns that third-quarter profit will significantly decline and that full-year profit from operations will be about same as last year (S)

headline: KEANE TO BUY INFORMATION SERVICES COMPANY IN BRITAIN
abstract: Keane Inc to acquire Icom Systems Ltd, based in Birmingham, Eng, for about $50 million in stock (S)

headline: Looking for Love In the Fed Funds Rate
abstract: World markets hunted last week for reasons to believe Federal Open Market Committte would cut interest rates; Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan hinted at rate cut (S)

headline: Seeking Unity in Jewish Giving
abstract: Article on tentative merger agreement reached between United Jewish Appeal and Council of Jewish Federations; terms of deal would shift power over spending abroad to grass roots and give local donors more control over how monies sent to Israel are spent (M)

headline: New I.R.S. Law: A Guide to Shifting Burdens
abstract: Provisions in new tax law governing taxpayer disputes with Internal Revenue Service described; law shifts burden of proof from taxpayers to IRS and requires judicial review before home can be seized to pay back taxes; chart (M)

headline: BELL CANADA INTERNATIONAL AND A.I.G. IN KOREAN DEAL
abstract: Bell Canada International Inc. and the American International Group Inc., the big New York-based insurer, teamed up yesterday to buy 39.4 percent of the Hansol PCS Company of South Korea, one of the Asian nation's three cellular phone companies, for $265 million. The Montreal-based Bell Canada, which is 75 percent owned by the Canadian telecommunications giant BCE Inc., will pay $159 million for a 23.6 percent stake, while A.I.G. will acquire 15.8 percent for $106 million through investment funds. Hansol PCS is controlled by a group led by the Hansol Paper Company.

headline: Novel TV Deal Could Rein In Program Costs
abstract: Ed Zwick and Marshall Herskovitz and their company, Bedford Falls, will create three television series for ABC, to be produced through studio owned by Walt Disney Co, ABC's parent, and one for Fox, to be produced through studio owned by Fox's parent; deal, possible first step in radically changed approach to controlling escalating program costs, will give broadcast networks' parents partial ownership of shows; Zwick and Herskovitz will get over 50 percent of syndicated rerun profits, instead of customary large upfront fees; photos (M)

headline: Regina Journal; A Place in History for a Traitor . . . or Maybe a Hero
abstract: Execution of Louis Riel remains source of bitterness among many Canadians 113 years after he was hanged for leading deadly rebellion of Metis, settlers of mixed Indian and European descent who were in way of Canada's westward expansion; many Canadians regard him as traitor, but others see him as bona fide but misunderstood martyr who stood up for his rights; to Metis, who have never been recognized by Canada as separete people, he is rallying point for dim dream of nationhood; Canadian Government has issued apology to Indians for abuse they suffered through several hundred years of paternalistic treatment and promises to reassess Riel's conviction and execution; Government statistics indicate there are approximately 152,000 Metis, who make up 19 percent of Canada's Indian population; map; photos (M)

headline: Students at B-Schools Flock to the E-Courses
abstract: Scores of graduate business schools in United States have over last five years built programs and majors in entrepreneurship studies, an arresting mix of plainly pragmatic and the utterly ephemeral; master's program at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management discussed; photo (L) (Special section on entrepreneurship in America) (L)

headline: Nigerian Pleads for Calm, Vowing Democracy and Autopsy for Foe
abstract: Nigeria's military ruler, Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar, tries to calm angry nation following sudden death of imprisoned opposition leader, Moshood K O Abiola; Abubakar agrees to allow outside experts to take part in autopsy, and makes vague promises about moving toward democracy; his gesture appears unlikely to have any immediate impact because power lies with military men on Provisional Ruling Council; country seems poised on knife-edge; riots that followed Abiola's death underscore explosive resonance of his name; situation is expected to remain highly volatile at least until results of autopsy are known; photos (M)

headline: Treasuries End the Day Unchanged
abstract: US Treasury bond prices are unchanged; price of 30-year bond is unchanged at 99 7/32 and its yield is unchanged at 5.55 percent; chart on US key interest rates (S)

headline: Europe Says Yes to Arms Industry Mergers
abstract: European military companies, unlike US counterparts, remain highly fragmented, with hundreds of small competitors struggling to pay for expensive research and development, even as national defense budgets shrink; French decision to privatize its aerospace giant, Aerospatiale, suggests process of sorting out European aviation and military industries is just beginning; envisioned now is enormous conglomerate, tentatively named European Aerospace and Defense Company, with divisions such as Airbus Industrie; obstacles are large: British Aerospace is efficient and profitable, while Aerospatiale has history of Government largess and bureaucratic management; mergers would also cost jobs, and Europe's unemployment rate is roughly double that in US (M)

headline: Annan Says Nigeria Plans to Free A Candidate and Other Prisoners
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan says that Nigeria's new military Government pledges to release all remaining political prisoners, among them Moshood K O Abiola, who was jailed after apparently winning 1993 presidential election; announcement follows meeting with country's President, Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar; chronology of major events in Nigeria since 1993; photo of Abiola (L)

headline: Destroyed German Synagogues Return to Life on a Web Page
abstract: Prof Marc Grellert of Darmstadt Technical University in Germany started project in 1996 that is bringing back to virtual life German synagogues destroyed during Nazi era; project's recreated synagogues are prominently displayed on Web site of university's architecture department; visitors can view three-dimensional images of synagogues and read about architectural and cultural history of each; photos (M)

headline: A New Small Book Publisher, In More Ways Than One
abstract: Peanut Press, fledgling publisher, is signing up partnerships with mainstream publishers to sell their books for downloading on Palm Pilot palmtop organizer; photo (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.69   5.46   5.77        3-month T-bills   4.74   4.72   4.91        6-month T-bills   4.75   4.69   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.66   3.64   3.60        10-yr. T-note   4.85   4.84   6.27        30-yr. T-bond   5.22   5.23   6.57        Telephone bd.   7.10   7.08   7.65        Municipal bds.   5.14   5.13   5.48          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Media Talk; Gannett to Merge Papers In Suburban New York
abstract: Gannett Suburban Newspapers will merge its 11 newspapers in Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties, NY, into one newspaper, Journal News, with five separate editions; papers already share president and publisher, Gary F Sherlock, and editor, Robert W Ritter (S)

headline: Jett, Ex-Kidder Trader, Says He Is Innocent
abstract: Joseph Jett, former star bond trader at Kidder, Peabody & Co who was accused of manufacturing huge phantom trading profits, angrily proclaims his innocence and strongly suggests that racism had added to his troubles; administrative law judge, Carol Fox Foelak, found him guilty of false record-keeping in civil case brought by Securities and Exchange Commission; Jett, who is black, says that securities cases similar to his had resulted in much lesser penalties; photo (M)

headline: McDonald's Japan Drive
abstract: McDonald's Corp to sell hamburgers in Japan for half usual price for 11 days this summer to try to improve sales in country by 20 percent; price of 65 yen (47 US cents) is lowest ever for McDonald's hamburger in Japan (S)

headline: USWeb to Buy CKS Group
abstract: USWeb Corp agrees to acquire CKS Group Inc for stock worth $21.66 a share, or $344.4 million, and will combine two under name Reinvent Communications Inc (S)

headline: A Man of Outsized Acts and Spending
abstract: Profile of Garth H Drabinsky, who has been ousted as chief creative director of Livent Inc, theater company he helped found (M)

headline: Bumps in the Road With Netcasts
abstract: Intel Corp plans to broadcast live performances of 300 bands on line and call adventure 'music festival'; home users with best chance of enjoying peformances are those with newer equipment; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Says Suspect Does Not Admit Role in Bombings or Ties to Saudi
abstract: Law enforcement officials said today that a key suspect in the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi had been interviewed at length by American investigators, but had not admitted any role and had not implicated Osama bin Laden, the shadowy Saudi-born extremist thought to have inspired the bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.    Nevertheless, the officials said they believed that the suspect, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh -- initially identified as Mohammed Sadik Howaida -- was an important figure in the Nairobi bombing plot and had knowledge of most of the details.

headline: 'Bunny' Breeds Rapidly, Sinking Belarus Economy
abstract: Belarus's ruble has lost half its worth in five months, and more than 10 percent in last week alone; Government has announced new plan to shore up ruble's value; it will no longer accept its own currency as payment for exports; that will keep outsiders from pumping more rubles into economy already flooded with so many that currency is essentially worthless; outside experts say it will not solve real problem: Belarus Government insists on printing more rubles whenever it runs short of cash; photo (M)

headline: DOW OFF 6% IN WAVE OF SELLING, ERASING MARKET'S GAINS FOR '98; PRESSURE FOR RATE CUT LIKELY
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 512.61 points, to 7,539.07, in sharp selloff that erases stock market gains for year and sends prices down more than 19 percent from peak set six weeks ago; volume is 914.7 million shares in third-busiest day on Big Board; frenzied selling dashes hopes of investors who expected market's recent slump to be stayed by fundamental strength of US economy; decline is second largest in Dow's history in point terms, trailing only 554-point drop in October 1997; Standard & Poor's 500 index falls more than 69 points, to 957.28, and Nasdaq Composite Index 140 points, to 1,499.25; selloff in stocks accompanies big rally in bond market, where investors sought shelter in securities; yield on benchmark 30-year Treasury bond falls to record low of 5.25%; economists and financial analysts say market rout is almost certain to put intense pressure on Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates; Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin says, despite selloff, US economy remains sound; graph; photo (M)

headline: Lower Dollar and Steadier Stocks Hurt Treasuries
abstract: US Treasury securities turn slightly lower, as dollar falls against Japanese yen before steadying, making dollar-denominated investments like Government securities less attractive to foreign investors; also putting pressure on bonds is Treasury's $11 billion auction of new 10-year notes, which followed disappointing auction of five-year notes on Aug 11; 30-year bond is down 2/32, to price of 107 15/32, while yield is unchanged at 5.60 percent; graph on average yield for Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp participation certificates; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: On heels of soccer's World Cup and baseball's All-Star Game, a big pitch begins for the N.F.L.
abstract: Annual advertising offensive to stimulate interest in National Football League games will begin almost two months earlier than usual and involve almost four times as many promotional commercials as before; fast start and increased exposure for NFL's sales pitch are result of league's most lucrative contracts ever with broadcast and cable television networks, covering 1998-99 season; ABC, CBS, ESPN and Fox will run more than 2,200 NFL spots (M)

headline: Official at S.E.C. Is Joining Law Firm
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission acting general counsel Colleen P Mahoney plans to join Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom law firm as partner; chairman Arthur Levitt Jr lauds her (S)

headline: Provident hopes using a different name for disability insurance will increase its sales.
abstract: Advertising column describes new campaign for Provident Companies, provider of individual disability insurance; campaign, devised by Saatchi & Saatchi, hopes to bolster image of Provident by describing its primary product as income protection plans; billings estimated at $10 million for first year (M)

headline: B Sky B Profit Slid 24% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: British Sky Broadcasting Group PLC says fourth-quarter profit fell 24 percent from year-earlier period; says net income fell to 64.2 million pounds ($105 million) from 84.5 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: A Flexing Of Muscle In American Steel
abstract: American Iron and Steel Institute reports 1997 US production of 107.5 million tons of raw steel, 22.3 percent rise over 1991; scrap steel segment of industry is gaining market share; graphs (M)

headline: It Hasn't Been This Good Since Jimmy Carter's Day
abstract: Manpower Inc says hiring in final quarter of 1998 will be highest for any fourth quarter since 1977; Manpower says 29 percent of companies will add to their work forces, 60 percent will remain at present levels, 7 percent plan to cut back and remaining 4 percent do not know their plans (S)

headline: Will It Be A Rebound Or Relapse?
abstract: Financial strategists measure length of downturn in US stock markets; Ron Reuss, chief economist at Piper Jaffray, Charles W Johnson, head of equity trading at Blaylock & Partners, and Thomas Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, comment (M)

headline: GEMSTAR REJECTS UNITED VIDEO TAKEOVER OFFER
abstract: Gemstar International Group Ltd rejects $45-a-share cash takeover bid by United Video Satellite Group Ltd, saying it is inadequate; General Electric Co's NBC network unit and Gemstar agree to develop interactive television program guide services; NBC will acquire 5 percent stake in TDN, joint venture of Gemstar and Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc (S)

headline: Finding the New Digital TV Shows
abstract: How to locate new digital television channels remains an unresolved issue; industry group has proposed that if network divides its HDTV bandwidth into four digital program streams, each should be considered part of main number and be given subnumber; has proposed way for network affiliates to retain cachet of positions they now hold on analog dial; diagram (M)

headline: NBC Backing an On-Line TV Service
abstract: NBC will invest in and supply programming to Intertainer Inc, startup on-line service to provide movies, television programs and music on demand to personal computers; agreement will allow viewers who miss television program to see it next day, at time of their choosing; NBC risks angering its affiliated local stations, which have interest in certain level of exclusivity (M)

headline: Thistle's Stock Plunges As Talk of Sale Ends
abstract: Shares in Thistle Hotels P.L.C., Britain's third-largest hotel operator, fell yesterday by more than 23 percent after Brierley Investments Ltd. of New Zealand, its partial owner, said talks to sell the company had broken off. Brierley said that the Thistle board had been in discussions with an unnamed buyer but that the talks had ended after the buyer put forth an unacceptable proposal.

headline: Still a Puny Military Force By the World's Standards
abstract: Chinese Government, in rare public description of outlook for China's military, admits that country's military forces are still rudimentary by international standards (S)

headline: New Venture For Ralph Nader
abstract: Ralph Nader has new project named Commercial Alert, meant to serve as outlet and clearinghouse for consumer complaints about increasing commercialism of American society; Gary Ruskin will be director; Commercial Alert is most recent in growing number of advocacy efforts intended to monitor Madison Avenue (S)

headline: DUPONT TO BUY SPANDEX BUSINESS IN SOUTH KOREA
abstract: DuPont Co to buy Tongkook Synthetic Fiber Co's spandex-fiber business in deal valued at $200 million (S)

headline: Chinese Book on Political Reform Stirs Hopes for More Debate
abstract: Publication of book on political reform is stirring excitement among Beijing's liberal intellectuals, who hope that it will encourage more open debate about the rule of law, freedom of information and role of Communist Party; book, Political China: Facing the Era of Choosing a New Structure, brings together 39 recently published essays by 32 scholars, journalists and former Government officials who were dismissed for their democratic sympathies (M)

headline: With the Pound Up, Exports Suffer
abstract: Layoffs that Rover Group PLC, money-losing British auto maker, blamed on impact of strong pound on export sales have touched off wider debate over monetary policy and other issues; debate raises question about Britain's decision to shift control of interest rates to Bank of England, which has raised rates to highest level in over five years; higher rates are key force driving pound higher; graphs comparing value of pound and German mark; table (M)

headline: Patents; Transparent shoes add colorful options for an unusual part of the wardrobe.
abstract: Steve Sileo receives patent for transparent laced shoes; Tae Woo Yoo gets patent for stimulator with acupressure spokes to be worn on underside of wristwatch, to alleviate nausea; Mark Steele patents mirrored hat that lets wearer see what is behind him or her; Timothy Dicker receives patent for exercise pants lined with restrictive rubber bands intended to work major leg muscles; Bob Caniglia gets patent for shirt with two methods of controlling flyaway ties; Alberta Moore gets patent for ankle ornament that loops around second toe (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Treasury Bond Yields Fall As Investors Flee Stocks  Turmoil in overseas economies sent investors fleeing stocks for the safety of bonds, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 5.51 percent, another new low. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 81.87 points, to 8,611.41.     Rumors that Russian bank failures were imminent and that Venezuela might be forced to devalue its currency, the bolivar, to combat a growing budget deficit, and persistent concerns about a similar move by China, buoyed the Treasury market. All of these things added to investor concerns that the financial crises among emerging markets may be spreading. [Page D5.]

headline: NatWest Profit Gains On Banking Business
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC says its first-half profit rose better-than-expected 46 percent; profit rose to 715 million pounds ($1.16 billion) from 489 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Tennessee Retailer to Buy Saks for $2.1 Billion  Saks Holdings, the parent of Saks Fifth Avenue, will be acquired by Proffitts, a Tennessee-based retail company with several department store divisions in the South and Midwest, for $2.1 billion in stock.    Proffitts has been on a buying spree. It acquired Carson Pirie Scott, a regional chain, in October for about $790 million in stock, creating the fourth-largest department store company in the nation. Its 237 stores in 24 states have names that include McRae's, Bergner's and Herberger's. [Page A1.]

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.50   5.47        3-month T-bills   5.00   4.98   5.05        6-month T-bills   5.01   5.02   5.09        10-yr. headline: Plug-Ins Offer A Richer Slice Of the Internet
abstract: Q. When I try to look at a video clip with my Web browser, I get a message saying I need a particular plug-in. What is this, and what should I do?  A. Plug-ins are small programs that you can download and install on your computer. They work within your browser, helping it handle certain types of audio, video and document files you might find on the Web.

headline: DIARY
abstract: DRUGS  Medicine for the Market    While the broad market slid, drug companies' shares climbed after the F.D.A. recommended approval of taxmoxifen as a means to reduce the risk of breast cancer. Zeneca Group P.L.C., which makes the drug, and Barr Laboratories, which sells its generic form, rose sharply. But Zeneca A.D.R.'s ended the week down $1.25 at $37.0625. Barr shares faired better, gaining $4.9375, to close at $33.3125. Barr also benefited from F.D.A. approval of its ''morning-after'' Preven Emergency Contraceptive Kit. Genentech rose, but fell back, ending the week off 25 cents at $68.75 after the F.D.A. approved its Herceptin biological drug to treat metastatic breast cancer.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.75   5.45   5.64        3-month T-bills   4.99   5.00   5.04        6-month T-bills   5.00   5.01   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.77   3.77   3.65        10-yr. T-note   5.47   5.48   6.18        30-yr. T-bond   5.70   5.71   6.47        Telephone bd.   7.14   7.16   7.55        Municipal bds.   5.25   5.25   5.49          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge   Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Tokyo Prosecutors Raid NEC Offices
abstract: Tokyo prosecutors raid NEC Corp on suspicion NEC authorized deal that would give its Toyo Communications Equipment Co unit a break on its overcharging on military contracts in return for giving lucrative jobs to two defense agency bureaucrats (S)

headline: NORTH KOREA SITE AN A-BOMB PLANT, U.S. AGENCIES SAY
abstract: US intelligence agencies detect huge secret underground complex in North Korea they believe is centerpiece of effort to revive country's frozen nuclear weapons program; spy satellites have photographed huge work site 25 miles northeast of Yongbyon, nuclear center where, until 1994 agreement with West, North may have produced enough plutonium to create six or more bombs; disclosure alarms White House and Pentagon; both fear North Korea may be trying to break out of four-year-old accord to give up nuclear weapons program in exchange for billions of dollars in Western aid; Clinton Administration has warned important members of Congress and South Korean Government in classified briefings; disclosure follows recent string of provocations by North, such as accusation that US has reneged on agreement because Congress has failed to authorize tens of millions of dollars in fuel shipments--main American contribution to $6 billion program under which South Korea, Japan and other nations would finance major electric energy program as quid pro quo for North's abandonment of ambitions to develop nuclear arms; Clinton Administration says North has not yet technically violated pact, since there is no evidence that Pyongyang has begun pouring cement for new reactor or reprocessing plant that would convert nuclear waste into bomg-grade plutonium; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS: DIARY
abstract: Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the same as in July. . . . Fewer foreign cars and cheaper oil meant that the nation's imports fell in July. But exports fell faster, reflecting soft demand in troubled Asian countries. So the trade deficit widened to $13.92 billion. . . . Sluggish sales in Asia hammered Nike, whose profits fell 35 percent in the latest quarter. . . . Three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland, including the chairman's son, were found guilty of conspiring to fix prices of lysine, the animal feed additive.

headline: Spelling Agrees to Sell Westwood Studios
abstract: Spelling Entertainment Group Inc. has signed a definitive agreement to sell all of the stock of Westwood Studios, a unit of Virgin Interactive Entertainment Ltd., and other development assets to Electronic Arts Inc. for $122.5 million.    Virgin Interactive is 91 percent owned by Spelling. Viacom Inc. owns 80 percent of Spelling's common shares.

headline: Politicians Woo Voters On the Web
abstract: Most candidates for high public office in November are campaigning on the Internet; some political consultants predict that Internet will become significant force in future elections, but others say Internet cannot approach television's impact because it is not universally available and because on-line information reaches only highly interested voters; one tactic favored by candidates is the electronic newsletter; one less welcome aspect of Internet is the way it can be used for pranks and smears; photos (M)

headline: De Beers Profits Fall After Cut in Sales
abstract: DeBeers Consolidated Mines Ltd and DeBeers Centenary AG say their combined earnings fell by 33 percent in first half of 1998 because of decision to cut back on diamond sales to support prices; combined first-half net income fell to $405 million, from $606 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Western Officials Say Accord On Kosovo Seems Uncertain
abstract: Special envoy Richard C Holbrooke and French Foreign Min Hubert Vedrine vow to keep pushing for diplomatic solution to head off a wider war in Kosovo, but agree that chances for success in the violence-torn Serbian province are uncertain (M)

headline: LIBERTY MUTUAL IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE FLORIDA INSURER
abstract: Liberty Mutual Group to buy Summit Holding Southeast Inc for $222.4 million, including assumption of $14.3 million of debt (S)

headline: Ericsson in Move To Buy Out Subsidiary
abstract: Ericsson A.B., the world's No. 3 mobile phone maker, said yesterday that it had offered to buy out the remainder of its Brazilian unit for $640 million in a bid to beef up its presence in its fifth-biggest market. Ericsson offered 37.11 reais per 1,000 Ericsson Telecomunicacoes S.A. preferred shares, representing a 55 percent premium over Friday's close. Phone equipment makers are set to cash in from last month's $19.5 billion sale of Brazil's phone infrastructure because companies will spend $52 billion in the next seven years to build and expand networks. Ericsson, which is focusing more on Latin America than its Finnish rival Nokia Oyj, has won more than $600 million in Brazilian network orders this year.

headline: A Theater Boom Is Born In Russian Film Industry
abstract: Success of Kodak Kinomir (Kodak Cinema World), Moscow, owned by Raymond Markovich and Paul Heth, has inspired other investors to look beyond Russia's economic instability and seek cut of action; Markovich and Heth plan to open up to 15 multiplexes, with 100 screens in all, over next five years, in investment projected at $110 million; they are part owners of film distribution company with exclusive rights to Walt Disney and Columbia Tri-Star pictures in Russia; Gorky Film Studios is promoting $94 million project to develop 100 modern movie theaters across Russia; Sergei Lisovsky has refitted vast 2,500-seat theater and is planning to put up 100 screens for about $120 million down the street from Kinomir; photo (M)

headline: TRIARC EXPECTS TO REPORT 3D-QUARTER INCOME DROP
abstract: Triarc Companies expects to report lower third-quarter earnings (S)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD ASKS 2,400 MANAGERS TO TAKE PAY CUT
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co is asking 2,400 mid- to upper-level managers worldwide to take 5 percent cut in pay for three months as company tries to cut costs; also says it plans to close offices worldwide for four days in late December (S)

headline: Putting Less-Than-Super Computers on Pi's Trail
abstract: Colin Percival, Canadian college student, has figured out pi--ratio of circle's circumference to its diameter--to five-trillionth binary digit, without help of supercomputer; he beat old record of one trillion digits with help of 25 people he found through Internet who donated use of their computers to complete calculations; photo (S)

headline: Malaysia Jails Opposition Legislator for Criticizing the Judiciary
abstract: Lim Guan Eng, opposition member of Malaysian Parliament, is imprisoned on charge of sedition for criticizing judiciary, raising questions about limits of free speech there; Lim has questioned Government's decision not to press statuatory rape charges against Abdul Rahim Tamby Chik, former chief minister from Lim's home state of Malacca, while detaining 15-year-old girl involved for three years in 'protective custody' (M)

headline: Defiant France Will Let Bird Hunters Blast Away
abstract: Frency Pres Jacques Chirac signs ynto law measure defying Europe-wide regulation banning the hunting of migratory birds during the nesting period; action could lead European Court of Justice to impose fine against France of about $114,000 for every day it violates ban (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    The National Association of Realtors reports on home resales for June. An annual rate of 4.84 million is expected, up 20,000 from May.  The Agriculture Department reports on 1998 crop conditions for wheat, corn, soybeans and cotton.

headline: Despite Late Rally, Dow Ends a Bad Week 5.1% Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 41.97 points, to 7,640.25; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 8.37 points, to 973.89; Nasdaq composite index drops 5.34 points, to 1,566.52; graphs; tables of hot and cold stocks and of favorite stocks (M)

headline: E. G. Lowry Jr., 95, Insurance Executive
abstract: Edward George Lowry Jr, former chmn and pres of General Reinsurance Corp, dies Aug 11 at 95 (S)

headline: Banks' Obligations
abstract: Warren W Traiger letter responds to July 5 article on mergers amng brokerage services, insurers, mutual funds and banks (S)

headline: Report Faults 'Soft Dollars' Use by Brokers
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission report shows that more than a quarter of brokerage and investment advisory firms make questionable use of 'soft dollars' that are supposed to pay for research that will help investment managers put together portfolios for clients; holds personal use by advisers of $1 billion of 'soft dollars results in bloated commissions for investors--which, in turn, lower investment returns; SEC's Office of Compliance, Inspections and Examinations director Lori A Richards says about 20 firms, or 7 percent of investment advisers surveyed, engage in 'egregious fraud' by siphoning off soft-dollar money for undisclosed use; under quirks of securities laws, trading soft dollars for questionable goods or services is generally not illegal as long as there is full disclosure to investment clients; Repr John D Dingell, ranking minority member of House Commerce Committee, calls for stricter guidelines (M)

headline: Bertelsmann to Merge Two Operations
abstract: Bertelsmann AG will merge its North American and international music and video operations; names Strauss Zelnick president and chief executive of merged operations; Zelnick will report directly to Michael Dornemann, Bertelsmann board member, who is also chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann Entertainment (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stepping out a bit from Coke's shadow, a big bottler is basking in its own spotlight these days.
abstract: Market Place column on Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc, largest bottler in Coca-Cola Co system; says Coca-Cola Enterprises, which accounts for 65 percent of Coke's domestic sales volume, will meet its goal of 10 percent growth in 1998 (M)

headline: Snapshot of Gerhard Schroder in Hot Pursuit of Voters
abstract: Gerhard Schroeder, who is campaigning to be Germany's next Chancellor, is seeking to project himself as emblem of new generation; travels with police security detail and speaks with expansive gestures geared to television cameras that incumbent, Helmut Kohl, reviles; gestures seem designed to project energy and form contrast with appearance of fatigue that sometimes hangs over Kohl, who at age 68, is 14 years Schroeder's senior (M)

headline: New York Utility To Sell 6 Plants
abstract: AES Corp, largest US-based power-plant developer, will buy six power plants in New York from New York State Electric & Gas Corp for $950 million, to expand Northeast electricity market; New York State Electric & Gas is selling its interest in another plant to Edison International; Edison International agrees to pay New York State Electric and Gas and GPU Inc $1.8 billion for coal-fired plant in Homer City, Pa (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Tries Again to Get Iraq to Allow Arms Searches
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan summons Prakash Shah, special envoy in Baghdad, for talks in Lisbon where he is on official visit, and sends him back to Iraq with message asking Pres Saddam Hussein to end refusal to cooperate with UN arms inspectors; is seeking to prevent new crisis over UN weapons inspections in Iraq from getting out of control; active weapons inspections were suspended on August 5, when Iraq announced that it would no longer cooperate with inspectors; only maintenance of surveillance equipment installed at Iraqi sites is being permitted (M)

headline: 'Manhattan Of Asia' Indifferent To Clinton
abstract: Pres Clinton winds up his visit to China with one-day stop in Hong Kong; receives tepid response to speech advocating speedier introduction of democracy under Chinese rule; photo (M)

headline: Stryker to Buy Orthopedics Unit From Pfizer for $1.9 Billion
abstract: Stryker Corp to buy Pfizer Inc's Howmedica orthopedics unit for $1.9 billion (M)

headline: Korea Sets Criteria For Kia Motors Bidders
abstract: South Korea says only Korean auto makers and world's top 20 auto manufacturers will be allowed to bid for insolvent Kia Motors Corp and its affiliate, Asia Motors Co; decision could enable Samsung Motors Inc to turn itself into major force in world's fifth-largest car industry by buying Kia (S)

headline: On-Line Ad Spending Seen Rising Tenfold
abstract: Report released by Forrester Research Inc says on-line advertising spending will reach more than $15 billion worldwide in 2003 from $1.5 billion in 1998 (S)

headline: Pet Sites to Love
abstract: Steven P Smith letter says Sept 10 article on Web sites for pet owners neglected to mention sites for pet adoption (S)

headline: CAREMATRIX IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR SENIORCARE GROUP
abstract: Carematrix Corp will buy Seniorcare Group Ltd for $100 million in cash and assumption of $50 million of debt (S)

headline: Serbian Cannon Fire Kills 3 Mother Teresa Aid Workers
abstract: Three ethnic Albanians working for Mother Teresa relief organization are killed by cannon fire from police vehicle in village of Vlaski Drenovac, Serbia; attack appears to be Yugoslav Government's most serious effort yet to terrorize aid workers; photo (M)

headline: Web Shopping Tangles
abstract: Letter from Rayner Colton on July 30 article on Internet shopping (S)

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF; On TV, a Backdrop Is Worth a Thousand Words
abstract: Article by Center for Study of American Business executive in residence Richard J Mahoney recalls his interview on network news program and importance of backdrops; drawing (M)

headline: TRANSMONTAIGNE PLANS TO ACQUIRE LOUIS DREYFUS ENERGY
abstract: Transmontaigne Inc to buy part of Louis Dreyfus Corp's energy division for about $161 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Mountains of Bad Debt Stifle Russian Economy
abstract: Russia's financial crisis is playing itself out on wider landscape of Russian economy; looming largest of all is mountain of unpaid bills that have accumulated as companies, private and government, run out of money to pay each other, their workers or their taxes; there is even thriving trade in debts; as Government moves to tighten monetary policy further, even less money is available, particularly for companies that offer services that many customers consider low priority; Russia's small-business sector is particularly exposed, lacking both access to credit and protection of well-developed system for bankruptcy and other restructuring; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodity prices are at their lowest since 1986, as concerns grow that currency weakness worldwide will reduce demand; graphs (S)

headline: As the Streets Clog Up, Cars Hit the Sidewalks
abstract: Moscow Journal: Moscow's traffic problems are not just awful, but boisterously, exuberantly so; Muscovites, many of them with no or little driving experience, have been free to buy anything they can afford for last eight years; never have so many cars driven by so many novices descended so quickly on such an unprepared metropolis; traffic signals are relatively infrequent, and they tend to change according to their own unwritten rules; many stoplights are not yet synchronized to speed flow of cars; this has brought out the cowboy in many motorists; there are 20 serious accidents on Moscow streets each day, and roughly 7,500 injuries and 800 deaths a year; photo; map (M)

headline: The Market Turmoil
abstract: STEADY AT FED --  While the slump has raised hopes that the Federal Reserve may lower interest rates, many economists are skeptical. Page C1.

headline: Return to Profitability Bolsters Club Med Stock
abstract: Shares of Club Mediterranee SA jump after company returns to profit after two consecutive annual losses; Club Med reports profit of 132 million francs ($22 million) in first half ended April 30, from loss of 413 million francs a year earlier (S)

headline: F.B.I. Chief Cites C.I.A. Help In African Bombing Inquiry
abstract: FBI Dir Louis J Freeh says much of progress made in investigation of bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania is result of unusual cooperation between FBI and CIA; says it does not make sense for past antagonisms to hamper collaboration between two organizations that can help each other fight terrorism (S)

headline: Set-Top Television Translator To Provide Spanish Captioning
abstract: TCC Communications offers television set-top box that converts English closed captioning to Spanish (S)

headline: A Group Uproots Arabs to Plant Jews
abstract: Jewish National Fund is embroiled in controversy over its efforts to settle Jews in Arab neighborhoods of East Jerusalem; Israeli peace activists assail its plans to evict Palestinian family of 28 from their home of 32 years and hand it over to Jewish settlers; fund says it is carrying out a mandate to acquire property for Jews in their ancient homeland; photo; map (M)

headline: Stocks of Small Companies Revive, Pulling Broader Market Higher
abstract: Smaller companies' stocks, which had plunged almost 14 percent to 1998 low in last three weeks, rebound, with Russell 2000 index rising 7.93 points, or 2 percent, to 406.62; Nasdaq index gains 41.31 points, or 2.31 percent, to 1,829.51; Dow Jones industrial average rises 30.90 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,577.68; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbs 8.20 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,089.63; graph on Dow Jones average; chart (M)

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO BUY BACK $3.28 BILLION IN SHARES
abstract: American Express Co will repurchase additional 40 million shares, or $3.28 billion in stock, expanding four-year buyback program (S)

headline: Massa Marittima Journal; Whatever's in the Lake, It's a Pain and a Puzzle
abstract: Lago dell'Accesa outside Massa Marittima, Italy, is closed to swimming after a visitor from Germany reports seeing a couple put a crocodile in the lake; the news prompts some Italians to stay away but facinates and draws others; photo; maps (M)

headline: Financial Planners Fume At the Taking of a Title
abstract: Article on opposition from investment advisers, accountants, stock brokers and other financial planning consultants to labeling of New York City welfare workers as financial planners (M)

headline: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: NEWS ANALYSIS -- Yeltsin Dismisses Russian Government; A Kremlinful Of Questions
abstract: Analysis of decision by Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin to dismiss Cabinet and to reappoint Viktor Chernomyrdin, whom he dismissed months ago, as Prime Minister; move may be act of desperation, carried out at moment when political credibility and clout were in danger of being swept away by country's latest financial shock waves; Yeltsin may be salvaging his own leadership at expense of program of economic reform he has embraced since coming to power seven years ago; photos (M)

headline: JACK HENRY TO BUY PEERLESS FOR $36 MILLION
abstract: Jack Henry & Associates Inc agrees to buy Peerless Group Inc for about $36 million (S)

headline: Strong Challenge to Kohl Is Strained by Infighting
abstract: Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democratic challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Germany's national elections in September, has gone out of his way to polish his image as a leader who would be good for business.    But when Mr. Schroder personally introduced members of his potential future cabinet on Monday in Berlin, one person was conspicuously absent: the man who would be his economics minister.

headline: Voting on the Web: Not Around the Corner, but on the Horizon
abstract: Internet voting is subject of keen interest to policy makers in state legislatures, election offices and even Pentagon; Department of Defense system under design would allow six million Americans overseas, both military and civilian, to cast ballots by using Internet; California Legislature passed bill to finance study of on-line voter registration and voting in 1997, but bill was vetoed by Gov Pete Wilson, who cited concerns about security; photo of Marc Strassman, who has campaigned for on-line voting for years, without much success so far (M)

headline: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?
abstract: Germany's Green Party seems almost certain to form coalition with Social Democrats of Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder; Schroder is concerned that Greens, founded in 1979 as loose coalition of pacifists, environmentalists, socialists and feminists, can evolve from free-wheeling ways of opposition into cohesive party of government that speaks with single vote; photos of Schroder and Green Party official Joschka Fischer (M)

headline: Playing It the Company Way
abstract: Readers are asked to submit stories about summertime corporate-sponsored sporting events; cartoon (M)

headline: Bit of Progress In Talks to End Strikes at G.M.
abstract: Norwood Jewell, often-combative head of United Automobile Workers who is heading strikes in Flint, Mich, says tone of talks with General Motors has definitely improved and that negotiations will continue over holiday weekend; GM spokesman also acknowledges talks are somewhat constructive (M)

headline: Oxford Health To Raise Rates And Cut Fees
abstract: Oxford Health Plans, troubled company that once held great promise for future of managed care, is warning doctors that it must raise premiums and reduce how much it pays doctors and hospitals in order to make money; Oxford's new chief executive, Norman C Payson, in letter sent to doctors, outlines steps company plans to take; Oxford is considering shrinking size of its hospital network and will try to more aggressively discourage members from going to doctors outside its network; chart (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Rise, With 30-Year Yield at 5.63%
abstract: US Treasury bonds rise for fourth day, driving yields to lowest level in more than three weeks, as sharp fall in stock prices bolsters appeal of less-risky Treasury securities; benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rises 13/32, to price of 107 4/32; yield falls to 5.63 percent from 5.65 percent on Aug 3; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Robert M. Luby, 88, Founder Of Regional Cafeteria Chain
abstract: Robert M Luby, cafeteria chain founder, dies at age 88 (M)8

headline: Investors Are Optimistic, But Cautious, About Russia
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 32.96 points, to 8,566.61; Nasdaq composite index falls 6.79 points, to 1,790.82; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 6.90 points, to 1,088.14; graphs of Dow Jones average; tables of hot and cold stocks and of favorites (M) y

headline: Jerusalem Journal; Aged Rabbi at Center of an Unholy War of Words
abstract: Rabbi Yitzhak Kadouri is playing bizarrely important role in Israel's political life; Iraqi-born mystic who is over 100 years old, has been used at festive political rallies to win votes for Shas, religious party that represents Sephardic Jews and has grown to be third largest political entity in Israel; wears fixed smile and dreamy gaze, which some take to be faith and others to be senility, and has recently been caught in unholy war of words among Israel's leaders over boundaries between religion and politics, rationalism and mysticism; many leaders have questioned Kadouri's lucidity and have complained about his exploitation; photo (M)

headline: UNITED VIDEO DROPS OFFER FOR GEMSTAR INTERNATIONAL
abstract: United Video Satellite Group Inc drops its $2 billion cash bid for Gemstar International Group Ltd and says it will develop its own interactive program guide for digital cable television (S)

headline: Industry View
abstract: Affiliate networks of Web sites that earn commissions for referring customers to retail Web sites are proliferating on Internet in almost every product category; main goal of affiliate programs is to lure first-time cybershoppers who might not otherwise seek or find way to retail site; drawing (M)

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Buy Medical Device Maker
abstract: Johnson & Johnson agrees to buy DePuy Inc, successful maker of orthopedic devices, for $3.5 billion in cash; Roche Holding AG, which bought 84 percent of DePuy 14 months ago, will collect about $2.9 billion; Roche got DePuy shares as part of $10.2 billion purchase of Corange Ltd (M)

headline: The 'Devastated' Envoy Now Faces Kenyans' Ire
abstract: Amb Prudence Bushnell, wounded in terrorist bombing that killed three dozen colleagues, many of them close friends, has become focus of anger of many Kenyans who believe United States did too little to rescue people trapped under rubble of building next to Nairobi embassy, where over 100 Kenyans died; Bushnell, bandaged, took charge of rescue two hours after blast and has set up mission in temporary quarters; defends US marines who turned away local residents trying to enter embassy to help with rescue, citing concern that gas tank might explode, endangering rescuers; diagram; photo (M)

headline: Cable Company Names Kirshenbaum Bond
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp awards its consolidated corporate branding account, with billings estimated at $25 million, to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners (S)

headline: Zimbabweans (Minus the President) Brace for a Crisis
abstract: Zimbabwe's President, Robert Mugabe, asserts that country's economy is on course, a view shared by no one else in country; Zimbabwean dollar has fallen 70 percent in value in last year, and inflation is nearing 40 percent; demonstrators have clashed with police three times since December; unions threaten a five-day strike; plans to seize 1,500 white-owned farms have stalled, but so have efforts to borrow money to buy farms for the poor; collapse of a bank revealed that its founder issued $45 million in unauthorized notes on a Government agency, which the state will probably have to honor (M)

headline: International Briefs; Indonesia Seizes Assets Of Bank Shareholders
abstract: Indonesia seizes 'shareholder rights' of four large banks, a sign Government is holding owners of troubled banks responsible for their problems; Government does not name the four banks (S)

headline: G.M. and Union Still in Hearings
abstract: There is no end in sight for arbitration talks between General Motors Corp and United Auto Workers (S)

headline: Economic Scene; The flimsy accounting in nuclear weapons decisions.
abstract: Peter Passell column on Brookings Institution's first thorough assessment of cost of nuclear weapons; 'Atomic Audit' estimates that $5.5 trillion in 1996 dollars has been spent by US Government on building, delivering and defending against The Bomb--and cost continues at about $35 billion a year; study estimates that building weapond cost just $409 billion in today's dollars, 2 percent of defense spending from 1940 through 1996; but delivery systems--aircraft, missiles and related equipment--added $3.2 trillion; drawing (M)

headline: Oxford Health Posts Big Loss For 2d Quarter
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc reports loss of $507.6 million in second quarter, reflecting several large charges and continued operating losses; much of loss is result of nearly $300 million in unusual or one-time charges; company's cash flow losses are roughly $85 million this quarter, and it says it expects to have another $100 million in losses over next six months; company says it will drop all Medicare business outside of New York and all of its Medicaid business; it will also drop much of its commercial business outside of New York area, leaving such markets as Illinois and Florida; new chief executive, Dr Norman C Payson, says that company is already raising premiums and cutting costs sharply to achieve its goal of making money by middle of next year; chart; photo (M)

headline: Bringing China on Line (With Official Blessing)
abstract: Dozens of companies are racing to put China and its 1.2 billion people on line; China Internet Corp of Hong Kong, backed by official New China News Agency, collects news dispatches from various wire services, which are sent to Beijing to be translated; China Internet will post material on its service, where anyone in China with computer and $30-a-month subscription fee can log on to world of Western news; company is backed by impressive array of American technology companies; Don Xia, chief executive of rival Unicom Media, says China Internet represents controlled, Government-directed approach, while hundreds of small-time entrepreneurs, most of whom lack China Internet's financial backing or political connections, labor to build truly free Internet; Beijing seems to have decided that benefits of Internet outweigh its dangers, although it still filters content of World Wide Web through central computers, and periodically blocks access to Web sites of certain Western news providers (M)

headline: Stocks in Brazil Rally, Buoying Latin Markets
abstract: Brazilian stocks show record gains, third consecutive day of a rally that has driven up market 45 percent; strong gains are fueled by growing sense among investors that developed nations will protect Latin American economies from devastation that has crippled Asia and Russia; in Sao Paulo, Brazil's benchmark Bovespa index closes up 18.68 percent; in Argentina, key index closes up 8.9 percent, while Mexican blue chips gain 12.92 percent; stocks also rise in Brazil on word that Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso plans to telephone Pres Clinton, which some interpret as sign of growing coordination at highest levels of government to steer Brazil through its turbulence; international financier George Soros warns that International Monetary Fund lacks sufficient funds to ward off turbulence; adds IMF bailout is not possible; graph; photo of Soros before House Banking Committee (M)

headline: RUSSIANS SAY LOAN BY I.M.F. MAY FALL SHORT OF THE NEED
abstract: International Monetary Fund and Russian Government are negotiating aid package that may produce less money than foreign investors say is needed to help ease financial crisis; even though Russians have publicly stated that they need $10 billion to $15 billion from fund and other lenders, Western investment bankers say country may need $20 billion or more to rebuild investor confidence; IMF says exact amount of financing is still under investigation and will ultimately depend on whether Russians take concrete steps to cut deficit and reform economy; is insisting that Russian Government reduce budget deficit in 1999 to between 2 percent and 2.5 percent of country's economy from current 5.5 percent, pass new tax code, adopt legislation on budget procedures, tighten bank regulation and take bold steps to end troublesome culture of nonpayment--in which wages go unpaid, tax debts accumulate and companies do business in barter; chart (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/  The time may finally be at hand for small-capitalization stocks to rebound. By Anne Tergesen.    INVESTING IT /Page 7/  Call him old-fashioned, but the man who runs the nation's first mutual fund looks for smart management above all else in buying stocks. By William R. Long.

headline: Thyssen Halts Plan To Buy Steelmaker
abstract: Shares of Cockerill Sambre SA fall after Thyssen Krupp AG cancels plans to bid for majority stake in Belgian steelmaker (S)

headline: Conservatives Win Decisive Victory in Bavarian Election
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's prospects for re-election receives significant lift as Bavaria's conservative Christian Social Union wins decisive victory over Social Democratic Party in state-wide elections in Bavaria; exit polls suggest Social Union received more than 52 percent of vote, compared with 29.5 percent for opposition Social Democrats (M)

headline: Hollywood Entertainment to Buy Reel.Com
abstract: Hollywood Entertainment Corp, second-largest chain of video rental shops, acquires Reel.Com, largest service selling videos over Internet; price is $100 million, of which $30 million is in cash and remainder in stock (S)

headline: Niches For Tastes And Tales
abstract: Internet has Web sites that gather personal anecdotes on aspects of modern life, large or small; one site focuses on stories of lost romances, one on stories by and about waiters and waitresses, and one on Barbie doll collectors; photo (M)

headline: Helpful in Finding Matches, On Court and Perhaps Off
abstract: Web site www.tennisw.com features conveniently categorized classified sections for those seeking everything that is tennis related; photo (S)

headline: When the News Is Bad, Analysts Feel the Heat
abstract: Article on rare downgrade of Agco Corp stock to 'market performance,' considered euphemism for 'sell,' by securities analyst David Snyder; other analysts comment on such actions and their consequences; graph (M)

headline: Talks on a Cease-Fire in Congo End; Peace Gets Only Lip Service
abstract: Despite official announcement of cease-fire agreement in Congo, latest peace negotiations in Zimbabwe end much like others in recent weeks, with nothing more than joint statement endorsing peace as ultimate goal; talks succeeded in bringing together all parties in conflict, but several issues apparently left participants deeply divided (S)

headline: DELUXE ENDS AGREEMENT TO SELL TWO OF ITS BUSINESSES
abstract: Deluxe Corp ends agreement to sell its Paperdirect Inc and Social Expressions component of Current Inc to private investor, because some conditions were not met (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Battle over right to sue H.M.O.'s isn't going away.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on proposal by Jeffrey O'Connell and James Neale for hastening settlement of malpractice suits, both in traditional doctor-patient litigation and those arising from managed care; says it seems inevitable that malpractice liability will be extended to managed care providers; drawing (M)

headline: Civilians Flee Congo's Capital in Fear of Rebel Advance
abstract: Thousands of foreigners and Congolese flee Kinshasa, fearing rebel advance; jam airports; airlines cancel flights; United States, France, other Western nations arrange charter flights to evacuate remaining citizens; exodusfollows night without electricity or running water after rebels reportedly seize hydroelectric dam; Government restores power, but not running water; rebels say they have resumed flights of men and weapons from eastern cities toward west; photo (M)d

headline: Playing With Lasers: An Update of the Good Old Game of Tag
abstract: Article describes game of laser tag; it is played in large arenas; players don vests stitched with sensors; their weapons are so-called phasers that shoot infrared rays the sensors pick up; phasers also fire red lasers, which are harmless; radius of infrared beam allows someone to score hit by firing within several inches of sensor; Pentium-powered personal computer runs laser tag with customized software; at end of game, players leave with detailed printout of their performances; diagrams (M)

headline: A Report From the Eye Of the Internet Firestorm
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews Michael Wolff book Burn Rate: How I Survived the Gold Rush Years on the Internet (M)

headline: Making the Best Of Computer Sound
abstract: Adding a sound system to a computer can enhance pleasure of playing games, exploring the Internet or simply listening to music while one works; five systems compared; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton Hints at Offer To Russia of Financial Aid  President Clinton suggested that the West would increase its aid to Russia if that country continues its tough economic reforms. His message was intended to encourage the Yeltsin Government to stick with its pro-capitalist course despite the nation's deepening economic crisis.    Mr. Clinton has told his aides that the United States should be prepared to lead a new international aid effort, which could draw on the Group of Seven industrialized nations and international organizations, such as the World Bank. [Page A1.]

headline: NatWest Announces Its Next Chairman
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC says it will appoint Sir David Rowland as chairman, effective April 1999 (S)

headline: White House Hopes Japan Can Restore Confidence
abstract: White House urges Japan's next Government to move quickly to restore confidence in Japan's financial system; Administration officials admit at same time that they fear political paralysis greatly complicates efforts to ignite recovery in Asia and ease pressure on other countries, including Russia (S)

headline: International Panel Closes Books on Gold Seized by Nazis in War
abstract: International commission set up 52 years ago to return gold that Nazi Germany seized from central banks of countries it occupied closes its books and disbands after returning most of last six tons to original claimants; Tripartite Gold Commission had delayed distribution of gold in 1997, amid disagreements about going ahead despite possibility that money, jewelry and tooth fillings of Holocaust victims might have become mixed up with it; members of commission, France, United States and Britain, pledged money to relief fund for individual victims who might have claims on monetary gold (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Suntrust Banks Is Buying Crestar in $9.5 Billion Deal  Suntrust Banks is acquiring the Crestar Financial Corporation for $9.5 billion in stock, creating the nation's 10th-largest bank holding company, with assets of $87.6 billion.     Analysts said the acquisition signaled that Suntrust wanted to be a buyer, and was no longer a takeover candidate. Suntrust shares tumbled nearly 10 percent. [Page D2.]

headline: Cambodian Government Tries to Bully Voters, U.N. Is Told
abstract: United Nations officials following preparations for July 26 elections in Cambodia say country's electoral institutions are heavily weighted in favor of Cambodian People's Party of Prime Min Hun Sen, who controls all broadcasting and has barred coverage of opposition campaigns; say voter intimidation has been widespread and Hun's supporters still operate in climate of impunity that has led to dozens of killings and disappearances (M)

headline: Indexes Make for Stiff Competition
