abstract: Article on failure of theory of diversifying investments; five money managers who began managing hypothetical retirement portfolios for New York Times in July 1993 have made money, but not enough to approach Standard & Poor's 500-stock index returns; charts; photos (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (L)

headline: DIANON SEEKS TO ACQUIRE UROCOR FOR $80 MILLION
abstract: Dianon Systems Inc offers to buy Urocor Inc for about $80 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. Says Incomnet Executive Hid Trading
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Sam D Schwartz, former top executive of Incomnet Inc, of filing false documents to conceal his trading in company's stock (M)

headline: BEACON CAPITAL TO BUY 14 PROPERTIES IN DALLAS AREA
abstract: Beacon Capital Partners Inc says that it agreed to acquire 14 properties in Dallas area from Breunig Commercial Management Inc of Dallas for $91.5 million (S)

headline: SEAGRAM TO SELL ITS STATE IN FRENCH FASHION HOUSE
abstract: Seagram Co will sell it majority stake in Herve Leger, a French fashion house, to BCBG Max Azria, maker of men's and women's clothing, for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Real Networks in Pact With America Online
abstract: America Online chooses Real Networks Inc's streaming technology, which delivers audio and video over Internet, as main way for users to play streaming media on new version of its on-line service; Real Networks chairman, Rob Glaser, says his recent criticism of Microsoft Corp, minority investor in company, has spurred interest in company; photo (M)

headline: The Royal Treatment; Ruling Family Feuds as Oil Income Drops in Brunei
abstract: Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah of Brunei is facing both bitter family feud and free fall in oil prices, which has thrown his country into financial bind; recent celebration marking crowning of Sultan's eldest son, Prince al-Muhtadee Billah, is coupled with economic crisis in which Sultan recently stripped his brother, Prince Jefri Bolkiah, of his posts as head of Brunei Investment Agency and its largest conglomerate, reflecting allegations that Prince squandered billions on bad investments and profligate lifestyle; reconstructing what happened to these investments is difficult because their operations are cloaked in secrecy; Sultan himself has come under scrutiny for living extravagantly while decline in oil prices drains Brunei's economy; Prince Billah is seen as possible help in overcoming some of Brunei's current ills because he projects less frivolous image than his uncle, or even his father at younger age; maps of Brunei's oil reserves (L)

headline: Lockheed-Pentagon Agreement Is Revised
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp agrees to pay Defense Department up to $75 million if failures continue in tests of antimissile system; agreement includes provision for Lockheed Martin Missiles and Space to win back portion of any fees for missile failures (S)

headline: Big Profit Drop For Toys 'R' Us
abstract: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said today that earnings before a charge decreased 57 percent in the latest quarter as the company, the world's biggest toy retailer, failed to find a hit product to help it regain sales lost to discount chains. Net income fell 63 percent.    In the quarter that ended Aug. 1, the company's fiscal second quarter, profit before the charge fell to $15.9 million, or 6 cents a diluted share, from $36.7 million, or 13 cents a diluted share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. The charge in the latest quarter, for the early retirement of debt, resulted in net income of $13.5 million, or 5 cents a share. There were no gains or charges in the earlier period.

headline: The Future of E-Books
abstract: Michael D Maltz letter comments on July 2 article on electronic books, which suggested that people may soon be wearing computers; says he would like to have one powered by the energy in his love handles

headline: SOFTBANK OF JAPAN IN $400 MILLION ON-LINE DEAL
abstract: Softbank Corp acquires 27.2 percent of E*Trade Group Inc for $400 million (S)

headline: Swiss Hills Are Alive With Sound of Diesels
abstract: Switzerland, which because of its location is subject to much of Europe's north-south traffic, is trying to create plan that would balance transport needs of European Union with protecting its scenic valleys from noise and air pollution created by truck traffic (M)

headline: Vladimir Dudintsev, 79, Dies; Writer Dissected Soviet Life
abstract: Vladimir D Dudintsev, reporter and novelist whose dissection of mid-1950's Soviet life drew wrath of Nikita S Khrushchev and muffled praise of dissidents, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Amazon.com Program Signs Member No. 100,000
abstract: Amazon.com has enrolled 100,000th Web site for Amazon.com Associates Program, affiliate network that pays commission of up to 15 percent for each sale referred from site; members simply recommend titles at their sites and establish links that enable direct purchases from Amazon.com; drawing (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Resume Slide On Worries About Profits  Share prices dropped sharply, more than erasing big gains from the day before, on persistent concern about unimpressive corporate earnings. Wall Street analysts said investors were finally awakening to the effects of the slowdown in Asia, which could diminish growth at home and stifle stocks for the remainder of 1998.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HARSCO CORP.,  Harrisburg, Pa., a maker of gas-containment sytems, agreed to buy the high-pressure valve division of Amcast Industrial Corp., Dayton, Ohio, a metal fabricator, for an undisclosed price.    INFOSEEK CORP.,  Sunnyvale, Calif., will pay Microsoft Corp. $26 million for a two-year exclusive agreement to provide Internet search and directory services on WebTV, Microsoft's Internet-television service.

headline: Little Industries Mean a Lot to Manhattan
abstract: Viewpoint comment by Joel Kotkin of Pepperdine Institute suggests that, with Wall Street money machine in turmoil, New Yorkers may see economic salvation in smaller-scale businesses, such as printing and graphics companies on Varick Street (M)

headline: Five Years After Accord, Mideast Peace Still Seems Distant
abstract: Fifth anniversary of Oslo peace accords is marred by third day of violent unrest and Israel's closing of West Bank and Gaza; US envoy Dennis Ross presses efforts to eliminate impasse in negotiations between Israel and Palestinians; palpable pessimism descends on those who had initial hopes for quick breakthrough during visit; there is fresh anxiety over possibility of terrorist attack to avenge Israel's killing of two Islamic militants days ago (M)

headline: Burmese Are Tense on Eve of Anniversary of Crackdown
abstract: Myanmar is tense on eve of tenth anniversary of start of crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators that over six weeks took thousands of lives; leaflets have reportedly been distributed calling for demonstrations, and Government has announced that it will meet street protests with force; pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi steps up pressure by refusing invitation to meet with Government officials, and demands that guard detail stationed for years within the gate of her compound be removed; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japan's Prime Minister Cites Others' Costly Errors  Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan, blamed his predecessor, the nation's powerful Finance Ministry and the heads of the country's huge financial institutions for wasting years before the country began to deal with its crippling banking crisis and a deep recession that is worsening the world's economic turmoil.    Mr. Obuchi's comments, in an interview as he prepared to address the United Nations, was the first acknowledgment by a Japanese leader that his country's leadership, both in government and in the private sector, had made huge errors that have now ricocheted around the world. [Page A13.]

headline: France to Sell Another Piece Of State Telephone Company
abstract: French Government will reduce its stake in France Telecom to 62.5 percent from 75 percent in sale of shares worth as much as $9 billion; Government will sell 5 to 6 percent of existing shares, while France Telecom will sell new shares equivalent to 5 percent of company; action is expected to occur in September or October (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises after lawmakers in Russia, which relies heavily on German trade and investment, approve some parts of plan to qualify for international aid; dollar falls to 1.7937 marks from 1.8043 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Playing It The Company Way
abstract: Item invites readers to send in stories about corporate summer games (S)

headline: Two Electric Suppliers In Britain to Merge
abstract: Southern Electric PLC, British utility, will merge with Scottish Hydro-Electric PLC, creating one of Britain's largest electricity suppliers; Southern Electric shareholders will own 55 percent of combined company (S)

headline: Fears Grow As Russia Postpones Debt Plan
abstract: The Russian Government tonight put off the announcement of its plan to change the repayment terms for its debt, after alarm had spread in the world financial community that Russia was prepared to discriminate against foreign creditors.     Deputy Prime Minister Boris G. Fyodorov, in charge of economic policy, said he would first review the plan with representatives of J. P. Morgan; Goldman, Sachs, and Deutsche Bank. Details of the expected swap of Treasury bills for longer-term securities, a crucial element in program to deal with the economic crisis, were to have been released on Wednesday.

headline: David H. Holladay, 73, Expert in Air Safety
abstract: David H Holladay, specialist in air safety, dies at age 72 (S)

headline: KEY ENERGY TO MAKE UNSOLICITED OFFER FOR A RIVAL
abstract: Key Energy Group Inc will make unsolicited bid to buy all shares of rival Dawson Production Services Inc for $14 each, or $161 million; will assume $149 million in Dawson debt (S)

headline: Frazzled Clinton Team Set To Fly Into Heart of Storm
abstract: Pres Clinton's aides scramble to prepare for trip to Russia, uncertain of what they will find when their get there (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Wheat falls 1.8 percent after Egypt buys 250,000 tons from France, raising speculation that US offers had been spurned; July contract falls 4.75 cents a bushel, to $2.605, lowest since July 1991; graph; chart (S)

headline: Prices Move Up Slightly as Flight to Treasuries Continues
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise slightly; 30-year bond rises 4/32, to 102 17/32, to yield 5.33 percent; table of key rates (M)

headline: Muted Criticism and Marches in Pakistan
abstract: Pakistan Govt condemns American attack on neighboring Afghanistan; charges missiles crossed Pakitan's air space without permission; photo of protesters in Karachi (M)

headline: CONGO RECAPTURES A STRATEGIC BASE
abstract: Congolese Govt forces and allies recapture strategic military base at Kitona from rebels, possibly halting their drive toward capital of Kinshasa; rebels appear to have seized Kisingani, country's third largest city, solidifying positions in eastern Congo; developments raise possibility of protracted war, in which Government and rebels, backed by respective allies, would fight each other from entrenched positions in country's second civil war in two years; military advances overtake diplomatic efforts, led by Pres Nelson Mandela of South Africa, to negotiate peaceful resolution; maps; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN GREETINGS TO TAKE A CHARGE AND CUT JOBS
abstract: American Greetings Corp will take third-quarter pretax charge of between $10 million and $20 million as part of 'pro-active' move to cut costs and maintain growth; says 120 to 240 workers--between 1 percent and 2 percent of company's 12,000 full-time employees--will be dismissed as part of review of operations (S)

headline: Building a Bridge, a Theater Troupe From the U.S. Is Embraced by Havana
abstract: Cuba welcomes veteran actors from Repertorio Espanol, first Cuban-Americans invited there since severing of relations with US in 1961; actors return to same stage in Havana where they worked before their exile; audience is comprised of relatives and strangers, friends and old colleagues who knew some of actors from work in Cuban theater and radio half-century ago; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Steady as Strong Demand Is Expected at Auctions
abstract: US Treasury bonds are little changed with yields at one-month lows and prices at highs; benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rises 2/32, or 67.5 cents per $1,000 bond, to price of 107 6/32, nudging its yield down basis point to 5.62 percent, lowest since July 10; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Tiger in a Sea of Pussy Cats; Trinidad and Tobago Bids Goodbye to Oil, Hello to Gas
abstract: Twin-island nation of Trinidad and Tobago, almost evenly divided between citizens of African and Indian descent, is experiencing burst of investment and growth; thanks to belated realization that its substantial natural gas reserves may prove to be even more valuable than its oil, Trinidad is rapidly emerging as region's foremost economic success story; since beginning of boom less than five years ago, 50 American companies now operating in Trinidad have invested more than $4 billion, remarkable figure in country with only 1.3 million people; seeking to take advantage of cheap and abundant energy supplies, petroleum, chemical and steel companies from Britain, Canada, Germany, India, Norway and Spain are also flocking to Trinidad and Tobago; Trinidadian oil and gas industry consultant says that in process, country is becoming industrialized and turning into Caribbean tiger; charts compare Trinidad's gross domestic product per person with those of Jamaica, Haiti and Dominican Republic (L)

headline: Film Industry Is Confronting Likely Change In Accounting
abstract: Financial Accounting Standard Board has tentatively approved new financial reporting standards for film industry that could cost some Hollywood studios hunderds of millions of dollars; new rules will also apply to producers of television shows, but not to cable companies or broadcasters, which follow other rules; most companies will not adopt new rules until 2000 (M)

headline: Livent Ledger Woes, Scene II: New Hire Replaces Impresario
abstract: Livent Inc announces its new artistic director will be Todd Haimes, current artistic director of Roundabout Theater Co; in unusual arrangement, Haimes will remain director of Roundabout until next year to oversee company's move to new theater; Livent officials are effectively supplanting Garth H Drabinsky, Livent's co-founder and producer of several lavish musicals, who was suspended along with Myron I Gottlieb, vice president, after new management team found accounting irregularities said to involve several millions of dollars (M)

headline: CAPITAL AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY 67 AUTO DEALER PROPERTIES
abstract: Capital Automotive REIT agrees to buy 67 auto dealership properties for about $334.5 million in cash and partnership units from Automotive Realty Trust of America; terms of purchase are not released (S)

headline: Cambodian Prince Offers Way to End Stalemate
abstract: Investors are pouring money into Mozambique, encouraged by the strict economic management practiced by Government and its success so far in privatizing the economy; country is on brink of a boom, although is remains one of the world's poorest countries; its role in world economy is still much like its colonial one: being exploited by foreign buyers of raw materials; maps and graphs (M)

headline: 7-Up Previews Super Bowl Ad Campaign For Its Bottlers
abstract: Dr Pepper/Seven Up Inc, seeking fresher, younger image for 7-Up soft drink, unveils series of new television commercials Sept 17 that will begin during Super Bowl in January; commercials were prepared by Young & Rubicam (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Economic Scene; Twisting Controls on Currency and Capital
abstract: Economic Scene column on economic crises in Russia and Asia focuses on ways to stimulate those economies and restore stability; suggests that debt relief will have to be part of any solution to current plight in Russia and Asia; holds the sooner it comes, the sooner a widespread economic rebound can begin; drawing (M)

headline: Moderate Serbs in Bosnia Remain a Political Force
abstract: Many foreign diplomats are now saying results of election in Bosnia are not disaster for Western strategy they first thought; others say problem is bad, but may be handled; less hard-line politicians across nation are doing well, despite victory of nationalist Nikola Poplasen in race for Bosnian Serb presidency (M)

headline: Lessons on Censorship
abstract: Letters prompted by recent articles in Circuits section from William K Baxter, Adam Epstein, Ron Krupp, Bill Adler Jr and Laura H Wise (M)

headline: New Unit for National City
abstract: National City Corp creates new unit, National City Investment Management, which will focus on asset management for institutional investors (S)3

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices surge on expectations that demand from European manufacturers will pick up; copper for December delivery rises 1.85 cents, to 77.35 cents a pound--its highest closing price since July 30; graph; chart (S)

headline: S.E.C.'s Funds Chief Is Leaving to Join Law Firm
abstract: Barry Barbash, who as head of division of Securities and Exchange Commission that regulates mutual funds oversaw one of fund industry's most rapid periods of growth, says he will step down next month to join law firm of Shearman & Sterling; Barbash will become partner in firm's Washington office and will oversee its investment management practices (M)

headline: Is This the Secret Heart of the Byzantine Empire?
abstract: Turkish archeologists may have discovered ruins of Great Palace of Byzantine Empire from which emperors ruled much of known world nearly thousand years ago; make discovery while cleaning underground Ottoman chamber in Istanbul; Great Palace was built by Constantine the Great after making city capital of Roman Empire in AD 330; construction continued intermittently for eight centuries; palace was home to more than 50 Byzantine emperors and stage for countless intrigues, some of which decided fate of nations; Alpay Pasinli, director of Istanbul's Archeological Museum and other Turkish scholars comment; photo (M)

headline: Whale Tissue Raises Worry on Toxic Chemicals
abstract: Dutch scientists find polybrominated compounds in tissue of whales that normally feed in deep waters of the Atlantic Ocean; say finding should serve as a warning of how far the chemicals, which are used as flame retardants in many everyday products but appear to be resilient and harmful in nature, have penetrated the ocean's food chain (M)

headline: German Regulators Oppose Pay-TV Deal
abstract: German antitrust authorities say they will probably block new plan by Bertelsmann AG and Kirch group to raise their stakes in country's largest pay-TV channel, because such a deal would give them pay-TV monopoly; Government says it will make final decision by mid-October on plan to buy stake in pay-TV channel Premiere from Canal Plus SA, raising their stakes to 50 percent each (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Jailed Nigerian Dies Amid Envoys' Visit
abstract: Moshood K Abiola, Nigeria's most prominent political prisoner, dies of apparent heart attack during visit with American and Nigerian officials in capital of Abuja; US State Department spokesman James P Rubin says there is nothing to suggest that death was from other than natural causes; says Abiola fell ill during meeting with Under Sec Thomas R Pickering and Asst Sec Susan E Rice; Pickering says Abiola initially seemed in good spirits but that his condition quickly deteriorated; Pres Clinton praises him as distinguished citizen and patriot of Nigeria; UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who met with Abiola week ago, calls on Nigerian Government to unconditionally release all remaining political prisoners and to define credible process for transition to civilian rule; Abiola's two daughters voice suspicions about death; say Government is culpable since it denied him medical treatment during confinement; Nigerian Government promises full, prompt autopsy in cooperation with Abiola's personal physicians; some political implications of his passing discussed; photos (M)

headline: A North Korean Satellite? U.S. Is Searching
abstract: United States, retreating from initial assessment that multistage rocket fired by North Korea over Japan was missile test alone, now believes North Korea may have put satellite into orbit (S)

headline: Ready for Robots
abstract: Prof Robert W Albrecht letter says just about everybody wants a household robot server, but development costs may be prohibitive (Aug 6 article)

headline: G.E. to Settle Debt-Collection Lawsuits
abstract: Frederic L Ellis, lawyer representing consumers, says General Electric Co agrees to pay as much as $147 million to settle lawsuits and consumer complaints accusing it of illegally collecting debts from bankrupt credit-card customers; GE disputes settlement figures, saying tht it agreed to less than $100 million to debtors who contended company's finance unit, GE Capital Corp, failed to properly file consumers' debt-repayment agreements in bankruptcy court (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRION INC., Sanford, N.C., the air-cleaning equipment company, said its acquisition by McLeod Russell Holdings P.L.C. for about $53 million in cash had been postponed.    AEROSONIC CORP., Clearwater, Fla., a maker of aircraft equipment, said it had been approached by unidentified parties interested in buying it.

headline: Frustrated by Kosovo Stalemate, the West Criticizes All Sides
abstract: United States, Russia and European countries monitoring fighting between ethnic Albanian and Serbian forces in Kosovo condemn outside support for fighters and urge all countries to prevent exiles from financing arms for insurgents; diplomats of so-called contact group of six countries acknowledge that primary responsibility for bloodshed in Kosovo lives with Serbia, but their latest statement is almost as critical of insurgents; diplomats say for first time that negotiations should include ethnic Albanian representatives (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.53   5.48        3-month T-bills   4.70   4.76   4.99        6-month T-bills   4.76   4.78   5.16        10-yr. T-infl.   3.81   3.80   3.56        10-yr. T-note   5.02   5.06   6.32        30-yr. T-bond   5.30   5.33   6.60        Telephone bd.   7.10   7.11   7.67        Municipal bds.   5.14   5.15   5.51          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: LIBRARY/GRAMMAR TUTORS; The Basics on a Shoestring
abstract: MULTIMEDIA HIGH SCHOOL GRAMMAR (Pro One; $14.95; Windows 3.0 and later.)

headline: U.N. Council Prepares Mild Reply to Iraq
abstract: UN Security Council is preparing low-keyed response to Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein's latest attempt to frustrate its arms inspectors; response reflects deep divisions among members over Council's approach to Iraq, as well as unwillingness of US and Britain to threaten military action as in February 1998 standoff; Council, faced with Iraq's defiant refusal to cooperate further with UN inspectors seeking to eliminate its weapons of mass destruction, will debate draft resolution acknowledging that plans to disarm Iraq have suffered setback, and instructing inspectors to press ahead with work and report any further Iraqi obstruction (M)

headline: Austria Moves Toward Returning Artworks Confiscated by Nazis
abstract: Senior ministers of Austrian Govt send draft law on restitution of art confiscated by Nazis to Parliament and say they expect that some paintings, furniture and other objects will be returned to their rightful owners by end of year (M)

headline: On an Indian Shore Where Ships Go to Die, Profit Is Law
abstract: Profile of grim scene in Alang, India, which has become world's biggest shipbreaking yard, where armies of mostly illiterate migrant workers strip ships' metal for scrap; Alang is a souless spot 185 miles northwest of Bombay; in recent years, what had once been a poverty-stricken village has become world's biggest shipbreaking yard; in 1990's, Alang has served as graveyard for almost half the ships scrapped by world's navies and merchant marine; photo; map (L)

headline: VORNADO REALTY TO SPIN OFF $100 MILLION UNIT
abstract: Vornado Realty Trust to spin off to shareholders new Vornado Operating Co, $100 million unit that will hold its non-real estate businesses (S)

headline: Artificial Intelligence Program Tries Its Hand at Cards
abstract: GIB, computer program that can play bridge, gave world's best human players run for their money in Lille, France, at 1998 World Bridge Championships; program placed 12th out of 35 in Par contest, which challenges competitors to solve tricky bridge puzzles; photo (S)

headline: Compressed Data; A New Watchdog Against Internet Fraud
abstract: John Reed Stark is named to lead Office of Internet Enforcement, new unit of Securities and Exchange Commission set up to combat investment fraud on Internet; photo (S)

headline: Autopsy Says Heart Disease Killed Abiola
abstract: Moshood K O Abiola, Nigerian opposition leader, died of heart disease, according to American and other Western doctors who performed autopsy; their preliminary report would seem to rule out foul play; it confirms official account given by Nigerian military Government; this seems unlikely to assuage Nigerians, who have reacted with fury to death of Abiola on eve of his promised release by new military ruler, Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar; photo (M)

headline: Strikes and Asian Crisis Are Factors in U.S. Productivity Drop
abstract: Productivity of US workers fell in second quarter, first such drop in three years, as Asia's economic crisis and strikes at General Motors plants took a toll; productivity fell at annual rate of two-tenths of 1 percent after surging at 3.5 percent pace in first quarter; second-quarter nonfarm productivity was 1.9 percent higher than it was in year-earlier quarter and near 2.4 percent year-over-year increase posted for first quarter (M)

headline: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS LEADS GROUP BUYING PAC-WEST
abstract: Group led by Safeguard Scientifics will buy Pac-West Telecomm Inc for $115 million; group includes Pac-West chairman, Bruce Westphal, and founder and president, John La Rue (S)

headline: South Africa's Role
abstract: News analysis of South Africa's unsuccessful efforts to mediate peaceful resolution of conflict in Congo; finds minimal results of efforts by Pres Nelson Mandela shows South Africa is still struggling to find its footing among neighboring nations, many of which remain suspicious and resentful of country's economic power and international adulation accorded Mandela (M)

headline: A Break in the Clouds, Or More Storms Ahead?
abstract: Article describes significant differences between fall 1997 US stock market drop, blamed on Asian currency devaluation, and latest downturn; some experts say decline shows bull market's long run has ended; drawing (M)

headline: Russia and France Gain on U.S. Lead in Arms Sales, Study Says
abstract: Study by Congressional Research Service finds US remains world's biggest arms merchant, filling developing world's arsenals, but that Russia and France are poised to overtake it; says US sold $15.2 billion worth of weapons in 1997, or 44 percent of shrinking global arms market; other findings discussed; chart (M)

headline: Ho Chi Minh City Journal; U.S. Embassy Passes Into History. Coming Soon: Real Estate Deals.
abstract: State Department has razed old embassy building, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, brooding reminder of United States presence in former Saigon during Vietnam War; move makes room for new consulate and possibly for commercial building; consulate general, Charles A Ray, says he hopes first American diplomatic mission in 23 years will spur commercial ties; map; photos (M)

headline: Phone Lines, and Lines and Lines, Keeping Their Appeal
abstract: Consumers are being given growing array of options for meeting their escalating need to fax, phone, send E-mail and go out on Internet; many newer transmission options are expensive, with higher service costs and extra charges for special modems, installation and even Internet service providers; many consumers simply increase number of regular phone lines; sales of regular phones lines are booming as phone companies seek to keep connection costs down; photo (M)

headline: Executive Quits DDB Needham
abstract: Mike Rogers, vice chairman and chief creative officer at DDB Needham New York, resigns; David Nathanson, senior vice president, is promoted to co-chief creative officer along with Steve Landsberg (S)

headline: Venezuelan Stocks Tumble On Fears of a Devaluation
abstract: Venezuelan stocks plunge 9.5 percent, biggest one-day drop in nearly four years, as market is rattled by worries that Government might devalue its currency; Caracas Stock Exchange's general index falls 363.82 points, to 3,460.64 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For Sony, Too Little Information Proved to Be a Dangerous Thing
abstract: Market Place column on Sony Corp, which has been fined $1 million by Securities and Exchange Commission for misleading investors in months leading up to Nov 17, 1994, day Sony shocked Wall Street with announcement that it was writing off value of its movie studios, Columbia Pictures and Tri Star Pictures, by $2.7 billion because of their poor performances; commission also orders Sony to have independent auditors examine section of its annual report where management provides details of business results for investors; never has commission made such a request; without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Sony accepts commission's order to 'cease and desist' from such practices in future; if it is charged with misleading investors again, it will face much more severe penalties; SEC says Sony 'obscured' movie studio losses by combining them with profits from its music division under category 'entertainment' (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In a volatile economy, newspaper stocks closely echo the rise and fall of the market.
abstract: Felicity Barringer Market Place column on rise and recent fall in newspaper industry stocks; notes investors fear drop in highly profitable classified advertising and pressure on newsprint prices; graph; table (M)

headline: World News Briefs; Authorities in China Arrest Newspaper Editor
abstract: Security agents in China reportedly arrest Shi Binhai, newspaper editor who contributed recently to book on political reforms (S)

headline: Hard Drive by Any Other Name Might Make Its Owner Blush
abstract: Trends in the naming of computer hard drives are detected by repair technicians; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Premier Promises Tax Cut for Long Term, Too
abstract: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto promises long-term tax cuts beginning next year, but he gives no details about how much move might fatten pocketbooks or lift sagging Japanese economy; Japan is under enormous pressure from United States and other countries to make permanent tax cuts to stimulate economy and reduce risk of global downturn; Hashimoto has been reluctant to lower minimum level of taxable income, because any tax cuts would have to be financed somehow by Government that has just declared fiscal austerity to be its medium-term goal (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Recover From Early Drop
abstract: Stock prices cascade around Asia in response to deep plunge on Wall Street; in Japan, Nikkei index of 225 shares drops to new 12-year low of 13,664.74, down 3.1 percent before rebounding, gaining 16.24 points, to 14,124.13; in Singapore, stock prices fall 1.99 percent, to 839.35 (M)

headline: Power Companies Embrace the Internet
abstract: Growing number of electric companies are getting into one of most rapidly changing businesses, offering Internet access; deregulation is forcing utilities to learn to compete, and to seek new sources of revenue; many investor-owned utilities own large fiber-optic networks that they built for internal communication across states and among power plants and field offices; now they are developing their own telecommunications businesses, including Internet access, using excess capacity of these networks; photo (M)

headline: Dow Ends Two Days of Losses as Buyers Put Jitters Aside
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 111.99 points, or 1.26 percent, to 9,026.95; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 17.74 points, or 1.58 percent, to 1,142.95; Nasdaq composite index soars 38.09 points, gain of more than 2 percent, to 1,919.58; graph; chart (M)

headline: International Briefs; Sanwa Bank in Japan Barred From Fund Sales
abstract: Sanwa Bank, fourth-largest in Japan, is barred from selling mutual funds for one year because of bribes to Finance Ministry and Bank of Japan officials for information about interest rates and bank inspections (S)

headline: Ciba Specialty Plans To Eliminate 1,100 Jobs
abstract: Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., the Swiss company that is the world's second-biggest maker of specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,100 jobs and possibly sell one of its biggest units. Ciba's first-half operating profit rose 2.7 percent, to 490 million Swiss francs ($325.7 million) from 477 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Analysts had expected an 11 percent increase.

headline: NBC Executive In Polygram Bid
abstract: Neil S Braun resigns as president of NBC television network to submit bid for one of Europe's largest film distributors, movie business of Polygram NV; Braun will be replaced at NBC by Randy Falco, president of broadcast and network operations; Braun says he and Marty Tudor are making bid; Seagram Co, which is buying Polygram from Royal Philips Electronics NV, agreed to sell film division (S)

headline: Memories of Glory; G.M. Strike Recalls Era When Cars Were Big, and So Was Union Power
abstract: Strike against General Motors, now 44 days old, brings back memories of Big Labor's heyday because United Automobile Workers has been able not only to shut down the entire company but also to cripple the very colossus that has long symbolized American industrial might; strike differs, however, from epic struggles of 1950's and 60's in that it did not start as a nationwide strike but rather as a dispute at one plant in Flint, Mich, and reflects downard movement in focus of bargaining to the plant, its work rules and its job security problems (M)

headline: Thinking Rationally As the Web Goes Wild
abstract: Interview with Munder NetNet fund head Paul Cook, who comments on sharp rise in Internet stock prices; photo (M)

headline: The Art of Driving Is All the Rage
abstract: World Wide Web sites are devoted to all aspects of automotive experience; road rage has triggered number of sites set up to record license plates; one site, called How to Drive Like a Moron, sarcastically compiles every possible bad-driving habit as part of its instruction in art of idiot behavior behind the wheel; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table of rates on key Government bond issues

headline: Surfing the Web and Snaring an Owed Pension
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp has created Internet site listing names of about 8,600 people who are due pension benefits from variety of companies (M)

headline: Computer Use at Home Looks a Lot Like Work
abstract: Survey done by Media Metrix on software programs for home computers finds most popular ones are busines-related applications; list also shows growing dominance of Microsoft, which makes 7 of 10 programs used most often (S)

headline: Dow Chemical Acquisition
abstract: Dow Chemical Co to buy European synthetic rubber business from Royal Dutch/Shell Group in effort to expand its own profitable rubber operations; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: When Management Shoots for the Moon
abstract: Article on buzzword sweeping through executive offices around the country: BHAG's, for 'big, hairy, audacious goals'; says BHAG is supposed to inspire an organization to reach for goal it might not otherwise think impossible; holds notion was refined by Gary Hamel and C K Prahalad and bigness and hair were added by James C Collins and Jerry I Porras, who apparently coined term BHAG in their 1994 book, Built to Last: Successful Habits of Visionary Companies; goals of some major corporations noted; photo (M)3

headline: PRESIDENT SWEARS TO USE 'ALL TOOLS' AGAINST TERRORISM
abstract: Pres Clinton says US will use 'all the tools at our disposal' to fight terrorist network of Osama bin Laden, as Administration outlines efforts to squeeze him financially after US cruise-missile strikes against sites linked to him in Afghanistan and Sudan; signs executive order calling for Treasury Dept to block any financial transactions with American companies by bin Laden and his principal terrorist organization, Islamic Army (M)

headline: James Lavenson, 79, Marketer Who Once Headed the Plaza Hotel
abstract: James H Lavenson, advertising and marketing expert and former president of Plaza Hotel in New York City, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: Virtual Virtuosos of the Holler
abstract: Hollerin' site on Internet offers pictures and sounds from National Hollerin' Contest held each year in North Carolina; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Walkouts to Cost G.M. $1.18 Billion in 2d Quarter  General Motors said strikes at two factories in Flint, Mich., which have forced 26 of the auto maker's 29 North American assembly plants to close, will cost the company $1.18 billion after taxes in the second quarter.

headline: SYBRON CHEMICALS BUYS RUCO POLYMER FOR $95 MILLION
abstract: Sybron Chemicals acquires privately-held Ruco Polymer Corp and Ruco Polymer Company for $95 million cash and also assumed debt (S)

headline: Rally Overseas Helps Bolster U.S. Markets
abstract: Led by a surge in technology shares and rallies overseas, United States stocks rose for a second day yesterday and helped the major indexes erase most of the declines suffered over the previous two weeks.    Although the market remains substantially below the highs reached a month ago, analysts said investors apparently were heeding reports pointing out how a wide array of stocks had fallen to relatively cheap levels.

headline: After 3 Violent Decades, Hope in Northern Ireland
abstract: Pres Clinton visits Belfast at one of Northern Ireland's most promising moments; there is unexpected momentum toward firming up terms of April peace settlement, and for first time people are expressing confidence that conflict between two warring communities that has cost more than 3,200 lives in past three decades is over; incident that has animated peace process was one that was aimed at stilling it--savage bombing by renegade Catholic guerrillas in Omagh on Aug 15 (M)

headline: Sedgwick Reports Loss in First Half
abstract: Sedgwick Group says it had first-half loss after it set aside 80 million pounds ($130 million) to cover cost of reimbursing some pension investors; Sedgwick had loss of 7.1 million pounds, compared with profit of 46.2 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: A Sacred Indian Site, but Still the Font of Strife
abstract: Hindu-Moslem distrust runs deep in India over plan to build a temple to Ram in Ayodhya on the site of a 16th-century Babri Masjid mosque, which was demolished by Hundu militants in 1992; Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which came to power on pledge to build the temple, has since pledged to build it only if the courts give permission and nation's laws are changed to allow it; photos; map (M)

headline: AT&T and British Telecom Merge Overseas Operations
abstract: AT&T and British Telecommunications PLC will merge most of operations into jointly owned company that would have $10 billion in revenue, creating powerful new player in fast-growing market for global communications; new venture represents AT&T's biggest commitment yet to comprehensive global strategy, and will focus on serving multinational corporations; will end AT&T's alliances with Unisource--Dutch, Swiss and Swedish phone companies--and with World Partners, which is loose confederation of more than dozen international communications carriers; photo; graph (M)

headline: Should Octogenarians Walk on the Wild Side?
abstract: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen answers question from Martin Field of Laguna Hills, Calif, on whether elderly should seek investment advice rather than tax-avoidance schemes; photo (M)

headline: In a Liquid Crystal Display, Molecules Keep Light in Line
abstract: Liquid crystal displays have helped make possible the great reduction in the size of computers and electronic devices since they were first introduced in early 1970's; differences between active-matrix and passive-matrix LCD's, their uses and how they work described; drawing (M)

headline: Venator and Sports Authority Cancel Merger
abstract: Venator Group Inc and Sports Authority Inc are canceling merger they had agreed to in May because Venator's stock has dropped 61 percent; decline in shares of Venator cuts value of its planned purchase of Sports Authority to about $398.5 million in stock and assumed debt, from more than $761 million when it was announced May 7 (S)

headline: Congo Begins Recruitment To Aid Army Facing Rebels
abstract: Congo Govt, with week-old insurrection approaching capital, opens recruitment drive, aimed at enlisting thousands of youths into country's badly stretched armed forces; recruiters go from neighborhood to neighborhood urging youths from ages 12 to 20 to respond to Pres Laurent Kabila's call to defend country against what he has characterized as effort by neighboring Rwanda to occupy Congo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY    None

headline: Worldcom's $6.1 Billion Sets Record
abstract: Worldcom Inc sells record $6.1 billion of bonds; money will help pay for Worldcom's acquisition of MCI Communications Corp; Government bond market is little changed, with price of 30-year bond down 1/32, to 106 16/32; yield is unchanged at 5.67 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: In a Divorce, Who Gets Custody of Those Stock Options?
abstract: Article on increasing instances in which couples who are divorcing try to gain control of corporate stock options and their proceeds; photo (M)

headline: Health Insurers: Middlemen or More?
abstract: Dr Jesse M Hackell letter disputes Aetna Inc chairman Richard L Huber's August 9 Viewpoint article opposing proposed federal regulation of private health insurance plans (S) y

headline: Lawyer Says U.S. Inquiry On Holbrooke Is Near End
abstract: Lawyer for Richard C Holbrooke, whose nomination as American representative at United Nations has been sidetracked by Federal ethics investigation, says that inquiry is nearly over and that investigators have found nothing to stop nomination from proceeding (M)

headline: SEALED AIR TO CUT 750 JOBS AND TAKE $112 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Sealed Air Corp expects to eliminate 750 jobs, reducing its work force to about 13,750, in reorganization related to its $4.9 billion purchase of Cryovac operations of W R Grace & Co in March; it also says it will take third-quarter charge of $112 million to $122 million and post separate charge of $23 million related to earnings of units not considered permanently invested in its business (S)

headline: INVESTING IT; Trading in the Rumor Mill, An Entrepreneur Harvests The Market Grapevine
abstract: Profile of Charles Payne, 35, Wall Street stock-picker and newfound media celebrity; operations of his tip sheet, Wall Street Strategies, described; interview; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 5 picture caption in Mutual Funds Report (Money & Business Part 2) about growth of Vanguard Group which misstated role of senior chairman John C Bogle (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies charts; dollar falls to 139.47 yen from 139.94

headline: Loving A Stock, Not Wisely But Too Well
abstract: John R Silber, former Boston University president, the university and Silber's friends and associates lose heavily in stock of Seragen, biotechnology company with promising cancer drug; company ran out of money despite Silber's persistent promotional efforts; stock collapsed, and company was sold to Ligand Pharmaceuticals Inc; Silber defends company's science; chronology of events; graph; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: NATURAL GAS RISES 8.7 PERCENT. Prices surged after a Midwest heat wave raised speculation that electricity producers would need more gas. The September contract rose 16.4 cents, to $2.041 per thousand cubic feet.

headline: Big Board Posts 1.97% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: Open positions of short sales on New York Stock Exchange increased 1.97 percent in last month, to 4.13 billion shares on July 15, surpassing last month's record of 4.05 billion shares; short interest fell four-tenths of 1 percent on American Stock Exchange as of July 15, to 194.38 million shares from 195.07 million shares; charts (M)

headline: Foreign Exodus Leaves Kinshasa Unfazed
abstract: US, Britain, France and other Western nations begin hurried final evacuation of their citizens in Congo amid signs that African-led negotiations to prevent rebel assault on Kinshasa will fail; Pres Laurent Kabila, who has been fighting for his political life against armed rebellion, has left Kinshasa and is in Lubumbashi; map; photo (M)

headline: New Breed of German Extortionist Has Soft Spot for Shoppers
abstract: Germany has become engulfed in wave of extortion attempts by people who threaten to poison food or cosmetics products and scare away millions of dollars in sales; police estimate that there have been 120 such cases in last year, many of which did not go beyond threatening letters; extortionists seem to be mostly amateurs who do not want to actually cause physical harm, since those who follow through on threats commonly warn companies where to look for poisoned products they have placed on store shelves (M)

headline: German Socialists Turn From Slogans to Jingles
abstract: Gerhard Schroder and his Social Democratic Party are running one of slickest and most American-style political advertising campaigns ever in Germany; media drive combines cozy images of happy Germany and edgy criticism of Chancellor Helmut Kohl; marks major departure from dull and didactic fare typical of German campaigns; contrasts with Kohl's old-school ads; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BNY ESI & CO., New York, a unit of Bank of New York Company, agreed to acquire Alpha Management Inc., of San Francisco, a brokerage services firm, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Chubb Is Forming Reinsurance Operation
abstract: The Chubb Corporation, one of the largest United States property and casualty insurance groups, said today that it was entering the business of insuring insurers, or reinsurance.    The company, based in Warren, N.J., said its new Chubb Re unit would be led by John Berger, former president and chief executive of F&G Re Inc. F&G is part of the USF&G Corporation, which was acquired by the St. Paul Companies in April.

headline: Arafat, at U.N., Urges Backing for Statehood
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat addresses UN General Assembly, speaking for first time in annual debate among leaders of governments and major international organizations; asks largely sympathetic audience for help in bringing independence to Palestinians by May 1999; receives rousing and sustained ovation; photo (S)

headline: NATO Readies Plan For Force in Kosovo
abstract: The United States announced that NATO has approved plans for the use of military force in Kosovo, the southern Yugoslav province where Serbian forces are carrying out a massive offensive against ethnic Albanian separatists.     The announcement was intended to push the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, to end the attacks. But no official would discuss what action in particular would lead NATO to use force.

headline: New Search Engine Is Placing Its Focus Outside U.S. Borders
abstract: More than half the traffic on World Wide Web is based in United States but growing number of search engines are emerging that emphasize foreign locations; one provider is Black Box (www.theblackbox.com), based in Hong Kong, which offers several Orientation search engines targeted to various world regions; photo (S)

headline: Telefonica's Profit Rises 15% in Quarter
abstract: Telefonica SA, Spain's largest telecommunications company, reports 15 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, to $438 million; cites growth in revenues from Latin American operations (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Executive Changes; Bank of New York names James Mason managing director (S)

headline: Moshood K.O. Abiola: From Wealth to Troubled Politics to Flawed Symbol
abstract: Obituary of Moshood Kashimawoo Olawale Abiola, apparent victor in 1993 Nigerian presidential election, who dies at age 60 as his release from prison seems imminent; photo (M)

headline: No Chief Chosen Yet at Broken Hill
abstract: Broken Hill Proprietary Co chairman Jerry Ellis says he expects to appoint chief executive soon (S)

headline: REGIONS BUYS ANOTHER BANKING COMPANY IN ARKANSAS
abstract: Regions Financial Corp agrees to buy Arkansas Banking Co for about $64 million in stock, continuing its expansion in Arkansas (S)

headline: Malaysia Imposes Controls On Trading in Its Currency
abstract: Malaysia Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad, in big gamble to halt slide in Malaysia's currency and stock market, imposes controls on sale of currency; says nation will introduce fixed exchange rate; acts day after Government announced plans to ban trading of Malaysian stocks outside country; Malaysia becomes first Asian nation to impose sweeping currency curbs since region's economic and financial crises began in 1997; new regulations are expected to keep investors and funds away at time when country is trying to pull out of first recession in 13 years; will give authorities more freedom to lower interest rates without having to worry about impact of low rates on currency; photo (M)

headline: Loans in Asia Depress Profit of Dresdner Bank
abstract: Dresdner Bank AG says first-half operating profit rose 3 percent; operating profit rose to 1.794 billion marks ($1 billion) from 1.743 billion marks in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Mongols, Told to Use Surnames Again, Are Trying to Remember
abstract: KARAKORUM, Mongolia  Sipping a bowl of fermented mare's milk inside his tent on the windswept plains of central Mongolia, D. Shatar proudly tells of the traditions he will pass down to the next generation.

headline: American and Iranian Try To Bridge Decades of Hurt
abstract: Barry Rosen, former hostage in American Embassy in Teheran, holds debate in Paris with one of his former student captors, Abbas Abdi; Rosen, 54, is now with Columbia University and Abdi, 42, has become influential journalist; Abdi refuses to concede that occupying embassy was mistake, but hopes US-Iran relations can return to pre-1953 days, before US aided coup (S)

headline: COMPDENT AGREES TO BUYOUT BY PRIVATE GROUP
abstract: Compdent Corp agrees to be bought for as much as $182 million by private investment group, which includes TA Associates Inc, NMS Capital Partners and Golder, Thoma, Cressey, Rauner Inc; acquisition is worth as much as $182 million before company's long-term debt is refinanced (S)

headline: Europe Bans Leaded Gas To Cut Smog
abstract: European Union announces tough new anti-pollution rules, which ban use of leaded gasoline and require many car engines and all fuels to become cleaner by 2000; even tougher standards will go into effect in 2005; with the changes, Government hope to cut as much as 70 percent of pollutants in emissions from cars, which regularly foul the air in some of Europe's most beautiful city centers (M)

headline: Microsoft Logs Gain of 28% In Earnings
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports 28 percent gain in its fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings, modestly exceeding Wall Street expectations; also says it has already sold more than one million copies of its new operating system software, Windows 98, to consumers; company earned $1.36 billion compared with $1.06 billion in year-earlier period; revenue rose 26 percent, to almost $4 billion, from $43.18 billion in fourth quarter of 1997 fiscal year; for the year, Microsoft earned $4.49 billion, up 30 percent from $3.45 billion in 1997 fiscal year; revenue rose 28 percent, to $14.48 billion from $11.36 billion; chart (M)

headline: China Admits Ecological Sins Played Role in Flood Disaster
abstract: Charges are mounting in Beijing that bad policies and official neglect have worsened this summer's disastrous flooding in China; Government has made unusual admission that its land-use mistakes are partly to blame and announced sweeping policy changes; officials have been shocked by vast scale of damage in southern and northeastern China, where severe flooding persists; official press has carried articles and editorials on harmful effects of clear-cutting timber along Yangtze River; Zhao Qizheng, chief of State Council Information Office, says Government has decided to shut down logging activities in upper catchments of Yangtze River; says all cleared areas will be replanted in long-term strategy of ecological restoration; this year's floods have revived private debate about Three Gorges Dam under construction along upper reaches of Yangtze; map; photo (M)

headline: Abortion Debated in Chile, Where It's Always a Crime
abstract: Chilean Senate takes up issue of abortion for first time, nine years after Gen Augusto Pinochet decreed that abortion is crime in Chilie even when necessary to save mother's life; advocates of women's rights say it is time for a change; bill, however, would only tighten regulations by increasing prison sentences for anyone convicted of performing an abortion; conservative opposition senators pushing bill say that want to crush 'abortion industry,' which they say is responsible for up to 160,000 clandestine abortions annually in country of 15 million people; photo of Sen Hernan Larrain (M)

headline: Japan Picks Ex-Leader To Find Way Out of Crisis
abstract: Kiichi Miyazawa, veteran Japanese politician who was forced out of office as Prime Minister five years ago, is named Finance Minister and charged with steering country out of its worst financial crisis in decades; Miyazawa oversaw growth of Japan's 'bubble economy' in late 1980's as Finance Minister; he has worked closely with American financial officials over four decades; world financial markets greet rumors of his appointment with cautious optimism; Japanese news reports state that Keizo Obuchi, new Prime Minister, has named Masahiko Komura to be Foreign Minister, Fukushiro Nukaga to be Defense Minister and Kaoru Yosano to be Trade Minister; photo (M)

headline: Perelman Is Likely to Get A Larger Stake in Sunbeam
abstract: Sunbeam Corp agrees to give one of its largest shareholders, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc, company controlled by Ronald O Perelman, right to increase its stake for attractive terms in exchange for guarantees that it will not sue Sunbeam; such a suit would have been likely to force Sunbeam into bankruptcy; Sunbeam grants MacAndrews & Forbes five-year warrants to purchase 23 million Sunbeam shares at exercise price of $7 a share; MacAndrews & Forbes already owns 14 percent of Sunbeam's stock (M)
